HEADLINE: Opening Up Japanese Skies

 BODY:
The market for airline service between the United States and Japan works nothing like a market. Governments, not customers, decide which airlines fly, where they fly and what they charge. The system serves passengers badly because fares are high and flight schedules are skimpy. The system also badly serves the carriers. Many are shut out of the market entirely. Others find that Japan restricts their right under a 1952 agreement to fly passengers or, in FedEx's case, cargo between Japan and other countries in Asia.
The two sides are now talking. The politics of these talks is as arcane as the economics. American carriers are at each other's throats every bit as much as they are at Japan's. That is also true of the Japanese carriers. Northwest and Japan Airlines jockey to preserve their privileged status under the existing accord, while several American carriers and All Nippon Airways fight for increased access. 
 Northwest, for one, has urged Washington to demand complete deregulation -- a pro-consumer policy started under the Bush Administration that Washington has negotiated with about 25 other countries. But few believe Japan will swallow "open skies" because its inefficient national carriers would never survive competition with their American rivals. Washington's bargaining strength is limited because Japan can always call off negotiations, renounce the 1952 accord and thereby end Washington's constant carping that Japan is violating its treaty obligations.
If Washington must accept less than open skies, the question is how much less. A new accord must guarantee the right of many more American passenger airlines, as well as FedEx, to fly into Japan and then on to other Asian countries. For that guarantee to work, Japan must go further and guarantee takeoff and landing rights at its crowded Tokyo and Osaka airports.
A new accord must also permit American carriers to cut their fares at will, at least for flights originating in the United States. Under the current agreement, Tokyo can veto price cuts to protect its high-cost national carriers. Indeed, if the new accord does nothing more than guarantee substantially more takeoffs and landings, the right to shuttle between Japan and the rest of Asia and the right to cut fares, then the impact will not fall that far short of complete open skies. After all, Japan's airports are too small, and will likely remain too small, to provide unlimited travel no matter what a new accord might promise.
If Japan refuses to budge even this far, the United States could take FedEx's plea to pick up packages in Japan and fly them to other parts of Asia to arbitration, backed up by trade sanctions if Japan refuses to abide by the ruling. That would leave passengers no better off than they are today, but it would preserve the domination of American passenger carriers over Japan's, and give Tokyo strong reasons to negotiate more seriously in the future.

HEADLINE: Will Wall Street Now Have to Pull In Its Horns?

BYLINE: By SHARON R. KING 

 BODY:
The not-quite-finished office building in Stamford, Conn., is an apt symbol of Wall Street's health and boundless optimism. It cost some $200 million to build, contains an up-to-date trading floor and by year-end will have created some 2,200 new jobs for the region.
For SBC Warburg Dillon Read, the building's proud owner, the project's scale signals the firm's ambitions as an aspiring Wall Street powerhouse, despite its site an hour out of New York. 
 Wall Street has indeed been expansive as the markets have boomed, but with this week's reversals many Wall Street executives and people who do business with them are questioning whether these firms will be forced to pull in their horns, reining in expansion plans and hiring -- not to mention trimming year-end bonuses.
Up until this week, brokerage firms whose stocks trade publicly have been the juggernauts in an impressive market, gaining 73 percent as a group for the year, more than double the market as a whole.
To the extent that Wall Street processed a record number of trades this week, there will be some increase in commission income. Fifteen percent of all brokerage firms' revenues now come from commissions, versus 24 percent 10 years ago.
But the flux in volume could be short-lived if investors sit out until markets calm. And these gains could be eroded if firms were caught with sizable investments in Southeast Asia when those markets collapsed.
"The firms absolutely, whether they should or not, trade as leveraged stock market proxies, so their movements are exaggerated" on both the upside and the downside, said Sallie L. Krawcheck, a research analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein, who expects earnings for these companies to dip 10 to 15 percent.
"Absolutely, we can benefit from volatility," said Donald B. Marron, chairman of Paine Webber Inc., cautioning that this was possible as long as "what you're seeing is a correction in price, without fundamentally damaging the market."
For its part, SBC, a subsidiary of the Swiss Bank Corporation, is moving ahead with plans to consolidate several offices into its new corporate headquarters in Stamford, where ribbon-cutting ceremonies were held on Tuesday. So far, about 150 of the firm's equity traders have moved in. Workers continue to hook up terminals in the vast trading room, readying it to house the firm's approximately 660 equity, fixed income and foreign exchange traders. And it can be expanded to hold about 1,000 traders.
"We're not concerned at all," Simon Canning, chief executive of SBC, said of the market selloff. "We believe we can add value in any market environment, and we're committed in the long term."
The move to Stamford has allowed the firm, which had recently added Dillon, Read and before that S. G. Warburg to its stable, to upgrade its computer systems. So while some brokerage firms struggled on Tuesday with the highest volume ever on the New York Stock Exchange, trades were executed at the one occupied end of the two-story-high trading room "without a hiccup," said Joel Nachman, an information and technology executive director at SBC. "The system wasn't even stressed," he said.
But "I'm glad it didn't happen two weeks ago," the day the firm handled its first trade in its new building, Mr. Nachman said, referring to Monday's 554.26-point drop in the Dow. "That would have really gotten everyone's adrenaline pumping."
Other Wall Street firms are also staying with their expansion plans, at least for now. Merrill Lynch is moving ahead with plans to hire 175 newly minted M.B.A.'s from the country's top business schools as associates, an official says, up from the 162 hired from last year's class.
But market performance during the next few months may have an impact on such decisions, says Joan Zimmerman, executive vice president of G. Z. Stephens Inc., an executive search firm.
And with characteristic bravado, this year's M.B.A. candidates still feel confident enough to say they expect to get several job offers and weigh them before making a choice.
"If there has to be a correction, we'd rather have it now before we start working and our compensation is tied to the market," said Craig Livingston, president of Columbia Business School's sales and trading club. "People at Columbia are very market savvy. No one's panicking."
Career placement directors say the pace of interviewing, which begins in earnest at this time of year, has not slowed. Still, to be safe, Columbia is inviting a more diverse group of firms from international banks expanding in the United States to firms in Latin America and Europe to recruit its M.B.A. candidates. It is also suggesting that its students consider careers in technology if they are dead set on a Wall Street job.
"We've been planning for a downturn and we've been getting to know lots of people in lots of regions," said Thomas E. Fernandez, assistant dean of career services.
But on Monday, that confidence temporarily wilted, as M.B.A. candidates at business schools around the country nervously watched the market dive.
"The halls were packed," said Portia Fultz, another Columbia student. "People were just watching the television. Some people who had job offers were like, 'I need to decide what I'm going to do.' Others were saying, 'I've already accepted. Does this lock me in?' "
Another concern is whether Wall Street bonuses will be cut. Wall Street firms in New York City paid out about $9.4 billion in bonuses in 1996, a 50 percent increase from 1995, according to estimates prepared by the New York State Comptroller's office. Over all, securities industry wages accounted for more than 15 percent of total wages in New York City in 1996, even though the jobs make up only 4 percent of the city's work force.
And investment bankers are not the only ones affected by the hefty cash infusion. Beyond the helpful lift their dollars give New York City's economy, Wall Street bonuses are believed to have a sizable impact on the national economy as well.
At this point, analysts and recruiters say the signals look good for bonuses to increase again this year.
"Strategically, people would be foolish not to pay well this year," said Gary Goldstein, president of the Whitney Group, an executive search firm. "This was a really stellar year and there are enough players out there who will pick up the good people" if they decide to move elsewhere, he said.

HEADLINE: Global Rally Lifts Markets As Tumultuous Week Ends

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

 BODY:
A global rebound in share prices helped buoy Wall Street yesterday, ending a tumultuous week of trading that some global investors feared would result in more wrenching declines.
Markets around the world, which had been roiled by an economic and currency crisis in Southeast Asia, appeared to stabilize after Hong Kong stocks soared early in the day. 
 That rally spread to Tokyo, London, New York and Sao Paulo, Brazil, at least temporarily reversing the domino effect of price drops that had infected markets the last two weeks.
 In Latin America, one of the hardest-hit regions, stock prices rose despite concerns that a banking and currency crisis may be developing. In Brazil, for instance, the main stock market index rose 1.5 percent.
 In New York, the recovery helped lift the Dow Jones industrial average 60.41 points, to 7,442.08. Still, the Dow -- the most widely followed market barometer -- has suffered one of its worst monthly setbacks in recent years, falling 6.3 percent in October.
 That decline came entirely from Monday, when the Dow plummeted 554 points, or 7.18 percent, its biggest rout in a decade.
Since then, investors around the globe have endured a roller coaster ride of buying and selling. Indeed, on the New York Stock Exchange, nearly four billion shares traded this week, easily surpassing the record of three billion shares set a week earlier. By comparison in the early 1970's, it could take a year to trade three billion shares.
The weekend could not have come too soon for many Wall Street traders and analysts who had long been expecting a violent setback to one of the greatest bull markets of all time.
But few analysts believe the crisis in Asia will undermine the United States stock market, largely because most of the problems are in countries like Thailand and Malaysia, which account for only a small portion of United States trade.
"This isn't a fundamental crisis, it's a crisis of confidence," said Alfred Goldman, the director of market analysis at A. G. Edwards Inc., a St. Louis investment firm. "The impact of Asia on our domestic economy is small. The impact is going to be fractional."
 The reason, many analysts contend, is that the United States economy's diversity is such that problems in isolated parts of the world cannot have a substantial impact.
Underscoring this point, the Government reported yesterday that even though growth accelerated in the third quarter, inflation dropped to its lowest level since 1964.
 "The statistics in this country are just fabulous; you just couldn't write better numbers," Charles Pradilla, a market strategist at Cowen & Company, said. "Our figures look better and better in comparison with the rest of the world."
 The economy's strength sent interest rates modestly higher yesterday, as the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond rose to 6.15 percent from 6.14 percent on Thursday. But the week's powerful rally in bond prices -- fed by global investors seeking a safe haven from instability elsewhere -- was largely undisturbed.
 The resilience of the United States economy and financial markets also helped strengthen the dollar in global foreign exchange dealings. In New York, the United States currency rose to 120.37 yen, up from 120.28 Thursday, and 1.7257 marks, up from 1.7189.
But most analysts agree that it could be weeks, if not months, before the stock market regains enough momentum to resume its powerful advance.
 "What we're seeing is a classical reaction; this is usually the way markets work after a big downturn," Mr. Pradilla said. "Until the issues that caused the break are clarified, we're probably going to tread water."
 But Laszlo Birinyi, a market analyst, said the demand for United States equities has not declined, even during the selloff earlier this week. "My big thing is money flows, and you'll find that even when the market cracked, people kept buying," he said.
 According to Mr. Birinyi, even as the prices of blue-chip shares were falling, demand for them was surprisingly strong. In Hong Kong, however, his research showed prices and demand both weakened.
 Few analysts are sayign the worldwide economic turbulence will subside in the next week. The International Monetary Fund has assembled an emergency aid package for Indonesia, but there are indications that Thailand has failed to heed some provisions of its I.M.F. agreement.
 Barton M. Biggs, the global strategist at Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter, Discover & Company, said world markets could be in store for even greater disruptions.
 "The sharp breaks in stock markets around the world are a warning to investors," he said in a report issued Monday when Hong Kong's free fall set off stock carnage around the world. "The global bull market has become very dangerous. The contagion has spread around the world, and no market, anywhere, is invulnerable to infection."

HEADLINE: THE 1997 ELECTIONS: THE GOVERNOR;
Whitman Works to Shore Up Her Softer Areas of Support

BYLINE: By FRANK BRUNI 

DATELINE: CRANFORD, N.J., Oct. 31

 BODY:
With the clock ticking down until Election Day and new polls showing that her re-election remains in doubt, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman turned her attention today to some of her softer areas of support, giving a speech on personal responsibility that seemed intended to appease social conservatives in the Republican Party and expressing her solidarity with minority voters who traditionally favor Democrats.
Mrs. Whitman, whose positions in favor of abortion and gay rights have alienated some fellow Republicans, told hundreds of teen-agers at Cedar Grove High School in Cedar Grove that she wanted to begin a dialogue with children in New Jersey about the importance of choosing between right and wrong. 
 Alluding to a number of widely publicized crimes by teen-agers in New Jersey over the last year, Mrs. Whitman said, "We as adults have not been doing a very good job of communicating to you and the people coming up after you about consequences and responsibility.
"When you make a decision and take an action, there are going to be consequences," she said.
Later, Mrs. Whitman stood on a dais outside the Oak Avenue School in Orange, a relatively poor city that has traditionally been a Democratic stronghold, and accepted endorsements from several local black leaders.
The words she chose to thank them tacitly acknowledged the broad spectrum of support she needs to win on Tuesday.
"To have people such as this come across party lines, step forward and be willing to back a Republican woman governor means that everything we've been doing over the last three-and-a-half years to help people is being recognized," Mrs. Whitman said.
"We didn't put policies in place that helped black people or white people or Oriental people," she said.
"We put them in place to help people. We didn't put them in place to help Democrats or Republicans or independents. We put them in place to help people."
The Governor made more than a half-dozen campaign stops in three counties in northern New Jersey today. For the most part, the events were short of speechifying and heavy on symbolism.
She teetered delicately on an undersized chair, looking like Gulliver among the Lilliputians, to read stories to young children at a day-care center in Bloomfield. She embraced elderly people who were waving red, white and blue pompoms at an assisted-living residence in Cranford.
And as she had been almost every day last week, Mrs. Whitman was flanked by prominent Republicans whose presence underlined her own stature.
The people accompanying her today were former Gov. Tom Kean and United States Senator Kay Bailey Hutchison of Texas.
At a stop in Union, Mrs. Whitman announced that a major pharmaceutical company, Pharmacia & Upjohn, had decided to relocate its worldwide headquarters from London to New Jersey, though the exact place has not been determined. Mrs. Whitman framed the announcement with upbeat assessments of economic vigor in New Jersey during her administration.
Mrs. Whitman began the day in a more defensive posture, sparring with her Democratic challenger, State Senator James E. McGreevey, during a taping in New York City of a segment of WNBC-TV's "News Forum" that is scheduled to broadcast on Sunday.
In what was expected to be their last meeting before Election Day, the candidates turned to familiar points of contention: auto insurance rates and government debt.
But Mrs. Whitman jettisoned such prickly topics for the rest of the day, focusing instead on shaking hands and posing for photographs with just about anyone who strayed near her.

HEADLINE: Miami's Election for Mayor Rouses Sour Mood in Voters

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO 

DATELINE: MIAMI, Oct. 31

 BODY:
The mood of Miami voters was in evidence on Tuesday at Bayfront Park, where 20,000 baseball fans celebrating the Florida Marlins' World Series victory lustily booed the Mayor who had promised to build a stadium to keep the team here.
"We're No. 1!" Mayor Joe Carollo shouted into a microphone as the boos got louder. 
 The same mood was apparent a day later at a meeting of the Shorecrest Homeowners' Association, whose board refused to endorse any candidate for mayor in Tuesday's election after hearing a debate between two other candidates, including Mr. Carollo's main contender, former Mayor Xavier L. Suarez of Miami. But board members did not stop there.
"We will encourage people to vote for two candidates and invalidate the ballot to say we have no confidence in any of them," said the association's director, Christopher Morson.
After a corruption scandal last year that sent the city manager and a city commissioner to prison and the subsequent discovery of a financial crisis that required state intervention, Miami voters last September approved a strong-mayor form of government in which an elected official, not an appointed administrator, would be held accountable for the city's management. The problem for many voters now is that in this effort to break with the past, they are faced with what seems to be a choice between political dinosaurs.
Mayor Carollo, 42, a Cuban-American businessman, served as a Miami commissioner from 1979 to 1987, a tenure characterized by strident anti-Communism and unpredictable behavior. (He once showed up at a news conference at which he had been expected to endorse a mayoral candidate but instead denounced him as a demagogue, to the shock of those present.) After voters returned him to the commission in 1995 and elected him Mayor last year, Mr. Carollo has scored points among voters by simmering down and helping to steer Miami out of a $68 million deficit attributed to mismanagement.
"We have brought the honesty and the professionalism that you rightfully expect from city government," the Mayor said at a recent campaign appearance. "Judge me on what I've done in the last 14 months."
Mr. Suarez, 48, a lawyer, was Miami's first Cuban-American Mayor, from 1985 to 1993, and last year ran unsuccessfully for Mayor of Dade County, whose government is responsible for the Miami metropolitan area. Mr. Suarez counts on supporters satisfied with his performance as mayor -- his nuts-and-bolts style of governing earned him the nickname "the pothole mayor" -- and puts great stock in his Harvard University education.
But many voters are disturbed that contrary to almost universal opinion, including a state panel of experts, Mr. Suarez insists that Miami has no fiscal emergency and that Mr. Carollo exaggerated the financial troubles to appear as the city's savior and in the process ruined its credit and image.
"I promise to give you common sense and efficient government, and you'll see how much money you have available," Mr. Suarez told a neighborhood group last week.
Polls show a dead heat between Mr. Carollo and Mr. Suarez in one of the few hotly contested mayoral races in a major city this year. Their battleground has been the Hispanic neighborhoods where more than half of the electorate resides. In competition with three other candidates who are expected to receive only a small fraction of the vote, Mr. Suarez or Mr. Carollo must get more than 50 percent of the ballots to win and avoid a runoff on Nov. 13 for the top two finishers.
But even among Hispanic residents, who make up more than 60 percent of the city's population of about 360,000, there are groans at the familiar faces and shenanigans. Although Miami has suffered corruption and financial trouble before, the one-two punch of last year has left many voters with little tolerance for business as usual.
At the Dr. Armando Badia Senior Center, a campaign stop for both candidates, many of the Hispanic elderly eating lunch last week said they were weary of the personal attacks in debates that are mostly conducted on Spanish-language television and radio. In one particularly raucous face-off at a Cuban restaurant, the candidates and their supporters even came close to a physical confrontation, according to published news reports.
"Its shameful," said Dolores Ramos, 67, who said she would vote for Mr. Suarez only because "he's not as dirty as the other one."
There is consensus among the candidates and economic experts that what Miami needs most is to attract business and expand its tax base to insure financial stability. In an interview, Mr. Carollo emphasized that the city was well on its way to recovery with a five-year budget plan and $2.5 billion in new construction over the next three years, including new hotels and office buildings.
Mr. Suarez, in a separate interview, said he would sell "unnecessary" city-owned buildings and reduce the salary of top city executives to reduce taxes and attract more private investment. But on the stump, Mr. Carollo is more often heard calling Mr. Suarez "Pinocchio" while Mr. Suarez condescendingly corrects Mr. Carollo's Spanish and declares him "incapable" of understanding Miami's finances.
Meanwhile, many voters listen skeptically, unwilling to exonerate longtime city politicians for problems of corruption and ineptness that were years in the making.
"I have to feel that part of the blame is with these gentlemen," a member of the Brickell Homeowners Association said as both candidates looked on at a meeting last week.
The same night, residents of Brickell, in an upper-middle-income neighborhood of condominiums near the downtown financial district, also heard from candidates for one of five city commission posts. They included Humberto E. Hernandez, a 35-year-old former city commissioner who is under indictment on Federal charges of mortgage fraud and money laundering and is seeking re-election while he fights in court.
The audience listened with politeness and a heavy heart.
"It's very sad," Joe Wilkins, a 47-year-old schoolteacher and Miami native said as he left the meeting at a local church. "It's not an encouraging election."

HEADLINE: The Economic Stakes in Asia

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31

 BODY:
When the Clinton Administration explained today why it was contributing $3 billion to a fund to stabilize Indonesia -- and with it the economies of Southeast Asia -- it argued that far more than stock market shocks and fluctuating currencies were at stake.
"Financial stability around the world is critical to the national security and economic interests of the United States," Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin said in a statement. "These countries are not only key markets for U.S. exporters, but are also crucial to our efforts to promote growth, peace and prosperity throughout the world." 
 This is hardly the first time the Administration has linked America's security interests with quelling an economic panic. That was the major argument for rescuing Mexico during the 1995 peso crisis, when the United States stepped in with $12 billion in aid. Mexico, though, was not only about the peso, it was about drugs and illegal immigrants.
But can the same case be made for Indonesia? If so, what about the next crisis, perhaps in Brazil -- where interest rates doubled on Thursday to 40 percent on an annual basis.
"It is a very, very sticky question," a senior Administration official said as the last touches were being put on the Indonesia package this week. "We can't step into every economic mess. But when the problem of contagion across markets becomes this serious, then it's hard to do what America once did -- regard an economic crisis as a confined event, like a civil war."
What prompted the Administration to move, officials say, was fear that the instability that first racked Asia, then sped to markets around the globe, could turn into something more virulent. Economists have been talking about the dampening effects that continued turmoil in the Asian markets -- and a slowdown in growth -- could have on American exports. That was certainly a concern, Administration officials say. But it was the least of the worries.
The bigger strategic concerns come in many varieties and cross a number of Washington's bureaucratic boundaries.
The immediate objective of the American action, of course, is what the Treasury calls "market contagion" -- the odd ways in which a loss of investor confidence in one nation spreads to others. Often that seems irrational: There is no reason that concerns about Indonesia or Thailand, for example, should rock confidence in Brazil. But currency crises have a way of gathering steam. And in this case, the willingness of governments in Asia to devalue their currencies because their neighbor has -- making their goods more competitive -- has prompted market speculators to suspect that other governments will follow suit lest they be priced out of the export race.
President Carlos Saul Menem of Argentina explicitly discussed that issue today when he gathered reporters to say that he had been assured by Brazil's President, Fernando Henrique Cardoso, that Brazil would not follow the Thais and the Indonesians.
"I spoke with the President of Brazil," Mr. Menem said, "a great friend, who told me in these very words: 'Carlos, we have no doubts about this. If we devalue, then you'll have to devalue and who knows where we will end up?' "
"I told him we must stay firm," Mr. Menem said, "and we'll overcome this crisis."
That may be both exaggeration and bravado -- the world seems pretty prosperous these days, even with the market instability -- but Mr. Menem was clearly trying to signal to the speculators that they should go elsewhere.
The second level of concerns in Washington center on one of the central goals of the Clinton Administration: To open world markets.
Mr. Clinton has made market-opening a centerpiece of his foreign policy and the market turmoil threatens his agenda.
No one yet knows how the instability of the last week will play out in Congress as it debates giving President Clinton "fast track" authority to negotiate new trade accords.
The third set of worries focus on the question of what happens if market instability turns into something more ominous.
Indonesia has had only one major transition of power in recent times. The 1965 fall of Sukarno and the rise of Suharto were accompanied by the deaths of an estimated half a million Indonesians. At the time, Washington's concern was to keep Communism from overtaking the country.
Today the concerns are very different. But Indonesia is now not only a major market for the United States, and a huge producer and consumer of goods for all of Asia, it intersects a critical shipping route for oil. That helps explain why the American military command for the Pacific, based at Pearl Harbor, has been searching around to beef up its team of regional economic analysts.
And one of the other major concerns arising from the currency crisis, Clinton Administration officials say, has been to make sure that Asians know that the United States is engaged in the region's economic stability. No sooner had the troubles began than Japan proposed the creation of a separate Asian stability fund, one that would sidestep the American-influenced International Monetary Fund.
Several Asian countries warmed to the idea, especially those that chafe at the conditions that the I.M.F. places on its loans -- closing failing banks, opening markets, breaking up cozy monopolies. All of those conditions were part of the I.M.F.'s package for Indonesia, which will provide the country with $15 billion to $18 billion in immediate financing, and another $12 billion to $15 billion in backup financing if the Asian crisis worsens.
Lawrence H. Summers, the Deputy Treasury Secretary, frequently calls rescue operations like the I.M.F.'s part of "preventative diplomacy."
"These are all part of promoting prosperity," he says, "and maintaining stability."

HEADLINE: THE 1997 ELECTIONS: THE VOTERS / CAMPAIGN STOP -- Views From the Neighborhoods;
Park Slope's Proud Democrats Feel Tug of Strained Loyalties

BYLINE: By FELICIA R. LEE 

 BODY:
Susan Friedland, a 29-year-old city planner, sounds a lot like many Park Slope residents when she talks about the mayoral election. She's a Democrat, she detests the Republican Party, and she thinks Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's popularity shows that voters have abandoned the ideal of social change to vote for their narrow personal interests.
"I'm a Democrat and I'll vote Democratic in the election," Ms. Friedland said the other day. "The Mayor's policy on welfare reform is cruel and inhumane. The economic regeneration is not due to increased jobs at all levels of the economy. All my friends are old-style New York Democrats. No one I know is voting for Giuliani, but I think the Democratic Party is falling apart." 
 "I think people are voting in a pretty selfish way," she said of polls showing Mr. Giuliani with a substantial lead over his Democratic challenger, Ruth W. Messinger, the Manhattan Borough President. "I think it's a national trend. People no longer think government can play a role in improving the lives of people."
This Brooklyn neighborhood on the northwest edge of Prospect Park, with its exquisite brownstones, funky coffee shops and a reputation for social tolerance, is a place where Mr. Giuliani is well liked, but Ms. Messinger is perhaps even better respected as a symbol of the kind of unabashed liberalism that many people fear has fallen out of favor.
Interviews this week on the Seventh Avenue commercial strip in the heart of Park Slope suggest that Ms. Messinger is likely to do well there. But they also indicated that Mr. Giuliani may do better in the neighborhood than he did in 1993, when he won only 29 percent of the vote against Mayor David N. Dinkins.
In the random but unscientific survey, 21 of 40 people said they were planning to vote for Ms. Messinger. In addition, 14 people said they would vote for Mr. Giuliani. Five were undecided, but three of those were leaning toward the Mayor. Most said they had voted for Mr. Dinkins, a Democrat, in 1993.
Park Slope is a predominantly white, well-educated, middle-class enclave, a place where residents say issues like the environment and race relations, as well as crime and education, are important to them. It is the kind of area where Ms. Messinger must do extremely well if she is to have a chance at an upset on Tuesday.
The neighborhood is 74 percent Democratic and only 7 percent Republican; almost three out of four voters supported President Clinton last year.
With one exception, all of those who said in interviews that they would vote for Mr. Giuliani were Democrats. They said they would support him for the same reasons cited in other neighborhoods: they felt safer, the city looked better and they believed the economy was on track. Even so, some supporters faulted Mr. Giuliani for lacking compassion or not paying enough attention to the poor.
"There are a lot of things in his character I disapprove of, but he gets the job done," Ida Deboissiere, who with her husband owns a neighborhood store called Mail Boxes on Fifth, said of the Mayor. "I'd like to see the city more conservative. I think it's half and half now. The city was more liberal five years ago."
Nancy Ivan, a 31-year-old television director who voted for Mr. Dinkins four years ago, now supports Mr. Giuliani. "I am thinking about my personal life," she said. Ms. Ivan has never voted for a Republican before, but she said, "I don't feel like I'm crossing any major line."
"The subway is cleaner," she added. "I feel better. I am voting for Giuliani because of the crime issue, mostly. I'm pretty impressed with what he's done in the past four years. We need to give him a chance to take it to the next level."
Some people said they did have compunctions about crossing party lines, but no one saw Mr. Giuliani's expected victory as a referendum on his party. Many noted that he is a moderate Republican, with a pro-choice stance and the backing of many prominent Democrats.
Kathleen McShane, a 33-year-old art professor, said she is bothered that as a Democrat she plans to vote for Mr. Giuliani. "He used to be a Democrat so I trust him," she said. "I never voted Republican before, but I will because I think he'll do a good job. It does actually bother me. To commit to a party whose values I don't agree with, that's difficult."
Joe Mangano, a 41-year-old health administrator, said he was undecided, but leaning toward Ms. Messinger. Mr. Mangano said neither candidate had done a good job of discussing issues like health care, the environment and education.
A Democrat, Mr. Mangano said he believed Mr. Giuliani's likely re-election reflects the power of the incumbency and underscores the importance of the sharp decrease in crime. "Policy-wise, there is not much difference locally between Republicans and Democrats," he said. "It's not like at the national level where you have Jesse Helms."
Others, like Janet Mann, a 51-year-old high school teacher, are undecided because they are weighing their traditional liberal ideology against more pragmatic concerns.
"It's depressing," Ms. Mann said. "I don't agree with Mayor Giuliani, but I don't think Ruth Messinger will make a good mayor. It's not so much who I want, but the message I want to send. I don't think Giuliani cares."
The hard-core liberals in the neighborhood saw no philosophical fences to straddle. They said they thought Mr. Giuliani trumpeted the interests of the privileged, was shortsighted in his efforts to combat crime, and in general displayed bias in an incredibly diverse city.
"As someone who made his presence felt through law and order, I don't see him having much vision about what it'll take to make things better," Raphael Rudnick, 64, an editorial consultant, said of Mr. Giuliani. He supported Ms. Messinger based on previous encounters with her, but he also said she was running an anemic campaign. "I'm convinced about her wanting to make things better," Mr. Rudnick said. "The city is becoming more conservative. It's that principle of selfishness. The chances of people looking each other in the eye is lessened."
The election reflects class divisions more than anything else, said another Messinger supporter, Molly Fox, a 43-year-old manager for the Equinox fitness clubs.
"I think people who are comfortable will be more comfortable, people who have less will continue to have less," she predicted of Mr. Giuliani's likely second term. "Things go in cycles. We had Jerry Brown, then we had Pete Wilson in California. I think we're in a conservative cycle. We're reactive, we're fearful, we want to hold on to our money. Social issues go by the wayside."
Liza Cowan, a 48-year-old artist who also supports Ms. Messinger, agreed. "I think Giuliani hides a lot of biases in his quality-of-life ideas -- race, sexuality and class biases -- and that angers me," Ms. Cowan said. "If you're a middle-class, and particularly a white middle-class New Yorker, there is an illusion of safety, but it's so superficial. I don't think people are looking beyond their own issues."
Many of the most ardent Messinger supporters said they did not expect her to upset the popular incumbent. Jeff Prant, a photographer who sat with a friend on a stoop eating lunch, said he saw the election as a referendum on Mr. Giuliani's record and not much else.
"The crime issue is the big thing that does it for people," said Mr. Prant, who is 41. "I'll be voting for Messinger. I think she has a more well-rounded view of what quality-of-life issues should be in the city. Crime is important, but no attention has been paid to air quality, traffic and noise."
Mr. Prant said he thought the election would be closer than many people expect. "With the vast majority of registered Democrats in this city, the turnout will tend to favor her," he said. "I just don't think she'll win."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Stocks Rebound Modestly, Ending Week of Turmoil
A punishing week in world stock markets closed on a slightly upbeat note as prices rebounded in a modest rally that started in Hong Kong and worked its way through Asia, Europe and the Americas. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 60.41 points, to 7,442.08.
But the Dow still ended October down 6.3 percent, one of its worst monthly setbacks, because of the rout last Monday that erased nearly 7.2 percent from the widely followed average. Moreover, many traders and Wall Street analysts said they expected more wrenching volatility because the underlying causes -- economic and currency problems in Asia and other emerging markets -- will not abate anytime soon. Page D2.
 
Court Blocks Rail-Fire Verdict
The Louisiana Supreme Court delayed enforcement of a $3.4 billion jury award until injuries suffered by all 8,000 victims of a 1987 New Orleans rail tanker car fire could be evaluated. The ruling relieved the CSX Corporation of posting a $2.5 billion bond, its share of the award, and reduced the possibility that the railroad company will have to pay the full amount. D3. 

Jury Favors Tobacco
A jury in Jacksonville, Fla., decided R. J. Reynolds was not negligent in the lung-cancer death of a 30-year smoker, a victory for the tobacco industry in a widely followed case that could increase the prospects for Congressional approval of the proposed national tobacco settlement. A11.
 
More Stamina, Less Inflation
The American economy grew vigorously this summer even as inflation dwindled to a level unseen since 1964. The data showed that the economy grew in the third quarter at an annual rate of 3.5 percent, up from 3.2 percent in the spring. The extraordinary performance provided some reassurance of the economy's resilience after the week of global financial market upheaval. A1.
 
Broad Goal in Indonesian Aid
In helping to quell an economic crisis in Indonesia with a $3 billion contribution to an aid package, the interests of the United States may not be as apparent as they were when the Clinton Administration rescued Mexico during the peso crisis. But what prompted the Administration to move was fear that Asia's financial instability could turn into something more virulent. News Analysis. A4.
 
US Airways Pact Ratified
Pilots at US Airways overwhelmingly voted in favor of a five-year contract that opens the way for the nation's fifth-largest carrier to reduce costs and expand through the purchase of new Airbus Industrie planes. D3 .
 
Gold Drops on Swiss Sale Plan
Gold tumbled 2 percent, its second big drop in a week, after the Swiss Government endorsed a sale of 800 metric tons. D11.
 
May a Thousand Stocks Bloom
President Jiang Zemin of China visited Wall Street, whose denizens are more likely to quote the Dow than Mao. He toured the New York Stock Exchange, where the flag of China flew outside for a day. Mr. Jiang even rang the bell to begin trading. "Good morning," Mr. Jiang said on the balcony of the exchange, "I wish you good trading." A1.
 
Metal Industry Merger
Allegheny Teledyne will buy Oregon Metallurgical for $560 million in stock, a merger that will create a specialty metals producer capable of taking advantage of the booming aerospace market. D2.
 
Ice Cream Deal Completed
Unilever, the British-Dutch food and consumer products company, completed its $930 million purchase of Kibon, Brazil's biggest ice cream maker, from Philip Morris. The purchase strengthens Unilever's position as the world's leading ice cream purveyor. D3.

SECTION: Section B; Page 4; Column 2; Metropolitan Desk 

LENGTH: 1426 words

HEADLINE: THE 1997 ELECTIONS;
Excerpts From Mayor's Conversation With Editors and Reporters

 BODY:
In an interview with reporters and editors of The New York Times yesterday, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani discussed his mayoralty and his top priorities. Following are excerpts from that conversation.
Q. Mr. Mayor, the polls show that most people think of you as a law enforcement mayor. That's the primary thing they know about you. I'm wondering if you want to change that perception in your second term, broaden your reputation so that you are as well known for something else, and what that would be. 
 A. Obviously if I have a second term, I would like to build on what we've been able to achieve in the first term. And I've always been a person that likes to think that I grow and change and try to absorb the different things that are needed at different times. I think that in the first years -- I think even during my administration, I changed.
I think the first year that I was the Mayor, I think it would be fair to say that I was a law-and-order mayor. I thought that was the major priority because I felt that was the biggest crisis the city faced. And as soon as that began to turn somewhat, we were able to keep the emphasis on that, and I began focusing on the economy a lot more. . . .
The priority I began when I was Mayor was that we had to dramatically reduce crime. Shortly after getting elected, I realized that I'd also have to be a mayor who made very tough decisions. . . .
I truly believed that the deficit I had to face was about 8 or 900 million even though the prior mayor said it was 300 million. I thought it was about three times more. I never realized it was like five or six times more. And, so, I had to start two kinds of mayors from the very beginning, law and order and reorganizing the city budget, because if I didn't reorganize the city budget, we would have had a disaster. . . .
In the second year, we began to devote a lot of attention to reorganizing city agencies. And in the third year we devoted a lot of attention to schools. I know that a lot of the focus on schools people tie to the election. But that really isn't true. I've been trying to reform schools from the time that I got into office. My focus has been to try and have accountability for the school system. It's been very consistent.
What I wanted to achieve was the same thing that Mayor Daley achieved in Chicago, which is that the Mayor being accountable for the school system so that I could have made the difficult decisions about the school system that I had to make in other parts of the city government: remove the boards, make the superintendents responsive to performance, remove the principals that aren't performing. And I realized a year ago, almost to the day because it was around October of last year, that I realized that there was a possibility of making a compromise if I were willing to achieve for Rudy Crew what I was trying to achieve for myself.
And I put that compromise together because the opportunity was there to do it. So, I'd like to build on that. And I think what I'd also like to be able to do over the next four years is guide the welfare-to-work transition in a way that sets New York apart.
New York used to be known as the crime capital and welfare capital. We changed the stereotype of being the crime capital. I think we're now the leader in how to reduce crime. People come here from all over the world to learn how to reduce crime from New York City.
I'd like us to be in the same position with regard to transitioning from welfare to work. The scale on which we've reduced welfare is greater than any place else in America. The scale of our workfare program is larger than any place else. And the opportunities of moving people from welfare to work are much greater in New York. So, I'd like to see us be able to achieve that.
And I'd also like to see us be able to achieve massive reduction in drug dependency, because I think it's at the core of maintaining the crime reductions, quality-of-life improvements that we've had. And it's critical to really helping young people have an opportunity to be free and independent.
Q. Might it be a concern for those who are going to vote for you that you're only going to be a two-year mayor?
A. Two-term mayor.
Q. Two-year mayor.
A. I intend to be the Mayor of New York City for the next four years. I resist all of the old games that are played, because I always hate to make the same mistakes that people have made in the past. So I have, I don't rule options out. I rule them in, and my intention is to be Mayor of New York City for the next four years. . . . And there's another reason why it would be foolish for me to rule out options.
Possibilities make my job as Mayor easier to bargain, leverage and fight for the City of New York. Particularly as the Mayor who is a lame duck mayor on the day that I get sworn in. It ain't bad for people who are saying, 'This guy has possibilities.' It makes it a lot easier for me to negotiate with Albany, Washington, for the benefit of the city. Most of our best mayors and governors have recognized that.
Q. What do you see as your biggest regret about your first term?
A. I have no doubt what my biggest regret is. There's more than one. The biggest one is not having anticipated, not having begun to reform the Child Welfare Administration on Day 1 the way I began the reform of the Police Department and Fire Department, even began the reform of the school system, but it took a lot of changes to have it really start happening two years later. I didn't anticipate it, didn't understand it enough, didn't know enough about it.
And because I think if I had started it literally two years earlier, we'd be that much further ahead now in understanding what has to be done to change it. I realized it because when Elisa Izquierdo died, I started to pay a lot of attention to it. I asked Howard Wilson, who was then the D.O.I. Commissioner, who was the best efficiency expert I ever worked with, the best beyond being a D.O.I. Commissioner. One of the reasons I hired him as D.O.I. Commissioner was to help me try to make city agencies more efficient. . . . He spent a month looking at child welfare, and he came to me and said it's an absolute disaster. . . . There are no standards for hiring people, there is no sense of mission, the priority is totally reversed. The priority is reuniting families, which is a wonderful thing to do, but it was like a dominant philosophy that overwhelmed, sometimes, common sense. And so I spent a lot of time focusing I wish I had done that.
Q. Are the city and the electorate changing?
A. The answer is yes to both. The city is still a Democratic city, and it is now a city that is more willing to move off party if it sees reasons to do that. This is the third time I've run for mayor, and each time the party identification becomes less significant. But it's still significant. . . .
Q. Do you think there's a chance that a Republican can win the mayor's office in 2001?
A. Sure.
Q. Do you think it's likely?
A. No, there's a chance. Just talking pure political strategy, there is one advantage to being a Republican, and then a disadvantage. The advantage is you don't have to be in a Democratic primary, which very often narrows the choice to the one who has the least chance of winning the general election. Because primaries tend to bring out the most extreme voters. They tend to be much more ideologically driven than a general election.
General election, all those people come out to vote who don't live, breathe and die for the Democratic Party or the Republican Party. They may be registered as a Democrat, may be registered as a Republican, but they tend to be more like average people, which is they'll vote either way. And if you are a Republican candidate, you can stay out of that primary and stay out of having to move yourself significantly over to one end of the spectrum or have to deal with group politics in a way in which eventually you define yourself away.
The disadvantage is the registration numbers are huge. They're still 5 to 1, and there is a stereotype of Republicans, actually a prejudice. It really is. It's like a form of prejudice, as it isn't as evil as a racial, religious or ethnic prejudice, but it's irrational. It has the same irrational concept to it.
Q. Have you given any thought to try to groom a successor?
A. No. I haven't given any thought to a successor, not any more than I have running for another office. But I'm not going to rule out giving thought to a successor.

HEADLINE: U.S. ECONOMY GREW AT A STRONG PACE IN THE 3d QUARTER

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31

 BODY:
The American economy grew at a vigorous pace over the summer and a key measure of inflation dwindled to a level not seen since 1964.
The extraordinary economic performance, reported today by the Commerce Department, provided a bit of reassurance after a week of turmoil on Wall Street and in the world's financial markets. 
 Despite concerns about the impact of slower growth in Southeast Asia and Latin America, the economy actually gathered steam in the three months ended in September, growing at an annual rate of 3.5 percent, up from 3.2 percent in the spring.
The expansion pace has surpassed 3 percent for four consecutive quarters, the most consistent gain of that magnitude since 1984, when growth surged after the economy emerged from the worst postwar recession.
"The United States economy continues to rumble along at an astounding pace," said Mark Vitner, vice president and economist at the First Union Bank.
Soaring business investment and a sudden rebound in consumer spending led the growth over the summer. Businesses are pouring huge amounts of capital into new plants and equipment at a stage in the business cycle when investment usually tails off. Such investment is growing even faster than the economy at large, helping to keep strong demand from pushing up prices.
"When you do that, it's unambiguously positive," said Mickey D. Levy, a senior economist at Nationsbank.
Indeed, inflation remained thoroughly subdued in the last quarter. According to one measure in the Commerce Department report, inflation crept up at an annual rate of just 1.4 percent, the lowest since 1964.
Such remarkable price stability has made it possible for the Federal Reserve to keep its foot off the brakes while the economy accelerates. Though the economy has grown rapidly for a full year, periodically renewing concerns that inflation lurks just around the corner, the Federal Reserve has raised short-term interest rates by only one-quarter point, back in March. Otherwise, the central bank's main effort to keep growth and inflation in check has been to make periodic comments, like the cautionary words about overenthusiasm in the stock markets by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman.
Still, today's economic report was somewhat stronger than expected and might edge the Federal Reserve closer to a rate increase later this year. A rate increase is considered unlikely at the Fed's Nov. 12 policy meeting in part because it could further disrupt the world securities and currency markets. A stock rout in Hong Kong, on the heels of a series of currency devaluations and economic troubles in weaker Asian nations pulled the Dow Jones industrial average down 554 points on Monday. After seesawing throughout the week, the Dow finished on a positive note, up 60.41 points today, narrowing the week's loss to 273.33 points.
If the worldwide markets settle down, economists said, the Federal Reserve may want to raise rates at its mid-December meeting. Among other things, the central bank will be looking for signs of inflationary pressure in the October jobs report, scheduled for release on Friday. Labor markets have shown signs of tightening -- first-time claims for jobless benefits dipped below 300,000 last week -- and the unemployment rate hovers close to a quarter-century low, at 4.9 percent.
The White House responded to the report by citing a host of recent figures that point to the best overall economic conditions since the early 1960's.
"The fundamentals of the economy remain strong," Janet L. Yellen, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, said in a statement. "Growth is robust; businesses are investing in new and better equipment; unemployment remains low at 4.9 percent; workers are experiencing real wage gains; inflation is in check and consumer confidence is high."
Americans opened their wallets wide in the latest quarter. Consumer spending grew at a 5.7 percent annual rate, rebounding from less than 1 percent in the spring. Major purchases like autos were largely responsible.
Economists said this torrid spending pace was unsustainable and would probably be curbed in part by the recent correction in the stock market, which shrank the paper assets of millions of Americans and injected a note of uncertainty about their financial futures.
"When you see declines of this kind, it makes individuals and businesses pause and reflect," said Richard D. Rippe, chief economist at Prudential Securities, referring to the market drop. "And consumers don't have a lot of savings left to dig into."
To finance their spending spree over the summer, households drew down their bank accounts. Personal saving as a percentage of disposable income fell to 3.6 percent in the third quarter, the lowest since early 1994, from 4.2 percent in the spring.
During the summer, business investment leaped at an eye-popping 18.7 percent annual pace after a 14.6 percent jump in the spring. Equipment investment grew at an annual rate of $33.3 billion, seven times the rate for structures.
Inventories expanded, but at a markedly slower pace than during the first half. If the buildup had not slowed, the gross domestic product would have grown 4.8 percent instead of 3.5 percent, the Commerce Department said.
Reflecting strong demand for foreign goods, imports surged at a 14 percent annual pace, more than twice as fast as export growth.
As for inflation, the price index for gross domestic purchases rose at an annual rate of 1.2 percent in the latest quarter, up from eight-tenths of 1 percent in the spring. When food and energy are excluded, this gauge fell to 1 percent from 1.6 percent.
The price deflator, a very broad measure of price movements, eased this summer to a rate of 1.4 percent, the lowest in 33 years, from 1.8 percent in the April-June period.
Lee Price, Acting Under Secretary of Commerce for Economic Affairs, said at a briefing that the outlook remained favorable for continued healthy growth and low inflation but declined to speculate how much damage might be inflicted by economic distress in Asia and the recent decline in American stock markets.
Data included in the gross domestic product for the third quarter follow, with all dollar amounts in billions at seasonally adjusted annual rates. Percentage changes are from the previous quarter at seasonally adjusted annual rates.

HEADLINE: THE 1997 ELECTIONS: THE MAYOR;
Mayor Foresees Better Relations With Minorities

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani predicted yesterday that his relationship with many minority groups would improve in a second term, as residents of poor neighborhoods realized they were sharing the benefits of lower crime and an improved economy.
In an hourlong discussion with reporters and editors of The New York Times yesterday morning, the Republican-Liberal candidate for re-election said he no longer finds the same resistance in neighborhoods that voted against him in his previous races against David N. Dinkins, the city's first black mayor. The endorsement of his candidacy by several prominent black elected officials shows that his policies are now appreciated outside his core base of support, he said. 
 "There used to be 1,000 shootings in East New York a year," he said. "Now there are 200. Those are things you feel in your life, and I think that that has created a certain amount of support and a relationship that wasn't there before. We have to build on that. So I don't think the barriers that we faced in the first two years will exist in the next four."
A recent poll by The Times shows that a plurality of black and Hispanic residents believes that life in the city has worsened during the last four years, but not as high a percentage as felt that way in 1993. Blacks residents tend to have an unfavorable opinion of Mr. Giuliani, while Hispanic residents hold a more favorable opinion; among both groups, however, Mr. Giuliani is held in higher regard than he was four years ago.
The Mayor did not outline any new priorities or outreach efforts to heal what has been a persistent rift between blacks and whites in their perception of the city, and in fact resisted the idea that he needs to address race relations at all. Instead, he said he hopes to continue trying to redefine the way New Yorkers relate to one another by concentrating on their shared experiences rather than their differences.
As in the rest of his campaign, the Mayor spent most of the discussion talking about his record during the last four years, deflecting repeated attempts by questioners to learn about new policies in a second term. Asked, for example, if he hopes to be remembered as more than a just a mayor who reduced crime, Mr. Giuliani said he likes to think of himself as someone who grows and changes and responds to different needs at different times. But he immediately began a year-by-year recounting of the various efforts in his first term, without describing his vision of a second.
In general, he said, he plans to build on his first-term accomplishments in law enforcement, economic matters and welfare, while beginning an intensive program to reduce drug abuse.
Only once, in response to a question, did Mr. Giuliani discuss his Democratic opponent, Ruth W. Messinger, saying she has "romanticized homelessness" and has been one of the strongest proponents of allowing poor people to become dependent on government. In contrast, he said, his administration believes in making people independent, and has done more for homeless people than any administration in years.
In the last two years, Mr. Giuliani has begun a policy of turning away thousands of families from the city's Emergency Assistance Unit for the homeless because they could not demonstrate that they truly needed shelter. Although the Mayor said that represented a more realistic, unromantic way of dealing with homelessness, a spokesman for Ms. Messinger said yesterday that the policy was simply uncaring.
"The Mayor is not making people independent of government," said Leland T. Jones, Ms. Messinger's spokesman. "He's cutting people loose. He's cutting kids loose from schools that don't give them a good education, cutting people from welfare-to-work programs that don't give them work, cutting families from soup kitchens and food pantries."
Although he has been repeatedly criticized by Ms. Messinger for his record on education, Mr. Giuliani said he was so satisfied by the performance of Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew that he would not spend any political capital in Albany trying to assume personal control of the school system, which he once demanded. He said he would rather fight the smaller battle of ending tenure for principals, possibly reserving the issue of mayoral control for late in his term, when suspicious legislators won't think he wants control for himself.
"I think that maybe we could win that battle fighting it for a future mayor," he said. "If you fight it for yourself, you get involved in Republican-Democratic politics."
He said he planned to continue scrutinizing each agency's budget for more reductions, and hoped to reduce the long-term projected deficit of $2.6 billion by about 40 percent. But he said he had no plans to reduce that number to zero, despite the demands to do so from outside budget monitors, because it is politically useful to him to show a long-term projected deficit.
"If there were all zeros here, the mayor would have no defense against a City Council that wanted to spend $10 billion more," he said. "This is a valuable thing to have, to restrain the desire of any legislative body to spend more money."
The Mayor gave a similar glimpse into the workings of his political calculus when discussing his future career, which is limited by law to one more term as mayor. Although he says he intends to serve out a full term, he would not rule out resigning early to run for higher office because, he said, it keeps his fellow politicians off guard.
"Possibilities make my job as mayor easier to bargain, leverage and fight for the City of New York," he said, "particularly as the mayor who is a lame duck mayor on the day that I get sworn in. It ain't bad for people who are saying this guy has possibilities. It makes it a lot easier for me to negotiate with Albany, Washington, for the benefit of the city. Most of our best mayors and governors have recognized that."

HEADLINE: Clinton and Congress Brace for Trade Fight

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31

 BODY:
As White House aides scurried to barter promises of economic aid and worker assistance in exchange for crucial Democratic votes on free-trade legislation, President Clinton took his campaign for the bill out to the country today.
The President's push came as the Senate majority leader, Trent Lott, tried to bring the trade bill to the floor but was blocked by Democrats, some of whom have signaled that they will fight to keep the measure from ever coming to a vote. 
 The first big test of the opponents' strength in the Senate was set for Tuesday, when the bill's supporters will try for the 60 votes needed to shut off a filibuster.
While the battle gathered steam in Washington, Mr. Clinton was in Florida, a state whose citrus and tomato industries are already buffeted by competition from Latin America.
In West Palm Beach, the President signaled that he would offer a package of aid for displaced workers to address Democratic fears that Americans would lose jobs as a result of free-trade deals flowing from the expanded authority the legislation would give him. That authority, he said, is "key to U.S. leadership in the world economy."
The legislation at issue would grant the President fast-track authority: the ability to negotiate trade agreements that Congress could then either approve or reject, but not amend. Just as he did when he pushed through the North American Free Trade Agreement in 1993, Mr. Clinton will be relying largely on Republican votes. But he still needs to convince enough Democrats that the legislation is important enough for them to defy the wishes of one of their strongest constituencies, organized labor.
The A.F.L.-C.I.O., which contributes heavily to Democratic campaigns, opposes the bill, saying it does not take strong enough steps to stop competitor nations from producing cheap goods by exploiting workers and cutting corners on environmental protection.
Mr. Clinton's biggest hurdle is expected to be in the House, where the Democratic leader, Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, is leading the fight against the bill, with Speaker Newt Gingrich cast in an unlikely role as the President's ally.
House Republicans say that of the 218 votes that will be needed for passage if all members vote on the measure, they can provide only about 150. So Mr. Clinton must corral a significant number of votes from his own party.
The vote-gathering has taken the form of deal-making, with one Administration official declaring privately that the "bazaar is open." Assistance for displaced workers is a cornerstone of that effort.
Mr. Clinton spoke briefly in West Palm Beach today, addressing about 400 workers and their families who had waited more than four hours for him in the parking lot of Tropical Shipping, the leading carrier in United States-Caribbean sea trade. He said the company would benefit greatly from the bill. As a fellow Democrat, Gov. Lawton Chiles, told the audience, Florida's "No. 1 cash cow" is trade, not tourism.
Mr. Clinton was hampered by laryngitis, which left him in the awkward position of having his Commerce Secretary, William M. Daley, read the President's most definitive statement to date on the trade issue.
But later in the day, his voice returning, Mr. Clinton said the answer to Democratic concerns over the trade legislation was to help workers whose lives might be disrupted by it.
"We ought to provide more education and better transition for people who lose their jobs through trade or technological changes -- not walk away from trade," he told about 20 people over lunch at a mansion where he raised $180,000 for the Democratic Party.
The worker-assistance package is not expected to be unveiled until the middle of next week. But aides said it would include about $500 million over five years in trade-related assistance and training programs, and additional sums for economic development and for communities that suffer from expanded trade.
White House officials, who sounded out members of Congress throughout the day, said the package was still "evolving."
Gene Sperling, the chief economic adviser at the White House, said that the worker assistance package would involve "policies we will say we will commit to put in the budget and fight for," but that the aid would not be attached to the trade bill.

HEADLINE: Reuters Given Big Tax Deal For Its Project In Times Square

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and executives of Reuters American Holdings announced yesterday that the giant British media company would build a 32-story headquarters in Times Square with the help of tens of millions of dollars in tax breaks.
Reuters, which had threatened to move to New Jersey or Connecticut, plans to build an 855,000 square-foot tower at the northwest corner of 42d Street and Seventh Avenue for about 1,800 employees now working at eight buildings scattered across Manhattan. 
 In return, officials said yesterday, the city and the state are to provide the company with a $12.5 million sales tax exemption on computers, desks and other equipment over the next 20 years. Reuters would get up to $13.5 million in additional tax incentives if it creates new jobs over the life of the deal.
Reuters would also benefit from large tax incentives, already tied to the site, that were approved in the 1980's to lure development to Times Square, until recently a seedy district with little appeal for developers.
"Reuters could have gone somewhere else, but they chose to stay in the media capital of the world," Mr. Giuliani said at a news conference in the MTV music studios overlooking Times Square. "This is great news for Reuters and New York."
The announcement of a new tower in Times Square is the second in the past 18 months: the developer Douglas Durst is building a 48-story tower across the street from the Reuters site for Conde Nast Publications. And, in the past two years, Disney, Warner Brothers, Virgin Superstore and others have moved into the area.
But as the economy has improved, the city has come under increasing criticism for continuing to grant tax breaks to corporations for moving to a booming Times Square and other sites in midtown Manhattan.
The total value of all the tax breaks for Reuters is more than $60 million. Asked to place a value on the first round of tax breaks that were tied to the site, Mayor Giuliani and Reuters executives refused.
Charles A. Gargano, chairman of the Empire State Development Corporation, said Reuters would get $36.9 million over 20 years; other city officials said the figure was $32 million and some developers and urban planners said it was much higher.
Critics say the city is giving too much away. "Giuliani has made Times Square the tax break or corporate welfare capital of the world," said State Senator Franz Leichter, a critic of the city's tax policies for more than a decade. "The next neon sign to go up should flash dollar signs with the amount of tax breaks going to corporations that fill Times Square."
After Conde Nast threatened to move employees out of the city last year, the publishing company got a $10.75 million incentive package to move to a Times Square site that already enjoyed significant tax breaks. MTV and its parent company, Viacom, got a $15 million tax break in 1994 from the Giuliani administration.
Next door, the Marriott Marquis hotel got a $90 million tax break in the early 1980's, and across the street, Bertelsmann AG, the German media conglomerate, got an $11 million tax break at 1540 Broadway, an office tower built with property tax abatements. Morgan Stanley, the investment bank, got a $100 million tax package when it purchased 1585 Broadway and 750 Seventh Avenue, two office towers also built with property tax abatements. Both companies had threatened to move at least some employees out of New York.
Mayor Giuliani said the tax breaks are necessary to retain the city's major corporations, especially when New Jersey and Connecticut are offering competing incentives, and to spark new construction in the city. Since January 1994, the Giuliani administration has struck 35 so-called corporate retention deals worth nearly $700 million.
As a result of their economic development policies, officials say, the city has saved 79,700 jobs and produced 40,000 new jobs.
But those numbers are difficult to confirm, since most corporations threaten to relocate only a portion of their employees, while city officials count the entire workforce as jobs saved if a company agrees to stay. To make matters more complicated, the city's list of deals includes Republic National Bank, even though the city canceled the $6.4 million tax break in 1996 when the company slashed its payroll.
Although the announcement yesterday ended Reuters's yearlong search for new space, the news did not lift the spirits of some 600 union employees negotiating a contract with Reuters. The company has asked for 104 concessions, union officials said.
"The timing of this is incredible," Peter Szekely, chairman of the Reuters unit of the Newspaper Guild in New York. "The same week they're asking us for monumental cuts in wages and benefits, they're getting a sweetheart tax deal. Yet this company has been very profitable for a long time."
Robert Crooke, a spokesman for Reuters, said the contract demands were consistant with the company's "desire to reduce costs, focus our business efforts and consolidate our operations in an amenable environment" in Times Square.

HEADLINE: No Accord, and Little Optimism, at Bonn Talks on Global Warming

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS 

DATELINE: BONN, Oct. 31

 BODY:
Delegates from 143 countries ended their preliminary talks on global warming here today with no agreement on key issues and growing concern about the prospect for success at the concluding meeting, to be held in Kyoto, Japan, in early December.
The United States' long-awaited proposal for cutting emissions of heat-trapping greenhouse gases has been scornfully attacked as too weak by delegates and environmentalists from around the world. And there is no sign that American negotiators are about to yield. Still, the Americans themselves said there was more than a little cause for hope, and they have been lobbying their counterparts here, urging them to take a closer look at the American proposal. 
 Meanwhile, several small-scale but higher-level meetings will be held between now and Dec. 1, when the Kyoto conference begins. The goal of the conference is to revise the climate treaty negotiated in Rio in 1992, which set voluntary limits on emissions.
"There are enough ideas out there to have an agreement," a senior State Department official said here, speaking on condition of anonymity. "We just don't see all the kinds of coalescence that you need yet" for that to happen.
On the surface, the American proposal looks like the weakest on the table. The proposal would require industrialized countries to reduce their emissions of greenhouse gases to 1990 levels in the period 2008 to 2012. By contrast, the European Union wants to cut emissions 15 percent below 1990 levels by 2010. But the American official said that the American plan compares more favorably with other countries' positions once the details are inspected, and that it is superior to a major alternative plan advanced by Japan. Japan calls for a 2.5 percent to 5 percent reduction in emissions by about 2010.
Other American officials here today released an analysis by the Department of Energy and the Environmental Protection Agency which suggests that the American position actually occupies a middle ground between those of Japan and the European Union. The contention is based mainly on the fact that under the United States' proposal, emissions of a full array of six different greenhouse gases would be controlled. The other proposals would control only three.
Some critics said the the American estimate that its plan occupies the middle ground were based on uncertain projections of future emissions of the less abundant gases. The Administration countered that even if the projections of future emissions are cut in half, the basic conclusion still holds.
The conclusion is "a valid point," said Dr. Daniel Lashof, a scientist with the Natural Resources Defense Council, an environmental group. "I think the U.S. proposal is stronger than the Japanese position, but it still falls short" of the European position.
With the Bonn phase of the talks over, key players must "review their options so that they can come to Kyoto with more flexible positions," said Michael Zammit Cutajar, the executive director of a 1992 climate treaty under which the discussions are proceeding.
The State Department official, however, said that "before we start perhaps working toward any compromises, we want to be sure that people understand" the full scope of Washington's position.
It may be, said Mr. Zammit Cutajar, that the Kyoto session will produce "an agreement based not on a single target, but on different targets for each country." The individual targets for emissions cuts would be based on an array of economic and social characteristics. The possibility of differentiated targets received much attention here over the last few days.
Talks between now and the Kyoto conference are to take place in a number of forums and through a number of channels, some of them at higher levels, between now and the start of the Kyoto conference on Dec. 1. Among the forums coming up is a meeting involving ministers from key countries in Tokyo Nov. 8 through 10. The American official said there was "great scope" for resolving many issues before the Kyoto talks begin.
Aside from the question of what cuts in emissions industrialized countries will make, and when, the biggest outstanding issue is the role of developing countries. While the 1992 Rio climate treaty generally requires them to control their emissions, it does not bind them to any specific commitments. The rationale is that since the richer countries are responsible for most of the greenhouse gas emissions so far, they should take the lead in reducing them. The negotiators in Bonn had no authority to consider new commitments for the developing world.
But the Kyoto meeting involves a higher-level conference of parties to the 1992 treaty, and it can take up the issue. The United States has insisted it will sign no agreement in Kyoto that does not include "meaningful" participation by the developing countries. Everyone agrees that eventually, the poorer nations will have to take on specific commitments if greenhouse gases are to be controlled, since their emissions are expected to surpass those of the industrialized world in the early decades of the next century.
"If all the industrialized countries shut down their economies, it wouldn't solve the problem," said Bert Metz, a prominent European negotiator from the Netherlands. But the issue of the developing countries' future role has proved intractable so far. In part, that is because these countries argue that the industrialized countries have become rich through a century of increasing emission of greenhouse gases. They argue that initially, the rich countries should bear most of the burden of preventing climate change.
The American diplomat here said that since the issue is so difficult, it may be possible to resolve only part of it in Kyoto, with negotiations continuing beyond that.
The Clinton Administration says that under its proposal to include all six greenhouse gases, total greenhouse emissions in the United States would be reduced by some 30 percent from what they would otherwise be around 2010.
The most important of the six heat-trapping gases is carbon dioxide, which is produced by the burning of fossil fuels like coal, oil and natural gas. The others are methane, which forms in landfills and is emitted in part as waste natural gas, and nitrous oxide, hydrofluorocarbons, perfluorocarbons and sulfur hexachloride, which are produced by a variety of industrial processes and have a variety of uses.
