HEADLINE: THE JIANG VISIT: THE CHINESE-AMERICANS;
Welcome, A Bit Blase, For Fellow Traveler

BYLINE: By DAVID W. CHEN 

 BODY:
For many Chinese in New York, President Jiang Zemin's trip yesterday to their new hometown was in a strange way not that different from their own journeys to America.
They had come from China and Taiwan to the center of the financial world searching for business opportunities and better lives. 
 And he came to visit not the Statue of Liberty or the Empire State Building, but the citadels of capitalism, including the New York Stock Exchange and I.B.M.
"I hope that Jiang Zemin can open up the country more, but he still needs more time," said Su Bin, a musician from Beijing who immigrated here in the early 1980's.
Mr. Su, who plays the erhu, a Chinese stringed instrument, took a break from one of the Blimpie's outlets he manages in New York City to discuss the visit.
"People who complain about human rights in China -- all they do is make noise here so they can advance their own careers and get a green card," said Mr. Su, 49, wearing a red apron that bore the words "Mrs. Field's Cookies."
For all the attention to the hundreds of protesters who have dogged Mr. Jiang on his visit, the reaction in the Chinese neighborhoods yesterday was underwhelming, even indifferent, as people went about their business as if it were any other Friday.
Many residents asked to size up the visit had the same response: His visit doesn't affect us much, but he is welcome, nonetheless.
In Chinatown, one man sitting on a bench near the statue of Confucius at the corner of Division and Bowery clutched a copy of the newspaper Sing Tao and said he had read all about President Jiang's visit.
"I'm just a worker," said the man, who declined to give his name. "But as a person, he clearly has distinguished himself and he deserves to be respected and welcomed."
Even those whom one might have assumed would have strong misgivings about the visit seemed to suggest that business was more important than politics.
Take Dr. Wang Shou-dong, 39. He grew up in a middle-class family, the son of a factory manager in Liaoning province. But when his father fell victim to Communists and the Cultural Revolution, the family suffered mightily: Dr. Wang was twice sent to rural labor camps, while his father was beaten and lost the vision in one eye.
Later he became a doctor, specializing in Chinese herbs and acupuncture. Still, he said, he felt stifled by the Chinese bureaucracy and his own scars from the Cultural Revolution -- to the point that he was afraid to do his best and become too prominent a doctor. So in 1995 he emigrated to New York.
Now he works at the Beijing Chinese Medical Hospital of New York, a small second-floor clinic in Flushing, where he has paper the walls with newspaper clippings about his work. He is happy to be in America, he said, and grateful that "you can learn a lot of things and do anything you want, as long as you work hard."
And yet, for all the bad memories of his youth, he said, he still welcomed the leader of a Government that he does not trust.
"This is a good thing, because he can see what's good and what's not so good about American business, and then he can take it home to China," he said. "The most important thing is that China raise its standard of living and develop its economy."
Lin Go, an immigrant from Taiwan and a former taxi driver in Taipei who now runs an jade store in Flushing, shared the sentiments of immigrants from the mainland. "We are all Chinese, and I think he has the same attitude that we Chinese immigrants do when we come here," said .
"For us, we come to New York to learn about business and support our families. For him, his country is his family. So he wants to learn about business and support his family."
There were, of course, some reminders that not all views were benign. In Flushing, for instance, several minivans decorated like Chinese jails circled the block, displaying anti-Jiang banners and chanting slogans of protest.
When the subject of the Tiananmen Square crackdown came up, several people interviewed said they could not forget or forgive what had happened, but many gave Mr. Jiang the benefit of the doubt.
"New York is the place where business is Number 1," said Joe Si, owner of Joe's Shanghai, a popular dumpling house in Flushing. "If he is able to reform and improve China because of what he learns in New York, then this trip will have been very productive for all the Chinese people."

HEADLINE: THE 1997 ELECTIONS: THE RECORD;
Whitman Stands on Record, But Newer Issues Stir Voters

BYLINE: By JENNIFER PRESTON

DATELINE: TRENTON, Oct. 31

 BODY:
Gov. Christine Todd Whitman was elected four years ago on the strength of a bold promise: she would cut state income tax rates by a third. Her opponents said it couldn't be done. She did it in two years, not three.
The tax cuts made Mrs. Whitman a national celebrity: the politician who kept a promise. But that has not been enough to appease New Jersey's voters in this fall's gubernatorial campaign. They are fed up with paying the highest auto insurance rates in the nation, and angry that their property tax burden continues to rise. 
 Those two issues did not rise to the top of Mrs. Whitman's agenda until this year, giving her Democratic challenger, State Senator James E. McGreevey, plenty of fodder to barrage her with criticism. What had been expected to be a dull race has turned into a close one.
The campaign's fixation on auto insurance and property taxes has overshadowed Mrs. Whitman's record in other areas. Cutting taxes was her most notable achievement, but not her only one.
Working with a Republican-controlled State Legislature, she imposed strict time limits and work requirements for people on welfare, but her plan also offers job training and child care to help recipients move into the workplace.
She established new statewide academic standards for public schools. She has signed one bill after another, imposing tough penalties on convicted criminals and requiring insurance companies to allow women to stay in the hospital up to 48 hours after giving birth and up to 72 hours after a mastectomy. She has also imposed new state regulations on health maintenance organizations, giving patients more rights and doctors more say in how they should do their jobs.
But some decisions are expected to cost her votes in this election, particularly among conservative Republicans who oppose abortion rights. Mrs. Whitman refused to sign legislation to ban certain late-term abortions unless the bill included an exception that would protect the health of the woman. She also has not pushed legislation that would let parents send their children to private schools with taxpayer dollars.
There have also been some notable policy failures, particularly during the last two years, when the tax cuts have not dominated the political agenda.
On school financing, the New Jersey State Supreme Court rejected Mrs. Whitman's argument that academic standards would end the disparity between rich and poor school districts. The court required the Governor and the Legislature to come up with another $250 million.
On property taxes, Mrs. Whitman has given municipalities some tools to lower rates, but she has also kept municipal and school aid flat during most of her first term. The average statewide property tax increase has been about 4 percent during each of the last four years, the lowest in decades. Yet local taxes still rose from a high base, making New Jersey's property taxes the nation's highest.
And while Mrs. Whitman did win legislative approval to eliminate auto-insurance surcharges and end automatic rate increases, lawmakers rejected the cornerstone of her proposal: lowering rates by giving consumers the option of reducing coverage.
 
Jobs and Business Focus of First Term
When Governor Whitman took office on Jan. 18, 1994, auto insurance was not New Jersey's most pressing concern. Its economy was beginning to show distinct signs of improvement, but the electorate was beset with economic anxieties. Home prices were falling. Major corporations were downsizing, and manufacturing companies were moving out.
Determined to lure jobs to New Jersey, Mrs. Whitman began her first term with a much-publicized "Open for Business" campaign. As she had hoped, her celebrated income tax cuts sent a signal that New Jersey was now friendlier to business. She also lowered 11 other taxes, from the tax on apple cider to the corporate tax on small businesses, which is now the lowest in the New York metropolitan region at 7.5 percent.
To the dismay of some environmental groups, however, she rolled back some of the tough environmental regulations that industry here had long complained about. She also sought to negotiate with companies that violate environmental laws rather than first take them to court, a sign that many environmentalists viewed as weakening enforcement.
Mrs. Whitman says that the state's economy is now humming. A Dun & Bradstreet study placed New Jersey eighth in the nation in the number of jobs gained by luring businesses from other states.
While the tax cuts did not produce the 450,000 new jobs that Mrs. Whitman once projected, more than 200,000 more jobs have been created since she took office, wiping out the losses of the early 1990's recession.
Total personal income has jumped 15 percent. But not everyone in every part of the state is thriving, and Mr. McGreevey has pointed this out regularly in his campaign. The cities have not shared in the economic recovery. The poverty level has not improved. The number of people without health insurance has risen. Many of the new jobs have been in the service industries, offering lower wages and fewer benefits than the manufacturing jobs that have disappeared.
"Her record is like the economic recovery that she has presided over," said Henry J. Raimondo, an economist and professor of public policy at Rutgers University. "It is very uneven."
 
Variety of Maneuvers Slows Budget Growth
Governor Whitman proclaims that she has slowed growth in the state budget to its lowest level for any four-year period in the last 50 years. But a review of her last four budgets suggests that she did not do it the old-fashioned way, by cutting programs or services. Over all, state spending has risen by more than $1.5 billion since she took office.
With legislative approval, she used budgetary maneuvers that included reducing the state's contribution to its seven pension funds by $3 billion, stretching out debt payments for $1.3 billion in state transportation bonds to 20 years from 10, and pulling millions of dollars from various state trust funds that had been designated for specific purposes.
But Mrs. Whitman has succeeded in controlling costs in important areas. She reached agreement on a four-year pact with the state's largest public employee union, freezing wages for two years and reducing the state's cost of providing health care benefits. She has also cut about 3,000 state jobs, mostly through attrition.
Any attempts by the Governor to bill herself as a strong fiscal conservative, however, were undermined this year when she pushed through a plan to borrow $2.75 billion for the state pension system. The borrowing, the first of its kind in the nation, allowed the state to reduce its scheduled pension payment to $220 million from $810 million, freeing $590 million to help balance an election-year budget.
Instead of using her political capital this spring to win support for her auto insurance plan, Mrs. Whitman found herself devoting a great deal of attention to pushing her borrowing proposal through the Legislature.
"For better of worse, the pension bond plan probably undermined much of the impact that she hoped to gain from the income tax cuts," said Donald Linky, president of the Public Affairs Research Institute of New Jersey, an independent, nonpartisan public policy organization in Princeton. "It gave her opponents an easy way to attack her tax-cutting record by simply saying that she borrowed in order to make up for the lost revenues."
Mrs. Whitman firmly defends her decision, pointing out that the state replaced one liability with another. The state put about 60 percent from the proceeds of the borrowing into the stock market, hoping to earn a higher return than the 7.65 percent payments on the bonds. But the sudden market downturn just days before the election enabled Democrats to point out that Mrs. Whitman had put the state at risk should stocks tumble steadily downward.
Mayor George Spadoro of Edison, a Democrat who fought an unsuccessful court battle against the borrowing for the pension system, said that the market drop confirmed "our worst fears about Governor Whitman's $2.75 billion pension bond gamble."
"The hard lesson learned on Wall Street is that Governor Whitman's borrow-and-spend policies don't work," he said.
 
Crackdown on Crime, But Crowded Prisons
Since Mrs. Whitman took office the crime rate has fallen steadily in New Jersey, as it has in many other states, according to the New Jersey Department of Law and Public Safety.
Crime fell by 7 percent last year, with violent crimes down 11 percent -- better than the 7 percent drop reported nationwide. The drop in crime was particularly steep in New Jersey's cities. In Camden, the number of murders dropped more than 50 percent. In Newark, violent crime fell 16 percent, and murders fell about 10 percent.
Governor Whitman can point to numerous tough new crime laws that she has signed since taking office. One requires violent criminals to serve up to 85 percent of their term before being paroled. Another requires anyone convicted of three violent crimes to be imprisoned for life without parole.
Mrs. Whitman has also pushed through several laws as a result of crusades by families of crime victims. In her first year in office, she signed "Megan's Law," named after a 7-year-old girl murdered by a neighbor who was a convicted sex offender. The law, which requires that communities be notified about the presence of convicted sex offenders, became a model for a new Federal law and similar state laws across the nation.
She has also signed "Joan's Law," named after another 7-year-old girl who was sexually assaulted and murdered by a neighbor. The law bars parole for anyone convicted of molesting and murdering a child.
Mrs. Whitman has also opened military-style boot camps for juvenile offenders. But the state and county prisons remain overcrowded, and with her new tough crime laws, the state prison population is expected to continue to swell. A new state prison opened this year, but prison officials acknowledge that it does not begin to address the demand for more jail cells. And no new prisons are planned.
 
School Spending Still Causing Conflict
Closing the spending gap between New Jersey's poorest and wealthiest school districts has bedeviled every New Jersey governor from Brendan T. Byrne to Jim Florio. Ordered by the New Jersey Supreme Court to end the disparity, Mr. Byrne pushed through the state's income tax in 1976. Mr. Florio pushed through a $2.8 billion tax increase in 1990, part of which was earmarked for schools. The tax increase helped lead to his defeat for a second term.
Mrs. Whitman tried a different approach. She sought to shift the debate away from how much money should be spent to what students should be learning. By imposing statewide academic standards, and promising to increase spending on public schools by $235 million, she contended that her plan satisfied the State Constitution's stipulation that all children receive a "thorough and efficient" education.
But the State Supreme Court rejected the plan in May. While the justices gave Mrs. Whitman credit for setting new academic standards, they ordered that New Jersey come up with more money for 28 urban school districts. Mrs. Whitman and the State Legislature complied and agreed to spend $250 million more.
But the problem is far from settled. Now 25 rural and suburban school districts are planning to sue the state, arguing that homeowners in their communities cannot bear the cost of imposing the new academic standards. They are not the only school districts complaining. During Mrs. Whitman's first three years in office, state aid to more than half of the state's school districts remained flat or declined, placing a heavier property tax burden on homeowners.
Mrs. Whitman herself acknowledges that she has not done enough to lower property taxes and auto insurance rates, and promises to do so in a second term. She says she believes voters will give her another chance.
"I think people do appreciate elected officials who keep their promises," she said. "And I think that will be reflected on Election Day."

HEADLINE: THE 1997 ELECTIONS: THE CANDIDATES;
Giuliani and Messinger Plot the Endgame

BYLINE: By NORIMITSU ONISHI 

 BODY:
The two leading mayoral candidates entered the last weekend before Election Day with a flurry of televised appearances, new advertisements and Halloween parades, as they prepared for the final frenetic days of campaigning that will include a visit by President Clinton for Ruth W. Messinger and a 48-hour bus tour of the city by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.
Yesterday, the Messinger campaign previewed one of its last two television commercials, in which Mr. Giuliani is castigated for accepting hundreds of thousands of dollars in illegal campaign contributions. 
 The advertisement, a farcical cartoon that shows the Mayor's ever-expanding head gradually blotting out the Manhattan skyline, also paints Mr. Giuliani as an opportunist more interested in running for higher office than in being Mayor for four years. Mr. Giuliani has refused to pledge that he would serve a full second term.
As for Mr. Giuliani, he continued to emphasize his record in his final television advertisements and ignore Ms. Messinger, even as his commanding lead in the polls seemed to embolden him to spend more time seeking the votes of the city's minority groups.
In recent days, Mr. Giuliani has also begun to address one of the longstanding criticisms from the Democrats: that the economic revival in the city has been unequal and that he is the mayor of the city's elite.
"We still have people that are left out and we still have people that feel they aren't part of it," he said during the taping of the WCBS-TV news program "Sunday Edition."
"It's my job to reach them," Mr. Giuliani said. "That's why I'm really doing this 48-hour tour. I want to go into the next term just reaching out to every neighborhood in the city and basically say that there's no neighborhood that we can't go to, no neighborhood that really shouldn't be part of this renaissance that New York City is going through."
The Mayor's change in tone reflected not only his growing confidence but also his campaign's push for a large margin of victory, which his admirers and critics believe would help position him to run for higher office.
Last night, Mr. Giuliani marched in a Halloween parade in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, one of the predominantly white ethnic neighborhoods outside Manhattan that make up his base of support. But a couple of hours earlier, he walked in a Halloween parade in Jackson Heights, Queens, a multi-racial and multi-ethnic district.
The Mayor received a polite, though not enthusiastic, reception. He threw himself into the largely Hispanic crowd only a few times, and his advance people failed to rouse many of the spectators along 37th Avenue.
At a news conference in City Hall Park, Ms. Messinger received the endorsement of leaders of several immigrant-rights groups. Ms. Messinger, the Democratic candidate, said that Mr. Giuliani had tailored his views on immigration for his political benefit.
"I am a little confused because when Rudy Giuliani worked for the Reagan Administration he helped run a Haitian policy that ignored human-rights abuses," Ms. Messinger said, flanked by a dozen representatives from organizations including the Guyanese-American Workers Unite and the American-Bangledesh Coalition for Immigrants' Rights. "Now, all of a sudden, the Mayor is a champion of immigrants."
Ms. Messinger arrived late at the event after her tan Ford Windstar minivan broke down on Broadway outside her campaign headquarters in lower Manhattan. She also encountered an awkward moment during the taping of "Sunday Edition" when the host, Marcia Kramer, asked her to say something positive about the Mayor.
"Love his hair," Ms. Messinger said. Slightly taken aback, Ms. Kramer said, "Um. O.K."

HEADLINE: Homeowners Record Is Set in Third Quarter

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES 

DATELINE: BALTIMORE

 BODY:
There is nothing special about the beige house with the burgundy door, except of course to its owner, Shari Crittendon.
The two-story, wood-frame house sits on a cul-de-sac in a new development near the city limits. It abuts a forested expanse where raccoons, foxes and deer often emerge to creep close to the rear deck. Out front, yellow and maroon mums, planted in the spring, are beginning to turn brown from an autumn frost. 
 But while the dwelling itself carries no great significance, its purchase by Ms. Crittendon last year was part of an important economic and psychological milestone for the country.
In mid-October, the Census Bureau reported that the percentage of American families owning homes had recently reached the highest level ever. According to the bureau, in the third quarter of 1997, 66 percent of the households in the nation owned their home, beating the record of 65.8 percent set in the third quarter of 1980. All told, 67.6 million households own their home, the bureau reported.
Independent analysts, as well as those in the Clinton Administration, say that the rising number of homeowners -- including many, like Ms. Crittendon, who are first-time buyers -- is the result of several factors. These include low interest rates, low unemployment, rising incomes, a number of Federal assistance programs, increased competition among mortgage lenders, and better enforcement of fair-housing laws.
But the main factor, many experts say, is growing consumer confidence. Indeed, the burgeoning rate of home ownership is perhaps the most tangible sign that after six-and-a-half years of economic expansion, the belief in the robust economy is now so entrenched that a record number of people are willing to undertake the biggest investment they will ever make in their lives: buying a home.
"It's not just that it's a strong economy," said Andrew M. Cuomo, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development. "It's that people are willing to believe that they'll have a job long term, that their house will appreciate and that their incomes will grow."
Census Bureau and HUD data, as well as that from private researchers, indicate that much of the growth in home ownership has been fueled by increasing numbers of buyers among minorities, single women, low- and moderate-income families and urban dwellers. While the number of non-Hispanic white households owning homes rose by 4 percent from 1993 to 1996, black home owners jumped by 7.5 percent and Hispanic home owners by 16 percent, according to the Joint Center for Housing Studies at Harvard University.
These increases stem in part from rising incomes and lowered unemployment among minorities and single women. The rise is also the result of several policies adopted by the Bush and Clinton Administrations. Starting in 1991, for example, Federal regulators, when asked to approve bank mergers, began to include a bank's lending history in low- and moderate-income areas as part of their review.
In 1992, Congress ordered the two Federally chartered lending companies, Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, to increase their loans to low- and moderate-income borrowers. In 1995, seeking to save his department from elimination by the newly elected Republican-led Congress, Housing Secretary Henry G. Cisneros adopted a "national homeownership strategy" that eased requirements to qualify for Federal Housing Administration-insured loans and reduced closing costs by as much as $1,200 on those loans for first-time buyers.
Stephan O'Connor, the senior director for residential loan production at the Mortgage Bankers Association of America, also noted that banks in recent years have discovered the potential profits from lending in low-income neighborhoods and begun to look for potential mortgage customers in areas that had previously been ignored.
All regions of the nation have participated in the increase. For the third quarter of 1997, 63 percent of households in the Northeast owned their own homes; 70.7 percent in the Midwest; 68.2 percent in the South, and 59.8 percent in the West.
The nexus of forces and policies that lifted home ownership can been seen in Ms. Crittendon's neighborhood, a development called The Woodlands at Cold Spring. Of the 101 houses there -- nearly all of which are owned by African Americans -- about 80 per cent are owned by first-time home buyers.
Ms. Crittendon, who is 35, is president of the home owners association for the development. She is a single mother whose daughter was born when she was a sophomore at Syracuse University. Since 1991, Ms. Crittendon had worked in sales at the Xerox Corporation while attending law school at the University of Maryland at Baltimore.
Law school tuition ate up whatever savings she had, as well as the pension she had accrued at Xerox. As a result, she did not have money for a down payment on a house, and was worried that she might not be able to move from her two-bedroom apartment in a rough neighborhood near downtown Baltimore.
Last year, Ms. Crittendon qualified for a program run by the City of Baltimore that provided a $5,941 interest-free loan for a down payment on the four-bedroom home, which cost $166,500. The loan for the down payment is not repayable until the mortgage on the house is paid off or the house is sold.
In addition, the city let Ms. Crittendon phase in the full payment of her property taxes. She is required to pay only 60 percent of her assessed taxes in the first year, with the amount rising in 10 percent annual increments for the next four years.
Ms. Crittendon, a lawyer for Morgan State University in Baltimore, now finds herself caught up in the kinds of activities indicative of a new home owner. She gardens, decorates and plans changes to her house.
"I spend most of my Friday nights at Home Depot," she said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Shari Crittendon, left, with her daughter, Brooke, in front of the first home they have owned, in Baltimore. Ms. Crittendon, a 35-year-old lawyer, said she gardened and decorated and already had plans to change her house. (Ann Grillo for The New York Times)

President Jiang on the Path To the Cradle of Capitalism
The President of China spent most of the day in New York, ringing the bell to begin a day of trading at the New York Stock Exchange and inviting 200 top executives from America's largest companies to dine at the Waldorf. Some scattered protests marked his visit. A1

U.N. to Defy Baghdad
The leader of a United Nations arms inspection team in Iraq said the monitors, including 10 Americans whom Baghdad has ordered expelled, would defy President Saddam Hussein's ban on Americans' taking part in the inspection. Iraq's representative at the United Nations said his country was not interested in a confrontation, but an official in Baghdad said Iraqis had prepared themselves for the worst. A4
 
Pope Addresses Anti-Semitism
Misinterpretations of Christian teachings contributed to the Holocaust and to centuries of persecution of Jews in Europe, Pope John Paul II told a group of Christian theologians meeting to discuss the origins of anti-Semitism. The Pope did not apologize directly for the Church's role in anti-Semitism, but said "wrong and unjust interpretations of the New Testament," particularly blaming Jews for the death of Jesus, had circulated for too long and had increased hostility against Jews. A6
 
Vichy Case Hears Historian
The French heard again from Robert O. Paxton, the American historian who provided France with the first comprehensive picture of the crimes of the Vichy regime in Nazi-occupied France during World War II. He testified at the trial of Maurice Papon, a senior Vichy official charged with crimes against humanity for deporting 1,560 Jews from Bordeaux to concentration camps in Germany. Mr. Paxton did not testify about the role Mr. Papon played, but said in an interview that Mr. Papon was a "fairly important cog in the wheel." A3
 
Irish Elect a Belfast Woman
Mary McAleese has been elected President of Ireland, according to official results. Ms. McAleese, 46, is a law professor in Northern Ireland and will be the first British subject ever to hold the office. She will replace Mary Robinson in the largely ceremonial position; Ms. Robinson is the next United Nations Human Rights Commissioner. A6
 
Russia Approves Weapons Ban
The lower house of the Russian Parliament voted 288 to 75 to approve a treaty banning chemical weapons. Russia was one of the first nations to sign the accord in 1993, but some legislators have worried about the estimated $5 billion cost of destroying its arsenal of poison gases, the world's largest, at a time when Russia struggles to pay pensioners. A3

The two moons, with respective diameters estimated at only 50 and 100 miles, are the faintest planetary satellites ever detected from the ground. A11

Rumors of Gang Attacks Empty Schools on Holiday
On a Halloween Day filled with rumors that took on an almost "War of the Worlds" tone, hundreds of thousands of New York City students stayed away from public schools because they, or their parents, feared a rash of gang-related attacks. Those who did venture out to school often found additional police officers patrolling in and near their classrooms and even escorting them to and from subway stations to keep them safe. By various accounts, they were. At Martin Luther King High School on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, for example, the hallways were deserted as some teachers sat at their desks reading novels, their classrooms completely empty. Only 1 out of 10 students showed up. A1

Dinkins, the city's first black mayor. A1

BUSINESS DAY D1-14
 
U.S. Economy Grows
The American economy grew at a vigorous pace over the summer and a key measure of inflation dwindled to a level not seen since 1964. The extraordinary economic performance, reported by the Commerce Department, provided a bit of reassurance after a week of turmoil in the world's financial markets. Despite concerns about the impact of slower growth in Southeast Asia and Latin America, the American economy gathered steam in the three months ended in September, growing at an annual rate of 3.5 percent, up from 3.2 percent the previous quarter. For four straight quarters, the pace has surpassed 3 percent, the most consistent surge since the lingering effects of the worst postwar recession were overcome 13 years ago. A1
 
Global Share Prices Rise
A global rebound in share prices helped buoy Wall Street, ending a tumultuous week of trading. Markets around the world, which were roiled by an economic and currency crisis in Southeast Asia, appeared to stabilize after Hong Kong stocks soared early in the day. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 60.41 points to close at 7,442.08. D2
 
Court Blocks CSX Verdict
The Louisiana Supreme Court blocked a $3.4 billion jury verdict, including $2.5 billion against the CSX Corporation, from taking effect until the injuries suffered by all 8,000 victims of a 1987 New Orleans railway fire could be assessed. Although this action does not reverse that verdict, it lessens the possibility that CSX will have to pay nearly so much. D3

LENGTH: 1321 words

HEADLINE: THE JIANG VISIT: THE OVERVIEW;
Mao's Heir Finds Path: Wall Street

BYLINE: By JOHN KIFNER

 BODY:
President Jiang Zemin of China trod a capitalist road yesterday from Wall Street to the suburban campuses of hi-tech American industry.
Free of all the irksome talk about human rights he had had to endure in Washington, Mr. Jiang concentrated in his trip through New York yesterday on a matter closer to his heart: money. It was an interest enthusiastically reciprocated by American business executives eager to cash in on the world's most populous market. 
 When Mr. Jiang dropped by I.B.M.'s Madison Avenue offices to ogle some of the company's most advanced gadgets, the company's chairman and chief executive, Louis V. Gerstner, Jr. greeted him in practiced Mandarin.
"Lao pengyou, ni hao," Mr. Gerstner intoned, to satisfied chuckles all around. "Old friend, how are you?"
And if Chairman Mao had once warned that the revolution is not a dinner party, President Jiang underscored the dramatic changes in China today by throwing a party -- swordfish at the Waldorf, where the guest list included some 200 top executives of blue chip companies like Boeing, Bristol-Myers Squibb, Fedex, Ford and Philip Morris.
Mr. Jiang even rang the bell in the balcony overlooking the trading floor to open the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, standing next to the bright red, gold-starred flag of China like a Socialist Realist hero -- except he was wearing a dark suit.
When he was introduced by the chairman of the exchange, Richard A. Grasso, there was a polite round of applause. But there were also audible boos.
"Good morning," Mr. Jiang said with a stiff little wave. "I wish you good trading."
The market had fallen sharply the day before and the mood was tense when Mr. Jiang pushed the button to clang the bell a few seconds early, 9:29:57 by the electronic clocks scattered above the floor. Whatever the correlation, the market was up 52 points at 9:32:53 and 77.85 points a few minutes later.
Mr. Grasso and William Johnston, the white-bearded president of the exchange, escorted Mr. Jiang for a brief walk through the hurly-burly of the trading floor, but by then the traders were too engaged in the shouting, waving and running about of their profession to pay much attention.
Mr. Jiang was not the first post-Cold War Communist to have rung the traditional opening bell, which actually began as a Chinese gong in 1870, said Wall Street veterans, who recalled that the last President of the Soviet Union, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, had also done so at the beginning of the decade.
But the act had a certain resonance with the bold economic reforms that President Jiang announced at the 15th Communist Party Congress in September, which included a sweeping plan to sell most of China's 13,000 large and medium-sized state-owned enterprises, as well as most of its 300,000 smaller companies.
Although cloaked in revolutionary language -- the plan was entitled "Hold High the Great Banner of Deng Xiaoping Theory for an All-Around Advancement of the Cause of Building Socialism With Chinese Characteristics to the 21st Century" -- the changes could include opening up the state-run economy to private stock ownership.
Mr. Jiang entered and left the exchange through its Wall Street entrance, out of sight and hearing of about a hundred protesters clustered behind police barricades more than a long block away at Broad Street and Exchange Place.
"Shame on China!" the protesters chanted. "China out of Tibet!"
Rinchen Dharlo, a Tibetan organizer of the demonstration, said that he doubted the Chinese President could see them, but that about a dozen people on the way to the demonstration had seen his cavalcade and were able to wave their Tibetan flags at it.
Mr. Dharlo added that he was grateful to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Gov. George E. Pataki for refusing to meet Mr. Jiang, adding, "At least they stood on moral principles, which I feel is very important."
Even at the Waldorf dinner, when the orchestra stopped playing, shouts of protesters outside could be heard by the 200 or so guests.
But if New York's political leaders snubbed Mr. Jiang over the issue of human rights, business executives showed little reticence.
The lure of the China market to American business dates back more than a century -- many of the great family fortunes in Boston were built on the China trade -- and early industrialists dreamed of great profits to be made "if every Chinese bought just one shoe."
The dream was revived when Deng Xiaoping, Mr. Jiang's predecessor, opened China to the West in the late 1970's, but the results thus far have been disappointing.
All but a few American companies are losing money in China as a result of Government restrictions, bureaucracy and corruption, experts say. Yet most large companies -- like I.B.M., which has eight joint ventures in China, A.T.&T. and Lucent Technologies -- feel they have to invest in the country or risk losing out when the vast China market finally begins to pay off in the next century.
Good relations with the Government are widely seen as the key to success, as Mr. Gerstner, the I.B.M. chairman, suggested with his frequent references to his long friendship and many meetings with Mr. Jiang.
In addition to his morning visit to I.B.M., Mr. Jiang went to New Jersey in the afternoon to visit the A.T.&T. network operations center in Bedminster and Lucent Technologies in Berkeley Heights, where he donned a white gown, white shin-high boots and a hoodlike mask and gloves to go into a sealed "clean room" where new, more powerful microchips trademarked Scalpel are made.
The visits were displays of high technology, and Mr. Jiang, trained as an engineer before he began his political rise as Mayor of Shanghai, seemed fascinated. At I.B.M. he voiced many key words in English -- "integrated circuits . . . prototype . . . chip" -- indicating that he understood the descriptions of the three devices he was shown.
One allows the transmission of data between two people when they shake hands, using an electronic device the size of a credit card; a second, called kiosk banking, allows complex financial dealings via the Internet; the third involved advanced numerical weather prediction for specific regions.
Joking that he had not practiced his engineering profession in years, Mr. Jiang told the I.B.M. officials, "when I saw your office, I was reminded of using a slide rule, because your calculators are so thin."
One of Mr. Jiang's major stated purposes on his trip is to learn more about American technology and its possible uses in China, a preoccupation he also emphasized during a midday meeting at his hotel with about 300 representatives from the city's Chinese communities.
He told them that China needed to catch up technologically, one of the people at the meeting said later, then posed for pictures and made a short speech about his visit.
"He said that as a youth, he read many books about the West and studied the languages," said the participant, an immigrant from Fujian. "But he said, 'You can read a hundred books on a subject but you get so much more seeing it, even if just once.' "
Beaming and looking relaxed, Mr. Jiang shook hands with heads of major companies who had come to greet him tonight, making small talk and patting acquaintances on the shoulder at the Waldorf banquet, given in his honor by the U.S. China Business Council and the China Chamber of Commerce in U.S.A.
In his address tonight, Mr. Jiang had some harsh words regarding the annual review required to renew China's preferred trade status.
"American entrepreneurs doing business or making investments feel the sword of Damocles over their heads," he said.
But he painted a bright future for Chinese commerce, promising to "continue to open our market steadily, speed up the opening of our infrastructure like energy and transportation, and gradually open up our service sector, including banking and insurance."

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Jiang Zemin of China was applauded as he visited the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. At left was Richard A. Grasso, chairman of the exchange, and at the right was William Johnston, its president. (Suzanne DeChillo/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Tax-Free Accounts Imperil Public Colleges;
Working Students

 BODY:

To the Editor:
An Oct. 28 news article reports that new teaching positions are to be awarded to City University of New York colleges on the basis of graduation rates. As any educator in public higher education knows, our students are not upper-income children routed from private schools or middle-income children who have graduated from parochial schools. Half are from other countries -- some with excellent educations but learning English; others with educations as bad as those provided by the city's public schools. 
 Our students are working at any jobs they can get to support themselves and their families. The slightest break in earnings knocks them out of school for a semester or a year. Our students are also as mobile as the rest of the country's workers and may transfer to the University of Texas or Florida without our knowledge.
To reward public colleges with appointments on an incentive system for graduation rates rather than meeting their real needs is Alice in Wonderland logic. The economy determines graduation rates. New York has a 9.5 percent unemployment rate: test the correlation with student jobs.
 
ED KENT
New York, Oct. 28, 1997
 
The writer is an associate professor of philosophy at Brooklyn College.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

SECTION: Section 7; Page 9; Column 1; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1286 words

HEADLINE: Dead Souls

BYLINE: By Michael Ignatieff; Michael Ignatieff is the author of "The Russian Album" and the forthcoming "Warrior's Honor."

 BODY:

ECHOES OF A
 NATIVE LAND
 Two Centuries
 of a Russian Village.
 By Serge Schmemann.
 Illustrated. 350 pp. New York:
 Alfred A. Knopf. $27.50. 
 "How beautiful life was," Talleyrand is supposed to have exclaimed, "before the revolution." Modernity leaves us incurably nostalgic for anciens regimes. The whips and the chains of the American Old South get airbrushed out of the lush images of the plantation; the sepia-toned melancholy that infuses our mental image of the long sunlit afternoon of Russia under the last Czar spirits away the drunken misery of the Russian village. Our appetite for lost paradises is insatiable.
The recollection of paradise has produced one masterpiece -- Vladimir Nabokov's "Speak, Memory," a work of genius precisely because its author mastered the tidal force of his own nostalgia. He did so by forcing his memory to wrest unmistakably real detail -- the sight of his father appearing magically in midair in front of a third-story window, lofted up there by peasants who were tossing him in a blanket -- from the boggy compost of sentimentality. But where Nabokov led, others have found it difficult to follow. I know something about the undertow of sentimentality and the lure of czarist kitsch, having written one such memoir myself.
With the fall of the Communist empire, the genre -- and the nostalgia -- have taken on a new lease on life. Grandchildren and great-grandchildren of the vast Russian emigration that flooded out of the Soviet prison-house after 1917 are now able to revisit the estates and town houses that had become the holy sites of family lore. But the search for roots often ends in disappointment. Face to face with the corruption, cynicism and chaos of Russian life, many in the second and third generations decided that they were actually less Russian than they had thought. Besides, the great houses had been burned down, ransacked or turned into shabby orphanages; the family graves had been plowed under.
Serge Schmemann, a correspondent for The New York Times in Moscow during the 1980's, takes this genre of the exile's return into new territory. Unlike that of many second-generation memoirists, his Russian is excellent and his knowledge of Russia is intimate. As a journalist, he was able to get access to hitherto unvisited Russian archives to track down his family's past.
Schmemann had grown up in Europe and America hearing tales about Sergiyevskoye, his family's estate on the Oka River, 90 miles south of Moscow. His family -- the Osorgins and the Schmemanns -- were gentry in service to the czar. One relative was governor of Tula during the 1905 revolution and dispatched the Cossacks to put down the demonstrations. But he was so horrified by the sight of whips lashing the backs of the fleeing students that he sought to call the Cossacks off, screaming -- in vain -- "Back! Don't!" This is the very image of the liberal gentry at the end of its tether.
Liberal in politics, pious in religion, indulgent and improving as landowners, Schmemann's ancestors were also affecting and talented memoirists. In
his unpublished recollections, Schmemann's grandfather insisted that, even in exile, his family's Russian patrimony had not been lost: "You, my grandchildren, you are not foreign, you have your rightful, personal place by my side, on that same dear Sergiyevskoye soil, which will nourish you and give you life, if only you do not turn away from it. So listen to your father and grandfather. I will try, as I can, to show you our sacred, unforgettable Sergiyevskoye."
When Schmemann reached Sergiyevskoye in 1990, he discovered that the manor house had burned down in 1923, as the peasants' revenge not against the old masters but against the Bolsheviks, who had seized the house and were forcing the peasants into collective farms. Only remnants of the glorious past remained: a gutted bell tower, a crumbling stable and a former parish school.
Schmemann might have left matters there, as most exiles do. Instead he struck up acquaintances with the villagers and discovered his true subject, and the core of this book -- the history of the village after his family had gone into exile. It is a story of the Russian 20th century in miniature. Through the villagers' recollections, their photographs and their own memoirs, we watch the revolutionary hope that dawned when the first tractors arrived, and then the descent into disillusion that followed forced collectivization and Stalin's terror.
This microcosmic viewpoint, centered on Sergiyevskoye, allows Schmemann to ask a key question about Soviet history: what really changed for ordinary people? On the surface, it seems, terribly little. Schmemann is nostalgia-proof when it comes to the czarist past: the villagers were drunk and miserable in his ancestors' time; czarist rule was despotic; material conditions were hard and the roads were often impassable. In the 1990's, everything seems nearly the same: drunkenness and misery, incompetent despotism in Moscow, muddy roads.
In some ways, conditions in the village are worse now than they were in 1900. Schmemann -- whose father was an Orthodox priest -- demonstrates that Communism ripped the spiritual heart out of the village. The villagers told him how the family's church had been taken apart by the drunken local commissar, who sold the bricks for vodka. He interviews old-timers who remember how, as fiery young Bolsheviks, they were incited to go out and taunt the Orthodox Easter processions. One of Schmemann's most trusted and responsive informants finally confesses that as a young woman, she worked in a secret K.G.B. plant in Moscow that melted down the icons, chalices and miters seized from Orthodox churches. "It was our youth!" she confesses plaintively. "We were convinced we were ushering in a better world!"
Schmemann's visits precipitated villagers into a confrontation with their own history. The daughters of peasants, who had been devoted Communists, began writing memoirs themselves, to assist Schmemann but also to make peace with a past that since Soviet times they could discuss only in whispers. The most affecting and interesting part of Schmemann's book describes the way he and the villagers jointly assembled the history of the village. After Schmemann let one local read his grandfather's memoirs, with their account of the well-kept church, the pious landowner and the alley of limes, he kept repeating: "All this we lost. All this we threw away."
Repeated visits to the village in the early 1990's -- he even bought an old wooden cottage there -- led Schmemann to be deeply pessimistic about the prospects for turning Russia into a thriving capitalist economy. The peasants' basic ethic had not changed in a century -- "he who had too little was due more, and he who grabbed too much was denying it to others."
The more Schmemann learns of Sergiyevskoye's 20th-century history, the more he learns the village's secrets -- the drunkenness, the violence, the murders -- the less charmed he is by the squalor at Russia's heart: "I was Russian enough to feel for these people, even to love them, but too foreign to tolerate their maddening fatalism and disorder. And they, who met me with open arms and shared with me their memories, they did not need me. . . . I was an exotic visitor from a distant land . . . and I came to represent a past they did not want to be reminded of, and a hostile world that was seeking to undermine their fragile security."
"Echoes of a Native Land" is that rare achievement: a Russian memoir that subverts the conventions of the genre and tells us, in clear, elegant and understated prose, that you can't go home again.

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT;
Southeast Asia Tourism Is Smothered by Smog

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS 

DATELINE: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia

 BODY:
WHEN athletes from around the region gathered in Jakarta, Indonesia, last month for the Southeast Asia Games, officials were unable to light the ceremonial torch. A huge magnifying glass was to have beamed a ray of sunlight into a giant bowl, but there was no sun.
Sunshine has been gloomily scarce throughout much of Southeast Asia for many weeks now as a pungent smog from vast Indonesian forest fires has blanketed a broad swath of the region. It is expected to continue at least into this month or December until monsoon rains, long delayed by El Nino, arrive to drench the fires. 
 People cough and wheeze. They stay home from work. On bad days, they wear surgical masks. Health officials say there could be a significant long-term toll in diseases like cancer and leukemia if the smog persists. Foreign residents have begun to worry. The American Embassy here has allowed dozens of employees to leave the country and several multinational companies have sent parts of their staffs home. And tourist arrivals have fallen in Singapore, Malaysia, Indonesia, Brunei, the Philippines and southern Thailand, where the popular resort island of Phuket has periodically been blanketed in what people here delicately call the "haze." The sun and the smog alternate depending on wind patterns, but tour organizers in Europe and the United States have reduced their business throughout the region, officials here say. "If you look at tourism, it's a major factor," Malaysia's Deputy Prime Minister, Anwar Ibrahim, said recently as he enumerated the ill effects of the smog.
It is a severe economic blow to the region's $26-billion-a-year tourism industry, one of the region's fastest-growing industries. And it is particularly painful coming as it has during a sharp economic downturn that has slowed several regional economies.
That downturn, paradoxically, has made tourism more attractive. Currencies in Thailand, Malaysia, Indonesia and the Philippines have tumbled by 20 to 30 percent or more and the dollar now stretches much further. The full force of the slump still lies ahead, following attacks that began in the spring on regional currencies.
A surge in tourism was to have been one of the few silver linings to the economic slump, but officials in Thailand say they have not yet noticed a hoped-for increase in arrivals. They blame the bad publicity resulting from the smog. Several governments in Europe and Asia, as well as the United States, have issued travel advisories warning their citizens against visiting smoggy areas, particularly Malaysia, Singapore and Indonesia. Some tour operators have begun to offer full refunds to people who have booked trips to these nations.
Airports in hard-hit areas like Borneo and Sumatra have been forced to close periodically, and hundreds of flights have been canceled when conditions deteriorate. Notably, the smoke from Indonesia's fires has mainly been drifting northward, so the main island of Java has been less affected. The tourist destinations of Bali and Lombok have mostly escaped the smog.
But some resorts to the north have suffered badly. On the Malaysian island of Langkawi, tourism officials say hotel occupancy has dropped to 10 percent, from a more typical 75 percent. They say economic losses run into the millions of dollars as Japanese and Taiwanese tourists as well as European visitors have canceled their visits. Particularly hard-hit has been Singapore, a hub for travel in the region, where tourism generates $7.2 billion a year. Pollution levels there have reached historic highs, and Yeo Cheow Tong, the environment and health minister, said people had been changing their routines to avoid the unhealthy air.
"There has definitely been an impact on the economy," he said. "People are going out less, restaurants have been reporting lower business levels, hotels have been reporting cancellations."
Four doctors surveyed by the Sunday Times newspaper in Singapore said the number of their patients with respiratory problems had increased by 20 percent during the haze. "People are experiencing watery eyes, more nasal discharge and throat problems," said Dr. Chan Tiong Beng, president of the Asthmatics Association.
In mid-October, the Health Ministry issued an alert saying: "The elderly and persons with heart or respiratory diseases should reduce physical exertion and outdoor activities. The general population should reduce vigorous outdoor activities."
Even in the sealed skyscrapers of Singapore's modern business district, people are coughing, blowing their noses and complaining of headaches. One evening in September the smog was so thick that the faint odor of wood smoke from the smog permeated the air-conditioned Victoria concert hall during a performance of Benjamin Britten's opera "A Midsummer Night's Dream."
Wildlife is also being affected, from the wild jungles of Borneo to the tidy parks of Singapore. In Borneo, tigers, elephants and great apes are fleeing the fires and flying foxes have emerged in a desperate search for shelter. In Singapore, the birds have stopped singing. Bird owners, who traditionally gather outdoors with their cages, complain that their birds have grown listless. They now stay home.

LENGTH: 1892 words

HEADLINE: THEATER;
Back on That Infuriating But Irresistible Broadway

BYLINE: By SYLVIANE GOLD 

 BODY:
EMANUEL AZENBERG, universally known as Manny, has a habit. Even though he suspects that at 63 he ought to know better, he keeps producing Broadway plays.
He thought he had the habit licked two years ago, when, with great fanfare, he took Neil Simon's "London Suite" Off Broadway, abandoning the arena where he had worked as a producer for some 30 years and won seven Tony Awards. But this season, after decrying a system that seems to defeat everything but runaway hit musicals, he is back in the expensive seats, surprising himself and everyone else not once but twice. 
 Two weeks ago, he opened "Side Show," an offbeat musical based on the lives of the Hilton sisters, the Siamese twins who had a vaudeville career. And on Thursday, he opens Neil Simon's newest play, "Proposals," at the Broadhurst Theater.
Mr. Azenberg, who has been producing Mr. Simon's plays since 1972, is something of a dinosaur, and feels like one. There are now only a few of his generation of old-fashioned, individual producers in the increasingly combine-driven theater industry -- producers like Robert Whitehead, who have the experience to help shape properties long before they reach the stage.
"I had planned on fading out," Mr. Azenberg said in his photo-filled aerie above the Neil Simon Theater, on West 52d Street, a few days before the "Side Show" opening. "An old soldier, fading away. Then these two shows happened." He makes it sound as if it were involuntary. "What else can I do?" he shrugs, his inflection redolent of his Bronx roots and Yiddish-speaking family. "It's too late to become a doctor."
In an office crowded with reminders of his past, it is no wonder he is feeling his age. There are photos of his parents. There are shots of him with Israeli notables, the legacy of a lifelong involvement with Zionism learned literally at his father's knee. (He remembers being pulled out of school in 1948 to meet Chaim Weizmann when he came to New York as the first president of the new Israeli state.) There are pictures of theater friends like Mike Nichols and Athol Fugard and Tom Stoppard, and political friends like Bill Bradley and Alan Simpson; and most telling of all, right in his line of sight, is a portrait of a young, young Manny Azenberg, in the uniform of the United States Army.
Still, the fading-away talk seems a bit improbable, coming from this imposing white-haired figure in bleached jeans and dusty-pink sweatshirt. He looks as if he could still play a mean shortstop in the Broadway softball league, which is where he first met Mr. Simon. But he is in an autumnal frame of mind, mulling over the passage of time and his own mortality, as well as that of the theater world he has been part of since the 1950's. He talks about how the students he has been teaching at Duke University keep getting younger and how his five children, who range in age from 7 to 37, keep getting older.
"When you're 23, in 20 years, you're going to be 43," he said. "That's a trillion years away. But when you're 63, in 20 years, you may not be. You get very selective about where you spend your time."
The fact that he has spent time producing "Side Show" and "Proposals" does not mean he has changed his mind about the business climate of Broadway. "The economics aren't any better than they were when we decided not to do it," he acknowledged. "In fact, they're worse. We outpriced ourselves. The victims are the culprits. No one planned for the future; we thought it would go on forever. And the 'we' is all-inclusive. I didn't know any better."
Of course, there are those who say that Mr. Azenberg knows the ins and outs of financing shows very well indeed. "Better than anyone," says Mr. Simon, who adds that this reputation is the reason the producers of the musical "Rent" hired Mr. Azenberg to manage that show when they took it to Broadway.
Bernard Gersten, the executive producer of Lincoln Center Theater, has another reason for having Mr. Azenberg manage his commercial transfers. "He's a tummler," Mr. Gersten said, using the Yiddish word for a live wire. "He plays. And if you don't play in the theater, you might as well go work somewhere else."
Nevertheless, what Mr. Azenberg calls "the boring stuff" -- how much it will cost for an extra stagehand or an extra line in the daily ad -- is one reason he has a winning record in the notoriously risky world of Broadway investing. He reckons it at "about 60 percent," and can go through a list of his more than 40 shows -- starting in 1966 with "The Lion in Winter" and "Mark Twain Tonight!" -- and tell you which returned a profit and how close the others came.
The losers (like the 1993 musical version of Mr. Simon's play "The Goodbye Girl" and his 1981 "Fools") hurt more than Mr. Azenberg's pride. He always invests in his own shows: "How do you go to somebody and ask them for money if you don't put your own in?"
So once again, he is putting both capital and pride on the line for an enterprise he now finds dubious. But his relationship with Broadway has always been a contentious one. In fact, it began with a row. As a young Off Broadway company manager, he wanted to work on Broadway but was barred by union work rules. Angered by his interview with the union's officials, he overturned the table they were sitting at and stormed out.
He has subsequently feuded with Roger L. Stevens over management of the Kennedy Center in the 1970's; with the Tony nominating committee in 1983, when it failed to nominate Mr. Simon's "Brighton Beach Memoirs" as best play; with a Dallas newspaper over the perceived unfairness of its theater critic; with the League of American Theaters and Producers over financial and policy issues. And given the fuss he made in 1994 over leaving Broadway, the question of why he is back practically poses itself.
To answer it, Mr. Azenberg goes into his fading dinosaur routine: "We want it. We want to have that old experience that we had in the heyday. Can you go home again? I hope so. At least for a minute."
Mr. Simon's "Proposals" was inspired by his courtship of his first wife during the summer of 1953. Set in the backyard of a summer cottage in the Poconos, it mixes the familiar Simon humor with darker intimations of mortality. "It's different from everything Neil's ever done," Mr. Azenberg said. "And it moves me. I think that's an old requirement."
"Side Show," he said, fills the requirement as well. "To say that we did a musical about Siamese twins is just untrue. It's about 'Who Will Love Me as I Am,' " said Mr. Azenberg, quoting the show's climactic song. "It's about how we're all freaks. At 3, 4 o'clock in the morning, the hour of the wolf, when all that posturing you do during the day is over, and you're lying in bed with your doubts, misgivings, failures, you ask yourself, 'Who could love me? Does this person next to me really know? And even if I told her, would she know?' "
"When you do Neil Simon," Mr. Azenberg said, "he has an audience, you get an advance, you have a cushion. When you do something out of the ordinary, you have to sit and worry. And you don't get a lot of compassion."
"Side Show" has received some positive reviews, but an equal number have been mixed or negative, and initial sales of tickets have been slow. Mr. Azenberg has taken chances with risky material before, doing plays about euthanasia ("Whose Life Is It, Anyway?"), cannibalism ("Devour the Snow") and the education of the deaf ("Children of a Lesser God"). And he has produced serious foreign plays like " 'Master Harold' . . . and the Boys" by Athol Fugard, "The Real Thing" by Tom Stoppard and "Molly Sweeney" by Brian Friel.
"I had a luxury," he explained. "And the luxury was Neil Simon." But even Mr. Simon's much-envied ability to print box-office money has faltered in recent years, with such critical and commercial disappointments as the musical "Goodbye Girl" and "London Suite."
"Proposals" is Mr. Simon's 30th Broadway production. He has been writing, rewriting and reworking it for about eight years. "I rewrite more than I write," he said, and it has now gone through more than 20 drafts.
The fulcrum of the play is the family maid, Clemma, played by L. Scott Caldwell. She presides over an afternoon of crises and reconciliations as the daughter of the house decides which of her beaus to marry and her ailing father helps her come to terms with the mother who walked out on them both.
Clemma is the first black character created by Mr. Simon, but he said that he had no problem getting inside the head of a black woman: "I soon found I was in love with her. So I didn't worry."
Like Mr. Azenberg, Mr. Simon has qualms about returning to Broadway. "It's not the Broadway I grew up in," Mr. Simon said. "Broadway is now the place where you go to see musicals." But his much-ballyhooed Off Broadway experiment with "London Suite" did not provide a viable alternative. Looking back on it, he said, he now believes that "neither Manny nor I thought that 'London Suite' was really good enough yet for Broadway." Nevertheless, when it was well-received at the Seattle Rep, they decided to proceed to New York.
"But there was still some doubt," Mr. Simon added, "so we said, 'Why pay a million and a half when we can do it for so much less Off Broadway?' "
Working with Mr. Simon and Mr. Azenberg for the first time is Joe Mantello, the director of Terrence McNally's "Love! Valour! Compassion!" He compares Mr. Azenberg to "a good parent" who "lets you make your mistakes and find your way."
THAT'S WHAT Mr. Azenberg aims for, once a production is under way. "There's the cast, the director and the playwright," Mr. Azenberg said. "And then, peripherally, there's this producer guy. I don't believe that producers are part of the creative group. I think you make a contribution. But in an ideal situation, they all work it out themselves."
And, in an ideal situation, the shows run. "They don't have to be big hits," he said. "But I want them to run. Partly for the sake of all the people connected with them, and partly for my own. It will justify my taste, my choice of material. And it will say I'm not outdated -- or any of those other confusing things that happen when you're 63." He wants Broadway to love him as he is.
 
Sayings of Manny
When you're young and you love the theater, you go for acting. But after I got out of the Army, I was older. The idea of walking around with my picture -- it had no dignity.
If you could win the Congressional Medal of Honor for doing "Hamlet" well, perhaps the theater would come back.
Actors used to list Broadway first on their resumes. Now it's film first.
After "Proposals" opens, we'll be one of the very few plays running on Broadway this fall. When we first started, you had to wait in line to get a theater. My first play, "The Lion in Winter," in 1966 had to wait three months.
The wonderful thing about the theater is the writer. Who writes a movie? Who wrote "Gone With the Wind"? The theater is the writer's place.
Once or twice I traded off my brain -- my soul -- and produced shows for what I thought would be money. But it didn't work out. Ever.
When I was growing up, your father said, "Sit and read." Dickens. Thackeray. You read it. Today, the kids sit home and play with computers and watch television.

HEADLINE: Westchester Q&A: Jeffrey C. Gershen;
Working to Make Housing Affordable

BYLINE: By DONNA GREENE

 BODY:
IT was a campaign issue in the race for county executive in 1976 and to some extent it has been one again this year. But the question of what to do to encourage the construction of affordable housing in Westchester comes down to some basic factors, says a man who builds such housing elsewhere: land costs must come down or allowable density must be increased.
Jeffrey C. Gershen of Katonah, president of Griffon Associates, has been in charge of various new and rehabilitated residential projects in New York, Connecticut and New Jersey. What he is saying may be obvious, he admits, but achieving change is difficult. 
 Situated in Elmsford, Griffon Associates, in concert with Wilder Balter Partners, a residential real estate development company, is building a 92-unit low-income community in Goshen in Dutchess County, on the site of an old infirmary. Previously, the group built a community in Middletown on what was an abandoned brewery. Mr. Gershen has been successful in obtaining various government subsidies to help keep costs down.
Here are excerpts from a recent conversation with Mr. Gershen:
Q. What are the obstacles and solutions for creating affordable housing in Westchester?
A. Nine times out of 10 the largest obstacle is money, and that is a function of the sources of funding for affordable housing. Affordable housing for the most part is rental housing, and conventional mortgaging of property is based on a rent stream.
To make housing affordable, the rent has to be low and the amount of mortgage has to be low. Therefore, other money has to be available to, in effect, subsidize that mortgage. The only money available currently to do that is the proceeds that come from the syndication of low-income-housing tax credits, which is a program that originates with the Federal Government and is delegated to the state in the form of tax credits.
In addition, there are what we call "soft second mortgages," which are usually either grants of some sort from a state housing agency, such as the New York State Division of Housing and Community Renewal, or the Housing Trust Fund Corporation. That's on the rental side.
On the home ownership side, you have state organizations such as the New York State Affordable Housing Corporation, which essentially gives mortgage subsidies that can drive the cost of housing down.
Q. Are you saying private enterprise cannot do this by itself?
A. Absolutely. It needs government help and it needs government encouragement, and the way the government can help obviously is to make more money available for the programs it has.
The other way of dealing with it is at the local level. Part of the problem in Westchester County is that the value of land is so extraordinarily high, and in order to translate high land value into less expensive housing, you would have to have a situation in which -- and this may be politically charged -- special zoning was created so that you can have higher density of units for a particular parcel of land.
Q. Most of your building is not in Westchester. Have you tried to get more involved in Westchester?
A. We have built in Westchester, at least Griffon has built for a client in Westchester, Bill Balter, who is also a Westchester resident. On one project, Stone Creek in New Castle, which is town houses, the vehicle to create a more affordable complex was the New York State Affordable Housing Corporation. Also -- remember my phrase "soft second money" -- we had a grant from the Westchester Housing Implementation Fund. This is essentially a pool of noninterest-bearing funds that can be used to finance infrastructure. And so that created an environment that despite high land costs and low density, the project was made more affordable.
Q. So the Housing Implementation Fund, created in the 1980's by the Board of Legislators, has had some impact?
A. Yes, it has. We have, in fact, accessed it twice. We also accessed it for a project in Cortlandt Manor, called Cross Creek at Van Cortlandtville. There again it was used essentially to finance the infrastructure -- roads, sewers, utility lines. But there is a downside to taking this Housing Implementation Fund money. The downside is Davis Bacon -- a Federal law with wage guidelines -- and therefore essentially Davis Bacon does drive the costs up.
Q. Discuss the brewery property you developed in Middletown.
A. It was an abandoned four-story beer brewery, Orange County Beer, that ended beer production probably in the 30's. Then it had a number of uses and it was eventually abandoned as a building. I can't say what went on inside it, but I'm sure it was used by the local night life. While it was structurally a very, very sound building, it had become an eyesore and something that was detracting from the neighborhood.
My partner, Bob Wilder, came up with the scheme along with a nonprofit organization from Orange County, called Orange County Rural Development Advisory Corporation, to develop it as an affordable income rental project. We redesigned the building and in concert with O.R.D.A.C. got tax credits and Housing Trust Fund Corporation grants and eventually a conventional mortgage. We developed apartments, all of which have lofts and four-foot palladium windows, and restored the building to what it looked like in the past.
Q. What you are doing at the Hearthstone in Goshen?
A. It is an even more challenging project than the Brewery was. Hearthstone is a development that includes five buildings on the grounds of the Orange County Infirmary, just outside the town of Goshen. The first of these five buildings was built in 1830, and the last was built in 1937. The previous use had been as a poorhouse and a home for the insane; more recently, one small building was used as a day-care center while the rest of it was kind of allowed to fall into various states of decay. We had to design all the insides of these buildings to create 89 senior citizen apartments on the grounds of the infirmary. .
Q. And did you obtain government subsidies?
A. Oh, yes. You have to understand that affordable rental projects must be supported in some way by low-interest or no-interest financing. We created a package of financing that is comprised of low-income- housing tax credits, grants and a conventional mortgage.
Q. What are the implications in Westchester?
A. That's a very politically charged question. If the goal is to create affordable housing in Westchester to keep young people from moving out and to support people who have lived all their lives in Westchester -- the middle-income working class -- the first thing you have to do is not be afraid of affordable housing.
Q. Do you think people are afraid of affordable housing?
A. Yes. There is a very strong fear in this county and in almost every community that affordable housing will detract from the community.
Q. Is this racially charged?
A. I would rather not say that. But affordable housing means bringing in people who may or may not share the same social values as the existing community -- social and economic. When most people see any housing that in some way has a public funding component to it, it triggers alarm; it triggers fear. My experience over the last eight years is that the fears are totally groundless.
The question is: how does the county executive convince local authorities and municipal town boards to pass zoning laws that allow for the kind of density -- not townwide obviously -- that would bring the high land values in line with the per-unit cost necessary to develop?
Affordable housing does not necessarily mean you cannot have a bucolic existence. Every town has to look at what its needs are. They may not be losing population, but the population is getting older. And as the population gets older you're going to have more and more battles over school taxes, which are the largest part of property taxes. So in a way affordable housing is a way to regenerate your community.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Jeffrey C. Gershen, head of Griffon Associates, at a housing construction site in Goshen. (Susan Harris for The New York Times)
