HEADLINE: In the Region/Connecticut;
How Shelton Won a Role in Fairfield's Office Market

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES 

DATELINE: SHELTON

 BODY:
IN 1975 Shelton's largest employer, the sponge-rubber plant that B.F. Goodrich had leased out a year earlier, was firebombed and destroyed in an insurance-fraud scheme, marking the end of the city's smokestack economy and its dependence on a single industry. The fire put 4,500 people out of work.
Today, R. D. Scinto, developer of 2 million square feet of offices in Shelton, Trumbull, Fairfield, Bridgeport and Wilton -- half of it in Shelton -- worth a total of some $200 million is Shelton's largest taxpayer and the foremost example of its transformation into a competitor in the Fairfield County office market. 
 Through the 80's Shelton worked hard to woo and win several corporations that wanted to move to Fairfield County but were disenchanted with the high costs on its Gold Coast. Among them were Tetley Tea, ITT, Chesebrough-Pond and Sikorsky Aircraft, which found Shelton's lower costs a fair trade-off for its relatively remote location.
Robert D. Scinto, president of the R.D. Scinto real estate firm, began constructing small office buildings in 1978, and between 1982 and 1989 his company erected 27 significant commercial buildings, including the Enterprise Park in Shelton, where his headquarters is situated.
His choice of eastern Connecticut as his market was based on three considerations: vacant inexpensive land, housing that employees could afford and zoning. "I never wanted to build in lower Fairfield County," said Mr. Scinto. "Too much zoning, too much risk. Shelton has a progressive zoning commission that recognizes the value of tax revenues for its citizens. They allow 10-story buildings and you get approvals right away."
This year he has more than 540,000 square feet of office projects in Shelton and Trumbull under construction or approved for construction.
After a hiatus of 9 years when he built nothing, his 28th building, of 128,032 square feet, was completed on his 70-acre Enterprise Park tract last month, fully leased to Cartier, Rhone-Poulenc Basic Chemicals, TranSwitch Corporation, Country Home Bakers and RMS, a computer company.
In Trumbull, a 42,000-square-foot Scinto office building is going up on Quarry Road, and there are 11 acres of Scinto-owned Trumbull land capable of accommodating 300,000 square feet of construction. Two 112,000-square-foot buildings earmarked for his corporate park in Shelton are on his drawing board, literally.
"I design the buildings myself," he said, "but I use an architect to draw up and file the plans." He will not build without substantial tenant commitments. Based on pending contracts he expects to start construction on the Shelton projects in 1998 and '99.
"What's so unusual about him," said Richard F. Gretsch, Jr., a Stamford realtor who handles all Scinto leases, "is that he does it all himself. Most developers have multiple partners."
"I wish he would not go ahead with all this construction," he added. "I've told him that he can raise rents and make more money on his existing buildings than he will with new buildings. But if he doesn't build he's not happy." Rents range from $16 to $22 a square foot including heat and cleaning, but excluding the tenant's own electric bill.
In 1984, the Route 8 Expressway, the first major north-south artery in the state, opened to connect Bridgeport to the Massachusetts border. It runs through Shelton and opened the city to the Merritt and Wilbur Cross Parkways, and Interstates 95 and 84, creating an additional inducement for commercial development.
The expressway's free-flowing traffic is still an attraction for companies wanting the cachet of a Fairfield County address without the daily gridlock on the Merritt and I-95 from Westport to Greenwich.
OTHER developers headed for the Shelton region include the Davis Companies of Boston, which has filed for site plan approval for a 385,000-square-foot complex of two to three office buildings on 12 acres in Shelton. It has also acquired a five-acre site for office development in Wilton.
"We intend to start construction in Shelton next spring with or without a tenant," said Paul Marcus, president of the company. "Boston is probably nine months ahead of Fairfield in building where people live, where costs are lower and space is flexible. Nothing is under construction in downtown Boston. Fidelity Investments and other companies got out of the city into suburbs like Marlborough, very similar to Shelton. We're seeing the same thing happening in Dallas and Los Angeles."
"In Stamford," he continued, "it might take two to three years to build. In Shelton it will be less than 10 months because there's no interference from traffic and encroaching buildings."
A Trumbull partnership called ElDorado Holdings LLC, headed by Camilo Soto, has opened a 17-acre parcel called Cyber Park on Route 111 in Trumbull. Divided into four lots it can accommodate a total of 200,000 square feet in four to five buildings. The first building, a 34,000-square-foot structure, has been completed and occupied by its first tenants: PCNet, resellers of personal computer hardware and software; and ViewTek, a company focused on electronic commerce and data interchange.
Incentives offered by the town are getting the attention of builders like ElDorado. "We will give tax abatements of 100 percent for the first two years to businesses with over $5 million of new construction," said First Selectman David Wilson, "and a one-year abatement for $500,000 worth of additions or reconstruction of existing buildings. We abated personal property taxes for the past three years by knocking off 30, 20 and 10 percent over the first three years. Even with the abatements we're drawing three-quarters of a million dollars in additional revenues."
So far, real estate professionals in the area agree, Mr. Scinto has no peer among developers in Eastern Connecticut -- from his engagingly personal style evident in the "hi, Bob" greetings from all levels of tenants and employees, to the smorgasbord of tenant perquisites he provides, to his ability to ride out rough times.
Most prized by such tenants as American Scandia Insurance, Massachusetts Mutual, General Electric, and Prudential Relocation, is the day-care center for 110 children at the Corporate Towers. A partial list of amenities includes full-service dining room, deli, dry-cleaning service, shoeshine parlor, bank ATM, carwash, limousine, helicopter, travel and car rental services, teleconferencing, fitness center, jogging path, hair salon, volleyball and basketball courts, and an annual Labor Day picnic for 4,500 tenants, families and friends. To insure his tenants and employees immediate access to health and legal services he recruited a dentist, a medical service, and a lawyer as tenants.
Perched incongruously on a white Ionic pedestal in his office is a battered old hulk of a machine. It is in stark contrast to the fine art and furnishings, marble floors and Oriental rugs elsewhere in the office.
The machine is a plumber's buffer, which was used to polish and fit galvanized-iron pipes. "It reminds me of where I came from," said Mr. Scinto. "I started life as a plumber with my father. When I was a kid he used to give me a penny a fitting."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Robert D. Scinto in front of his Enterprise Park headquarters in Shelton, where his firm developed about a million square feet of office space. (Thomas McDonald for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Facing Intense Pressures, Hospitals Step Up Mergers

BYLINE: By JOHN RATHER 

 BODY:
THE merger of two premier teaching hospitals and the reorganization of four Roman Catholic hospitals is changing health care on Long Island and reflecting rapid shifts across the industry.
The merger, the largest for hospitals on Long Island, is uniting two competitors, North Shore Health System, whose flagship is North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, and the Long Island Jewish Medical Center of New Hyde Park and Queens. 
 Barring a last-minute legal problem, they are forming a 4,708-bed multihospital system that will be the largest of its category on the Eastern Seaboard.
The way was cleared when Judge Arthur D. Spatt of Federal District Court in Uniondale ruled against a Justice Department move to block the merger as anticompetitive and a violation of antitrust laws.
The reorganization of the Catholic hospitals, which Bishop John R. McGann of the Rockville Centre Diocese ordered last month, reinforces a church mission to care for the poor who are sick, regardless of ability to pay. The move was also a response to economic pressures, including falling Medicaid and Medicare reimbursements and lower rates negotiated between hospitals and health maintenance organizations.
Those pressures also prompted the merger of Long Island Jewish and North Shore, which are facing a combined estimated loss in Medicaid and Medicare payments of $175 million over the next five years.
The pressures are also leading to affiliations among other hospitals, as stand-alone institutions are rapidly facing what may be untenable economics and, even, obsolescence, experts said. Nassau has 14 acute-care hospitals and Suffolk has 13.
The state deregulatedhospital rates on Jan. 1, opening the way for major changes, sharply increasing the influence of H.M.O.'s and emptying hospital beds in a state previously known for regulations that had encouraged hospital stays. Regional hospitals are reporting record numbers of empty beds, and some hospitals are advertising to fill them.
Bishop McGann said 85 percent of Catholic hospitals nationally had joined health-care systems, adding, "We are restructuring as a means to embrace these changes while preserving the soul of Catholic health care."
The hospitals here are Good Samaritan Medical Center in West Islip, Mercy Medical Center in Rockville Centre, St. Charles Hospital and Rehabilitation Center in Port Jefferson and St. Francis Hospital -- the Heart Center, in Roslyn. They have a total of nearly 1,300 beds and nearly 8,000 employees.
The reorganization dissolves the boards at the four hospitals, a step that shocked some members. None of the hospitals were apparently in financial difficulty, and although they were affiliated they operated independently.
The job of one top administrator, Dr. Robert F. Vizza, president of the St. Francis-Mercy Corporation, which helped manage those two hospitals, will be eliminated. A spokeswoman for St. Francis, Lucille P. Kissane, said the hospital would have no statement on the reorganization.
Bishop McGann complimented the boards and managers for placing the diocese "in a strategic position to create a unified Catholic Health Services system." But he said in a statement, "The larger issues evolving in health care and the mission of the church go far beyond the efforts of these individual boards."
The hospitals will be under a single board headed by Bishop McGann for a 30-day transition period.
The bishop's secretary for health affairs, Msgr. Alan J. Placa, said the church was concerned about "entrepreneurial economic pressures' causing hospitals around the country to make drastic decisions" that might harm the poor. The reorganization, Monsignor Placa added, "will strengthen our care for those who are disadvantaged."
Long Island Jewish and North Shore, where treatment is also given regardless of ability to pay, said charitable care would continue after the merger.
That merger is creating a new system that will have 6,500 affiliated physicians and 18,000 employees, will offer care ranging from primary to tertiary and will position the institutions to compete vigorously with hospitals in Manhattan and elsewhere.
More than 50,000 patients in Nassau, Suffolk and Queens traveled to Manhattan last year for tertiary treatment, one expert estimated. The new system will try to compete against what officials call the colonization of Long Island by city hospitals through advertising campaigns, the purchasing of medical groups and affiliations with local hospitals.
Tertiary care involves highly skilled medical treatment for heart disease, cancer and other serious illnesses.
Hospital officials said the merger, which will take months or even years to complete, would lower rates through efficiencies and cost cutting while improving care. "The patients are going to be the winners in this," the co-president of the new organization, John S. T. Gallagher of North Shore, said. "We will raise quality standards and spread them across the system."
"With what is happening with health care, for hospitals to be at the top of their game you are going to have to meld the best talents available," said Dr. David R. Dantzker of Long Island Jewish, the other co-president of the North Shore-Long Island Jewish Health System. "Now we are going to be able to become, as a system, among the best in the world."
The Justice Department filed its antitrust action in June, saying that the merger could create a monopoly, raise rates and lower the quality of care.
But Judge Spatt ruled that the Government had failed to prove that the merger would constrain competition. He said Winthrop-University Hospital in Mineola, the Nassau County Medical Center in East Meadow and hospitals in New York City were competitors for tertiary care and that more basic services would continue to be widely available from those and other hospitals and treatment centers.
He also ruled that there was "no credible evidence" that the merged hospitals would "not attempt to reduce costs."
"On the contrary," he wrote, "the court finds that the principal reasons for this merger are to continue and advance the high quality of treatment of the hospitals' patients, to seek advancement of medical technology, to foster the education and training of its physicians, to further pursue medical research at both hospitals and to avoid duplication, thereby reducing costs."
The judge also disagreed with testimony by a Government witness that the merger would result in a 20 percent price increase for primary and secondary services, raising costs for managed-care organizations $55 million or more a year. The hospitals have agreed to cap rates for two years and have said rates may fall.
The new organizations forecasts more than $2 billion a year in revenues.

(Photographs by Steve Berman for The New York Times); Bishop John R. McGann of the Rockville Centre Diocese has ordered 4 Roman Catholic hospitals to merge. (Rebecca Cooney for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
Reviving a Parsippany Town-House Project

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
FOR nearly eight years legal problems caused by the real estate recession have thwarted plans to transform into housing 48 acres at the intersection of Route 46 and North Beverwyck Road in Parsippany-Troy Hills. But now the site is being prepared for a $32 million town-house condominium community.
Roseland Property Company of Roseland took over the project last June, after resolving title and tax issues and modifying it with fewer, but larger, units to make the community more salable in today's market. 
 The project, called the Townhomes at Hunting Ridge and comprising 208 town-house units of 1,800 to 2,300 square feet, will be completed in three years in this eastern Morris County township. The original project, conceived by developers who defaulted on their loan, consisted of 274 units that were about half the size of the new ones.
To move its project along, Roseland agreed to the township's request to restore a more-than-century-old historic farmhouse on the site and retain it for use for both residents and the public. It also agreed to add extensive landscaping throughout the development, including a linear greenway along the site's southern border to mask it from the highway.
"The site, which over the last decade had become an eyesore, forms the crossroads into our community," said Parsippany's Mayor, Mimi Lettes. "So, visually we wanted it to make a positive impact and the changes made to the project were absolutely necessary to accomplish that."
The revamped project, she said, "will be an asset to the township," adding that though Parsippany "is not chasing ratables it will also generate new tax revenue."
Roseland is using its own equity and a $22.5 million construction loan from First Union Bank in Newark to develop Hunting Ridge, an attached-housing community. It is one of the few new sizable condominium projects begun in recent years in Parsippany. In the mid-80's construction boom the county witnessed substantial retail and office growth within its 25 square miles.
As in other communities in the developed eastern portion of the county, there is a limited amount of attached housing in Parsippany because of a scarcity of properly zoned land for it. Though a handful of such projects are planned, most of the town houses now under construction constitute the final phases of existing projects begun or restarted several years ago, real estate brokers said.
A case in point is Longview, a 576-unit project in Montville that was stalled by the recession after 103 units were built. Pinnacle Communities and Garden Homes, both of Short Hills, took over the project three years ago and built and sold all but 46 of the 2- and 3-bedroom homes.
"There just are not a lot of town-house projects coming in right now," said Raymond K. Chang, principal planner for the Morris County Planning Department. "I would dare to say it is a countywide trend."
OF the 1,001 housing permits issued so far this year in Morris County the majority were for one-family detached homes, Mr. Chang said. He added that home building was moving westward in the county, where large tracts of land are available and costs are lower.
The focus on attached housing, he said, is assisted-living or continuing-care retirement communities that offer housing, services and health care for the elderly. As an example he pointed to the 1,400-unit continuing-care complex that Senior Campus Living, of Baltimore, plans to build in Pequannock.
The limited supply of new town houses, brokers said, has kept the selling pace steady. That, coupled with an improving housing market in Morris County, as in the rest of suburban New Jersey, has nudged up prices. Michael H. Campbell, president of the North Central Jersey Association of Realtors, said that sale prices for all types of houses throughout the county have risen over the last year by 5 to 6 percent.
Factors in the improving market are increased demand, increased consumer confidence in the economy and the winding down of corporate consolidations and mergers, said Marvin J. Crane, who is a broker at the Mountain Lakes office of Coldwell Banker and the sales manager for Hunting Ridge.
Another stimulant for new housing production is the fact that Morris County, which has about 6.8 percent of New Jersey's 3.5 million jobs, is considered among the state's fastest growing counties. Its population is expected to rise to 465,500 in 2005 from 438,471 in 1994 and its job base to expand to 274,200 from 240,800, according to state figures.
Those market conditions were part of Roseland's decision to move ahead with Hunting Ridge, said Carl J. Goldberg, a Roseland partner, adding "the demand outstrips the supply." Other factors, he continued, were existing approvals for the site, its gently sloping terrain and location.
The site is near shopping, a park-and-ride lot with bus service to Manhattan and one mile west of the intersection of Route 46 and Interstates 80 and 287. In addition, the state is completing the widening of the intersection of Route 46 and North Beverwyck Road in front of the site, which was a community concern in the first project.
Roseland, which specializes in taking over distressed properties, acquired the site for what Mr. Goldberg called "a reasonable price" from the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. The F.D.I. C inherited the site three years earlier when its seized the assets of the Howard Savings Bank, whose development arm had been a joint venture partner in the original project with the first developer.
The partners had secured approvals to build 274 town houses on the site just as the recession hit. That in turn pushed the partners to default on their $16 million loan and after the bank failed, the project was thrown into a legal limbo.
Roseland spent the last seven months working through the legal impediments attached to the site, which ranged from clearing up tax liens and title issues to paying the township some $700,000 in unpaid real estate property taxes, said Mr. Goldberg. The company did so, he explained, because buying such properties, the supply of which is fast dwindling, "is real fertile ground for well-capitalized developers."
Mr. Goldberg said the new community, which will have a pool and other recreational amenities, will consist of 30 two-story residential buildings, each with three to nine units. The buildings, designed in traditional style by the Martin Organization of Philadelphia, will be laid out to follow the natural contours of the site and clustered in groups to resemble large single-family homes.
The 2- to 3-bedroom units, each with a one-car garage, are expected to range from $195,000 to $250,000, with monthly maintenance charges of about $150. New town-house units within a 10-mile radius of the site are selling for $175,000 to $395,000, said Mr. Crane, the broker. The average price for a new one-family detached home in the county is about $350,000.
Mr. Crane said, and Mr. Goldberg agreed, that the project is expected to attract first-time buyers and empty-nesters because of its pricing and its easy access to major highways and mass transportation.
Mr. Goldberg said work was under way to restore the 19th-century farmhouse on the property, which is listed on the National Register of Historic Places and was once owned by the Condit family, one of the county's prominent landowners. Stephen Condit, the last family member, died in 1984, freeing the site for development and leaving the fate of the house uncertain.
Roseland is investing $500,000 to preserve the Victorian-style structure, where the two ground-level rooms will house documents pertaining to Parsippany's history for view by the public. The upper floor will be for use of the Hunting Ridge Homeowners Association, which will own the building.

HEADLINE: Hanging On to Hartford's Past

BYLINE: By JACK CAVANAUGH

 BODY:
WITH the Old State House, the State Capitol and the former homes of Mark Twain and Harriet Beecher Stowe, among other, Hartford has more than its share of historical structures. But it also has close to 1,000 vacant and abandoned buildings that are a blight on many of the city's neighborhoods.
Starting this week, Hartford will begin to demolish about 85 of those buildings, some of which were put up in the latter part of the 19th century. But unlike the case in Stamford, where room was made over the last two decades for corporate office complexes that radically altered the city's downtown and even some residential areas, Hartford seems determined to preserve structures with historical significance and architectural merit. 
 Aware that the city was on the verge of tearing down scores of vacant buildings, most of them apartment houses, a group of about 25 people formed the Hartford Preservation Alliance. "There's a critical need for an organization like ours to be able to examine any list of buildings scheduled for demolition to see whether they have any historical or architectural significance and, if they do, whether they can be rehabilitated and re-used," said Lee Kuckro, a lawyer from Wethersfield who works in Hartford. "We don't want to end up with a plastic city that has been denatured and leaves us with no sense of place."
Mr. Kuckro, who is general counsel for Advest Group Inc., was a founder of the preservation alliance as was Gregory Secord of Marlborough, an executive with a real estate company in Wethersfield. Both men belonged to the now-defunct Greater Hartford Architecture Conservancy, a nonprofit group formed after urban renewal and a highway construction project near the Connecticut River resulted in the demolition of hundreds of buildings.
"The Conservancy was formed in the early 1970's in reaction to the demolition of some old and historic buildings along Front Street so that Interstate 91 and Constitution Plaza could be built," Mr. Kuckro said.
John W. Shannahan, the director of the State Historical Commission, added, "Front Street was a vibrant Italian American neighborhood. But at the time, the demolition of those buildings was viewed as progress."
Mr. Kuckro conceded that it was necessary to demolish many of the vacant and abandoned buildings with the decline in the city's population -- from a high of 177,397 in 1950 to 124,096 in 1994, the last year a census estimate was made. But he said it was imperative that an outside organization, like the Hartford Preservation Alliance, work with city and state officials to insure that not all of Hartford's historic physical presence be lost.
"We have to determine whether, in many cases, there are alternatives to demolition," he said. "Look at what's happening in Providence and what they've done with some old neighborhoods. Maybe Hartford can do something, too." Mr. Kuckro was referring to an acclaimed restoration effort in Providence that has resulted in the rehabilitation of hundreds of old buildings and the ensuing rejuvenation of some of the city's neighborhoods.
Linda Bayer, the assistant city manager in Hartford, said the impending demolition project was in response to the wishes of neighborhood residents. "We went into the communities and asked the people what their priorities were," Ms. Bayer said, "and the first priority was demolition of the vacant buildings."
She added that, "People in the communities told us that the physical appearance of the buildings was blighting, and that the buildings were dangerous and that there was drug trafficking in some of them. They also feel that tearing down the vacant buildings will reduce density and create more open space for children to play in and where 'pocket' parks can be built."
The demolition will be financed by a $7 million grant from the state, which is to cover mothballing chosen buildings for possible reuse. Mr. Shannahan said some Federal tax credits were available to restore old buildings, provided they are listed in the Historic Register. For example, Federal investment tax credits of up to 20 percent are allowed for the rehabilitation of income-producing buildings. And the state legislature is expected, during its next session, to consider a bill that would provide income tax credits to property owners who rehabilitate owner-occupied residences.
"We need more carrots like this if we're going to save some of these old buildings," he said. "I think we've learned some hard lessons in the past. But the idea of just saving buildings because they have historic significance or archictural merit alone is not going to fly these days. If you're not going to tear it down, you have to be able to put the buildings to a productive use."

HEADLINE: Store Owner Faults Music for Decline

BYLINE: By THOMAS STAUDTER

DATELINE: OSSINING

 BODY:
ANOTHER Saturday afternoon and Herb Smith, the proprietor of Arcadian Music and Books, was waiting for his next customer. Occasionally, he looked up from a magazine as cars and other vehicles positioned in and out of the parking spaces across from his small storefront here in the Arcadian Shopping Center on Route 9, though everyone seemed to be heading toward the neighboring supermarket and home-decorating store.
After a while, a young man walked in and politely asked for a book of matches and Mr. Smith, his reverie broken, found one in a box behind the counter. 
 "Business was steady this morning, but after lunch it died," he said after the man had left the store. "Now, I'm already thinking about my first martini."
Despite surviving a decade of broad competition from chain stores and giant retailers, it has been the prolonged slump in the music industry that has most hurt Mr. Smith's business and other small music retailers. It is hard times for the local record shop, just as it has been for many businesses that have resided on Main Street in America.
"Around three years ago my sales dropped off and things got dire," Mr. Smith said. "I thought it was related to the economy and that a lot of people were cutting back on music purchases so they could afford the necessities. "But the other half of the story is that there haven't been too many big hits or new trends for customers to get excited about either."
When his store is not doing well, it is frightening, the 60-year-old lifelong resident of Ossining said. "Each month it's a challenge just to pay the overhead and stay afloat. There's not much for Herbie after everyone gets theirs."
Last April, two officials from the State Department of Taxation and Finance, accompanied by a locksmith and a police officer, closed down Arcadian Music and Books because Mr. Smith's sales-tax payments were in arrears. Before being closed, he had negotiated a schedule of repayments to the state, but feeble earnings forced him to disregard them.
Closed for three weeks, the store reopened when one of Mr. Smith's friends lent him enough money to clear his tax bill. Several family members also helped support the store to keep it open.
"The state even billed me for having the locks changed," he said in exasperation.
Robert Caruso, owner of Tunemaster Records and Tapes in Valhalla, which he started in 1978, said, "It's a marginal business at best right now and certainly no way to get rich." Recently, he suggested that the introduction of the compact disk in the 1980's may have actually slowed the momentum of rising sales in the music industry.
"Music lovers, especially younger folks, are discouraged from increasing their collections because of the price of compact disks, which are significantly higher than records and tapes," he said, observing that CD's, even on sale, cost $12 to $15.
Independent music retailers typically combat their bigger competitors by specializing in hard-to-find products like vintage records or confining their stock to certain musical genres. The Alternative, a tiny record store in Ossining, for instance, caters solely to aficionados of heavy metal and punk music.
Also, the owners of smaller music stores are increasingly looking at every new wrinkle in retailing to help sales. Mr. Caruso, whose store contains several thousand records from the 1960's and 70's, now markets his rare treasures through a Web site. And many stores now feature listening stations -- stereo equipment set up with headphones -- so customers can preview music before buying it.
For the most part, though, it is the personal attention afforded individual customers who reciprocate with loyalty that keeps smaller music stores open. "I'd say that 80 percent of the people who walk through here I know by name," said Jeff Loh, referring to his Port Chester store, Vinyl Solution, now in its 10th year.
At Arcadian Music and Books, Mr. Smith helped a customer find a recording of Sammy Davis Jr.'s "Candy Man" in a catalogue and wrote out the order for a cassette. "The guy who'll search far and wide for something special -- that's me," he said.
Although many patrons can recall the heyday of Mr. Smith's store in the 70's and 80's, when people stood shoulder to shoulder in front of the rows of record bins, very few could know that he first began selling records in Ossining while a senior in high school in 1953.
"I first worked at Abelon's, a stationery store in town that also sold records," Mr. Smith said. "The owner, Morris Hirsch, hired me and even kept the job for me when I entered the Army after high school. When I was home on leave he'd advertise in the paper that Herbie was back in town selling records."
He worked at Abelon's for 13 years, until it closed. In 1970, after several years at another music store in Briarcliff, Mr. Smith was asked to manage the Music Plus One store in the newly opened Arcadian Shopping Center. A new owner rechristened the store Book & Record four years later, and Mr. Smith remained and has been there ever since, orchestrating the proceedings, as always from his stool behind the counter. In 1984 he bought the store and renamed it.
The narrow, 900-square-foot establishment seems almost frozen in time. Even though Mr. Smith carries a fair selection of new CD's, a majority of the store's stock dates from past decades. The books on the shelves -- always a sideline -- will either defy recognition or evoke nostalgia. To keep the place lively and interesting, Mr. Smith has taken on consignment clothing, jewelry and various fashion-related accessories.
Just before he closed on a recent Saturday, an old customer showed up to say hello. Lisa Galli-Lise, who grew up in Ossining and now lives in New Jersey, was in town to organize her 20th high school reunion and was happy to find Herbie still in business. She gave him a big hug and said, smiling, "I still have every record I bought here."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Herb Smith, owner of Arcadian Music and Books in Ossining. A slump in music industry has hurt business. (Susan Harris for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Lodging in New York City;
Hotel Occupancy and Room Rates Are Up

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
BERNARD GOLDBERG stood in the lobby of the Roger Williams Hotel at Madison Avenue and 31st Street, waved his arms expansively and explained to a visitor, "You 're standing where the noodle shop used to be."
The noodle shop is long gone, as is the barber shop, the tavern and other commercial operations on the ground floor of the building. Also gone are some guest rooms on the second floor. They have been replaced by a 20-foot-high atrium with floor-to-ceiling glass facing both Madison Avenue and 31st Street. 
 Inside the lobby are touches typical of Mr. Goldberg's Gotham Hospitality Group: a restored 6-foot, 4-inch-long Steinway grand piano; original sculptures, plenty of seating space and structural columns clad with fluted zinc to minimize their intrusiveness.
"People say you can't afford to give up commercial space, but you can't have a 4-foot-by-9-foot lobby for a 209-room hotel," Mr. Goldberg said. The design, by the architect Rafael Vinoly, did away with all the stores and four guest rooms to produce the spacious lobby, with the registration desk at the far end.
Mr. Goldberg said his formula, which has been applied to five midsize hotels in Manhattan, was to take rundown properties and add equipment and services that attract a more affluent clientele. "You are giving up commercial revenue," he said, "but by adding amenities, you can attract the type of customer that allows you to raise the room rate."
Indeed, before the restoration, the 1928-vintage Roger Williams was able to command only about $40 a night and several floors had been used by the Red Cross to house homeless families. Now, with the restoration complete, the room rate is over $170 a night.
Mr. Goldberg hopes to keep attracting guests with amenities such as a CD player in every room and a library of CD's for guests to play. He is counting on live music as well, with chamber music groups centered on the Steinway in the lobby.
At his other hotels, the Wales, the Franklin, the Shoreham and the Mansfield,, concerts are formal, sit-down affairs held on specific days of the week. "At the Roger Williams we will be more casual," he said. "We will have music, say, from 8 to 9:30 in the morning, 2 to 4 in the afternoon and maybe later in the evening."
For now, though, Mr. Goldberg reports that the Roger Williams has been virtually full in recent weeks.
So has just about every other hotel in New York. With a robust overall economy and the city's newfound attractiveness, both business and recreational visitors have been pouring in, driving occupancy rates and room charges to record levels.
"We are projecting that the citywide occupancy rate for this year will be 83 percent," compared to 81.3 percent last year, said John A. Fox, a senior vice president of PKF Consulting, which specializes in hotels. "We expect that level to be flat in 1998, because the industry is essentially at capacity -- you can't fit any more people in." The only way hotel operators could find to rent more rooms, Mr. Fox said, would be to persuade people to visit the city in January and February, which are traditionally the months of lowest demand.
Meanwhile, the unrelenting demand has allowed hotel managers to increase their room rates to levels never before seen. Mr. Fox said his firm estimates that the overall average room rate in the city for 1997 will be $188. And the expectation is that it will rise over $200 in 1998. "That will be the first time the average rate has gone that high in America," he said.
With this kind of demand, the expectation would be that developers would be putting spades in the ground to bring more rooms to market. Indeed, there has been a lot talk -- but little action.
Renovations, such as Mr. Goldberg's, do not add rooms to the inventory; they just shift the market segment from the lowest to something attractive to a middle-class businessman or tourist. Only two new hotels are being built now, a 384-room Marriott Hotel that will be part of a 1.4 million-square-footoffice-conference-hotel complex in Brooklyn known as Renaissance Plaza, and a 240-room Marriott Courtyard on 40th Street between Avenue of the Americas and Broadway. A construction shed is in place at 866 Third Avenue, where part of the building is to be converted into a 308-unit Marriott Courtyard.
HOTEL industry analysts and real estate executives say many lenders were badly burned by the hotel building boom of the 1980's, which led many hotel owners to default during the slump of the early 1990's and left the lenders reluctant to get involved in the industry again.
"Hotels are not like office buildings, where you sign a lease and go home," said Vijay Dandapani, chief operating officer of Apple Core Hotels, which has restored five hotels in the city since 1992. "You have to re-rent them every night; management has to be able to do that."
C. Scott Robertson, a senior vice president at Sonnenblick-Goldman Company, said that many hotels and hotel chains have traded hands this year. Indeed, a mergers and acquisitions survey by Coopers & Lybrand shows that hotel deals totaling over $32 billion have closed or been announced so far this year.
Mr. Robertson said this activity showed that money was available for the right kind of deals. "If something is up and built, you can find financing for it," he said, "Financing speculative construction is a lot more difficult unless it's a corporation with good credit and there is lots of equity."
Nevertheless, some analysts say that hotel economics are favorable enough in New York now to attract lenders. "Until recently, room rates did not justify new construction, but now I think we are there," said Arthur Adler, a partner on Coopers & Lybrand's lodging and gaming group.
Mr. Adler said projects like the Embassy Suites hotel in Battery Park City, the Tishman E-Walk hotel at Eighth Avenue and 43d Street and the Sofitel on 45th Street near Times Square all appear to be close to getting under way. "I expect to see things coming out of the ground in the next 18 months," he said.
Another optimist is Paul Stern, managing director of Sonnenblick-Goldman, who was involved in the sale of the 1,705-room Hotel Pennsylvania to a group including Vornado Realty Trust, Planet Hollywood International and a Singapore-based company headed by Ong Beng Sang. The hotel, across Seventh Avenue from Madison Square Garden, is to be converted to a sports-theme hotel and entertainment complex called the Official All Star Hotel.
"New York is in the midst of a great economic resurgence," he said. "Five years ago people were saying New York would go the way of Newark and Detroit. I think it is only halfway through a recovery that will last into the next century. At the turn of the century, New York will be the best place on Earth to be."
This sort of talk makes some veteran hotel owners nervous. "I saw the same kind of euphoria in 1988," said Richard Born, whose BD Hotels company owns and operates 14 hotels in the city, including the Stanhope, Holiday Inn, Hotel Elysee and Metro Hotel.
"Room rates of $200 a night and occupancy rates of 90 percent are not sustainable," Mr. Born said. Looking back, he noted that the hotel business slumped in 1974 and 1975 and dived again from 1991 to 1993. "Sometime in the next decade we are going to have two bad years back to back and we are going to see the same problems as before," he said. He said that he bought hotels in the early 1990's because there were bargains to be had, but that he is less likely to invest now that the industry has heated up. "I look at properties every day," he said, "but when I see projected numbers, I try to use a little caution." He and some other hotel investors said any deal predicated on steadily rising room rates was likely to come apart in a downturn, just as happened with office buildings in midtown in the early 90's.
One of those investors is Mr. Goldberg. On one hand, he is thinking big, saying he would like to buy the Chrysler Building and turn it into a massive 1,700-room hotel. On the other, he keeps an eye on the pitfalls.
"The up side takes care of itself," he said. "You have to live with the down side." He said the Roger Williams deal was structured so he could survive at a much lower room rate than the over $170 charged now.
"I can afford to charge $90 a night at 70 percent occupancy and still serve breakfast," he said.

HEADLINE: OFF THE SHELF;
Genius Nerds, New Machines And the Culture They Made

BYLINE: By DEBORAH STEAD 

 BODY:
"THE SOUL OF A NEW MACHINE," Tracy Kidder's classic 1981 narrative about the creation of a computer, has been reissued by the Modern Library ($16.50), and it feels as up to date as ever.
The new machine of the title, a 32-bit supermini built during an arduous three years at the Data General Corporation, no longer generates excitement, of course. But its story, adjusted, you might say, for technological inflation, is amazingly current. 
 Here, in Pulitzer Prize-winning prose, are the ingredients of computer tales to come: the code names, genius nerds, brash marketing ploys, project rivalries, 20-hour workdays and passionate commitment twinned with a penchant for secrecy. (Visitors to Data General's Massachusetts compound were monitored by rooftop cameras.)
"By giving this book its odd title," Mr. Kidder writes in the introduction to the new edition, "I meant to imply something about the collective character and effort of a group of people who worked only partly for their pay, most of them reveling in the difficulty of their circumstances."
This "something" has evolved into an industry culture, and it is gracefully decoded again in a new book, Tim Jackson's "Inside Intel: Andy Grove and the Rise of the World's Most Powerful Chip Company" (Dutton, $24.95).
Intel, founded in 1968 in Mountain View, Calif., about the same time as Data General, gave the world the microprocessor that allowed powerful computers to fit on desktops. In this compelling account of the company's rise, Mr. Jackson, who writes a weekly Internet column for The Financial Times, shows, in effect, how Intel became the Brain of Your New Machine. (Intel chips are famously "inside" about 80 percent of personal computers.)
Intel's chairman, Andrew C. Grove, who wrote his own corporate account last year in "Only the Paranoid Survive," didn't cooperate with the author. And Mr. Jackson writes that the company tried to thwart his reporting from time to time.
Still, the results are anything but patchy, and as the book chronicles Intel's advances in microprocessors, memory chips and marketing, it hands out praise with its criticisms.
Started by Robert N. Noyce and Gordon E. Moore, who defected from Fairchild Semiconductor, Intel made the usual transition from a freewheeling outfit, at which engineers could order $100,000 worth of gear without authorization. Mr. Grove, hired early on as operations director, has shaped the company's current culture, the author says, a culture of strict performance reviews, secrecy, wariness and a sharp-elbowed competitive style involving lots of litigation.
The author concludes, however, that this strong home-grown management has been good for the company, although its accompanying failure to hire outsiders to high posts is a weakness, he says.
Intel, after all, is prospering, and it has helped others in the industry prosper, too. Its chips "began the familiar path of rising costs, rising performance and diminishing size," the author notes. Intel's Mr. Moore is the source of Moore's Law, the rule of thumb that computer chips get twice as fast and twice as cheap every 18 months. (A few weeks ago, Intel and Hewlett-Packard announced a new chip architecture that may make things go faster even faster.)
"Inside Intel" does a lively job of explaining the technological struggles in all this, though some passages will be a hard go for lay people (like me). But the sections likely to get the most attention concern the company's culture, management and mistakes.
There's a nice description of the day in July 1969 when company engineers were allowed to take radios into the lab so they could hear Neil Armstrong's message from the moon. And there are fascinating narratives about Intel's outwardly cool but inwardly panicked response to the threat of unionization, its digital-watch debacle and its crisis in 1994, when news of its flawed Pentium chip raged across the Internet.
And at a time when Intel and other computer industry giants are being scrutinized by Federal regulators, the author also says there are company practices that reveal the price of success.
Midlevel managers, he says, are warned never to say the company "dominates" the microprocessor business, but only that it "leads." And from time to time, he says, Intel stages mock raids, invading an executive's office unannounced and taking files away to search them for careless phrases that might jeopardize the company in a lawsuit.
 
A DIGITAL GUIDEBOOK "Release 2.0: A Design for Living in the Digital Age," by Esther Dyson (Broadway Books, $25), is a treatise on the age of technology by someone at the center of the action.
Ms. Dyson is the high profile president of Edventure Holdings, which publishes Release 1.0, an influential industry newsletter. The company also organizes PC Forum, an annual computer industry event at which the elite meet (and occasionally serve one another's companies with subpoenas).
Unfortunately, Ms. Dyson, like cyber-gurus who have gone before, offers disappointingly bland prophecies and prescriptions when tackling the Big Thoughts: the impact of computers on education, work, politics and culture.
But if her picture for 2004 seems flat rather than futuristic, her dazzling familiarity with current technology, especially the Internet, finally gives the book a futuristic feeling. As the author mounts her arguments about privacy, security and self-governance on the Internet, she adopts the matter-of-fact tone of a science-fiction writer, giving readers an illuminating behind-the-scenes tour of her strange universe.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 2; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 585 words

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
These Good Times Will End With a Whimper

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
The bull market lives on, thanks to millions of Americans who did exactly what they had told pollsters they would do: They stayed calm when Wall Street panicked. Some even bought stocks.
"All the new investors since 1987 learned that you should buy the dips," said Donald B. Marron, the chairman of Paine Webber. "And that may be close to a majority of all investors." 
 The panic on Monday set off the New York Stock Exchange's circuit breakers and forced all American markets to close early. It terrified people around the world, but not in Peoria, Ill. or Boise, Idaho. And that illustrated just how much Americans now believe in stocks as the one and only superior long-term investment.
This panic was largely a matter of professional investors getting worried about the risks of collapsing prices, profits and banks in Asia. It will be interesting to see if it has a long-term effect on attitudes toward investing in emerging markets. But it is not likely to damage confidence in American stocks.
Bears on the American stock market need to remember that stocks do not go up or down because of earnings, or interest rates, or because they are trading at ridiculous multiples of profits or sales. They go down when there are not enough buyers at a certain price. If something does not influence investors, it won't affect prices.
That is why the stock market's high valuation is not very important right now. Investors will move from less attractive stocks to more attractive ones, but they will not get out of the market.
Alan Greenspan, in his Congressional testimony last week, tried to gently criticize that attitude, saying that stock price gains since 1995 appear to be based on the assumption that profits would keep rising indefinitely from already high levels. He knows that is unlikely to happen and seems to regret his own public flirtation with the so-called new paradigm, which holds that this time is different. But his ability to influence the market is limited, assuming he is unwilling to raise interest rates enough to bring on a recession.
Someday, of course, there will be a bear market. But it is unlikely to begin with a crash. As last week showed, even a very bad day will not shake a public that deeply believes in the long-term case for stocks.
The more likely picture is a choppy market, followed by a slow decline, like the one in the late 1960's and early 1970's. Faith in stocks as sure things was strong then, as it is now. The Dow Jones industrial average peaked at 1,051.69 on Jan. 11, 1973, not far above where it had been a few years before.
The 1973-74 bear market began slowly. Not until November, after the Dow was down 11.3 percent from the peak, did the market have a day in which prices fell by 2 percent. By then, there was obvious economic news to explain a weak stock market: an Arab oil embargo that was leading to the first oil price shock and a deep recession. The worst day of that bear market saw a 3.5 percent fall, less than half the decline that was seen last Monday. But by the time prices bottomed in late 1974, the Dow was off 45 percent from the peak. The worst days came near the end, not at the beginning, of the decline.
It took months, and even years, of performance that fell below expectations before most investors got out.
It will probably take a real recession to kill this bull, and then it will die slowly. But once it is dead, it may be a long time before a new bull is born. The 1973 high stood as a record until 1982.

GRAPHIC: Graph: "Some Bear Markets Start Gradually . . ."
Dow Jones industrial average, 1973-74.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 9; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 892 words

HEADLINE: THE MANIC MARKET: AN INVESTOR'S GUIDE;
No Shore Is Safe for Emerging-Market Funds

BYLINE: By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
INVESTORS who have embraced the gospel of global diversification preached so fervently by investment advisers in recent years have no doubt found themselves filled with growing frustrations and skepticism the last two weeks.
For while most of the world has been focused on the turmoil in Asia and the dyspeptic reaction of the American markets, mutual funds that invest in European, Latin American and other emerging markets have also been coming unraveled. 
International investment experts say fund shareholders should not, however, give up on the idea that spreading their assets across a broad array of markets is the best way to invest for the long term.
"The linkage between all these markets is more psychological than economic," said Lawrence Kantor, a managing director at the Lexington Management Corporation in Saddle Brook, N.J., which oversees both a Russian and an Asian specialty mutual fund. So while there will be short periods when all markets seem to move together, over longer periods each market's growth will depend on factors peculiar to its region.
"Hong Kong was the best-performing market over the last 25 years because the economy there has boomed," he said. "Eastern Europe has had a poorly performing economy for five of the last six years. But it is just starting to turn around." Therefore, he said, the long-term growth of the two markets is unlikely to remain closely linked.
Nevertheless, Lexington's Troika Dialog Russia fund was hit particularly hard over the last week. The fund, which invests most of its assets directly in Russian equities, was the best performer of all mutual funds in the first three quarters of the year, gaining 115 percent. In the five trading sessions ended Thursday, however, the fund slumped more than 14 percent, cutting its 1997 gain to 88.5 percent.
The Vontobel Eastern European fund, which invests in Russia, Poland, Hungary and Croatia, also fell last week. In the first three quarters of the year, the fund gained 30 percent, far behind the Troika fund but still in the top one-tenth of the funds in the emerging-market sector tracked by Lipper Analytical Services.
The last week has been a disaster, however, as worries grew that some Eastern European countries, including the Czech Republic, might be vulnerable to the same type of currency crisis that has afflicted so many Asian nations. Even funds that have little or no holdings in the Czech Republic found themselves hurt by those worries: The Vontobel fund fell more than 17 percent in the week ended Thursday, cutting its gains for the year to 8.8 percent.
Those funds and others that invest in Eastern Europe might find themselves under pressure in coming weeks from growing illiquidity as the markets there retreat from their quick ascents of earlier this year. Whether the region's liquidity problems will ease anytime soon is an open question; banks like Chase Manhattan that were big lenders to Russian companies were reported last week to have suffered big losses on Russian debt securities.
Equity funds that invest in the region take some steps to limit their holdings of illiquid securities, which have restrictions on their sale or the use of any proceeds or both. But when an index of the country's largest stocks falls 18 percent, as Russia's did in the week ended Thursday, the definition of what is an easily tradable security is certainly open to some interpretation.
The Troika Dialog fund, for example, says in its prospectus that it limits its holdings of illiquid stocks to 15 percent of its net assets at the time of purchase of such a security. At June 30, when assets in the fund totaled $84 million, 13 percent of its assets were in securities deemed illiquid. Included in that portion were 4 percent of the fund's assets invested in shares of Sibneft, an oil and gas company. (By the end of the third quarter, the fund's assets had grown to $186 million as the fund's stellar performance attracted new investors.)
Mr. Kantor said that the fund had built up a 15 percent cash position in anticipation of a market correction but that redemptions were relatively small through last week.
SOME of the weakness in Eastern European markets spilled over into the more established countries to the west, and mutual funds that invest broadly in European markets also fell. Among the largest European funds, the Dean Witter European Growth fell 2.7 percent in the week ended Thursday, Merrill Lynch Eurofund dipped 1.6 percent, as did the T. Rowe Price International European fund, while the Vanguard International Index Europe fund fell 2.1 percent.
Latin American funds, which in the first nine months of the year were the best performing of all categories tracked by Lipper, also fell prey last week to concerns about currency problems. Most Latin American funds have their biggest holdings in Brazil, which is the region's largest and most liquid stock market. Brazil is also the country that many international investment experts expect will be the next target of currency speculators.
Not surprisingly, many Latin American funds finished the week ended Thursday worth much less. Among the largest funds, Fidelity Latin America lost 18 percent of its value, T. Rowe Price International Latin America fell nearly 20 percent, and the Scudder Latin America fund skidded 17 percent.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: ROOSEVELT ISLAND;
After 26 Years, Turbulence for an Urban Experiment

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
Envisioned as an ambitious urban experiment in the 1970's, Roosevelt Island has always been an odd duck in New York City -- a neighborhood of 8,000 in the middle of the East River that is run, in effect, by the state government.
Now, 26 years after groundbreaking on an island that once housed a prison and a mental hospital, the community is going through its most turbulent times ever. The state, seeking to end what it considers decades of waste and mismanagement, has eliminated state aid and now is planning to sell the largest tract of open space there, 10 acres known as Southpoint. 
 For the residents, the proposed sale of Southpoint is the latest in a long list of grievances. They say that land, which includes the ruins of the historic Smallpox Hospital, which is visible from Manhattan, was promised to them as a park when Roosevelt Island was created. But the Roosevelt Island Operating Corporation, a state agency, wants to develop the property for commercial, residential or mixed use.
Residents complain that they were not consulted, and City Councilman Gifford Miller, who represents Roosevelt Island, is on their side. Mr. Miller said developing Southpoint would require changing the 1969 agreement by which New York City leased the island to New York State to create the community there. That would require Council approval, he said.
Michael Greason, a spokesman for the Roosevelt Island agency, said that the project would likely include a park and that a public meeting would be held on the plan, probably in January. He said he would have to check with agency lawyers on whether the project is subject to Council approval.
That a New York City neighborhood is run by Albany is something of an accident. The legislators who created the community, which is linked to Manhattan by the Roosevelt Island tram, envisioned a small town, free of cars and racially and economically diverse. Planners believed that a population of 20,000 was needed to generate enough revenue through rents and other fees to sustain the community without state subsidies. But the island never developed enough to house that many people.
For years, the state subsidized the island's operating budget, which totaled $8.8 million for the year ended March 31. But last year, at the urging of Gov. George Pataki, the Legislature cut the subsidy to $600,000 from $1 million. Financing for capital projects, which had been $5.2 million the year before, was eliminated.
Mr. Greason said that $600,000 was not even needed because the island had a surplus for the 1996-97 year, and was expected to finish this fiscal year with a surplus, too. The Legislature refused to approve either operating or capital money for this year.
Michael F. McKeon, a spokesman for the Governor, said the budget cuts were made to curb waste and mismanagement. "Roosevelt Island has become more self-sufficient with a much-improved management team," he said.
Patrick Stewart, president of the Roosevelt Island Residents Association, said that except for fire and police protection, the island received few city services.
"It's not like we want anything extra," he said. "We just want what everyone else has."
Relations between residents and the president of the Roosevelt Island Operating Corporation, Jerome H. Blue, have become increasingly tense. Residents claim he evades questions about how the island will cope without state money, which he denies.
In June, the residents association called for Mr. Blue's ouster, prompting some to say the criticism of Mr. Blue, who is African-American, was racially motivated. Mr. Stewart says that is untrue.
The racial tension especially worries longtime residents. "We used to call this Paradise Island," said Frances Salten, 84, a retired lawyer. "Not anymore." ANTHONY RAMIREZ

HEADLINE: THE MANIC MARKET: AN INVESTOR'S GUIDE;
Bonds Are Back, but Be Wary When Buying

BYLINE: By SANA SIWOLOP 

 BODY:
IN the wake of the stock market's canyon-sized dip on Monday, many investors moved money into Treasury securities, which sent their prices surging.
These investors thus joined a herd of others who have been turning to bonds lately, attracted by the rising prices inherent in a low-interest rate environment. But, like most markets that suddenly get hot, the bond market can burn investors who have scant knowledge of the rules. 
 To be sure, bond analysts expect prices to keep rising. One reason is that they consider it unlikely that the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates anytime soon. Another is that the supply of both Treasuries and tax-free municipal bonds is shrinking as the Federal budget deficit is pared and as public-sector privatization grows. And with demand high and supply tight, bond prices tend to rise.
Kevin McClintock, the head of taxable fixed income at the Dreyfus Corporation, says this environment provides a "very favorable backdrop" for bond buyers.
Still, with prices high, it is not easy to spot value.
Experts advise caution not only for novices but also for more seasoned investors who are perhaps considering re-entering the bond market after a prolonged honeymoon with stocks.
It is true, they note, that bond prices lately have been gyrating far less than stocks. The bellwether 30-year Treasury bond, for example, after surging on Monday by 126/32 , or $18.125 for each $1,000 in face value, to 1036/32 , ended the week at 1032/32 , while its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, moved from 6.14 percent on Monday to 6.15 percent.
STILL, bonds have occasionally reacted strongly to factors like the possibility of higher oil prices or even the slightest whiff of a possible rise in inflation.
Traditionally, investors have needed to keep three kinds of risk in mind when buying bonds: the risk that inflation will push interest rates higher, the risk that the credit-worthiness of the bond will drop and, in the case of international bonds, the risk of big swings in currency values.
In addition, bonds -- like stocks -- have recently taken a hit from a string of economic problems abroad. Last year, according to Lipper Analytical Services, which tracks mutual funds, emerging-market bond funds were one of the few stars in the bond fund market, scoring a heady 41 percent return. But in the wake of the market's recent drop, Mr. McClintock estimates that emerging-market bonds have dropped in price, on average, 35 percent.
Indeed, for most investors, the bond market is a vastly different animal from what it was just a year ago. One example, when it comes to bond mutual funds, is the growing amount of junk, as well as emerging-market debt, that is popping up in even the highest-quality funds as their managers seek to bolster yield.
"It's becoming a poorer and poorer way to manage, but a lot of fund managers have been chasing yield through lower-credit issues," said John Poole, the head of fixed income at Mellon Private Asset Management.
He added: "One concern that we have is that if interest rates do go lower, then people will increasingly go to things that foolishly jeopardize their principal in order to get more return. Investors also need to remember that as rates go lower, price volatility rises."
At the Bond Investors Association, a nonprofit research and information company in Miami Lakes, Fla., Richard Lehmann, the company's president, is concerned about the growth of what he calls "cocktail-party bonds," which some bond experts say have quadrupled in assets over the last decade.
These bonds, he said, were initially intended to appeal to institutional investors who were looking for glitzier offerings within the relatively unglamorous bond world. But Mr. Lehmann senses that the bonds' issuers are now focusing on individual investors.
ONE recent example of cocktail-party bonds, he said, was the more than $50 million offering of "David Bowie bonds" that institutional investors bought earlier this year. Those bonds were backed by estimated future royalties for the rock star.
"Imagine talking about Texaco's efforts in the Indian Ocean when you could be talking about a rock singer's royalties," he said. "Cocktail-party bonds are now a multibillion-dollar market.
"We've seen bonds that are backed by credit card receivables on used-car loans; some municipalities are even backing them with delinquent parking tickets," he added. "In harder times, such strange stuff wouldn't have gotten noticed, but with the baby boomers there is so much liquidity now that it's fueling anything that moves."
Mr. Poole agreed. "There's more money out there than there are bonds, so it's been hard to be choosy," he said. "But there are a lot of gimmicks out there."
MR. POOLE cautioned bond buyers to be wary of unregistered bonds, too. While the Securities and Exchange Commission restricts the sale of such bonds to well-off investors, the bonds have become increasingly common over the last two years, tripling in volume this year alone. He noted that companies have taken advantage of a Federal law that allows them to sell bonds before registering them with the S.E.C. as long as they are registered within 270 days. That means investors are purchasing debt issues without having read the prospectuses.
According to Mr. Poole, unregistered bonds generally have yields that are a quarter or a half of a percentage point higher than similar, registered issues. Investors are so confident, given the low rate of business defaults nationwide, he said, that they tend to forget that they will not have as complete a contract to fall back on for making claims if their particular bond issuer does default.
"If a company has a credit rating and you know what you're getting into, then these issues are fine," said Patrick Smith, an editor at the Income Securities Advisor, a newsletter published by the Bond Investors Association. "But what worries me is the nonrated issue that offers a 12 percent yield and that gets hyped by an unscrupulous boiler-room operation, even though it has only a single-B or single-C credit status," he said. "Investors may not realize that this is a company that makes wagon wheels for stagecoaches."
Another source of worry to bond experts is that investors are still pouring money into high-yield junk bonds, which are often aggressively priced. Junk bond funds have lately been yielding 8 percent to 14 percent a year. But experts advise investors to look beyond yield and focus on total return, the sum of yield and the change in the portfolio's value.
At first glance, junk bonds, issued by companies whose credit ratings are not of investment grade, seem to hold plenty of appeal because, with the economy strong, the chances of a company's defaulting on its debt are lower than they were a few years ago.
But bond experts like Mr. Poole urge investors to think again before buying junk. The yield spreads, or difference in yields, between junk bonds and investment-grade bonds -- as well as those between intermediate-term bonds and longer-term issues -- have narrowed so much lately that investors are no longer being adequately compensated for the additional risk, he said.
"A lot of the game is over," Mr. Poole said. "In this market, if you have a lot of extra yield, you need to be very, very suspicious because almost all credit issues have pretty much the same yield today."
He added that investors might be better off "buying higher-quality, intermediate issues," those that mature in 5 to 10 years.
Mr. Lehmann also urged investors to focus on bond quality, adding that if investors were still determined to go for higher yields, they ought to stick to bonds with at least a double-B credit rating. Also, he said, be sure to buy recent issues; their credit rating is generally more trustworthy.
"The high-yield bonds that we're currently recommending yield anywhere between 8 and 11 percent, while investment-grade corporate bonds are yielding between 7 and 9 percent," he said.

HEADLINE: THE MANIC MARKET: AN INVESTOR'S GUIDE;
Waiting for Those Dreams to Get Cheap Enough to Buy

BYLINE: By ANNE TERGESEN 

 BODY:
IT has been a tough year for value investors -- the bargain hunters whose search for cheap stocks has been frustrated by the climb of the Dow Jones industrial average. As the bull market reached new heights, thrift-minded fund managers carried more cash than they wanted and even adjusted their definitions of a good buy.
"Everybody had to stretch their valuation parameters upward," said Shelby Davis, chief investment officer of Davis Selected Advisors. "Where we used to think we could find stocks at 10 to 12 times earnings, we've been in the 13 to 15 range." 
 But with the stock market's dizzying selloff and semi-rebound last week, and a close on Friday that left it more than 800 points below its August peak, value investors can now dare to dream. What if the market continues to slide? Will the overpriced stocks of otherwise great companies come within reach?
Three mutual fund managers -- one specializing in large companies, one in medium companies and one in small ones -- were asked what stocks they most wanted to see tumble. Besides identifying some promising prospects, their answers show how these investors skirt what many call this bull market's fatal flaw: overvaluation.
In a pullback, Mr. Davis said, he would buy several stocks for his large-company funds, Selected American and Davis New York Venture. One wish-list company is Applied Materials, which makes equipment for semiconductor manufacturers. The company should benefit greatly from expected annual growth of 15 to 20 percent in demand for its industry's machines, Mr. Davis said. And with silicon chips -- its customers' end product -- finding their way into everything from computers to cars, the large equipment maker can only become more attractive, he said.
Applied Materials stands out even within its booming field. It is the largest player in a consolidating industry and its annual earnings growth rate, 20 to 25 percent, well exceeds the industry average.
But in order for the Davis funds to bite, the stock of Applied Materials must fall. One of Mr. Davis's rules of thumb: the ratio of a stock price to the estimated earnings per share next year must be equal to or less than the company's expected percentage growth in earnings in 1998. Under this principle, the stock of Applied Materials will have to fall to $25 from its current $33.375 to interest Mr. Davis.
Similarly, Mr. Davis likes Warner Lambert, the drug company. A big reason is the company's two new blockbuster drugs -- Lipitor, a cholesterol reducer, and Rezulin, a diabetes medicine. Both will have patent protection for many years, and Mr. Davis thinks that Warner Lambert will also continue to benefit from large trends, like the aging of the world's population.
But Warner Lambert stock must tumble to $120, from its current $143.375 for Mr. Davis to buy it. At $120, the company's price-earnings ratio would match the 29 percent expected earnings increase in 1998.
Thinking about such drops may seem like daydreaming. But after Monday it may seem less so. Warner Lambert fell from $151 to $140.50 on that day -- about half the drop that Mr. Davis wants before snapping it up.
In a down market, Richard Weiss, the manager of the midcap Strong Opportunity fund, would take a look at Sigma-Aldrich, which makes specialty chemicals. About 80 percent of its sales are to university, government, hospital and other laboratories. Sigma has a solid 10 percent of the lab market, and is also attractive for its operating margins of 21 percent, annual sales growth of 10 to 15 percent and a virtually debt-free balance sheet, Mr. Weiss said.
But Sigma's stock price of $35.125 -- or 22 times earnings -- is too expensive for Mr. Weiss. He would buy it at $30.
CNF Transportation, a trucking and air freight company, is on Mr. Weiss's watch list, too. In August, CNF's Emery Worldwide subsidiary snared a $1.7 billion contract to deliver priority mail on the East Coast for the Postal Service. CNF also should benefit from a recent restructuring. Recent shipping delays in the railroad industry may mean more profits for CNF, too.
But "a lot of expectations are built into its stock," which has risen this year from about $20 to $44.625 at Friday's close, Mr. Weiss said. CNF stock could disappoint, particularly if an economic slowdown curtails shipping. However, if the stock's price were to fall to $32, Mr. Weiss said he would jump in.
Mr. Weiss looks for a stock trading at a 40 percent discount to the company's estimated acquisition value, or what a rival or other company would pay for the enterprise. To arrive at acquisition estimates, he uses a variety of yardsticks, like price-to-sales ratios or the value of an oil company's oil reserves. With CNF, as with Sigma, the gauge was a ratio of earnings (adjusted for interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization) to the company's value, or its market capitalization plus debt minus cash.
In a decline, Steven Reid, manager of the Oakmark Small Cap fund, dreams of buying something tasty -- Tootsie Roll Industries.
"If this stock got hit, I would love to buy it," he said. The company has no debt and the fame of its brands, which include Tootsie Rolls and Charms, means it can avoid huge marketing expenditures. The company also has operating margins of more than 20 percent, sales generally undisturbed by economic downturns and a hefty cash balance. With its chairman and controlling shareholder, Melvin Gordon, 77, well within sight of retirement, it may be a takeover candidate, too, Mr. Reid said.
Using a complicated ratio to gauge priciness -- operating cash flow compared with the company's market capitalization plus debt and minus cash -- Mr. Reid has set $37 as the target buy price.
That is a far cry from the current $56.75, and Tootsie Roll is a steady performer unlikely to be too severely battered in a down market. Then again, the company was trading at Mr. Reid's target price of $37 as recently as early February, although earnings growth and the market's rise have bolstered the price since then.
THE largest holding in Mr. Reid's fund is Peoples Bank of Bridgeport. From a closing of $36.083 a week ago Friday, the Connecticut bank's stock ended on Monday at $31.
Given its profitable credit card operations, expanding supermarket presence, and strong reputation siphoning depositors from out-of-state banks, Peoples is a bargain below $30 a share, Mr. Reid said. He tried to get yet more shares for his fund on Monday, but liquidity problems prevented him from doing so.
But he is watching for the next drop.
