HEADLINE: Rising Fires Renew Threat to Amazon

BYLINE: By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO 

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 28

 BODY:
In Porto Velho in western Brazil, thick clouds of black smoke have forced airports and schools to shut down. In southern Para state near the Amazon frontier, people gasping for air have collapsed and ended up in hospitals. In the city of Manaus, the sun has disappeared for days at a time.
Twenty years after the goal of rescuing the Amazon rain forest first captured world attention, becoming the pet cause of celebrities and a regular topic in children's schoolbooks, deforestation and the burning of vast areas are again climbing. 
 Data in recent weeks suggest that the burning going on in Brazil this year is greater than what has occurred in Indonesia, where major cities have been smothered under blankets of smoke that spread to other countries.
Despite the fact that hundreds of millions of dollars have been spent to save the rain forest, burnings in the Amazon region are up 28 percent over last year, according to satellite data, and 1994 deforestation figures, the most recent available, show a 34 percent increase since 1991.
"Deforestation has done nothing but go up," said Stephen Schwartzman of the Environmental Defense Fund, a nonprofit group based in Washington. "Where the most money has gone is where the fires have increased the most." The group noted that half the fires recorded this year were in Mato Grosso, where the World Bank lent $205 million to save the rain forest in a natural resource management program.
Roughly a fifth of the fires that rage annually between June and October cause new deforestation, and another tenth is burning of ground cover in virgin forests.
Scientists now say that the Amazon rain forest may be reaching a critical level of dryness, in which standing forest could catch fire and burn out of control. A report by the Environmental Defense Fund warned the Amazon "may be edging closer to catastrophic fire events," and predicted "potentially enormous global consequences."
The World Wildlife Fund found that 93 percent of the original Atlantic rain forest in the northeast had disappeared over the centuries, and some 12 to 15 percent of the Amazon rain forest.
The report said that Brazil was losing more rain forest each year than any other country on the planet. In addition to the 5,800 square miles a year that satellite images show are deforested each year, the Woods Hole Research Institute estimates that another 4,200 are thinned through logging beneath the forest canopy.
Eduardo Martins, the president of the Brazilian federal environmental agency, said in an interview that the increase in fires, while worrisome, did not result in an increase in deforestation, although the two problems have risen in tandem. He contended that most fires were set by small farmers who would starve if they could not clear land for planting, and that the environmental damage paled next to fossil fuel emissions in the United States.
Beneath the noxious haze covering much of Brazil every burning season is an opaque, often contradictory, Government policy toward the environment. "Properly speaking, we still don't have a policy, but we have a start," Mr. Martins told a Brazilian news magazine earlier this year.
Lacking enforcement muscle, the Government environmental agency ultimately collects only 6.5 percent of the fines it imposes. The rest are thrown out in court.
In a recent interview, President Fernando Henrique Cardoso acknowledged that the agency needed more money and muscle. A bill to strengthen it, stalled in Congress since 1991, passed the Senate this year. It is now idling in the House, where the Federation of Industries is lobbying against it on the ground that threats of cash fines and prison will open the way for corruption.
For now, not surprisingly, the agency is usually ignored by the people it is supposed to monitor. While permits are required for burning, the agency has reportedly issued licenses to clear a total of only about 24,700 acres this year -- an area seemingly far smaller than what would produce the dense clouds of smoke that have appeared over several states. Mr. Martins disputed that permits were issued for only such an area, but his office declined to provide other figures.
While even poorly enforced measures and licensing procedures are intended to deter deforestation, until recently other Government statutes deemed cleared forest to be "an improvement on the land," which meant it was less likely to be considered unproductive and seized for agrarian reform. If the owner sold it for Government redistribution to peasants, burning and planting paid off in higher compensation. Mr. Martins said that is changing now.
But the pace of destruction appears to be dictated more by the marketplace than by any Government measure. The demand in Europe and the United States for hardwoods like mahogany, used for furniture, has ushered in large illegal logging operations throughout the Amazon.
A report by the Federal Secretary of Strategic Affairs, recently disclosed in the Brazilian press, said that 80 percent of all logging in the Amazon is illegal.
The Government appears caught between largely international pressure to reduce the amount of burning and deforestation, and powerful domestic lobbies from the logging industry, farmers and large landholders. It is building several major roads that will cut into the Amazon, and a $1.2 billion state-of-the-art surveillance project will soon locate minerals, ores, and other natural resources hidden beneath the forest canopy.
The Amazon surveillance project could also provide current information on deforestation, but ecologists are wary, for the Brazilian Government has been in no hurry to analyze the data it has already. After years of saying that deforestation was on the decline, last year the Government released deforestation figures for the first time in four years -- showing the 34 percent increase.
The Government tried to diminish criticism by announcing measures to reverse the trend. It increased the share that each landowner in the rain forest was barred from burning from 50 to 80 percent, and announced a moratorium on new licenses for logging mahogany and another hardwood, virola.
But field reviews by the environmental monitoring agency show that the conditions of its permits are routinely ignored. And once again, the figures of deforestation since 1994 are late. "The scene in general is one of rampant illegal logging," said Robert J. Buschbacher, conservation director of the World Wildlife Fund-Brazil.
The Government has also fought successfully to keep mahogany off a list that would have subjected the licenses for logging it to outside monitoring and established targets to reduce exports. It argued that globally mahogany is not an endangered species, even though domestically it is considered one.
Mr. Martins said his Government opposed the move because it was sponsored by the United States, which he considered "hypocritical," since America provides much of the market for hardwood furniture. He said that Brazil had seized hundreds of thousands of illegally cut logs, which he said the Government plans to use for low-income housing and public buildings.
A recent study by the Amazon Environmental Research Institute estimated that for every acre that shows up as cleared and burned in satellite images, another partly burned or logged acre goes undetected beneath the forest canopy.
Daniel C. Nepstad, president of the Amazon institute and a scientist at the Woods Hole Research Institute, said such burning and logging make the forest more vulnerable to fire and means a 50 percent greater likelihood of deforestation.
For the first time in 14 years, as part of his research, he was able to set fire to virgin rain forest, he said. Though he quickly put it out, the lesson was important: Until now, a moist root system and dense vegetation had made it virtually impossible to set fire to a primary forest.
"With logging it becomes more flammable," said Philip M. Fearnside, an ecology professor at the National Institute for Research in the Amazon. "So the fires can escape and go into the forest."

Map showing the location of the Amazon rain forest: Demand for mahogany has led to illegal logging in the Amazon.

HEADLINE: Prisons: A Growth Industry for Some;
Colorado County Is a Grateful Host to 7,000 Involuntary Guests

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: FLORENCE, Colo.

 BODY:
A few miles from the "Alcatraz of the Rockies," the maximum security Federal prison where Timothy J. McVeigh spends 23 hours a day in an isolation cell, a cheery billboard beckons tourists: "Stop and do time with us. Colorado Territorial Prison Museum and Park. Historical, Educational, Exciting."
Eight miles down U.S. 50, at Canon City, a gray souvenir T-shirt proudly proclaims in red lettering: "Corrections Capital of the World -- Fremont County." 
 While local boosterism can lead to exaggeration, 18 percent of Fremont County's 40,000 residents are involuntary guests of the "Graybar Hotel": 7,150 inmates in 13 prisons, 4 of them Federal and 9 state.
As prisons emerged as a growth industry in the 1990's, this county, nationally known as the home of the magnificent Royal Gorge, illustrates a modern trend -- using prisons as a tool for rural development.
Nationwide, the number of beds in state and Federal penitentiaries increased 43 percent, to 976,000, in the first half of the 1990's, according to a Justice Department survey released in August. And prison employment jumped 31 percent, to 347,320.
A variety of economically pressed small communities, disregarding the stigma traditionally attached to the label "prison town," have opened their doors to prison construction in recent years, ranging from Hobbs, N.M., to Tupper Lake, N.Y., to South Bay, Fla., to Beeville, Tex.
In a measure of prison pride, museums have sprouted up. Every year, about 15,000 tourists troop through Canon City's museum, located below the looming gray walls of Colorado's oldest prison, the Territorial Correctional Facility, built in 1871 and still operating. Just inside the gate, visitors encounter a deactivated, lime-green gas chamber.
Likewise, Leavenworth, Kan., beckons tourists with a billboard: "How about doin' some TIME in Leavenworth?" The local convention and visitors bureau uses a new slogan: "You don't have to be indicted to be invited."
Ruth M. Carter, an 81-year-old who serves as Mayor of Canon City, said, "We have a nice, nonpolluting, recession-proof industry here." With local coal mines closing and ranches limping, the prisons of Fremont County filled the vacuum, employing 3,100 men and women. Here, prisons are simply called "the industry."
For this industry, Canon City has always been a company town. In the 19th century, when Colorado's territorial legislators decided to give the capital to Denver and the university to Boulder, they gave the prison to Canon City. The trend has continued.
The four Federal prisons that opened since 1994 just south of Florence have brought a flood of jobs and new residents. The four adjoining institutions employ slightly more than 1,000 workers, with an average salary of about $30,000. At the maximum-security prison where Mr. McVeigh is incarcerated, there is almost one employee for every inmate.
"We as a community are doing better and better," Mrs. Carter said of the influx of workers, adding, "They are buying and renovating houses that I would have bulldozed."
A former juvenile probation officer, Mrs. Carter recently traveled to Odessa, Tex., to preach the benefits of prisons for ailing rural towns.
"I told them that you are worrying that your grandmothers, your mothers, your daughters are going to be raped and sodomized," said Mrs. Carter, who lives in a cottage, surrounded by her cats, cactus plants and collection of cut crystal. " 'No sirree,' I told them. 'When those people get out of prison, they are getting out of town as fast as they can.' "
Jail breaks have been infrequent in the 125 years that Fremont County has been Colorado's corrections capital. Two convicted killers cut through two fences at a medium-security prison outside Canon City on Wednesday night. One was recaptured on Thursday afternoon, but another remained at large Friday night.
Lulled by a sense of security, the beauty of the region's mountains and canyons, and the Arkansas River Valley's mild winters, Fremont County is attracting retirees.
Here in Florence, where there is now one prisoner for every free citizen, an upscale housing development centered on a golf course is being built just over a knoll from the prison where Mr. McVeigh awaits his appeal of a death sentence for the Oklahoma City bombing.
For esthetics, a forest-green, Colorado lodge-style roof tops off the beige walls of Mr. McVeigh's prison, officially the United States Penitentiary Administrative Maximum Facility, also known as ADX. The highest security prison in the United States, it has replaced a penitentiary in Marion, Ill., which itself replaced Alcatraz decades ago.
For Mr. McVeigh's protection, he lives in a 7-by-12-foot cell, isolated from the 407 other prisoners, who include some of the nation's most violent convicts. Almost two-thirds of the inmates are here because they attacked or tried to attack guards or other prisoners elsewhere.
For security reasons, there is no group dining, exercise, work or religious services. Each inmate has an in-cell shower stall with flood-proof plumbing controlled by guards. The bed, desk, stool and bookcase are made of reinforced concrete, anchored in place. Meals are served through a slot in the cell door.
While some communities might see such a prison as the societal equivalent of a nuclear waste dump, Fremont County fought hard for the $60 million penitentiary complex that holds Mr. McVeigh.
"When I first came here, in 1984, the city was in a depression," said John Lemons, a reporter for the Canon City Daily Record. "There were empty stores on Main Street; unemployment was 11 percent. The R.O.T.C. commander said he had great luck recruiting here."
Residents were so eager to lure a Federal prison that they massed on Canon City's Main Street for the TV cameras of "Good Morning America" and held up a banner reading: "We want a Federal prison! Fremont County, Colo."
To further impress Federal officials, county residents raised $125,000, bought 600 acres in Florence and donated the site to the Federal Bureau of Prisons.
"The Bureau of Prisons was accustomed to having to muscle into a county," said George R. Turner, director of Canon City's Chamber of Commerce. Mr. Turner, who lobbied for even more prison construction here, added: "Here, they found a community that said, 'We want you and we will give you the land.' "
Today, Main Street is bustling and unemployment is 4 percent.
The Federal money has allowed Fremont County to look the other way as state legislators, seeing prisons as a tool for economic development, turn their attention to the state's eastern plains.
As late as 1985, there were no major state prisons outside Fremont County. But in the last decade, Colorado, which jails its citizens at well below the national rate, has seen its prison population triple, to about 13,000 inmates today. By the year 2000, there will be 8,240 prison beds on the eastern plains, more than in all of Fremont County. These new prisons will allow Colorado to bring home the 1,500 inmates it houses out of state.
A mix of state and privately run facilities, the new prisons are giving new life to a far-flung archipelago of aging farming towns: Brush, Burlington, Las Animas, Olney Springs, Ordway, Ramah, Sterling and Walsenburg.
In coming years, Eastern tourists heading to Colorado's booming mountain resort towns will fly over a growing network of what one Denver wag calls "Big Houses on the Prairie."

HEADLINE: Amtrak Is Fighting Off a Walkout

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1

 BODY:
Almost every afternoon for the last week, a group of union leaders, Transportation Department officials, Amtrak managers and members of Amtrak's Board of Directors have gathered in the office of the Transportation Secretary for discussions that lasted into the early morning hours, with occasional breaks for take-out Chinese food.
On the surface, the issue is a contract dispute with 2,300 members of the Brotherhood of Maintenance of Way Employees, who have been without a contract for three years and have been threatening to strike, their newest deadline being 12:01 A.M. next Thursday. That strike would close down the Northeast Corridor from Boston to Washington and hundreds of long-distance trains east of the Mississippi, and could interfere with commuter service in Boston, Chicago, New York, Philadelphia and Washington. 
 But Amtrak is facing four other impasses. One concerns $3.2 billion in capital funds set aside by Congress but not yet released, and the others are operating funds, layoff protections and rules on liability. Amtrak needs to solve this entire set of problems if it is to keep operating over the next few weeks, and get off its current path, which is a financial decline that seems certain to bankrupt it within a year or two.
But some of those disputes go unresolved not because of problems with the beleaguered railroad itself, but because of political debates unrelated to Amtrak.
The House, for example, could not pass an Amtrak bill this week because the railroad was caught in the middle of an argument between conservative Western Republicans and more moderate members from the East on a grazing bill that would make it easier for landowners to sue the Federal Government over changes in land-use regulations. The Westerners, angered at their Eastern colleagues' votes on those bills, opposed the Amtrak legislation.
The situation will take on an added urgency because Congress, which has the power to solve the entire set of problems, plans to adjourn for a holiday recess in a few days, and would not return until the end of January. And late Friday, four influential Senators, including the majority leader, Trent Lott, sent a letter to Amtrak saying that they should expect no increase in financial help.
For a time one week ago it appeared Congress could end the dispute at once, if the union struck and all the issues could be wrapped up in a single emergency bill that would end the walkout. But then the union and the company extended the cooling-off period.
Amtrak's problem, as one union official said, is not just that Amtrak has trouble getting resolution of the group of issues, but that it is "getting them out of sync."
The Senate may try again on Monday to put those issues back in sync, when a new compromise bill may be introduced, and that could create the momentum to get it through the House, too. If the $3.2 billion in capital is released, Amtrak might get permission to raid some of that for day-to-day expenses.
A "blue ribbon" panel of experts named by the House Transportation Committee earlier this year said the railroad was just months from bankruptcy. When the last fiscal year ended on Sept. 30, Amtrak said it had lost $83 million and would probably lose $100 million more this year, borrowing money to meet day-to-day expenses. That is above the subsidies already planned.
And the $100 million assumes no contract increases; if the union gets what was recommended by a Presidential emergency board, and if the other unions settle on the same pattern, as is usually done, it would cost about $136 million.
Amtrak has only about $150 million in credit remaining, and in early December it will meet with its short-term lenders about extending that credit. If the impasse continues on Capitol Hill, the railroad may find itself without credit. Even now, Amtrak executives say, some of the companies with which it does business are growing reluctant to sign long-term contracts.
Amtrak's survival is not at the top of labor's agenda. More important to the unions is what precedent is set in negotiations with the passenger railroad, because they would carry over into the far larger freight segment of the business. In addition, Congress and the White House agree that they want to phase out operating subsidies by the year 2002.
Negotiations with the union have been complicated by a partial change-in-command at the railroad. At the beginning of this past week, four of the nine members of Amtrak's board of directors took over discussions with the union, largely sidelining Amtrak's management; Amtrak officials have been referring all requests for comment to the Transportation Department, where Rodney E. Slater, the Transportation Secretary, who is one of the nine, has been the host of the talks.
On Friday, the directors voted to impose a gag order on themselves, but some people connected to the negotiations have continued to talk, and the outlines of the railroad's problems are clear.
Amtrak, like the White House and the Congress, wants a railroad weaned from operating subsidies. "It's not our choice to be beholden to Congress every year," said one Amtrak official involved in negotiations. The railroad thought it had found a way: a $3.2 billion injection of capital money, set aside by the House and Senate in a tax bill earlier this summer. Amtrak executives believe they can use the money to upgrade service on the Northeast Corridor and elsewhere and take in $150 million extra a year, which they can use around the system.
The money was set aside, but never released by Congress; the House of Representatives, in fact, tried several times last week, but failed to achieve consensus. The reason is that Republicans in Congress say that to prosper, Amtrak must be freed of provisions in Federal law that forbid contracting out if that will cause layoffs, and provide up to six years of severance pay for workers it lays off. In addition, they say, caps should be put on the amount of punitive damages that people injured in train accidents can collect.
The Democrats say the damage caps are unfair and the labor provisions are more important to ideology than economics, because Amtrak rarely lays off employees. A bigger complication, though, is whether the labor provisions would apply to other railroads; that question helped sidetrack the House last week.
The directors, according to people involved in the negotiations, proposed giving the union an increase, contingent on getting more money from Congress. On Friday evening, the four Senators responded with a letter that said, "Amtrak's posture is not only inappropriate, but it is ill-advised and unrealistic."
Ross Capon, executive director of the National Association of Railroad Passengers, said, "I cannot for the life of me understand what the Amtrak board members are thinking."

HEADLINE: Nazi Gold Was Recast And Issued In the U.S.

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1

 BODY:
Of the many bizarre tales seeping from archives around the world in the Nazi gold investigations, few are as strange as this one: In 1950, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York melted down hundreds of gold bars bearing the swastika imprint and recast them with the pristine stamp bearing the words "United States Assay Office."
At the time, according to memorandums released by the Federal Reserve, the United States Treasury knew that much of the gold -- worth about $23 million at the time -- had been looted from the Netherlands and Belgium when those nations were invaded by Germany. 
 These, bars, like most of the gold stolen by Germany during World War II, had been discreetly sold on world markets before May 1945 by the Swiss National Bank, with the proceeds helping to finance Hitler's faltering war effort.
But by 1950, America's main concern was rebuilding Europe, not asking too many questions about the origin of gold that moved from Swiss hands to other nations, and eventually crossed the Atlantic into the Federal Reserve's vaults deep below the streets of lower Manhattan.
Thus, at the request of National City Bank, which later became Citibank, the Treasury Department authorized the "reissue" of the gold -- a polite phrase for purifying it and wiping out the German markings -- so the gold could be used as collateral for a transaction between Spain and the I.T.T. Corporation, the documents show.
"The facts seem pretty plain," said Jack Morris, the spokesman for Citicorp, the parent company of Citibank, after reviewing documents that the Federal Reserve provided to researchers for Swiss television. "This all happened in an era when there wasn't as much introspection about this kind of transaction."
The documents not only provide a stark view of the trafficking of Nazi gold -- first through Swiss banks, then through the central banks of Europe, and finally to the Federal Reserve -- they also raise some haunting questions.
A report issued by the Clinton Administration this year concludes that the Germans' mint often took the gold that German troops stole from the central banks of Europe and melted it together with gold of a more gruesome variety: the tooth-fillings, wedding rings and other jewelry of death- camp victims. Germany's goal was to turn the gold lifted from the mouths and fingers of the victims into a form that that could be traded on world markets, usually courtesy of the Swiss National Bank.
No one knows how widespread the practice was; the fillings and rings were certainly not part of every bar, and may have been part of only a small fraction of the mint's wartime output. But the re-smelting conducted by the United States Assay Office -- an institution that no longer exists -- likely wiped out all traces of what historians delicately call "non-monetary gold" in the bars. In fact, the purpose of the re-smelting was to assure that any gold in the Federal Reserve Bank's vaults met the American Government's standard, a gold "purity" of 99.5% or better.
There is no evidence in the documents indicating that the Federal Reserve or the Treasury suspected in 1950 that any portion of the gold in their possession had come from Holocaust victims. But the issue is important to modern-day diplomacy.
For the last several months, the Clinton Administration has been trying to convince nations around the world to contribute a relatively small amount of gold still under the control of the Tripartite Gold Commission -- set up after the war for returning gold to nations around the world -- to the survivors and heirs of Holocaust victims. The Administration's effort has been led by Stuart Eizenstat, Undersecretary of State for economic and business affairs.
The fact that some unknown portion of the Nazi gold came from Holocaust victims provides the rationale for the contribution. Most other nations with a potential claim on the gold, including many central European countries, have agreed to the donation, though a final accord has not yet been announced.
The Federal Reserve's dealings with the Nazi gold began when Spain needed to put up collateral to buy a telephone system from I.T.T. in the late 1940's, as Europe was being rebuilt under the American assistance program known as the Marshall Plan.
It shipped $31 million in gold bullion to the New York Federal Reserve, gold that is worth about 10 times as much today.
Interoffice correspondence from the Federal Reserve says "some of the gold in the shipment was identified as having been part of the gold looted by the German authorities during the last war and melted and reissued as 1937 Prussian Mint bars."

HEADLINE: THE JIANG VISIT: THE MAIN ISSUE;
U.S. Refrain on Human Rights Strikes No Chords With Jiang

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON 

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 1

 BODY:
At every stop on his tour of the United States this past week, President Jiang Zemin has been urged by American officials and protesters to improve human rights in China.
Almost every time, Mr. Jiang has answered patiently, as if to slow-witted students who do not understand the complexities of his country. The terms he used seemed to reveal an enormous gulf between two different perceptions of human rights, perhaps even wider than previously thought. 
 At a luncheon with prominent Americans in Washington, for instance, Mr. Jiang told his audience that democracy was really a notion that Chinese scholars came up with 2,000 years ago.
Employing a historical analogy he thought his listeners could understand, he added that when Chinese troops took control of Tibet in 1959, it was actually a liberation for Tibetans, akin to the freeing of the slaves during the American Civil War.
Human rights stood out this week as the most insoluble issue in United States-China relations, and as the issue on which Americans most want to see progress. And yet, however the Americans pressed for change, the Chinese resisted. As student-led demonstrators at Tiananmen Square learned when the military crushed their democracy movement in 1989, the rights issue is not one on which China's leaders are willing to yield.
"Jiang Zemin doesn't show any sign of changing," said Xiao Qiang, executive director of Human Rights in China, a New York-based group. "This political system is built on suppressing people's rights."
As someone who monitors and opposes rights violations, Mr. Xiao insists that international pressure can make a difference in the lives of individual political prisoners, because it undeniably has in the past. Yet, he says, he also recognizes that outside pressure is only one of many factors that can bring about change, and that there is no easy way to bridge the divide between the American and Chinese positions.
In seeking the right approach, Mr. Clinton has been criticized by business people for talking about rights too much and by protesters for talking about them too little.
But Mr. Jiang's intransigence this week suggests that any approach by an American President will run into a Chinese wall. Forcing China to change on human rights, as Mr. Jiang's unflappable demeanor seemed to indicate, may be beyond the reach of even the world's most powerful nation.
The reason for Beijing's reluctance to negotiate, China scholars say, is that in a political system relying on the appearance of infallibility and unanimity of a single ruling party, the authorities generally fear that any concession could be interpreted as a sign of weakness by domestic adversaries.
China's leaders today can hardly fail to remember how intense a torrent of criticism they faced in 1989, when the door to protest was opened a crack, and ensuing demonstrations at their peak brought more than a million protesters to Tiananmen Square in Beijing.
Negotiating on other contentious issues, like trade and nuclear proliferation, seems easier for Chinese officials, because the political legitimacy of their regime is not involved.
"Progress in political reform is only made when there is an elite that is at least willing to consider political change," said Harry Harding, a China scholar at George Washington University. "And when there is a pressure for change from key sectors of society, and when the general socioeconomic context is favorable enough that the tensions produced by this process of political ferment don't bring the system down. So it is a very, very tough process."
Because Chinese authorities have in the past been known to release political prisoners at diplomatically opportune times, many activists here hoped that Mr. Jiang would let a prominent dissident out of prison before his visit.
Yet there is always a danger that releasing a political prisoner will draw attention to that person, and highlight the system that incarcerated him or her in the first place.
Human rights dominated the news conference held by Mr. Clinton with Mr. Jiang on Wednesday in Washington, providing a dramatic and unscripted debate at an event that had been expected to stress similarities.
After Mr. Jiang defended the suppression of the Tiananmen protesters as a "necessary" measure in an atmosphere that jeopardized security, Mr. Clinton said that strong nations do best by learning from their differences, not crushing them.
Mr. Jiang answered by arguing that human rights is a relative term: "Concepts on democracy, on human rights and on freedom are relative and specific, and they are to be determined by the specific national situation of different countries."
Mr. Clinton then argued that all the negative news about him and his family had actually made the United States a stronger nation. This conveyed disapproval of China's unwillingness to allow even the slightest criticism of its leaders in its media, which are state-controlled.
Mr. Jiang is adept at talking about his country's best-case scenario and ignoring the rest. Only occasionally does he veer off into the fully improbable, as when he asserted that Chinese philosophers supplanted the Greeks as the original democrats.
In Washington, and in discussions in Philadelphia and New York, Mr. Jiang maintained that human rights conditions in China were improving steadily because average living standards were rising each year.
It is true that personal freedom has expanded greatly in recent years as a result of an economic growth that offers choices. There has also been a gradual easing of party authority over everyday life, which has allowed people to choose their own homes, jobs and marriage partners.
Yet leaders choose not to talk about the way that tolerance of open opposition to the Government has remained virtually unchanged in the 20 years that economic revolution has been under way.

HEADLINE: THE JIANG VISIT: ON THE STREET;
Dueling Demonstrations Greet Jiang in Rowdiest Showing Yet

BYLINE: By CAREY GOLDBERG 

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 1

 BODY:
Encountering the biggest, rowdiest street action of his visit to the United States, President Jiang Zemin of China was met by dueling masses of several thousand demonstrators here today, one side shouting their welcome and the other their demands.
As Mr. Jiang's motorcade arrived at Harvard University, where he delivered a speech, hundreds of Chinese and Chinese-American supporters on the north side of Cambridge Street waved red Chinese flags and the American Stars and Stripes, shouting, "No separation! One China!" Overhead, a corporate plane flew a banner of warm greeting. 
 On the south side of the street, and at the nearby Swedenborg Chapel, hundreds of Asian and non-Asian protesters raised signs accusing China of human rights abuses, beat drums and chanted: "Free China! Free Tibet! Free Taiwan!"
Taken together, the two sides appeared to constitute the largest street gathering at Harvard since the Vietnam War era, the Cambridge police said. They estimated the crowd at near 5,000, and said no arrests had been made.
The anti-Jiang protests, put together by a constellation of more than 25 Harvard and Boston human rights, Tibetan and Taiwanese groups, were meant to serve as the culmination of protest during his eight-day visit to the United States.
What had been less advertised was the large turnout by Chinese and Chinese-Americans in support of Mr. Jiang. The Jiang supporters, organized by the Greater Boston Area Chinese Welcome Committee -- a coalition of four dozen groups, many of them Chinese student associations -- appeared to rival the numbers of their opponents. Many carried identical sets of Chinese and American flags, and their red banners, too, had a uniform, manufactured look that contrasted with the handmade signs of the other side.
"People have to look at how good Chinese-American relations will help the whole world," said Joe Chou, an investment professional from China. "You have to look at the dynamic, not the static situation. How much change has there been in China in the last 10 years?"
"You cannot say," put in Jim Xue, an environmental health researcher also from China, "that overnight we will become a democracy."
Standing near a giant red banner reading "M.I.T. welcomes President Jiang -- Chief Engineer of China," Yaping Liu, president of the North American-Chinese Association for Science and Technology, struck an even warmer note.
"We support collaboration and friendship," he said. "I believe the two countries having a good relationship is very important to the peace of the world and the next century."
Such arguments, however, failed to move the protesters calling for the release of China's political prisoners, for the closing down of its labor camps and for independence for Tibet and Taiwan.
"Jiang Zemin, go home!" they chanted. Some of the Americans chanted "Shame on Harvard!" for playing host to Mr. Jiang.
"I have one thing to say to the people welcoming Jiang Zemin here," said Wang Xizhe, a prominent dissident who served 14 years in jail in China. "Don't follow fascists! Don't follow dictators!"
A Tibetan protester, speaking to the crowd, said: "Do not wave the flag that enslaves you! It's not enough to have a TV set. It's not enough to fill your rice bowl. We must have freedom."
Raymond L. Flynn, the former Boston Mayor who recently ended a four-year stint as the American Ambassador to the Vatican during which he worked extensively on human rights issues, observed the dueling sides of Cambridge Street with a twinge of misgiving.
"The real issue is making sure human rights is a center of our foreign policy and not just an afterthought," he said. "We should all be together sending the same message to Jiang Zemin -- human rights and economic opportunities on the same side of the street."

HEADLINE: Mayors in Largest Cities Coasting to Re-election

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

 BODY:
Buoyed by economic prosperity and declining crime rates, mayors in many of the nation's largest cities appear to be gliding toward easy re-election on Tuesday, a striking turnabout, given that only a decade or so ago some of those cities were considered all but ungovernable.
The most obvious example is New York, where Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is widely favored after one of the quietest contests in a generation. But an examination of the 223 mayoral races around the country, based on interviews and polls, indicates that mayors in cities like Detroit, Cleveland, St. Paul, Buffalo, New Haven and Charlotte, N.C., do not appear threatened by their competition. In Boston, despite the city's storied history of contentious local politics, Mayor Thomas M. Menino is the first incumbent in recorded history to have no opponent at all. 
 The only big cities where incumbents find themselves in hard-fought races are Atlanta, Miami and Minneapolis, but they are still by far the favorites. The two most competitive contests are where the mayor's seat is vacant: Houston and Seattle.
"It's never peaches and cream," said Mr. Menino, a Democrat. "But we're doing much better. People are more optimistic about Boston."
The lack of competition in cities that were battlegrounds as recently as four years ago is the latest demonstration that the relative contentment of voters has penetrated urban areas that in recent decades were bastions of electoral ferment, often over joblessness and racial conflict.
The improved mood among voters transcends party and geography, and may offer a hint of what to expect in 1998, when far more offices will be up for grabs. In the early maneuvering for next year's gubernatorial races, for example, formidable opposition has yet to surface against at least a dozen incumbents.
Another result -- or perhaps cause -- of the absence of roiling campaigns is a lack of voter interest. Democrats and Republicans alike said they expected turnout to be especially low on Tuesday.
The calmness of the campaigns also demonstrates the emergence of an era of nonpartisanship, as Republicans and Democrats are having trouble settling on themes to differentiate themselves. Borrowing a mantra from President Clinton's campaign last year, many mayors are proclaiming, simply, that their cities are on "the right track."
The absence of deep ideological rifts has also been apparent in the two gubernatorial races on Tuesday -- in New Jersey and Virginia -- where candidates often appear alike even as they try to stake out stands on social and economic issues.
"Mayors often did not have control of the situation, but got swept out anyway with frustration over the way the country was going and frustration over the way individual cities were going," said Mayor Paul Helmke of Fort Wayne, Ind., a Republican who is president of the United States Conference of Mayors. "But across the country, mayors have a take-charge attitude and are pretty much ignoring party lines to get things done."
Prof. Alan Altshuler, a specialist in urban affairs at Harvard University's Kennedy School of Government, said people were still not thrilled with the conditions of cities but had learned to expect less. "There was a sense for a long time that things were spiraling out of control and cities were becoming jungles where it was dangerous to do business -- let alone think about living," Professor Altshuler said. "Now, if the economy doesn't seem too far out of whack, people are pretty grateful."
For years, political machines held sway in many large cities. Then in the late 1980's, the trend was for black Democrats to extend their hold on many City Halls. Now, the most noticeable shift is that more pragmatic politicians of all backgrounds are presiding over cities.
Michael N. Danielson, a professor of politics at Princeton University, said declining crime rates had helped incumbents tremendously because voters do not think mayors have much control over the economy yet "perceive that mayors should be able to do something about crime."
Whatever the reason, in city after city the campaign season has been remarkably tame. In Cleveland, which went through a financial default in 1978, Mayor Michael R. White, a Democrat, is expected to have an easy re-election. The central issue posed by his challenger, Helen K. Smith, is not the city's condition but Mr. White's abrasive manner.
Arnold Pinkney, Mr. White's campaign manager, has sought to keep the focus on the condition of the city. "Clevelanders no longer feel bad about themselves," Mr. Pinkney said, adding that property values have risen 43 percent since 1989.
One of the most surprising turns is in Boston, where crime is down, the economy has recovered and the Mayor has no opponent.
"The Mayor is focused on bread-and-butter issues," said Thomas O'Connor, a historian who has chronicled the history of the mayor's office in Boston. "He's filled the potholes. He's cleaned the streets. He's responded a great deal to the neighborhoods rather than the downtown financiers. At least that's the perception."
One of the few lively races is in Minneapolis, where Mayor Sharon Sayles Belton is favored to win a second term. Ms. Sayles Belton is fighting a challenge from Barbara Carlson, a flamboyant independent.
Ms. Carlson, a former City Council member, has been a radio talk show host who is known for frequently broadcasting from her hot tub and inviting guests to join her in the froth. Last year, she wrote "This Broad's Life," a book about her sex life, her bouts with depression and her failed marriage to the state's Governor, Arne Carlson.
Ms. Carlson accused Ms. Sayles Belton, a member of the Democrat-Farmer-Labor Party, of not being aggressive in battling crime and improving education.
At the close of a debate last week, Ms. Sayles Belton shot back, ridiculing the notion that cities like New York had rebounded while Minneapolis had not. "Don't let Barbara Carlson suggest that New York City is better than Minneapolis," the Mayor said. "We know that is not true. Don't let her suggest we are miserable here. It's not true."
Across the river in St. Paul, Mayor Norm Coleman, a Republican, has a huge lead in the polls over his challenger, State Senator Sandy Pappas. Ms. Pappas has accused Mr. Coleman of neglecting neighborhoods in favor of downtown, a serious charge in a city that prides itself on its pleasant residential areas.
But Mr. Coleman has plastered the city with billboards that proclaim, "Optimism is contagious."
In Detroit, Mayor Dennis Archer is also being accused by his opponent, Ed Vaughn, of neglecting the city's neighborhoods. But Mr. Vaughn, a State Representative, does not appear to be making headway.
In Syracuse, Mayor Roy Bernardi, a Republican, is favored to win a second term. Crime is down, the city's finances have improved, and Mr. Bernardi has a large war chest.
"I'm not sure that it's a case that everyone is happy," said Jeffrey Stonecash, a political science professor at Syracuse University. "There is a sense that the economy is doing better, and that makes it harder for the challenger."
Another reason incumbent mayors may be having an easier time is that the rigors of running for office -- and then running a city -- may discourage challengers.
"Who would want to be mayor?" asked Joseph F. Crangle, an ex-Democratic Party chairman in Buffalo, where Mayor Anthony Masiello is considered a shoo-in for a new term. "In Buffalo, it's a dead end. You have to go back to Grover Cleveland to find someone moving beyond it."

SECTION: Section 1; Page 37; Column 2; Metropolitan Desk; Second Front

HEADLINE: Couple Accused of Beating Daughters Tell of Adoption Ordeal

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: PHOENIX

 BODY:
In Moscow one night in May, Richard and Karen Thorne watched one of their newly adopted daughters tuck her doll under the covers, whack it on the head with a shoe, then calmly straighten the covers. It seemed just part of her routine, like a good-night kiss. Only it was a good-night smack.
The Thornes were alarmed. They worried aloud, they recalled, that the girl had learned such behavior by being abused herself. Her birth mother, they had just discovered, had been an alcoholic who left the girl in an orphanage when she was 18 months old. The mother later hanged herself. 
 But of the two 4-year-olds they were adopting, the Thornes say they worried more about the other, the blonde. She had done nothing but scream from the moment she met them in the same orphanage, where she had lived since she was found as a baby on the street.
Still, it hardly mattered. The Thornes, who had gone through years of unsuccessful fertility treatments, were determined to adopt the girls and complete their family.
"It doesn't matter what people tell you or how much you think you know," Mrs. Thorne said. "You expect that Christmas-card photo. You have stars in your eyes."
The Thornes provided such snapshots of their adoption odyssey in their first in-depth interview since they were arrested May 28 and accused of beating and verbally assaulting the girls on a plane ride from Moscow to New York. They have been separated ever since from the girls, who are now in their fifth foster home.
While other adoptive parents tell hair-raising stories of struggling with out-of-control children on the way home, adoption experts know of no other case in which the parents' behavior led to their arrest. And while the Thornes have minimized their actions as a single slap, a Queens judge said last month that they were lying and found them guilty of neglect.
Still, whatever the truth about their behavior on the plane, the Thornes' account offers a vivid picture of their adoption experience and may provide a cautionary tale of a path to parenthood that more and more Americans are choosing.
Russia, which offers white children in a relatively short period of time, has become an increasingly popular source of adoptions for Americans. In 1992, the first year that Russia legalized out-of-country adoptions, Americans adopted 324 Russian children, according to the United States State Department. In the 1997 fiscal year, which ended Sept. 30, Russia provided Americans with 3,800 children, making it the leading source of international adopted children and surpassing China, which provided 3,500 children last year. Children adopted in Russia tend to be older and to have spent some time in institutions.
But the Thornes' story is not just an adoption story. At a time of heightened sensitivity about child abuse, it underscores the ambiguities and uncertainties involved in drawing the line between discipline and abuse in an emotionally freighted situation.
 
A Childless Couple Look to Russia
 Richard Thorne, 49, and Karen Thorne, 43, who were married in 1985, own and operate a distribution warehouse on the cactus-studded outskirts of Phoenix. They drive to work in a white van that they outfitted for their daughters with a television and videocassette recorder. Their van is as immaculate and orderly as their computerized offices, and as pristine as their home, with its white rugs, showcase of ceramic figures and sparkling pool.
The Thornes said that when they gave up on having biological children, they briefly considered adopting in America but turned to international adoption because they worried that an American birth mother could reclaim the child. They sought a child under 3 years old.
Their adoption agency, Hand in Hand of Mesa, Ariz., told them in January of two unrelated 4-year-old girls who needed a home, and the Thornes said they quickly accepted the idea. Mr. Thorne, who has two grown children from a previous marriage, said they also started seeing the advantages of older children. "No diapers," he said.
In addition, they had known several people who had adopted one child from Russia, then gone back for a second. Mr. Thorne said they decided that getting two at once would "be more economical." And they liked that the two girls would have a shared experience.
Soon, pictures of the girls arrived, as did sketchy medical forms. (The New York judge has ordered that the girls' names not be disclosed.) The forms said the girls had brain damage. But like many other adoptive parents, the Thornes dismissed this as a necessary maneuver by the Russian authorities to help get the girls out of the country. A study of Russian medical forms for adoptees, published in September in the Journal of the American Medical Association, found that such forms frequently say neurological problems exist when they do not.
"We were told that if they put on the form that these were healthy, wonderful children, they wouldn't let them go for foreign adoption," Mr. Thorne said.
The Thornes also received a videotape of the girls. "It just showed us that they could run and play like normal kids," Mr. Thorne said.
The day before the Thornes left for Moscow in mid-May, they received a fax from their agency's Moscow coordinator saying one of the girls was fine, but the other "will be reserved and will be harder to adjust and she was not real happy about the adoption." The Thornes thought that meant the girl would be shy.
"We knew there was a possibility there would be problems," Mrs. Thorne said. "But my attitude was, when you give birth to your own children, you don't know what conditions they'll have. We figured that whatever happened, we'd deal with it. We didn't really think there was anything that wouldn't be fixable or treatable."
In mid-May they arrived in Moscow -- like other adoptive parents, with thousands of dollars in crisp bills strapped to their bodies. They were met by an interpreter, who joined them for the 12-hour train trip to the orphanage, in the rural village of Voronezh, about 290 miles southeast of Moscow. Apart from their own luggage and clothes for the girls (they had to guess at their sizes), they lugged a suitcase and cardboard box stuffed with "gifts" that Russian intermediaries instruct prospective parents to bring for the bureaucrats and facilitators who arrange their adoptions.
 
At the Orphanage, Signs of Trouble
As they approached the orphanage, a house in the woods, they heard screaming. Once inside, a little girl with dark hair greeted them chirpily and boasted that she was going to America with them. The screams they heard came from another room and grew louder when the door opened and an orphanage worker emerged with the blonde, who would not let go of the worker.
The Thornes, who went through 35 hours of child-rearing classes in preparation for the adoption, in addition to detailed criminal and financial investigations, are reluctant to criticize those involved in the adoption, as they are still trying to gain custody, but Mrs. Thorne did say: "We should have known that the child wasn't reserved but that she was hysterical."
The Thornes said they were confused and hurt by the girl's rejection. But the orphanage workers told them that if they did not take the girls, they would be sent to another orphanage, where they would get less attention. The workers said the girls would be fine once they got over the shock of leaving the only caregivers they had known.
The parents proceeded with the adoption, completing it in court, processing a score of documents and taking the train back to Moscow with their new family.
But there, the dark-haired girl became aggressive, kicking strangers in an open-air market. The blonde continued to scream. During a routine medical check, which typically focuses more on infectious diseases than a child's psychological state, a Russian doctor in Moscow told them: "It's not too late not to take them."
Mr. Thorne said that things can seem so bad, running away "is a thought that crosses your mind" but that he was repulsed by it. "That's almost like aborting a child," he said.
In the end, the Thornes said, they decided to press on.
"We decided, we had come this far, we're not going to give up on her," Mr. Thorne said.
 "She had absolutely no future in that country," Mrs. Thorne said.
 
By Everyone's Account, A Bad Flight Home
By now they were dreading the flight to New York. The Thornes said they asked Moscow doctors for sedatives for the girls but were refused. They said that they also asked their agency's coordinator for a Russian-speaking escort from Moscow to Arizona, but that they were turned down.
Margot Matthews, the administrative director and social services director of the adoption agency that arranged the Thornes' adoptions, said that the Thornes had indeed been offered an escort, but rejected one.
In any case, the Thornes said, the plane ride was a nightmare. In the Queens courtroom, two flight attendants and three passengers later testified that the couple had abused the girls. The Thornes testified in court that they had each hit the girls once, but not on the face, and that although they were angry, embarrassed and exhausted, they had not crossed the line to abuse. But both said that their discipline had quieted the girls, at least for a while.
Ms. Matthews said that her adoption agency, which has completed more than 2,600 adoptions in 23 years, counsels strongly against corporal punishment. Since the Thorne case, she said, the agency has added to its pre-adoption training a session called "Airplane 101," and also hands out a list of "Suggestions for what to do when your child is going berserk!!" They include using coloring books, headsets and music and feeding the children snacks.
The Thornes said that they had tried most of these techniques. But the best respite came in an unexpected way -- when the blonde poked her hand through the seats and reached for the woman in front of her. The woman took the girl's hand, and the girl stopped crying. They held hands for nearly an hour, never speaking or looking at each other.
"I didn't do anything to pull her away," Mrs. Thorne recalled, embarrassed at relying on a stranger but grateful for the relief.
"I never saw the woman's face," Mrs. Thorne said. "I don't know if she was an old woman, a young woman, Russian, American, French."
Whoever she was, the anonymous woman provided the girl with comfort that the new parents could not. And she illustrated a characteristic often found among children who have been institutionalized for long periods -- an inability to "attach" to their parents and an indiscriminate ease with strangers.
That, said Ms. Matthews, who observed the girls recently, is what she noticed most about them. "They're not attached," she said. "They didn't seek affection from anyone."
And she worried that, even more than most children, these girls would repeatedly test the Thornes' limits. "They are constantly going to be saying, 'How far can I push you before you get rid of me, because everybody else has?' "
 
Five Months Later, An Empty Bedroom
The Thornes are still trying to gain custody of the girls and are due back in Family Court in Queens on Nov. 7. The girls, still under the authority of New York City's Administration for Children's Services, are now here in the foster care of Mrs. Thorne's brother. The Thornes say that physically the girls seem fine, but they are pondering how to develop their relationship with them beyond playmates and gift-bearers to something less artificial.
In their house, the door to the girls' room is kept closed. Inside, the beds are crisply made, the animals precisely arranged, a doll -- one blond, one dark-haired -- on each pillow.
The girls have never spent a night with their new parents since arriving on American soil more than five months ago. But their lives have moved relentlessly forward as they learn English, celebrate birthdays and grow, still orphans.

HEADLINE: Market's Nod To a Rebirth;
In South Bronx Enclave, Rising Property Values And Suburban Living

BYLINE: By BARBARA STEWART 

 BODY:
Sunday afternoon. A middle-aged couple slowly cruise up and down rows of nearly identical ranch houses on streets lined with trees. The wife looks intently at the homes on the right; the husband, at the wheel, scans the left.
Friends had told him about a house for sale on Louis Nine Boulevard. Just what they wanted: three bedrooms on a quarter-acre lot in the right neighborhood. But when he got there, the owner said it had already been sold, for $185,000. 
 "This is where we want to retire," the man said glumly. "Not many of these go up for sale."
The setting could be any modest, well-kept suburb, where a nice little house on a good street would not last long at $185,000.
But this is the South Bronx. Not too many years ago, only the rats and stray dogs were fighting for homes in this neighborhood.
In the 1970's, as most of America and much of the rest of the world came to learn, the South Bronx had become the definition of urban blight, nearly destroyed by poverty, crime and arson. But that picture began to change late in the 1980's. Community advocates and elected officials, pointing to thousands of new homes and intensely loyal and determined residents, declared that the South Bronx had been reborn.
Now the real estate market, a notoriously unsentimental observer, is offering its own verdict on the transformation, or at least one piece of it. And $185,000 for a ranch house in the neighborhood known as Charlotte Gardens qualifies as a ringing endorsement.
Built almost entirely with money from the city between 1983 and 1986, the 89 single-family, suburban-style houses in Charlotte Gardens originally sold for $49,500 to $60,000, depending on the extras. Now the owners -- truck drivers, police dispatchers, secretaries and other people of modest means -- could sell for three to four times what they paid.
"I put the sign up Saturday morning," said Joseph Martinez, the broker for the recently sold house on Louis Nine Boulevard. "I got to my office and I must have had 10 calls on the machine. I've never seen anything like it."
Despite the intense interest, only eight houses have been put up for sale. That is partly by design: to insure community stability, the first owners agreed not to sell their homes for 10 years, and faced heavy penalties if they did.
But even as the time limits expire, residents expect very little turnover. Despite the high demand, few owners appear to be interested in selling.
Rafael Ceballos, who paid $52,600 for his house in 1985, was not fazed when he learned that an identical house across the street had just gone on the market for $200,000, and said he had no desire to sell.
"I live like a king," he said, his eyes trailing over his quarter-acre lot.
Mr. Ceballos's domain was built on a sea of rubble. Today, not only have property values in Charlotte Gardens quintupled, but politicians and urban planners say the very audacity -- and the success -- of the development helped change the attitude of government officials and the public about what was possible in the South Bronx. That, in turn, led to broader renewal efforts and more new homes, raising values all over the South Bronx.
Those rising property values reflect trends in other parts of the city once considered hopeless ghettos. These days, it is hard to find a single-family home in any neighborhood for under $100,000, as changing lending practices help invigorate once depressed housing markets. And in other cities, like Chicago, Cleveland and Houston, new housing is being built to accommodate a demand from people who want to move back downtown from suburbs.
In New York City, more than $2 billion in state and Federal money has been spent since 1986 to build or renovate 30,000 units of housing in the South Bronx, according to the borough president's office. Within a three-mile radius of Charlotte Gardens, there are about 500 new row houses and town houses and at least 800 units in renovated apartment buildings.
"Absent Charlotte Gardens, it's hard to imagine the extensive revitalization happening," said Paul Grogan, president of Local Initiatives Support Corporation, a nonprofit housing investment organization that was the first contributor to the construction of Charlotte Gardens. "Its very strangeness gave a symbolic wallop, a way to reverse the hopelessness, the implicit triage policy of the city."
Today, the neighborhood's appeal to home buyers is clear in some ways but less obvious in others. Despite the years of progress, Charlotte Gardens is still in the poorest Congressional district in the nation. In the South Bronx as a whole, unemployment is still at more than 45 percent, crime and drugs are still constant sources of fear and the public schools are among the city's worst. Most Charlotte Gardens parents pay tuition for parochial school, and residents drive elsewhere -- even as far as New Jersey -- to shop; there are no supermarkets nearby.
Other Bronx neighborhoods, like Pelham Bay and Throgs Neck -- where a house comparable to the one on Louis Nine Boulevard would go for $185,000 or less -- have higher income levels, safer streets, more successful schools and vastly better shopping. For generations, South Bronx residents have moved to those neighborhoods, and then to Westchester County or New Jersey as their incomes rose. But in Charlotte Gardens, the pattern has changed.
"I tried to talk people into buying into homes in another neighborhood," said Mr. Martinez, the real estate agent. "They say no. They want to live there. Don't ask me why. There's no shopping near. You can get mugged going to the subway. It doesn't make sense to pay that kind of money there."
But those comparisons are lost on many residents of Charlotte Gardens, and on others who would like to live there. Many grew up in the South Bronx; in Charlotte Gardens, they can stay close to family and old friends while enjoying the space, the mowed lawns and the relative safety of suburbia. Most important, they say, it is a tightly knit neighborhood with a sense of community.
Adela Villamil, 24, who bid unsuccessfully for the Louis Nine house, said the neighborhood reminded her of the South Bronx the way it was when she was growing up.
"It was beautiful," she said. "The doors were left open. Everybody knew everybody's kids. Neighbors would pick up kids when their mother couldn't, and drive them home and feed them. When somebody was cut, everybody hurt."
Although separate statistics are not available, the residents of Charlotte Gardens say crime is relatively low. Neighborhood watch groups help deter burglaries and street crime, and the 41st Precinct has obliged the homeowners' association with more patrol officers, said Henry Hilton, the group's president.
This tiny island of blue-collar suburbia began in 1983, when the first two model homes were built on a heap of rubble that Jimmy Carter and Ronald Reagan both used as an example of poverty and blight. People came from all over the South Bronx to stare at the ordinary single-family houses on display, and 500 signed up to buy one.
Construction of the development, overseen by the South Bronx Development Organization, faltered many times. When it looked as if the city money would dry up after 10 houses were built, the director of the group, Ed Logue, ordered the remaining foundations to be poured -- 79 at once. "To remove any doubt," he said recently.
For all this effort and anticipation, the ranch houses were unremarkable. They had been manufactured and trucked over in halves. They had the basics -- a kitchen with a dishwasher, a basement, the three bedrooms, a living room and front hallway. Most lots were a quarter of an acre.
Nearly everybody immediately took down the white picket fences Mr. Logue had insisted upon. The fences they eventually put up -- for safety and privacy -- are imaginative and varied: there is ornamental wrought iron, arched brick topped with thick evergreens and high chain-link.
Inside, residents live like suburbanites. On weekends, they care for their lawns. They have tools that people don't use in apartments: power mowers, edge trimmers, fertilizer spreaders, hedge clippers, rakes, shovels and more.
But their neighborhood is subject to intrusion. News reporters and urban planners -- from as near as Manhattan and as far as Sweden, Poland and Japan -- have been coming and asking questions since Charlotte Gardens opened. "Very annoying," said Freemon Rose, a Charlotte Street resident.
Mr. Rose, like others in Charlotte Gardens, has become familiar with famous people. A few years ago, he was irritated, not impressed, by an urgent phone call. President Clinton was nearby, said an aide. He wanted to go into a Charlotte Gardens neighborhood and be photographed with the homeowners.
"I was eating dinner!" Mr. Rose said. "The man should have some consideration!" But he let the aide talk him into meeting the President on the front lawn and shaking hands with him for the photographer.
The winning bidders for the house on Louis Nine Boulevard were Diana and Steven Gonzalez, who paid $185,000 to have everything they have been deprived of in their South Bronx apartments: their own roomy home on a safe, quiet street. Living in Charlotte Gardens, they said, they can raise their three daughters comfortably and be close to relatives.
"It's a whole new community," Diana Gonzalez said. "It's family oriented. Everybody looks out for each other's kids. All the kids go to Catholic schools. I looked in other areas -- they didn't feel like home.
"I won't be worried about my girls. They'll be protected there, definitely. They're not going to be South Bronx kids -- they're going to be Charlotte Gardens kids."

HEADLINE: THE 1997 ELECTIONS: THE AD CAMPAIGN;
Money Sends Messages That Messinger Couldn't

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

 BODY:
The advertisement opens with a scene of Ruth W. Messinger at a mayoral debate, proclaiming that the election is "not about the past." An announcer then challenges that assertion, sifting through Ms. Messinger's past to evoke images of one incident when she marched on behalf of a Washington Heights drug dealer who was killed by a police officer, and another in which she allegedly gave a party for a killer of an Attica prison guard.
The unusually pointed advertisement was produced for the campaign of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani but never appeared on television. It was shelved by Mr. Giuliani's campaign aides, who felt that such a fierce attack on the Democratic mayoral contender would, as one Giuliani associate said, seem superfluous, and perhaps produce a backlash. 
 There are another dozen or so advertisements sitting around Ms. Messinger's headquarters. These nearly finished 30-second spots deal with education, the city's economy and homelessness, contrasting Ms. Messinger's views with what she has repeatedly called the Republican Mayor's weaknesses in those areas.
These advertisements will not be seen by the public either, but for a different reason: the Messinger campaign never had the money to put them on television.
These two contrasting scenes illustrate a great disparity that has emerged between Ms. Messinger and Mr. Giuliani in these final days of the campaign: their television advertising efforts. In an era when commercials can turn an election, Mr. Giuliani's television campaign has dwarfed Ms. Messinger's on every level: the number of advertisements produced, the television time bought and, in the view of political consultants not involved with either campaign, the quality of the effort.
There is no other area of the campaign in which Mr. Giuliani's fund-raising efforts have produced such a clear advantage. He bought a total of $4.6 million in television time, more than twice what Ms. Messinger was able to buy. In the last week alone, Mr. Giuliani bought about $900,000 in time, or three times as much as Ms. Messinger. It was an extraordinary one-week purchase, a point that was made by Ms. Messinger's aides in explaining what they themselves called their own relatively feeble advertising effort.
"It's really easy to look good when you're outspending your opponent two and a half, three and a half to one," said Jim Andrews, Ms. Messinger's senior campaign consultant.
Mr. Giuliani's television consultant, Adam Goodman, released nearly 40 television advertisements. There were ads in English and in Spanish. "Necesito tu ayuda y tu voto," Mr. Giuliani says in one. "Gracias." ("I need your help and your vote. Thank you.")
There were ads that extolled Mr. Giuliani and attacked Ms. Messinger. There were ads showing Mr. Giuliani as funny, ads that compared Mr. Giuliani to Fiorello H. La Guardia and ads that showed Mr. Giuliani being in control. There were ads tailored to each of the five boroughs, including one, broadcast only on Staten Island, in which Borough President Guy V. Molinari warned that Ms. Messinger, the Manhattan Borough President, would bring a Manhattan bias to City Hall if she won.
In an indication of the confidence among Mr. Giuliani's advisers, not one citywide ad attacking Ms. Messinger by name has run in nearly a month, by their count. "The competitive nature of the campaign changed from competing against Ruth Messinger to campaigning for a vote of confidence for the future," Mr. Goodman said.
By contrast, Ms. Messinger had released a total of seven ads by yesterday. Most of them focused on her central campaign theme, which is that Mr. Giuliani has neglected the public schools. Mr. Andrews argued that those ads helped to account for rising public concern about how Mr. Giuliani had handled the schools.
Ms. Messinger used the final weekend to lay out a new theme -- voters were urged to send Mr. Giuliani a "messenger" -- and to present a humorous attack on Mr. Giuliani's personality and political ambitions.
"Is power going to Rudy Giuliani's head?" a narrator inquires, as a photograph of the Mayor's head inflates until it flies off over New York City. "It's time to bring Rudy Giuliani back to earth."
Mr. Andrews, Ms. Messinger's senior campaign consultant, in linking the advertising difficulties to a lack of money, denounced Mr. Giuliani for what he called illegal fund-raising efforts. Mr. Andrews was referring to contributions that Mr. Giuliani was forced to return by the Campaign Finance Board, which ruled them illegal, as well as to city advertisements that extolled the strengths of New York and that Ms. Messinger said were intended to lift Mr. Giuliani's electoral prospects.
"They had a great early jump-start funded illegally by the taxpayers and by illegal contributions," Mr. Andrews said. "Within all this, we've tried to make the best argument that we could. She had a lot of great ads about homelessness and unemployment and other things that we could never afford to run."
But political consultants not associated with Ms. Messinger's campaign said that even given the restraints, Ms. Messinger had waged an undistinguished campaign. By contrast, they described Mr. Goodman's effort for Mr. Giuliani as highly effective, if at times somewhat overly aggressive. (The campaign kept broadcasting advertisements quoting Ms. Messinger as saying pornography stores added character to neighborhoods, even though she denied saying it and they couldn't prove she did.)
"Ruth has not connected," said Henry A. Sheinkopf, a Democratic consultant. "The spots do not have an emotional context to them. The Giuliani spots have an emotional core to them that talks directly to New Yorkers."
Ms. Messinger's media consultant, Mandy Grunwald, declined to discuss any aspect of her advertising campaign. "I don't care to talk about it," Ms. Grunwald said.
Ms. Messinger's advisers made a few important tactical calls that outside political analysts described as questionable. First, her advertisements did not begin until late August, whereas Mr. Giuliani's began in June. Mr. Andrews attributed the late start to money, but Mr. Goodman said that even a modest early campaign might have drawn attention, and thus contributions, to Ms. Messinger's effort.
The second was that Ms. Messinger decided to use one of her few commercials to respond directly to Mr. Giuliani's pornography ad. One result, several Democrats noted, was that rather than trying to force Mr. Giuliani to discuss her own criticisms of his tenure, she ended up giving even further circulation to the original charges about pornography.
Mr. Goodman's advertising campaign for Mr. Giuliani had three major goals: to pre-empt criticism of Mr. Giuliani's handling of the public schools before Ms. Messinger could begin attacking him on it, to try to present Mr. Giuliani as a more likable figure and to undercut Ms. Messinger by attacking her record before she had a chance to present her own image to the public.
