HEADLINE: THE 1997 ELECTIONS: THE CANDIDATES;
RAIN AND APATHY DOG MAYORAL RACE AS IT WINDS DOWN

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

 BODY:
Confronting pelting rain, bursts of wind and often small crowds, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Ruth W. Messinger headed into the final weekend of their campaign yesterday, as Mr. Giuliani again played what he considers his political trump card -- the latest decrease in crime -- while Ms. Messinger warned that things were not as good as they seemed.
From shopping malls to radio shows, from barber shops to diners, Ms. Messinger and Mr. Giuliani -- adjusting their schedules to accommodate the inclement weather along the way -- began a vigorous final 72 hours of campaigning, with both candidates asking voters to ignore polls that showed Mr. Giuliani heading for a strong victory and to turn out to vote on Tuesday, Election Day. 
 Mr. Giuliani's comfortable position is echoed in many large cities around the nation, where economic prosperity and declining crime rates have given incumbents a strong edge in Tuesday's elections. Page 24.
The Republican Mayor mixed government and politics throughout the day, turning from a news conference one moment, in which he and his Police Commissioner announced the latest monthly crime statistics (homicides: down), to a ribbon-cutting for the wet, white, refurbished school bus he will use for these final days of the race.
Standing across the street from Grand Central Terminal, first for the news conference and then, a camera flash later, for the ribbon-cutting, the Mayor proclaimed that his 48-hour bus tour would "try and create a new spirit for, hopefully, a new administration -- a spirit of outreach to everybody in the city.
"There are still people that feel left out," Mr. Giuliani said. "There are still people that feel that they are not included. And I want to say to them that I am going to dedicate the next four years -- if you give me another four years -- to try to make everyone feel that they are part of the success, and possibilities of success, in the city."
Ms. Messinger, the Manhattan Borough President, went to Brooklyn, where rain forced her to cancel both a motorcade through Bedford-Stuyvesant and a walking tour of Sunset Park. Stymied by the weather, the Democratic candidate went indoors in search of a crowd, stopping first at Junior's Restaurant on Flatbush Avenue, where she ordered a bacon and Swiss cheese omelet with peppermint tea, then proceeding to a Pathmark supermarket.
Feisty and undeterred, she presented herself as a "tough mother," and said that the crime reductions being trumpeted by her opponent across town were not enough to justify re-electing him.
"I think this city has to worry about things besides crime and I'm telling New Yorkers, I've told them what I will do -- to improve the schools, to open up after-school programs, to grow the economy and create jobs," Ms. Messinger said.
"I believe that the greatest days of this city are still ahead of us," Ms. Messinger told 200 women at a labor breakfast in Manhattan. "I think we need a mayor who will say, 'Education, jobs, police brutality, access to health care, the rights of workers, the need of working people to have a decent income and be able to meet their families' needs -- those are the issues that this city has to address in the 21st century.' I'm ready to address them."
Despite efforts by both candidates to drum up enthusiasm, there often was not much of it evident on the wet streets of New York yesterday or even, for that matter, in the warm and dry headquarters of the nominees. A series of public and private polls have suggested that Mr. Giuliani is heading for re-election by a wide margin, which would make him the first Republican Mayor to win a second term since Fiorello H. La Guardia in 1937.
It was a projection that neither camp was challenging during the final hours of this campaign. There was, accordingly, a sense of going through the motions yesterday, of a campaign rolling toward an inevitable conclusion in one of the least suspenseful mayoral races in a generation.
With the end almost at hand, both candidates found themselves returning to what had been the overriding themes of their campaigns.
For the Mayor it was crime, as he produced statistics for both October and the relatively crime-free night of Halloween. He was again reminding voters of the issue that has most accounted for the political success of Mr. Giuliani, the city's first Republican Mayor since John V. Lindsay. "I think, without question, October of 1997 was the safest October in 32 years," the Mayor proclaimed to rolling television cameras and scribbling reporters.
Ms. Messinger countered by saying that despite the good news on crime, there were other problems that Mr. Giuliani had neglected.
"I think it's wonderful that the city is safer," she said. "Every single person in the city wants to see the crime rate continue to go down, and I can promise every New Yorker that as their mayor, I will continue all the good work that's been done to keep the crime rate down.
"I think as we go into the 21st century, we have to pay attention to the problems we haven't solved yet," she said, ticking off reports of increased violence at homes and in schools.
Both candidates did what they could, in the face of challenges both political and meteorological, to inject some energy into what has largely been a desultory campaign. Mr. Giuliani warned against complacency that might lead his supporters not to bother to turn out on Tuesday.
"Make sure that you vote -- O.K.!" Mr. Giuliani bellowed over a public-address system at a Waldbaum's supermarket in Lindenwood, Queens. "We need your help! We need your support! Have a wonderful day!"
For some of the day, Mr. Giuliani, wearing a dark-blue, pin-striped Yankees rain slicker, campaigned from the open back of his bus -- in effect, a street-bound version of a whistle-stop train -- shouting in the rain to motorists and passers-by.
As the bus lurched through the city, Mr. Giuliani waved with one hand and in the other held a cell phone, which he used to conduct an interview. A cabdriver in Manhattan honked hello, and Mr. Giuliani leaned over the railing of his bus. "So you'll vote for me?" the Mayor inquired.
"Yes, definitely."
Mr. Giuliani did not begin explicitly to campaign for re-election until two weeks ago. But he was relaxed and animated inside his campaign bus, which was stocked with a gourmet food basket from the Vinegar Factory and a jack-o'-lantern brimming with candy corn. He bounced around the bus, at one point humming the theme from "Rocky."
Ms. Messinger was forced to do some fast rescheduling because of the rain, searching for venues from which to make her pitch to voters. At the Pathmark in Bedford-Stuyvesant, in a part of the city that is as solidly Democratic as any place, she encountered a mostly, though not uniformly, enthusiastic reception. At the checkout line, Mina Opont, 47, a Democrat, told Ms. Messinger that she found the choice in the election a "tough thing."
"When I put my key in the door, I don't have to look around me," Ms. Opont said. "I used to have to look around me."
Ms. Messinger, who by now is familiar with such encounters, responded: "I know how to be tough on crime. I also know how to be tough on police brutality. I also know kids need a place to go after school."
She received a hearty welcome when, with Bronx Borough President Fernando Ferrer at her side, she spoke for 10 minutes in unbroken if slow Spanish at a rally in the Bronx. And Ms. Messinger found some respite from the rain as she attended the gala opening of a barbershop owned by the salsa star Tito Nieves.
She climbed into a barber chair and let one of the stylists, Mike Perez, blow-dry and comb her hair, as newspaper photographers snapped to attention.

HEADLINE: President Spends a Weekend With Big Donors

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: AMELIA ISLAND, Fla., Nov. 1

 BODY:
Bill Clinton may think he is underappreciated. But he is not undervalued.
More than 50 people shelled out $50,000 each to spend the weekend schmoozing with him and with Vice President Al Gore here at one of the nation's premiere oceanfront resorts. The money, more than $2.5 million, is to help bail the Democratic National Committee out of debt. 
 The party is reeling from that debt, although the $3 million it has on hand from Mr. Clinton's prolific fund-raising reduces it to about $15 million.
The amount is an intolerable burden for the Democrats, who are trying to recapture the House in 1998. And Mr. Clinton does not want to pass the debt on to the man he sees as his heir, Mr. Gore.
The weekend event here was believed to be the first of its kind, in which a sitting President and Vice President lent themselves out not just for a half-hour over coffee or an hour at lunch but for a full weekend, including two nights in the Ritz-Carlton Hotel, where the Presidential suite goes for $1,500 a night.
The weekend was also noteworthy for the price of admission, a sum that the public-interest group Common Cause skewered as being larger than the annual income of most Americans.
"The event represents the buying and selling of access to the highest officials of the land and is an affront to average Americans," said Ann McBride, president of Common Cause, which is based in Washington.
But the President was blunt on Friday night about why cash is important. "Usually at the end of these campaigns," he told contributors in Boca Raton, where he raised $600,000 at dinner, "the party with the most money wins."
Today the President joined in three panel discussions with about two dozen donors each. He then took to the emerald fairways on the island's white-sand beaches, famous for the challenge presented by the breeze off the ocean.
Mr. Gore was due for a dinner and a songfest by Art Garfunkel. The Vice President is to join discussions on Sunday while Mr. Clinton campaigns in New York and New Jersey for Democratic candidates.
What donors did not count on was that the President would be unable to speak, having lost his voice to allergies and excessive use. But the point of this retreat for high-rollers was not so much to hear the President as for the President to hear them.
"Your command of the details is remarkable," George Munoz, president and chief executive officer of the Overseas Private Investment Corporation, told the President after a discussion on the economy.
Bob Lynch, president and chief executive officer of Americans for the Arts, told Mr. Clinton at the end of a workshop that his policy analysis had been useful. And at a workshop on the arts with Mr. Clinton, Skeets Friedkin, wife of Monte Friedkin, a Florida industrialist and major Democratic contributor (he recently pledged $250,000), said: "I like to use a different part of my brain, instead of just my pocketbook."
Party officials assured the donors all weekend that it was their brains the party was after.
"People, donors and citizens alike, like to be respected for what they have to offer intellectually," Steven Grossman, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, said in an interview.
The Democrats know that events like this expose them to charges of brazenness and hypocrisy. But the debt is so steep, money-givers said, that the President must risk the criticism and intense scrutiny that he and his party have received in the Congress and the press for their fund-raising practices.
"It's total desperation," said one top Democratic fund-raiser who spoke on the condition of anonymity. "The donors are so traumatized that no one wants to give to the party, and the party has high expenses. If this were a commercial enterprise, they would have been bankrupt a long time ago."
The party line here is that the Republicans undertook a deliberate strategy to bankrupt the Democrats and succeeded by unfairly tying them up in knots over their 1996 fund-raising practices.
Gov. Roy Romer of Colorado, general chairman of the Democratic National Committee, said that half of the party's debt resulted from defending itself in Congressional investigations and that Democrats were not going to take it anymore.
In a thundering speech at lunch today, he accused Republicans of reveling in an "orgasm of righteousness" over their portrayal of Democrats as sleazy. "We're going to resist any strategy that takes the resources of this party and diverts them to that kind of a false charge," Mr. Romer said.
Mr. Romer aggressively asserted that there was nothing unseemly about the weekend's $50,000 price and said that by allowing reporters into the events, this was "the most open political fund-raiser America's ever had." (Mr. Clinton still had a chance to talk privately with donors, in casual conversations after the panels and out on the golf course.)
Many of the big donors, like Bill Titelman, a lawyer from Harrisburg, Pa., said they expected nothing in exchange for their money. "I came to express by my physical presence my support for them," Mr. Titelman said of the President and Vice President. "I didn't need this," he said, gesturing to a plate of grilled chicken, "to give." Mr. Clinton appears ever bolder in his fund-raising, spending more time with wealthy donors and seeking their money while calling for an end to a system he exploits. He seems eager to erase not only the debt but any suggestion that it is his legacy.
Speaking on Friday to 20 people who paid about $10,000 each to have lunch with him in West Palm Beach, he suggested that the party should appreciate him for improving its image.
"In the '98 elections going forward," he said, "people will not be able to paint this sort of gnarled, twisted picture of Democrats anymore. You can't say we're weak on foreign policy and national defense. You can't say we can't be trusted to manage the economy. You can't say we're spending the country blind."
He bristled at the notion that he had merely co-opted Republican policies and passed them off as his own. He told the contributors that on Thursday night he happened to be re-reading an article he wrote in 1988 and it "basically sounds like the speeches I'm giving today."
But he also admitted today that he had "completely failed" to sell Americans on one important part of his economic program, a trade bill that Congress is voting on next week.
"When my voice is working, sometimes I get credit for being a reasonably effective communicator," the President said to 27 executives gathered in a small meeting room.
"According to every public opinion survey, I have completely failed to convince a substantial majority of American people of the importance of trade to our economic development," he said.
Tonight, Mr. Clinton told the contributors that the political debate in America had become stale and meaningless, but he claimed credit for changing its nature. "I very much hope that the simplistic anti-government reactionary approach had its last gasp in the Republican Congressional victory of 1994," he said.

HEADLINE: China's New Generation Wants to Join the World;
Lost American Jobs

 BODY:

To the Editor:
An Oct. 29 Business Day article suggests that American businesses can "shrug off" the tumult in Asian currencies and stocks. However, American labor may not be so lucky, as it faces the potential loss of even more low-skilled manufacturing jobs as a result. 
 For a decade, Asia's tigers have been governed by the dictum of former Prime Minister Lee Kwan Yew of Singapore: Asians need discipline, not democracy. American businesses happily took advantage of this ethos -- low wages with militaries used to break strikes in places like Malaysia, Thailand and Indonesia.
The Clinton Administration's strategy of "commercial diplomacy" was supposed to bring on stream tens of thousands of good jobs for Americans, resulting from huge infrastructure projects in the region. These projects are now on hold indefinitely. Can't policy makers resist the importunings of corporations and their antidemocratic allies?
 
JEFF BALLINGER
Alpine, N.J., Oct. 29, 1997
 
The writer is director of Press for Change, a labor rights group.

HEADLINE: Milestones and Memories;
Creative thinkers, innovative ideas and movements that changed education in this century.

BYLINE: BY JACK BEGG 

 BODY:
1901: The Indiana Supreme Court upholds the constitutionality of Indiana's compulsory school attendance laws. By 1918, all the states will have passed some kind of compulsory school attendance legislation.
 
Jan. 12, 1903: The General Education Board, a foundation for the promotion of education, is incorporated. Endowed by John D. Rockefeller, the oil executive, with $150 million, it will become the world's most powerful educational foundation.
 
Oct. 3, 1904: In Daytona, Fla., Mary McLeod Bethune, a teacher, founds the Daytona Educational and Industrial Institute, a school for black girls. In 1923, the school will merge with the Cookman Institute; it will be renamed the Bethune-Cookman College in 1929. In 1936, Bethune will join the National Youth Administration, a Government agency, and will become an influential adviser to President Franklin D. Roosevelt on race relations.
 
Oct. 10, 1905: President Theodore Roosevelt summons the athletic advisers of Harvard. Princeton and Yale to the White House and tells them something must be done to reform the game of football. The Intercollegiate Athletic Association is formed to draft new rules. In 1910, it changes its name to the National Collegiate Athletic Association, or N.C.A.A.
 
1912: The first Montessori school in the United States is opened in Tarrytown, N.Y., by Anne George, a teacher, translator and former student of the educator Maria Montesori.
 
Jan. 1, 1916: The American Association of University Professors accepts a report by its Committee on Academic Freedom recommending that certain measures be adopted by every university to render the teaching profession more attractive to "men of high ability." The report defined the present-day system of tenure, which existed then but was haphazard and much abused.
 
1920: John J. Mahoney, the Massachusetts Supervisor of Americanization, publishes a training manual for teachers on how to instruct the immigant child in American ways.
 
PUB-DATE: July 21, 1925:
 
1925: Herbert Hoover, then Secretary of Commerce, becomes chairman of the newly formed National Research Endownment "to increase and strengthen American contribution to the mathematical, physical and biological sciences."
 
1926: The College Entrance Examination Board, created in 1900 to supply standardized entrance exams to its member colleges, administers the first Scholastic Aptitude Test.
 
1930: Scott, Foresman & Company, a publisher, introduces the Dick and Jane books, a series of reading primers that will dominate the textbook market for decades.
 
PUB-DATE: June 14, 1943:
 
june 22, 1944: President Roosevelt signs the Servicemen's Readjustment Act, popularly known as the G.I. Bill, which provides funds for American veterans to pursue higher education.
 
Aug. 1, 1946: The Fulbright Act becomes law Sponsored by Senator J. William Fulbright, Democrat of Arkansas, it grants scholarships to American students for study abroad and to foreign students for study in the United States.
 
1951: As fears grow of a nuclear attack, school districts from New York City to Redwood, Calif., give children "identification necklaces" from The Bead Chain Manufacturing Company, a supplier of Army dog tags.
 
PUB-DATE: May 17, 1954:
 
1955: Rudolf Flesch, an authority on literacy, publishes "Why Johnny Can't Read," which advocates teaching reading by the sounds of letters, or phonics, rather than by whole words. The book becomes a best seller and has great impact on the teaching of reading.
 
October 1955: The Belaire School of San Angelo, Tex., opens. It is the first air-conditioned public elementary school in the country.
 
Sept. 25, 1957: Led by soldiers of the 101st Airborne Division, nine black students march up the steps of Central High School in Little Rock, Ark., and enroll in classes. The decision to use Federal troops to enforce integration was made by President Eisenhower after Governor Orval Faubus ordered the National Guard to block the entrance to the school. Federal marshals and soldiers will also be required to insure the desegregation of the University of Mississippi in 1962 and the University of Alabama in 1963.
 
Oct. 4, 1957: The Soviet Union launches Sputnik, spurring schools throughout the United States to require more math and science courses.
 
Jan. 30, 1961: In his first State of the Union message. President John F. Kennedy declares that Federal grants for education can no longer be delayed because "our classrooms contain 2 million more children than they properly have room for, taught by 90,000 teachers not properly qualified to teach."
 
PUB-DATE: June 17, 1963:
 
Dec. 3, 1964: Mario Savio, leader of the Free Speech Movement, and 800 other students of the University of California at Berkeley are arrested during a sit-in at the campus administration building. The sit-in was the climax of three months of protest over rules limiting the activities of civil rights groups and other political organizations on campus.
 
PUB-DATE: April 11, 1965:
 
PUB-DATE: May 18, 1965:
 
Nov. 8, 1965: The Higher Education Act becomes law, providing financial assistance to college students in the form of Basic Educational Opportunity Grants, renamed Pell Frants in 1980 to honor Senator Caliborne Pell, longtime chairman of the Senate education subcommittee. It also established Guaranteed Student Loans, renamed Stafford Loans in 1988 for Senator Robert Stafford, a fellow committee member.
 
PUB-DATE: April 20, 1969:
 
PUB-DATE: May 4, 1970:
 
PUB-DATE: April 20, 1971:
 
PUB-DATE: June 8, 1972:
 
June, 1978: Hanna Holborn Gray is named president of the University of Chicago, the first woman to head a major American research university.
 
Oct. 17, 1979: A bill creating the Department of Education, the 13th cabinet-level agency, is signed by President Jimmy Carter.
 
PUB-DATE: June 15, 1982:
 
PUB-DATE: April 26, 1983:
 
Jan. 28, 1986: The space shuttle Challenger explodes 74 seconds after liftoff from Cape Canaveral, Fla., killing all seven astronauts aboard, including Christa McAuliffe, a New Hampshire school-teacher. The highlight of the mission was to have been a broadcast from space of two lessons by McAuliffe to millions of students around the country.
 
PUB-DATE: March 21, 1989:
 
Sept. 27, 1989: President George Bush convenes of National Education Summit on Charlottesville, Va., and calls for national curriculum standards in public schools.
 
PUB-DATE: March 5, 1990:
 
Sept. 4, 1990: State vouchers covering tuition enable 400 low-income Milwaukee, Wis., schoolchildren to begin attending private schools.
 
May 1991: Minnesota becomes the first state to pass legislation permitting groups of teachers and parents to set up charter public schools, institutions virtually free of school district control.
 
PUB-DATE: May 16, 1991:
 
PUB-DATE: July 6, 1992:
 
Sept. 1, 1992: A private company, Educational Alternatives Inc., assumes operation of nine Baltimore public schools under a five-year contract. It is cancelled in 1995.
 
PUB-DATE: March 1, 1993:
 
Dec. 17, 1993: Walter Annenberg announces a gift of $500 million to aid reform in public schools.
 
June 1995: The Illinois State Legislature passes a bill giving the Mayor of Chicago, Richard M. Danley, complete control of the nation's third-largest school system, one of its most troubled.
 
Jan. 23, 1996: In his State of the Union address, President Clinton declares that the Administration is working with the telecommunications industry "to connect every classroom in the entire United States to the Internet by the year 2000."
 
Dec. 18, 1996: The Oakland, Calif., School Board adopts a resolution officially recognizing black English, or Ebonics, as a distinct language. After sparking nationwide debate, the decision is ultimately reversed.
 
Feb. 10, 1997: The New York State Board of Regents removes 18 of the 19 trustees of Adelphi University for misconduct and failure to oversee the compensation of President Peter Diamandopoulos - one of the highest-paid college presidents in the nation. New trustees soon remove Mr. Diamndopoulos from his post.
 
PUB-DATE: April 5, 1997:

SECTION: Section 3; Page 14; Column 4; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1029 words

HEADLINE: SPENDING IT;
Helping a Few Taxpayers At the Expense of Many?

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
REPUBLICAN Congressional leaders say their bill to overhaul the Internal Revenue Service, which President Clinton now supports, will protect people from abuse by the tax agency. But as tax practitioners take a close look at the bill, they see changes very different from what the politicians see.
The Taxpayer Bill of Rights 3, as House Republicans call the measure, also seeks to overhaul the governance of the I.R.S. Politicians of both parties are vying to show their commitment to helping individual taxpayers in disputes over taxes. 
 Tax experts across the country say the practical benefits of the bill will be minor, with a big chunk of the expected $2.6 billion in reduced taxes over five years going to businesses. Indeed, only a tiny number of people, perhaps just a few hundred, will benefit -- and then at the expense of added burdens for perhaps a million taxpayers a year.
"Most of the bill's provisions are very limited and will not have a significant impact on most taxpayers," said Stuart E. Seigel, a tax partner at Arnold & Porter and former chief counsel of the I.R.S.
The centerpiece of the bill is a shift in the legal burden of proof in tax disputes, so that taxpayers are presumed to be in the right and the I.R.S. must show otherwise. But tax litigators say that change will directly benefit no more than 28,000 taxpayers annually, and perhaps only a few hundred, out of the 115 million people who file individual income tax returns.
The burden will shift only in civil tax disputes, and only in disputes about facts and not those about the law. And the shift would occur only after the disputes get into court and only if the taxpayer has fully cooperated with the I.R.S. It applies to individuals, partnerships worth less than $4 million and corporations worth less than $7 million.
Tax litigators and former I.R.S. lawyers say about one million taxpayers a year will face added burdens because the I.R.S. will demand more documents during audits. That way, it will be ready to bear the burden of proof in cases that end up in court.
"What we are engaged in here is symbolism, not substance," said Edward Zelinsky, a visiting professor of law at Columbia University who has written influential commentaries on tax policy. "I would be impressed that something substantial was being done if the bill was accompanied by investments in training and technology that will make the I.R.S. operate in a modern way."
Mr. Siegel, the former I.R.S. chief counsel, said "the well-intentioned provision to shift the burden of proof" would expand litigation, with judges conducting "mini-trials over whether you cooperated fully."
Elliott H. Kajan, a tax litigator in Beverly Hills, Calif., said the shift would affect only a few Tax Court cases, such as when the only evidence of a deduction is the taxpayer's word. An example would be when a fire destroys a receipt for cash given to a charity whose records are also lost.
Under current law, taxpayers lose such cases, he said, but "the taxpayer will have a better shot in court -- if they are a credible witness."
Kenneth Kies, chief of staff of the Joint Committee on Taxation, said the provision's real significance would be in helping taxpayers negotiate better terms with the I.R.S. before going to court, a change he estimated would result in $795 million less tax revenue over the next five years.
Enrolled agents -- tax preparers who are authorized to represent taxpayers before the I.R.S. -- say they do not believe that most I.R.S. audits will become more onerous because of the shift in burden.
"Shifting the burden of proof is a very good development at least in having taxpayers feel that the system is not rigged against them," said Joseph Lane of Menlo Park, Calif., the head of the government affairs committee of the National Association of Enrolled Agents.
The most significant feature of the bill, tax experts agreed, helps divorced spouses -- mainly women -- who get a tax bill for income their spouse hid during their marriage or from deductions their spouse knew to be illegal. "Innocent spouses," as they are known, could get off the hook for most taxes owed on joint returns.
Another significant provision extends the lawyer-client privilege to accountants and enrolled agents. Supporters say the provision grants moderate- and low-income people the same advantages as those who can afford tax lawyers.
A NUMBER of experts said they were concerned about a provision restricting the use of so-called economic reality audits to instances where the I.R.S. has "a reasonable indication" to suspect unreported income.
In an economic reality audit, I.R.S. agents try to show that an individual cannot support his way of life with the income shown on his tax return -- for example, a taxpayer with a mansion and yacht whose tax return lists a modest income.
Donald C. Alexander, who headed the I.R.S. during the Nixon Administration, said he was troubled that the provision might inhibit aggressive enforcement against tax evaders, who, he said, drive up the burden on honest taxpayers.
"This should be called the mobsters and drug dealers tax relief act of 1997," agreed Lee A. Sheppard, a tax lawyer who critiques tax law and court decisions for Tax Notes, the policy magazine.
Some experts also expressed concern about a provision allowing taxpayers to collect up to $100,000 in damages when they win a tax dispute and prove negligence by the I.R.S.
Jeff Trinca, who was chief of staff for the National Commission on Restructuring the I.R.S., said that he favors damage awards, but that " 'negligence' is an incredibly low standard."
"I think the right answer is to require proof of outrageous or purposeful acts," he said.
Others pointed with concern to a provision inserted at the behest of restaurant owners. The bill prohibits the I.R.S. from threatening an audit of a restaurant or its owners for their refusal to sign an agreement requiring food servers to report all of their income from tips. The I.R.S. says its studies show that under-reporting of income is a big problem in all cash businesses -- and is rampant among waiters and bartenders.

CORRECTION-DATE: November 9, 1997, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about legislation to overhaul the Internal Revenue Service misstated the proposal's scope. Tax experts expect that only a few hundred taxpayers a year will benefit from provisions shifting the burden of proof in Tax Court cases to the Government, but larger numbers stand to benefit from other aspects of the proposal. A letter from Bill Archer, the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, appears today on page 44.

HEADLINE: Looking Back At Forward Thinkers

BYLINE: BY WILLIAM H. HONAN; William H. Honan writes about higher education for The New York Times.

 BODY:
Education is at the top of almost everyone's agenda these days.
President Clinton, who rarely misses an opportunity to talk about what he calls "my No. 1 priority for the next four years," has promoted a series of initiatives, from national educational standards to the Hope Scholarship tax credit for college students. 
 Meanwhile, House Speaker Newt Gingrich is campaigning for programs like school tuition vouchers to give children from low-income families public funds to attend private schools.
Other Federal and local leaders are talking about issues from charter schools and better teacher training in the lower grades to reducing or eliminating faculty tenure in higher education.
As we consider the merits of these proposals, it may be instructive to look back at some of the century's innovative thinkers and doers who forged the path that brought us here. The following list was suggested by interviews with leading educators, historians and other scholars. It includes a philanthropist (Andrew Carnegie) and a crusading union leader (Albert Shanker), who elevated the social and economic status of teachers. Although the progress was welcome, some critics are questioning whether faculties have become too powerful.
Also included are a Harvard professor (Charles William Eliot), a Columbia philosopher (John Dewey) and an early childhood educator (Maria Montessori), who revolutionized the what and the how of education, and set the stage for current battles over curriculum. Joining them are a lawyer (Thurgood Marshall), a state legislator (Annette Polly Williams) and a college president (Benjamin E. Mays), who fought for opportunities in education for minorities, a struggle that remains bitter.
And the list also features a university president (Clark Kerr) who established the modern state-supported "multiversity" system that budget-conscious legislators are wrestling with today.
These are by no means the only movers and shakers of the century, but some of the more provocative leaders on whose shoulders the future is being built.
 
Charles William Eliot
Choose Your Own Classes
It would not be wrong to name almost any of this century's presidents of Harvard University as an Olympian in higher education. But the tallest of these giants was Charles William Eliot (1834-1926).
A Boston-bred Unitarian, Eliot was the president of Harvard University for 40 years, beginning in 1879. His greatest achievement was the establishment and defense of the "free elective system," which let college students choose their own courses. The only graduation requirements were a foreign language and freshman English.
Before Eliot's revolution, students had to memorize their lessons and recite them mechanically when called on. Course offerings, heavy on Latin and Greek, theology and the kings of England, were cut and dried.
In time, Eliot's free-elective system was reined in, as students at Harvard and elsewhere were increasingly required to major in one area, in addition to taking a variety of courses. But shopping for courses remains an essential feature of undergraduate education at Harvard and many other colleges and universities.
W. B. Carnochan, a historian of higher education at Stanford University, likens Eliot's academic revolution to the French Revolution of 1789. Eliot's program "was so far-reaching and his tenure so long," Carnochan has written, "that American higher education has never been the same after him."
 
Andrew Carnegie
Making Teaching More Attractive
He is well known for his lavish gifts to colleges and universities and for founding no fewer than 2,800 libraries across the country. But one of Andrew Carnegie's least remembered philanthropies may be his most telling: He started a retirement program for college teachers that helped to attract many first-rate intellects to the profession.
A Scotsman who immigrated to the United States when he was 12, Carnegie (1835-1919) made a fortune in iron and steel manufacturing before he turned 40. He once recalled his shock at discovering that college teachers were paid "only about as much as office clerks," making it virtually impossible for them to save for retirement. When Carnegie heard about retired professors or their widows in desperate circumstances, he frequently helped support them.
In 1905, he established a $10 million free pension fund for professors, which, he said, should improve the lives of those in "the least rewarded of all the professions."
In 1918, he went a step further by helping to establish the first nationwide self-supporting and portable financial system in which college professors could invest for their retirement. The organization, today called the Teachers Insurance and Annuity Association -- College Retirement Equities Fund (TIAA-CREF), is now the biggest pension system in the nation, with assets of $200 billion and over two million participants.
 
John Dewey
Keeping Education Practical
The followers of John Dewey said he was the equal of Socrates. That may smack of hyperbole, but it reflects the passions Dewey aroused a generation ago.
With 40 books, more than 700 articles and countless lectures, Dewey (1859-1952) conceived, and became the leading publicist of, a new approach to education. His revolution went by many names, from instrumentalism and pragmatism to progressive education, but it centered on the notion that a broad public education is an essential component of democracy. He condemned elitism and abstract metaphysics, favoring creativity, free-spiritedness and practicality in teaching.
Alan Ryan, a Dewey scholar at Oxford University, has written that Dewey, a teacher from Burlington, Vt., was no dry or reserved clinician but was "driven by a passion for the spiritual wholeness and psychological integration that the Romantic poets had celebrated."
After testing his ideas in the Laboratory School at the University of Chicago, Dewey moved to Columbia University in 1904, where he taught philosophy until his retirement in 1930.
Some of Dewey's radicalism can best be understood through his long-running quarrel with John M. Hutchins, the president of the University of Chicago. Since the turn of the century, Dewey had been stressing the need for uniting vocational and academic instruction. In 1936, Hutchins challenged Dewey in his book "The Higher Learning in America," arguing that the college curriculum should be focused on broad, abstract principles, like those found in the works of Aristotle, Aquinas and other great scholars. Such a "great books" curriculum would leave no room for practical or vocational subjects.
Dewey struck back. Hutchins's approach, he declared, would lead to "the greatest possible aloofness of higher education from contemporary social life." Furthermore, Dewey said, the approach was elitist and fundamentally undemocratic. If higher education was to be relevant, it must concern itself with current social problems and help to solve them.
Often, Dewey's language was so fuzzy that it was incomprehensible, but he could also be pungent, provocative and even inflammatory, with statements like these:
"Education becomes the art of taking advantage of the helplessness of the young." And, "The inert, stupid quality of current customs perverts learning into willingness to follow where others point the way, into conformity, constriction, surrender of skepticism and experiment."
Dewey could bring conservatives to a boil when he praised the educational accomplishments of the Russian revolutionaries Lenin and Trotsky. On the other hand, he was little comfort to liberals when he remarked, "The slogans of the liberalism of one period often become the bulwarks of reaction in a subsequent era."
Some of these battles, like the importance of relevance, still kindle debate today. But if many of Dewey's ideas seem old hat, that is largely because they have become widely accepted.
 
Maria Montessori
Stimulating Children's Senses
In a typical preschool classroom, you see brightly colored blocks, objects covered with sandpaper to stimulate touch and rows of beads that faintly suggest arithmetical concepts.
The teacher is not so much instructing as allowing children to pursue their own interests: deftly encouraging one, questioning another and laughing with a third.
Such an environment, commonplace today, reflects the influence of Maria Montessori (1870-1952), a physician and educator who gave her name (and philosophy) to thousands of schools for young children around the world.
The concepts guiding Montessori schools are that children must not be spoonfed knowledge but should discover it for themselves; that the senses must be developed by working with the hands; that grades, rewards and punishments must be eliminated, and that children should learn to discipline themselves.
After becoming the first woman to graduate from an Italian medical school, Montessori began teaching retarded children in the slums of Rome. There, she made a surprising discovery: by stimulating the tactile sense of the children, encouraging them to express themselves and never hurrying, rewarding or punishing them, she could teach many to read and write. Later, she used these methods to educate other poor children.
After publishing a book in 1909 about her technique and its results, which was hailed by educators around the world, Montessori devoted herself to writing, traveling and organizing a worldwide network of schools.
Montessori's critics argued then, and have continued to maintain, that her method emphasizes working with the hands at the expense of intellectual development and creativity. Nonetheless, the "Montessori miracle" continues to have a wide following.
 
Franklin D. Roosevelt
Opening University Doors
The contributions to education by the 32d President of the United States are not nearly as well known as his efforts to end the Depression, sponsor the Social Security program and lead the Allies to victory in World War II. Yet Franklin Delano Roosevelt (1882-1945) played a crucial role in two profound developments in higher education.
First, he conceived, and urged Congress to adopt, the G.I. Bill of Rights, which opened the doors of higher education to the middle class. Second, he commissioned a wartime report that led the Federal Government to support the nation's great research universities.
In November 1942, while the United States was still reeling from the Pearl Harbor attack, President Roosevelt invited a panel of leading educators to develop a program to benefit returning servicemen and women after the end of the war.
Roosevelt's panel came up with a number of recommendations designed to help approximately 10 million veterans adapt to peacetime. There were low-cost home mortgages, unemployment insurance, job placement services and, critically, educational grants.
The following summer, Roosevelt asked Congress to establish the program. After a hard-fought battle, he prevailed, and the Serviceman's Readjustment Act, commonly known as the G.I. Bill of Rights, became law in 1944.
Turning his attention to the research universities later that year, Roosevelt asked Vannevar Bush, his wartime director of the Office of Scientific Research and Development, to propose ways in which "the vision, boldness and drive" of scientific research that was helping to win the war could be harnessed to provide "a fuller and more fruitful life" in time of peace.
Bush's report, "Science: The Endless Frontier," argued that the nation's health, economy and military security must be constantly nourished by new scientific knowledge, and that it was the responsibility of the Federal Government to provide the necessary financial support.
Bush's vision, although hotly debated in Congress, soon became the blueprint for the establishment of the National Science Foundation, the Federal agency that would award grants, contracts and fellowships, mainly to research universities.
Since its founding in 1950, some $37 billion have been poured into the agency, and it has produced not only nuclear warheads, rockets and missiles but also polio vaccines, pacemakers, computers, semiconductors and lasers.
Roosevelt died before he received Bush's report, but there can be little doubt that in commissioning it, he had seen the future.
 
Thurgood Marshall
Reading, Writing and Race
He has many claims to fame, including being the first black Justice of the United States Supreme Court. But in the field of education, Thurgood Marshall is remembered for his achievement as a lawyer.
It was while serving as counsel to the N.A.A.C.P. Legal Defense Fund that Marshall became the architect of the legal strategy that in 1954 led to the Supreme Court's ruling in Brown v. Board of Education, which outlawed segregation in American public schools.
Although considerable gains in desegregation resulted, much have since been eroded. (A Harvard University study released last April indicated that the rate of resegregation is rapid.) Nevertheless, Marshall boldly raised the consciousness of the nation.
His argument before the Supreme Court concerned the constitutionality of the so-called "separate but equal" system of racial segregation then practiced in the public schools of 21 states.
Marshall presented the case in his plain-spoken manner. At one point during the argument, Justice Felix Frankfurter asked Marshall what he meant by "equal."
In a memorable response, Marshall replied, "Equal means getting the same thing, at the same time, and in the same place."
In later years, Marshall was annoyed by the glorification of past accomplishments in race relations. "Take it from me," he said. "We haven't won yet."
 
Benjamin E. Mays
Fighting Religiously For Equal Rights
Benjamin E. Mays, the president of Morehouse College in Atlanta, inspired a host of civil rights advocates, including the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr.; Julian Bond, the former Georgia State Senator; Louis W. Sullivan, the former Secretary of Health and Human Services; Maynard H. Jackson, the first black mayor of Atlanta, and Walter Massey, former director of the National Science Foundation and current president of Morehouse.
"He was at the center of the movement and inspired a generation," said John Hope Franklin, the historian.
The son of former slaves, Mays (1894-1984) was ordained a Baptist minister and served as dean of the Howard University Divinity School, where he gained an international reputation as an educator and lecturer. But his importance lies not so much in his scholarship as in the force of his personality and ideas.
Between 1940 and 1967, while he presided over Morehouse, a historically black college for men, he preached the gospel of racial equality and social justice. Mays got to know his students (and they him) at Tuesday morning lectures in which he stressed intellectual excellence, religious piety and a commitment to racial advancement. A firm believer in integration, he freely criticized American religious institutions for not speaking out against segregation.
"A religion which ignores social problems will in time be doomed," he said.
Mays and the young Martin Luther King Jr. became close through their frequent, lively discussions. One subject of common interest was the philosophy of Mohandas K. Gandhi, who liberated his country from the grip of British colonialism. Mays had recently visited India to study Gandhi's tactics, and young King was fascinated by what Mays reported. King immediately saw that Gandhi's strategy of Satyagraha -- leading an unarmed multitude in nonviolent protest -- could work for black Americans.
In later years, Mays said his greatest honor was having taught and inspired King. King was quoted as having replied that Mays was "my spiritual mentor and my intellectual father."
 
Clark Kerr
Master Planner for Higher Education
He once wisecracked that a university is "a series of individual entrepreneurs held together by a common grievance over parking."
Clark Kerr, 86, could get away with poking fun at the "multiversities," as he called them, because he was so firmly on their side.
In 1960, while president of the University of California at Berkeley, he conceived a sweeping new plan for state-supported higher education in California. Soon it became a model for the nation.
Under Mr. Kerr's master plan of a defined and disciplined system, the government would for the first time guarantee any high school graduate access to higher education. Two-year community colleges would focus on career preparation; four-year state colleges would provide scholastic training to more able students, and elite, four-year research universities would receive those with the highest academic credentials. The elite universities would pursue the academic "crown jewels": doctorate programs and basic research. A key part of the plan was creating a commission to coordinate the administration of all three types of institutions.
Previously, higher education in the state was divided and scattered. The state community colleges considered themselves an extension of K-12 schools, state colleges were limited to teacher training, and the public research universities were disconnected from the rest.
In recent years, cost-conscious state legislatures have been whittling the size of these institutions in California and elsewhere. Even so, 80 percent of the country's 15 million college students are attending publicly supported colleges and universities patterned after the California master plan.
 
Albert Shanker
Raising the Voice of Teachers
Albert Shanker (1928-1997) transformed the teaching profession as the longtime president of New York City's United Federation of Teachers and its parent organization, the American Federation of Teachers.
Before Shanker, public schoolteachers were largely dutiful employees who took orders and had little say about the institutions in which they taught. Since Shanker, they have become a professional, if still highly criticized, class with clout.
It took eloquence, organizational skill, political deftness -- and, many would say, obstinacy -- for Shanker, a former substitute teacher, to accomplish this change. In 1960, he guided a merged body of teachers' unions, the United Federation, to win the right to bargain for all teachers. He steadily gained pay raises for schoolteachers and helped build professional self-esteem in the rank and file.
Although in recent years, he was known as a respected commentator on educational issues, Shanker earned his reputation for tough-guy stubbornness during the turmoil that surrounded New York City's decentralization crisis in 1968. The controversy, which stirred deep racial and religious antagonism, led to the closing of most of the city's schools for 55 days during the fall term.
For years afterward, Mr. Shanker was often criticized for having tarnished his union's reputation for fairness and racial harmony and for leaving a legacy of tensions between blacks and Jews.
At the time of his death last February, the American Federation of Teachers had 900,000 members, mostly concentrated in the big cities across the nation. Membership in the U.T.F. is about 85,000.
 
Joan Ganz Cooney
How Big Bird Came to Count
As the originator of the preschool educational series "Sesame Street," in which puppets teach children to talk, read and count, Ms. Cooney, 68, not only created a new art form, she also shaped the teaching of young schoolchildren. Today, "Sesame Street" reaches an estimated 235 million viewers each week in more than 85 countries. In the United States, the series is broadcast by some 300 stations of the Public Broadcasting Service.
In 1966, Ms. Cooney, then a young television producer, was asked by the Carnegie Corporation to prepare a report on the possible use of television to educate young children. Her report became the blueprint for "Sesame Street," which made its debut in November 1969.
The cast, including Jim Henson's Muppets -- Big Bird, Kermit the Frog and other whimsical characters -- quickly won the hearts of adults as well as children.
What was unique about "Sesame Street" was the way it weaved puppets, animation and live actors into an interracial tapestry that delivered educational messages.
"When I began to study the potential uses of television for preschool children," she said in a recent interview, "I was aware of the fact that children all across the United States were singing advertising jingles. I wanted 'Sesame Street' to do the same thing for reading, writing and arithmetic."
In 1995, Ms. Cooney was awarded the Presidential Medal of Freedom, the nation's highest civilian honor.
 
Allan Bloom
The Fight Over Multiculturalism
In 1987, Allan Bloom, then a shy, retiring translator of Plato and Rousseau at the University of Chicago, shook academe to its foundations when he argued in his book "The Closing of the American Mind" (Simon & Schuster) that the capitulation of college and university administrations to the demands of the student, feminist and black power movements in the 1960's and 70's had fatally compromised higher education.
Writing with glee and deliberate hyperbole, Bloom (1930-1992) compared radical feminism to the Reign of Terror in the French Revolution, dismissed the anthropologist Margaret Mead as a "sexual adventurer," compared Woodstock nation to Hitler's Nuremberg rallies and denounced "cultural relativism," which sees all cultures as equal, as an intellectual heresy.
At first, "The Closing of the American Mind" earned praise from critics of almost all persuasions. Christopher Lehmann-Haupt of The New York Times declared that the book hit the reader with the force of "electric-shock therapy." Joseph Coates, writing in The Chicago Tribune, went even further, saying the book "may be the most important work of its kind by an American since World War II."
As some came to call his book a new conservative bible, "The Closing of the American Mind" was also scorned for its polemical approach and conservative bias by the likes of Derek Bok, the Harvard University president; the educational philosopher Mortimer Adler, and Kenneth Tollett, a professor of higher education at Howard University.
All this suggests that Bloom's greatest accomplishment may have been an irrefutable demonstration that the American university, above all else, is keeping the world safe for controversy.
 
Paulo Freire
The Politics Of Reading
The radical Brazilian educator Paulo Freire (1922-1997), considered by many scholars to be among the most influential theorists of his time, deplored what he famously called "the banking conception" of teaching. This conventional approach, he said mockingly, is based on the idea that the brain of the student is a piggy bank and that the job of the teacher is "an act of depositing knowledge."
The banking conception, Freire argued in his best-selling book, "Pedagogy of the Oppressed" (Continuum, 1970), is "a characteristic of the ideology of oppression," which "negates education and knowledge as a process of inquiry."
Working for years with Brazilian laborers and peasants in literacy campaigns in the country's impoverished northeast, Freire developed what he considered an enlightened approach. Like Socrates, he engaged in a dialogue with his students, using everyday words, tacitly acknowledging that he could learn from his students as well.
In teaching, Freire seized upon loaded terms like rich, poor and landlord. By the late 1980's, many black, Hispanic and feminist organizations in the United States had embraced his methods in literacy campaigns.
As one American educator put it in 1994, Freire espoused a "pedagogy of liberation."
But effective as his teaching techniques proved to be, many of his countrymen feared Freire as a subversive. He was jailed in 1964 and then exiled for the next 15 years. Living in Chile and Nicaragua and in nations of Portuguese-speaking Africa, he published and lectured widely. In 1980, he returned to Brazil under a political amnesty.
John Devine, a professor of education at New York University who teaches a course in Freire's life and work, considers him "the dominant figure in education in the last half of the 20th century."
Freire was scheduled to teach at Harvard this fall, but died of a heart attack in May.
 
Annette Polly Williams
Vouchers in Our Future?
The concept of vouchers, if not the word, has been around for decades. The G.I. Bill of 1944 was an early voucher program in that it authorized the Government to give checks to individual students, who were then free to spend them at public or private colleges of their choice.
In recent years, the use of taxpayer money to provide private education for poor public school students has become a major political issue. Some politicians, including national Republican leaders, and many parent advocates argue that the competition for students will stimulate and improve failing urban school systems. Others, including President Clinton and other groups of parent advocates, argue that vouchers will drain vital funds from hard-pressed public schools, and that private schools will not be accountable to the public.
One of the most successful champions of school vouchers is Annette Polly Williams, 60, the Democratic state legislator from Milwaukee who wrote the Wisconsin school voucher program that became law in 1990.
"People with money have always been able to choose schools for their children," said Ms. Williams, who represents a largely black constituency in Milwaukee. "They can afford to send their children to private schools, or they can buy expensive houses in communities that have good schools. What this law does is put power in the hands of poor people. Now they can choose."
The Milwaukee program, like a newer, larger program in Cleveland, has been challenged in the courts. But the sheer longevity of the program, which now provides vouchers to some 2,000 students, assures it a place in education history. (The fate of either or both programs may be determined by the United States Supreme Court).
The Wisconsin law provides vouchers, worth $4,300 each year, in private, nonsectarian schools. But Ms. Williams and others are seeking to expand the legislation to include sectarian schools, as the Cleveland program does.
Similar voucher programs are under consideration by more than a dozen state legislatures; the latest plan is the Republican-sponsored measure to establish such a program in the District of Columbia.
"I got the idea of choice for low-income families back in the 1970's, when I sent my four kids to the Urban Day School, a private school," Ms. Williams recalled. "It had high expectations for the students, and that made all the difference."

CORRECTION-DATE: November 16, 1997, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
An article in the special Education Life section on Nov. 2 about educational innovators referred imprecisely to some scientific developments that became legacies of Franklin D. Roosevelt's era. Although advanced by financing from by the National Science Foundation, the development of nuclear warheads, rockets and missiles was mainly the work of the Atomic Energy Commission. Polio vaccines were primarily the responsibility of the Public Health Service, through its National Institutes of Health.

HEADLINE: Island Paradox

BYLINE: By Thomas Carothers; Thomas Carothers is the director of research at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace in Washington.

 BODY:

PUERTO RICO
 The Trials of the Oldest Colony
 in the World.
 By Jose Trias Monge.
 Illustrated. 228 pp. New Haven:
 Yale University Press. $35. 
 Americans are not famous for their knowledge of other lands. Brazilians visiting the United States are often dismayed to be asked where in Africa their country lies. Austrian tourists regularly report having to insist to curious American hosts that there are no kangaroos in their native land. Puerto Ricans suffer greatly in this regard. Although Spain ceded Puerto Rico to the United States almost a hundred years ago, most Americans know little about the island beyond a vague sense that it is "ours," but not exactly part of "us."
"Puerto Rico: The Trials of the Oldest Colony in the World," by Jose Trias Monge, is a useful antidote to this ignorance. Monge presents a pithy account of Puerto Rico's troubled 500-year history while also setting out a carefully reasoned case for a new approach to the perennially unresolved issue of Puerto Rico's status vis-a-vis the United States. A former Chief Justice of Puerto Rico, Monge distills a lifetime of work in Puerto Rico's legal and political affairs into this slim, incisive volume.
"Puerto Rico" wakes up the reader early on with some stark facts. Despite Federal aid expenditures on Puerto Rico of approximately $9 billion per year (close to the total amount of United States aid to the rest of the world combined), 60 percent of Puerto Ricans live below the poverty line, crime is far worse than in the United States, drug transshipment through Puerto Rico to the United States is rampant and Puerto Rican political life is increasingly polarized and angry.
Monge proceeds with dispatch through the historical chapters to his central argument: United States-Puerto Rican relations are in a debilitating rut. The endless debates on the island over the three main options -- statehood, independence or heightened commonwealth status -- are going nowhere. Plebiscites in Puerto Rico, though appealing in principle, have done little to settle the issue.
The root problem, Monge asserts, is that owing to the many limitations on its sovereignty, Puerto Rico remains effectively a colony of the United States. He uses the emotive term "colony" with caution, expressly not in "the usual, vituperative sense" that implies economic exploitation but as a way of highlighting Washington's "unnecessary retention of excessive power over Puerto Rico." The longstanding United States avowal that it merely wants to respect the wishes of Puerto Ricans has become, in his view, a policy of avoidance. "One cannot indulge in heady talk about self-determination . . . unless one defines the range of possibilities and is ready to listen to the choice of the people."
Washington, Monge argues, must establish Puerto Rico's sovereignty and decouple that step from decisions about the island's ultimate status. He sets out a number of concrete approaches for "decolonization" and then offers a careful analysis of both the various options for Puerto Rico's ultimate status and the exact nature of the United States interests at stake.
Judicial at every turn, Monge is sure-footed in treacherously politicized terrain. He credits the United States with generosity and criticizes Puerto Rico's political elites for short-sightedness. Yet he is adamant on a basic point: "The issue should not be whether further powers of self-government should graciously be extended to the colonies, but rather, what powers do the dependencies want to entrust to the former empire. . . . Nobody has the right to govern another: it is as simple as that."
Monge strengthens his arguments by highlighting the ways many other Caribbean islands have achieved both greater wealth than Puerto Rico and either full independence from their former colonial masters or full integration with them. He also describes how other United States territories with smaller populations, like Guam, have enjoyed greater autonomy than Puerto Rico.
Monge's reasoning is relentless. Yet one leaves this thoughtful book with the unpleasant suspicion that logic alone, no matter how compelling, will not be enough to rouse the United States Government to unstick this policy problem. Far too many times in the past Washington has persisted in ignoring growing troubles in other lands until they deteriorate into crises. It seems unlikely that Puerto Rico will escape this deeper form of American ignorance about the world.

A review on Nov. 2, about "Puerto Rico: The Trials of the Oldest Colony in the World," by Jose Trias Monge, used the author's surname incorrectly. It is Trias Monge, not just Monge.

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
For $1, Four Books That Show Your Good Taste

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER LEHMANN-HAUPT 

 BODY:

A FEELING FOR BOOKS
The Book-of-the-Month Club, Literary Taste and Middle-Class Desire
By Janice A. Radway
Illustrated. 424 pages. The University of North Carolina Press. $29.95.
 In "A Feeling for Books," Janice A. Radway, a professor of literature at Duke University, acutely describes a dilemma that must surely be familiar to anyone who has ever been in love with reading. On the one hand, she was aware of the almost physical pleasure of being transported by a book. For her, this awareness went back to a time in her youth when she was recovering from surgery. She would escape her sense of confinement by reading a collection of books from her local library that happened to comprise many Book-of-the-Month Club selections. 
 On the other hand, after her passion for reading had led her into the academy and taught her to deal with what she calls "the esthetic complexities of true literature," she found herself ashamed of her enjoyment of popular reading, which she kept up with by finally joining the Book-of-the-Month Club and secretly reading its selections at night.
How to resolve this dilemma? Ms. Radway decided she would follow up a book she had written on why women read romances ("Reading the Romance") by exploring the subjects summed up in the subtitle of her new book, "The Book-of-the-Month Club, Literary Taste and Middle-Class Desire." She would combine autobiography, ethnography, sociology, economic history and literary criticism, and hope thereby to fuse her tastes into a whole.
She would begin by visiting the Book-of-the-Month Club offices, where she found a congenial world that mirrored her academic one in its love of books, except that here books were looked upon as tools to serve readers instead of hierarchical esthetic objects to be studied for themselves. Yet this world was threatened, she found. Time Inc. had recently acquired the club and was trying to stanch an increasing loss of members by introducing more aggressive marketing techniques. Ms. Radway would see in this threat a conflict that went deep into the American past, which she explores in the main part of the book.
This investigation is too complex to do more than touch upon it here. The animating force of the conflict she sees was the accelerating means of production and distribution that dominated the American economy in the era following the Civil War. By the early 20th century, this advancing capitalism had divided the book world into two opposing camps. On one side were mass-market works of instruction and entertainment created by anonymous hack writers under the direction of enterprising editors. On the other side were unique works of high literature that were created by distinguished authors, judged by independent-minded critics and interpreted by discriminating scholars.
The genius of the Book-of-the-Month Club, Ms. Radway writes, was to reintegrate the book world by disentangling "the notion of the new from the concept of the uniquely occurring," that is, by showing that "the new could be understood as amenable to infinite variation and repetition."
By first persuading readers to buy a stream of books and then using its committee of judges to individualize them, the club became "a system in perpetual motion" that "was nothing more or less than the application of the modern logic of integration to the realm of book production and distribution." By seizing the space between high literature and the low, the club had invented middlebrow reading.
Understandably, the new system posed a threat, Ms. Radway concedes, which was why the club aroused such extreme hostility. Critics might have complained that in choosing the best books by committee, the club was turning culture into a commodity. What was really going on, Ms. Radway insists, was an expression of fear by a combination of the dying pre-Civil War elite and a rising professional-managerial class that their turf was being invaded. After all, the seemingly independent critics who attacked the club also "dispensed advice and opinions about cultural goods available on the market." It was a case of the upper part of the face calling the forehead middlebrow.
Ms. Radway never does resolve the division in her view. As she writes in her introduction: "My ambivalence is persistent and real. The effect of the resulting dual perspective is more like that produced by newly acquired bifocals that render the world in fractured form across a disjunctive, arbitrary line."
Through one set of lenses she writes with graceful eloquence of her love of warmblooded books; through the other she peppers her astringent analysis with words like valorize, foregrounded, concretize, habitus, metonymic, auratic and fungibility.
If she calls the book club's critics hypocritical, she accuses the club itself of dressing up its middlebrow product in the trappings of high art. And when, in the last section, she rereads and analyzes at length some of the favorite books of her childhood, "Marjorie Morningstar" by Herman Wouk, "Gods, Graves and Scholars: The Story of Archeology" by C. W. Ceram and "To Kill a Mockingbird" by Harper Lee, she is struck, as of course she hadn't been the first time she read them, by how much each celebrated men over women and white people over everyone else.
Still, she finally accepts her bifocal vision, which is probably how most of us take in the world of art and entertainment these days. What she sees most clearly is how those middlebrow books she read in her childhood gave her the appetite to keep on reading, until her mind grew powerful enough to produce this deeply penetrating book, which not only lays bare the forces that produced middlebrow reading but also explains a good deal of what is going on in the world of books today.

HEADLINE: Increasingly, Electronic Cooks Are Being Used to Keep the Soup From Spoiling

BYLINE: BY KATE MURPHY 

 BODY:
Care for a digitally developed doughnut? How about an electronically evolved animal cracker? Go ahead and enjoy your favorite packaged snacks, safe in the knowledge that before processed foods and drinks tantalize your taste buds, they have been sampled by electronic chefs to insure that you will go back to the store for more.
Of course, it should be no surprise that automation is now standard in food processing. The wonder is that it took until the 1990's to become so. Until this decade, computers and electronics -- integral to the production of manufactured goods from televisions to airplanes -- were conspicuous by their absence from food processing. 
 But now, computers are taking hold in the food processing industry. The Nabisco unit of RJR Nabisco, along with Philip Morris's Kraft Foods, Nestle, Pepsico's Frito-Lay, Morgan Foods, Kellogg, Quaker Oats and General Mills are among the large food producers that have recently installed sensors to help make their products, according to equipment vendors, automation consultants and the companies.
And while Frito-lay, Nestle and Kraft declined to disclose which of their products were manufactured with the help of electronic sensors, vendors of automated equipment said that everything from packaged puddings to cream-filled cookies to potato chips were now prepared with electronic assistance.
In part, technological improvements have driven the shift. The nettlesome defects that made electronic sensors and other devices unreliable sous-chefs a decade or more ago have largely been corrected.
Economics was the impetus for change. Early in the 1990's, the makers and sellers of automation systems were eager to find a replacement for cyclical markets like the petroleum industry or shrinking markets like shipbuilding. The food industry's relative stability was attractive, so makers of automation equipment have put more effort into meeting the needs of food producers.
"After the recession in the oil industry, we started looking at the food business as a market because it's less volatile: No matter what happens, people have got to eat," said Robert E. Tarrant, assistant director of sales and marketing at the privately held Nametre Company of Metuchen, N.J., which is majority owned by Tytronics Inc., a manufacturer of automation equipment in Bedford, Mass.
Nametre makes a viscosity sensor that was originally used to test the consistency of refined oil products but was modified in 1990 to monitor the thickness of frosting, pudding, salad dressing, whipped topping and the like.
Nametre is one of hundreds of companies that have worked in the last decade to develop more accurate, easily integrated and durable electronic sensing devices that detect everything from the creaminess of sandwich cookie filling to the piquancy of pasta sauce. In Nametre's case, sales have risen to $2.5 million from $752,000 in the last eight years.
Not that human taste tests are a thing of the past. It is just that much of the food being tried out on focus groups has been tried out on electronic sensors first.
In part, the trend toward automation was slowed by the conviction that creating things culinary is a craft. Master bakers are still a fixture on some bread production lines, stretching hunks of dough between clenched fists to insure proper elasticity. But their time may be passing.
"To some extent, processors have become more open to technology lately because those kinds of craftsmen are starting to fade away," said Ted Labuza, professor of food engineering at the University of Minnesota. "No one apprentices anymore to learn that kind of thing."
This realization, coupled with a highly competitive marketplace in which profit margins are typically a slim 5 percent to 6 percent, has enouraged "a movement in the industry away from the art and toward the science of making food," said Mike Werlein, director of electrical systems at Kraft.
Steve Smith, manager of the Computer-Integrated Food Manufacturing Laboratory at Purdue University in West Lafayette, Ind, said, "Food manufacturers are finally beginning to look to computerized process control instead of human inspection to enhance the quality and safety of their products."
The total market for food processing control instrumentation has doubled in the last 10 years to $2.2 billion worldwide, according to McMahon Technology Associates, a consulting firm in Leonia, N.J. Among the companies providing such equipment are Rockwell International's Rockwell Automation, Honeywell Industrial Automation and Control of Phoenix and Emerson Electric's Fisher-Rosemont Inc. of St. Louis.
The biggest technological advances have come in sensing devices that can help determine and control everything from optimum cooking temperature to product uniformity. And a new generation of sensors can measure more taste-specific variables. For example, Maselli Measurements Inc. of Stockton, Calif., a distributor for Maselli Misure S.P.A. of Italy, sells refractometers, which use light refraction to measure the sweetness of fruit juice, jellies and tomato products like pasta sauce.
The original market for these sensors -- which detect sugar levels by the degree to which light passing through food bends -- was the pharmaceutical industry, which used them to measure soluble solids.
In the past, few if any of the sensors used in the pharmaceutical industry were durable enough to withstand the harsh environment of the food processing plant, where cleaning of food preparation equipment requires powerful pressure washes containing caustic chemicals.
"Now, thanks to better design and materials, sensors can survive that kind of rough treatment," said Douglas Burns, business development manager in the food and beverage division of Rockwell Automation.
Sensors are also far more sensitive and accurate. "The early versions that came out in the '70's and '80's weren't always reliable," said Mr. Smith of Purdue. Temperature variations and flow interruptions would go undetected, sometimes leading to burned or soggy products. However, today's electronic sensing mechanisms set off alarms if the temperature of ovens or ingredients are off by the slightest amount.
And sensors are now equipped with "intelligence" so they can, for example, report when they need to be serviced or make calculations based on values detected.
Developed for the food processing industry, innovative moisture and color sensors made by private companies like the Dantec Systems Corporation of Waterloo, Ontario, and Key Technology Inc. of Walla Walla, Wash., are finding their way onto production lines.
For example, in 1995, Austin Quality Foods, a division of the German cookie maker Bablsen, installed a sensor to monitor the moisture of the 130 million pounds of sandwich crackers and cookies made each year by its bakery in Cary, N.C.
Shi Tien Ting, the engineering manager at Austin Quality Foods, said that before installing the sensor, plant operators ran moisture analyses on just-baked crackers every 15 minutes to make sure they were adequately cooked. The laboratory test takes about 30 minutes to perform, so if the crackers were not right, that meant 30 extra minutes of substandard production before an adjustment could be made.
By contrast, the sensor makes readings continuously and communicates information to a central process logic controller, which regulates oven temperature. According to Mr. Ting, the system -- which cost $100,000 -- has already paid for itself in the "reduction of scrap."
But humans retain a role. The most advanced sensor has the ability to detect only one or two food attributes; a person's taste buds can pick up the thousands of properties responsible for a single food's flavor and texture. "No one's come up with a replacement for the human tongue," Mr. Werlein said.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "Putting an End to the Taste Test"
Food processing companies have adopted a number of technologies to make the business more efficient.
 
SWEETNESS
Sensors detect the sweetness of juice, for example, using refracted light.
 
OLD TEST
Taste it or submit it to time-consuming laboratory tests.
 
NEW TEST
A sensor measures sugar levels by degree to which light bends passing though juice. Deficiencies as well as excesses are automatically corrected by the addition of more sweetener or water.
 
VISCOSITY
Viscosity sensors determine the consistency of products like pudding using an electric circuit.
 
OLD TEST
Stick a spoon or spatula into a pudding sample.
 
NEW TEST
A sensor maintains a constant vibration that is altered by the thickness of the pudding flowing by. Deviations in the vibration measure the creaminess.
 
PORTIONS
Sensors insure exact measure-ments of ingredients in products like margarine.
 
OLD TEST
A worker holds down a knob for a specified period of time to introduce ingredients. Air pockets and lumps made this method imprecise.
 
NEW TEST
Flow sensors measure the mass of each ingredient, so that every batch is made the same.
 
MOISTURE
Moisture sensors measure how wet foods like cookies are.
 
OLD TEST
Taste it, or submit it to time-consuming laboratory tests.
 
NEW TEST
A moisture sensor bounces radio waves off passing cookies. Moist cookies absorb more waves than crispy ones do, so the sensor is able to identify undercooked batches.
