HEADLINE: As Union Pacific Traffic Snarls, So Do Customers

BYLINE: By CAROL MARIE CROPPER 

 BODY:
For the Huntsman Polymers Corporation on the windswept West Texas prairie in Odessa, the Western rail logjam has been one unending, agonizing squeeze.
Service disruptions in the 36,000-mile network of the Union Pacific Railroad, the country's largest, have created huge backlogs in deliveries of coal, grain, plastics, chemicals, automobiles and other products in much of the nation. They have pushed up natural gas prices by 50 percent in some areas, and created a drag on economic growth. 
 Moreover, the system, which has been hampered by congestion, shortages of equipment and crews and multiple wrecks, could become further strained in the next few weeks as bumper crops of soybeans and corn are harvested.
In response, the Federal Surface Transportation Board in Washington declared a transportation emergency on Friday in the West and ordered Union Pacific to open a section of track to a Texas competitor, the Texas Mexican Railway, to ease the gridlock.
For Huntsman, though, it is not the broad repercussions that are so painful. It is the wrenching frustration of watching its business shrink day by day as its chemical shipments are stalled, lost or stranded.
In the 1950's, it seemed like a good idea to build a sprawling polymer and petrochemical plant in Odesssa where land was cheap and access to rail transportation was easy. But now, being more than 300 miles from the nearest big city creates a monumental challenge.
While some customers agree with Union Pacific that service has been improving lately, Huntsman executives said that if anything, it was getting worse. Because of its site and because it keeps some of its chemicals off the highways for safety reasons, Huntsman has become dependent on Union Pacific rail cars that either show up in large numbers or not at all. Texas companies closer to the Gulf of Mexico can ship by water, while those more centrally situated find it cheaper to use trucks.
Huntsman estimates the problems have cost it more than $7.5 million in lost business and increased shipping costs since the rail glitches began in June. And that is in addition to the headaches of trying to track down errant rail cars and deal with desperate customers who depend on Huntsman's chemicals to make and ship their own products on time. In October, Union Pacific had to negotiate with Mexico to retrieve a Huntsman car filled with polyethylene, which is used to make plastics, that was headed for a small Texas town but somehow wound up in Mexico.
A far more serious blunder took place in the summer when two tank cars loaded with liquid styrene monomer, which is also used to make plastics, spent more than 40 days on the rails -- one in Cora, Ill., and the other in Midland, Mich. -- before the loads became unstable and released vapor in late August. About 4,000 Michigan residents were ordered to stay in their homes while crews stabilized the cargo.
David Parkin, the Huntsman executive in charge of tracking rail cars, showed a letter from one customer notifying Huntsman that it would start buying from another supplier because of delivery delays. That customer has since taken its $400,000-a-month business to a company on the East Coast, he said.
Huntsman shipped some chemicals by truck, Mr. Parkin said, but that increases costs three to four times.
Johnny W. Lasiter, the plant manager in Odessa, now begins his workday by checking to see whether any rail cars have arrived. When cars come late, crews have to work into the night to fill them. "Half the time the last couple months, we've had to load on Sundays," he added.
Mr. Lasiter, who has worked at the plant for 20 years, said he had never seen a rail disruption like this.
While Union Pacific said that it was getting its problems under control, the Chemical Manufacturers Association said that almost 200 major chemical plants had complained about poor service and that 29 had disclosed total losses of $60 million.
A report for the Railroad Commission of Texas written by two economists at the University of North Texas put the loss in Texas at $300 million to $400 million. "The national economic loss may easily have topped $1 billion," the report said. As the problems continue, price increases will start affecting consumers, said Bernard L. Weinstein, the co-author of the report.
Dr. Weinstein also said he thought the situation was getting worse in Texas. "If it is easing, it's because the Union Pacific is refusing to take orders from shippers" as a way of easing traffic, he said.
Dr. Weinstein attributed part of this crisis to diminishing competition as the industry consolidates and suggested that smaller rail customers might be squeezed out as a result. After Union Pacific merged with the Southern Pacific Rail Corporation in September 1996, it reported difficulties in linking the companies' computer systems. Moreover, union crews from one company are still not allowed to run trains on some lines belonging to the other.
Dr. Weinstein added that thousands of workers were dismissed to pay merger costs. Not true, a Union Pacific spokesman said. Employment now totals 54,000, up from the two companies' combined work force of 53,000 in 1995, he said, and it is expected to grow this year.
Dick Davidson, chairman of the Union Pacific Corporation, the railroad's parent company, called the merger the ultimate solution to service backups, rather than their cause. Without it, Southern Pacific would have continued to falter, he said. This year's troubles, he added, resulted from an unusual convergence of events, including heavy rains that washed out tracks near Houston and the Mexican railroad privatization, which has backed up rail traffic across the border.
So far, Union Pacific has been sued and threatened with suits by shippers and is discussing possible safety violation citations and fines with the Federal Railroad Administration.
For all the company's woes, though, Mr. Davidson was upbeat. "Once we get the merger in place down there, we will have a wonderful system," he said. "Our customers will get better service."

HEADLINE: Havana Journal;
No Joy in Cuba, as Its Baseball Team Strikes Out

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: HAVANA

 BODY:
Through years of hardship and regimentation, Cubans have always had one consistent consolation: the invincibility of their national baseball team, which has won countless international competitions, including the Olympics, and is often said to be the best squad not playing in the major leagues.
But no longer. With the regular season set to start on Nov. 15, the team's failure to win recent tournaments in Japan and Spain, where it lost games by humiliating scores like 11-2 and 16-6, has plunged Cuban baseball into what fans and the sports press here describe as a crisis so profound that it has set off a purge of Government officials who have run the sport for decades. 
 In a society as tightly controlled as this one, any serious criticism of the Communist Party and its leaders remains risky. But President Fidel Castro is himself a fan, a former pitcher and an occasional commentator on baseball. So venting grievances about the national sport is an approved activity, almost a patriotic duty, and the official press and the man in the street are taking advantage of the opportunity.
"The situation is desperate and discouraging," Prensa Latina, the state news agency, lamented in a recent dispatch.
"I must confess that I do not know how to write about defeats," a reporter for Granma, the newspaper of the Cuban Communist Party, moaned after one particularly galling loss.
The defection of young prospects like pitcher Livan Hernandez, now with the Florida Marlins, and shortstop Rey Ordonez of the New York Mets, has been widely publicized and is acknowledged to be part of the problem. But the main cause of the sudden nose dive, fans, reporters and others say, lies in the Cuban Government's failure to adequately reward loyal team members who have chosen to stay home.
"This is not merely a slump," said Milton Jamail, a professor of Latin American politics at the University of Texas who is writing a book about baseball in Cuba. "This is something structural, entirely linked to things that are happening in every other aspect of Cuban society, especially the dollarization of the economy, and the Government cannot respond to it."
During the last year, more than 50 players, most still in their prime, have retired from the Cuban league, which provides the pool from which the national team is selected. They have left to take advantage of a new, Government-authorized plan that allows them to earn hard currency by playing abroad in "amateur" leagues. Many of them, fans complain, have been replaced by players more renowned for "revolutionary spirit" than baseball prowess.
Among those who have retired are Victor Meza, who was closing in on the Cuban career records for hits and runs scored, and Jorge Luis Valdes, the pitcher with the most victories in the history of the Cuban league.
"With so many of the best players gone, not only have our chances of winning abroad diminished, but there's less of a reason for fans to go out to the ball park," said Pedro Perez Palma, a physical education instructor.
All of the "retired" players are now playing in semiprofessional leagues in Japan, Italy, Colombia, Ecuador and Nicaragua, where they are paid in dollars. The salaries are a pittance by the standards of Major League Baseball, and the players must turn over as much as 80 percent of what they earn to the Government, but the money is still better than the $20 or so that a star player would earn monthly playing in the Cuban league.
"The bottom line is that the position of baseball players in Cuban society has gone from privileged to underprivileged" since Cuba legalized possession of dollars in 1993, Dr. Jamail said. "Musicians and artists are allowed to come and go, and if I'm a professor or a dentist, I can become a waiter or a vendor and make some dollars. But if I'm a baseball player, I can't do any of that. I have to be a saint."
Whether out of fear that other players may also defect or for other reasons, management has also made some recent roster choices that baffle fans. As Jorge Luis Tapia, a 36-year-old teacher, put it, "Some players who ought to be on the national team aren't, and other players who are on the team shouldn't be."
Outfielder Javier Mendez, for example, had a Cuban league record .462 batting average last season, but was left off the national squad, along with Luis Rodriguez, who hit .338, and Ariel Benavides, a .335 hitter. But infielders Luis Ulacia, who hit .242, and Miguel Caldes, a .274 batter last year, somehow made the team.
"It really leaves you wondering what criteria they are using to pick the players," said Rene Mena, manager of a sandlot softball team that was playing a Sunday game in the suburb of Cojimar. "To be on the national team, it's not enough to be a good guy and a good comrade. You've got to perform, too."
Those management decisions, combined with the suspension of several players who were thought to be likely candidates to defect, forced Manager Jorge Fuentes to make some strange moves. The roster at one tournament that Cuba lost included five third basemen, which compelled Cuba to play Omar Linares, considered by many major league scouts to be the best third baseman in the world, at shortstop.
As in the major leagues, the easiest solution to any problem is always to fire the manager, and Mr. Fuentes has now been dismissed. So have Miguel Valdes, the national team's general manager, farm chief and scouting director for the last 29 years, and Domingo Zabala, the longtime head of the Cuban Baseball Commission, whose replacements did not respond to repeated requests for an interview to discuss the tailspin and its causes.
 On Oct. 31, Cuban state television announced the dismissal of Reynaldo Gonzalez Lopez, director of the National Sports Institute and president of the Cuban Amateur Baseball Federation. Humberto Rodriguez, a member of the Central Committee of the Communist Party, was designated his replacement.
On radio programs and in street-corner discussions, fans are arguing that sports officials should not be allowed to choose a successor to Mr. Fuentes behind closed doors, but should simply appoint the manager of whichever team wins the 92-game regular season.
"That is not only the most democratic manner to do it, but the most intelligent," said Rafael Lopez, a 27-year-old solderer. "Let the best man emerge through competition."
At recent commission meetings called to discuss the crisis, sports officials have also gingerly discussed the granting of "material incentives" to players, according to people who attended. These would, if approved, include both cash bonuses and prizes, to stem both defections and retirements.
But fans, dismayed at seeing their best players depart for greener pastures abroad, are demanding more basic changes in the state sport apparatus, which is also bedeviled by a corruption scandal. That is the only way, they argue, that Cuba can recoup its dominance and hope to win a third consecutive gold medal at the Sydney Olympics in 2000.
"The talent is still out there, just waiting to be developed, and it will always be there, because we are Cubans and baseball is in our blood," said Diosvel Rojas, a 28-year-old surveyor. "What needs to change is the entire system. But that is a much more difficult task."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Complaining about their once-proud baseball team, recently humiliated in tournaments in Japan and Spain, has become a new national pastime for Cubans. Fans discussed baseball in Central Park in Havana. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: THE JIANG VISIT: THE EXILES;
Sudden Visibility for Dissidents Who Hope to Influence China From the U.S.

BYLINE: By RICHARD BERNSTEIN 

 BODY:
In seizing on President Jiang Zemin's visit to the United States to call attention to human rights violations in their homeland, many of the Chinese in exile in this country have been exercising the right of free expression that was taken away from them eight years ago when Mr. Jiang's Government violently suppressed the huge student-led demonstrations at Tiananmen Square in Beijing.
But their week of activities, including news conferences, demonstrations and even trailing Mr. Jiang with vans symbolically holding Chinese political prisoners, represents something of a high point in visibility for the Chinese democracy movement since it moved to the United States after the 1989 Tiananmen protests. 
 The Chinese political exiles are an amorphous and disparate group, consisting of former students, former academic figures, former political prisoners and a few former senior Government advisers and even Communist Party ideologists who, taken together, represent a remarkable assortment of some of China's best and brightest.
Xiao Qiang, executive director of Human Rights in China, a monitoring group based in New York, says the exile community numbers 5,000 to 10,000, ranging from a few well-known individuals to at least three organizations with branches across the country and abroad.
"These are the people that the Chinese President doesn't want to meet," said William F. Schultz, executive director of the American branch of the human rights organization Amnesty International, gesturing at 17 dissident figures who were introduced at a Washington news conference last week. "These are the people whom the United States should champion."
Does the exile community have any influence in China itself? That is not easy to determine.
Among Chinese outside the exile community and non-Chinese analysts of China, there is a good deal of skepticism about the possibility that the exiles can have much impact in China itself. Their belief is that most people in China are too swept up in the race for economic gain to be paying much attention to a small and faraway group in this country.
In this sense, the Chinese exiles may resemble the various Russian exiles who at one time or another fled or were expelled from the Soviet Union but, separated from their country and their people, were never again able to play a role in their native country.
Many of the Chinese exiles, by contrast, argue that by using their personal connections at home and by exploiting technology that did not exist before, they are able to make their presence felt in China.
Some of the exiles are regularly interviewed on the Voice of America and Radio Free Asia, which are presumed to have audiences of many millions in China.
"With satellite television, overseas Chinese newspapers, the Internet, E-mail, the Voice of America, the BBC and other radio broadcasts, there are a lot of opportunities for the exile community to have an impact back home," said Mr. Xiao, one of the organizers of the anti-Jiang protests.
Mr. Xiao, who came to the United States to study astrophysics but became executive director of Human Rights in China after the Tiananmen incident, spoke of an Internet news group called China News Digest, which he estimates to have a quarter of a million readers across the globe, including in China.
"It was one of the first Web sites that was blocked by the Chinese Government," he said.
Wang Juntao, a former magazine editor who achieved prominence as the director of a research institute in Beijing that urged political reform, said, "What we can do is provide a vision."
Mr. Wang was accused by the Chinese Government of being one of "the black hands behind the black hands" masterminding the 1989 demonstrations.
"We try to give alternatives for China, a democratic idea about policy that is different from the Government's," he said. Since he has been in this country, he said, he has organized research groups that have published four books outlining a program for China's future. The books, he said, have made their way into a China whose borders are far less controlled than before.
"Democracy is an ideal, but if it is not connected to Chinese interests, they won't follow it," he said. "We are trying to offer a democratic vision for China that will help solve Chinese problems."
Mr. Wang spent four years in prison before being released for medical reasons. He is now a Ph.D. candidate in political science at Columbia University.
"I think they do have influence," said Andrew Nathan, a professor of political science at Columbia who maintains close contacts with many exiles. "People I meet from the mainland seem to have a polite curiosity about them. There's a sort of sympathetic celebrity interest in them, especially for the senior people."
Mr. Nathan identified the group Human Rights in China as especially important in this respect. Headed by Mr. Xiao and by Liu Qing, a former democracy advocate who spent nearly 11 years in prison in China, the small group has become the main source of information for the condition of dissidents inside China.
"Human Rights in China is in a class by itself for impact both here and in China," Mr. Nathan said. "It has become the main channel for the way people in China get news out about themselves, about the fate of dissidents, worker protests and prison conditions."
That information helps shape opinion about China in the United States, Mr. Nathan said, and then gets fed back into China through means like the Voice of America broadcasts.
The Chinese exile population can probably be broken down into three categories. Perhaps the best known are the small number of students who escaped from China after the military suppression of the 1989 Tiananmen Square demonstrations.
Since then, many of the most famous dissidents have been absorbed into American life, playing less visible roles than they did before.
Wuer Kaixi, for example, one of the most charismatic of the student leaders, who is on China's most-wanted list, came to the United States and later married and quietly moved to Taiwan, where he was for a time the host of a radio talk show. Li Lu, another of the students on the most-wanted list, earned undergraduate and law degrees at Columbia and went to work for the investment company Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette.
There are also several dozen senior figures, including scholars, journalists and even some former high-ranking Government officials, mostly scattered in various American university towns, especially New York, Boston and Princeton, N.J.
Among these exiles, for example, is Chen Yizi, once an adviser to Zhao Ziyang, the purged General Secretary of the Communist Party; Liu Binyan, who was once far and away the most famous journalist in China, and Fang Lizhi, the astrophysicist, now at the University of Arizona, who came to the United States after spending a year as a refugee in the American Embassy in Beijing.
Su Shaozhi, who was once the head of Beijing's Institute of Marxism-Leninism-Mao Zedong Thought, is now, along with Mr. Liu, among the leading figures at the Princeton China Initiative, which studies China's economic and political conditions and publishes a journal called China Focus. Illustrating the way that the exiles in this country maintain a voice inside China, Mr. Liu does a twice-weekly commentary in Chinese on Radio Free Asia.
Probably the least-known exiles are those who run the larger democracy organizations like the Chinese Alliance for Democracy and the Federation for Democratic China, which publish newsletters and journals as part of their effort to build a base of support for political reform in China.
"Their primary purpose is to know each other, to set up a structure," said Li Lu, the former student leader. "They have a political approach as well as a human rights approach. The want eventually to be an opposition party inside China."
But whether any of the current exiles will ever be able to return to China, much less play a political role there, remains doubtful, especially given the apparent stability of the current Chinese Government and the success of its economic reforms.
Asked whether he felt any of the democracy organizations might become politically active inside China, Mr. Li replied, "They have a chance, but not now."

Scientists Issue Warning On Global Warming
A growing number of scientists warn that at the rate political leaders are going it may be impossible to avoid a dangerous doubling of heat-trapping gases in the atmosphere. Mainstream climatologists say that a doubling of pre-industrial levels would raise temperatures from 3 degrees to a potentially catastrophic 8 degrees, disrupting the earth's climate and causing the seas to rise. Silence from Pathfinder
Scientists have all but given up on restoring radio communication with the Pathfinder space probe that landed on Mars on July 4. Pathfinder fell silent on Sept. 27, after nearly three months of sending back information. On Tuesday, scientists at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Pasadena, Calif., will stop daily efforts to re-establish contact and will instead try only once a week, or perhaps just once a month. The scientists speculate that communications were severed by a burned-out battery, by cold affecting the spacecraft's communications equipment or by a computer problem. (Agence France-Presse)

One of the most ambitious such plans in the nation, Denver's proposal reflects the West's sharpening love-hate relationship with mass transit. A poll showed narrow support for the plan. A18

Rail Problems in the West
Service disruptions in the 36,000-mile network of the Union Pacific Railroad, the country's largest, have created huge backlogs in deliveries of coal, grain, plastics, chemicals, automobiles and other products in much of the nation. They have pushed up natural gas prices by 50 percent in some areas and created a drag on economic growth. The system, which has been hampered by congestion, shortages of equipment and crews and by multiple wrecks, could become further strained in the next few weeks as bumper crops of soybeans and corn are harvested. In response, the Federal Surface Transportation Board in Washington declared a transportation emergency on Friday in the West and ordered Union Pacific to open a section of track to a Texas competitor, the Texas Mexican Railway, to ease the gridlock. HEADLINE: Mood Is Grim as Israeli-Palestinian Negotiations Resume

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL 

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Nov. 2

 BODY:
Israeli and Palestinian negotiators have been spelling out sharply contradictory goals for a new round of peace talks that is scheduled to begin in Washington on Monday, which does not bode well for the American diplomatic effort.
The United States is to act as mediator in the talks, which the Clinton Administration hopes might put the two parties back on track toward carrying out their old agreements and hashing out new ones. After months of paralysis in the peace effort, one American goal is to demonstrate enough progress to persuade angry Arab states to join Israel at an economic conference in Qatar later this month. 
 But the gulf between Israel and the Palestinians remains so wide that Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, has already dismissed the talks as "just a waste of time."
Israel has proposed a postponement of the troop withdrawals it is obligated, under the earlier peace accords, to carry out this month from rural areas of the West Bank. Israel wants the redeployment set aside in favor of accelerated talks on the final status of a settlement between Israel and the Palestinians.
In the meantime, Israeli officials have said, this week's talks should aim to work out differences over carrying out a 1995 accord that called for creating a safe-passage between Palestinian-governed territory in the West Bank and in the Gaza Strip as well as for building an airport and a seaport in Gaza.
Mr. Arafat and his aides have insisted that the troop withdrawals go forward before any kind of final-status talks begin. They have also called on Israel to demonstrate good will by declaring a halt on settlement activity in the West Bank, which the Israeli Prime Minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, has firmly resisted.
In an interview published today in the Israeli newspaper Maariv, Mr. Arafat said he had agreed to send a negotiator to the Washington talks only because Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright had officially invited him to do so.
"We will take part in the talks despite the fact that they have no chance of success," Mr. Arafat was quoted as saying.
By contrast, the Israeli negotiator, Foreign Minister David Levy, said in a separate interview published today in the Israeli newspaper Yediot Aharonot that he is "confident it will be possible this time to make progress with the active cooperation of the Palestinians."
"Our negotiating partners will find that we are ready to compromise if they show the required flexibility," he said.
Israel has dispatched nearly a dozen officials in a delegation headed by Mr. Levy. But Palestinian officials said today that the Palestinian side would include only Mahmoud Abbas, a deputy of Mr. Arafat, and two other negotiators.
Since midsummer, when the first of two suicide bombings in Israel sent the quest for a broader peace into a state of crisis, the United States has worked intensively to try to put relations between Israel and the Palestinians on a more solid footing. But its efforts now are clearly being formulated with an eye to the regional conference in Qatar, which is being threatened by the prospect of an Arab boycott.
Along with representatives from Israel and Jordan, Ms. Albright has already announced that she will attend the gathering, whose main purpose is to promote economic ties between Arabs and Israelis.
But as a gesture of protest against what is seen as Israel's intransigence in dealing with the Palestinians, a number of Arab states have said they intend to stay away. The level of Arab participation appears certain to be lower than in any such gathering since the first in Casablanca, Morocco, in 1993. Among past participants who have said they plan to stay away are Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates. Even Egypt, the host of last year's conference, has said that it has not yet decided whether to attend.
Martin Indyk, the former Ambassador to Israel who was recently sworn in as Assistant Secretary of State for Middle Eastern and Near Eastern Affairs, has been using a get-acquainted tour of Arab capitals to try to rally support for the gathering. But there has been no sign that the overture has yielded positive results.

HEADLINE: THE JIANG VISIT: IN CALIFORNIA;
Jiang Does Business On Last Stop Of U.S. Visit

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 2

 BODY:
From a high-tech satellite factory to a power lunch in Beverly Hills, President Jiang Zemin of China cheerfully promoted trans-Pacific commerce in California today, despite some noisy protests and a pointed warning from his host, Gov. Pete Wilson, that "the great elixir of individual freedom" is the best recipe for economic growth.
As Mr. Jiang wound up his weeklong visit to the United States with a stop in a state that accounts for more than a quarter of all American exports to China, he sat in the passenger seat of a Buick Regal -- the type that is to be built in China starting next year -- and then met privately with the Governor before gently pleading with business and political leaders for patience in resolving differences and improving ties. 
 "As the old Chinese saying goes, a 10,000-mile journey begins with the first step," Mr. Jiang told an audience of some 700 people that included former Secretary of State Warren Christopher; Peter O'Malley, the owner of the Los Angeles Dodgers; Rupert Murdoch (who is in the process of buying the Dodgers) and other corporate chieftains, and Mayor Richard J. Riordan of Los Angeles.
A similar number of protesters gathered outside the Beverly Hilton, burning Chinese flags and waving placards with slogans like "Communism Kills," "Give Jiang a Heart" and "China Most Favored Oppressor." The demonstrators drew honks of support from passing motorists.
Mr. Wilson, who visited China on a trade mission last winter, invoked the memory of the Chinese laborers who toiled on California's railroads to welcome Mr. Jiang to "the state built with Chinese muscle in the 19th century and with Chinese genius in the high-tech world of the 20th century." But in introducing Mr. Jiang at the lunch, the Republican governor also referred indirectly to China's human rights record as Mr. Jiang sat stone-faced on the dais.
"A free people deserves to be, and inevitably will be, more creative and productive in every way than those who labor in servitude with no hope of sharing the fruits of their labor," Mr. Wilson said. "The great elixir of individual freedom is the best prescription to accelerate and intensify your success."
Tonight, at a dinner downtown for 1,000 Chinese-Americans representing 140 local business associations, Mr. Jiang heard a musical program that featured Carpenters songs played on Chinese instruments. Later, he regaled the crowd with a few bars from classic Chinese opera sung in his own voice. It was the sole appearance of his trip aimed especially at a Chinese-American audience, and he brought down the house.
The overall theme of the day was economic cooperation -- hardly surprising since California now exports goods worth about $6 billion a year to China, mostly in computer and aerospace equipment, and China is now the state's sixth-largest trading partner, just behind Taiwan. Unlike politicians along the eastern seaboard, many of whom shunned Mr. Jiang, officials here cannot ignore the commercial impact of China on their state.
"The whole West Coast is more aware of what a huge part of the economy it is, I think," said one of Mr. Jiang's lunchtime listeners, Mayor Beverly O'Neill of nearby Long Beach, which is trying to expand the presence of Chinese shipping in its port. "He's getting a reception that shows that we would like to talk."
Mr. O'Malley, who built a baseball field for a school in Tianjin, near Beijing, a decade ago, has sponsored coaching and sports medicine exchanges between Chinese baseball clubs and their counterparts on the Dodgers. He ultimately hopes to build a baseball academy in China, where baseball is just beginning to become popular.
"Sports can do so much," Mr. O'Malley said. "Baseball can bring people together. My dream is to someday see a Dodger from the People's Republic."
For his part, Mr. Wilson said he favored a "two track" approach of registering protests and disapproval of Chinese abuses, while seeking better ties.
"I think that if you fail to meet with people, it is very hard to communicate," he said.
The Chinese are feuding with Hollywood these days over several movies -- including the Walt Disney Company's coming "Kundun," about the Dalai Lama, that portray China in a less than flattering light -- and Mr. Jiang passed up the chance for souvenir photo opportunities at Southern California meccas like Disneyland or the Mann's Chinese Theater. Instead, first thing this morning, the former electrical engineer headed for the headquarters of Hughes Electronics Corporation near Los Angeles International Airport and later to its manufacturing plant.
At Hughes, Mr. Jiang celebrated the communications satellite equipment that the company is selling to China and the automobiles that its parent company, General Motors, plans to build there. Company officials showed off a new service using satellite technology in which motorists who lock their keys in the car can telephone a central operator and have the doors unlocked.

HEADLINE: U.S. Will Ask U.N. to Force Iraq to Admit Arms Monitors

BYLINE: By NEIL A. LEWIS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2

 BODY:
Clinton Administration officials said today that they would ask the United Nations Security Council on Monday to take swift and firm action to force President Saddam Hussein of Iraq to allow Americans into his country as members of a United Nations weapons inspection team.
Iraq blocked two Americans on the team from carrying out their work today, its second such action in less than a week. 
 "This is serious, it's unacceptable and it's outrageous behavior on the part of the Iraqis," said Bill Richardson, the United States delegate to the United Nations. "We're not seeking a military confrontation with Iraq. We want to resolve this diplomatically. But we're not ruling anything out."
The two American inspectors, who landed at Habbaniya Airport about 60 miles north of Baghdad, were asked to leave by Iraqi officials and returned to Bahrain on a United Nations plane, news services reported. A third American who arrived with them, who works for the International Atomic Energy Agency, was not prohibited from staying but chose to leave with the other Americans.
The weapons inspectors had tried unsuccessfully to continue their work in Iraq on Thursday, and their expulsion today was the latest in a series of confrontations with President Hussein over the inspections put in place after the Persian Gulf war in 1991.
Speaking on the ABC News program "This Week," Mr. Richardson said pointedly that there was no room for compromise with Mr. Hussein's demand that no Americans take part in the inspections.
"There is no negotiation," Mr. Richardson said. "He is in noncompliance, and he must comply. This is not a fight between the U.S. and Iraq. This is Iraq confronting the United Nations."
United Nations officials said tonight that Secretary General Kofi Annan planned to press home that message with Mr. Hussein by sending a three-member delegation to Baghdad this week. The officials said the delegation would consist of three experienced diplomats whose instructions would not permit them to negotiate with Mr. Hussein, only to emphasize that he may not exclude Americans or people of any other nationality from the weapons inspection teams.
The three diplomats expected to make up the delegation are Lakhdar Brahimi of Algeria, a diplomatic troubleshooter for the Secretary General; Emilio Cardenas of Argentina, a banker and diplomat, and Jan Eliasson, a senior Swedish diplomat.
Mr. Richardson previously opposed sending a similar delegation, but the United States has since been assured that the team will not negotiate, only insist on compliance.
While Mr. Richardson, selected by the Administration to be its main spokesman on this issue, suggested that military action would not be the first option, members of Congress from both parties lined up eagerly today to say they would be wholly supportive if President Clinton chose to strike at Iraq.
The House Speaker, Newt Gingrich said on the NBC News program "Meet the Press" that he would "absolutely" support a decision to take military action against Mr. Hussein. That sentiment was echoed on the program by the Senate majority leader, Trent Lott, and the Democratic leaders in Congress, Senator Thomas A. Daschle and Representative Richard A. Gephardt.
The confrontation could heat up this week. The head of the United Nations weapons inspection team, Richard Butler, said in a telephone interview that he intended that his team would resume its work in Iraq on Monday morning as the Security Council meets in New York.
Of the 40 weapons inspectors now in Iraq, 7 are Americans, United Nations officials said. Two Americans left on Thursday as part of the normal rotation of team members, the officials said, and another left today. One Western diplomat said he believed that there were eight Americans still in Iraq; there was no explanation of the discrepancy.
Mr. Butler said he expected to resist Mr. Hussein's demands that the remaining Americans leave Iraq by Thursday.
"I expect them to go about their work in a normal way," he said. "They will assemble in the inspections center and then head out to inspect certain sites where we monitor their weapons industry and other places where we have reason to look and ask questions."
Mr. Butler, an Australian diplomat, has been resolute in not yielding to Iraq's demands and has often seemed to be leading the Security Council on the issue.
"I'm mystified as to why Iraq has done this," he said, "because it cannot and will not be allowed to stand. It's simply against all the rules. U.N. procedures cannot work if a nation can say it doesn't want Americans on a U.N. team."
Mr. Butler recently reported to the Security Council that Iraq might still be hiding biological and chemical weapons. "We've got serious questions about their biological and chemical weapons programs and whether they've been leveling with us," he said.
The inspections were ordered by the United Nations to insure that Baghdad does not rebuild the military might that it used to invade Kuwait in 1990. Baghad agreed to the inspections as a condition for eventual removal of economic sanctions.
Senior Administration officials said today that they had decided to use the Security Council to confront Iraq to avoid portraying this fight as simply between Washington and Baghdad.
Underlying the thinking, one senior official said, is an uncertainty about the cohesiveness of the anti-Iraq coalition that waged the Persian Gulf war. Evidence of the coalition's fragility was displayed two weeks ago when the Security Council declined to impose sanctions on Iraq for its earlier resistance to the inspection teams.
In recent days, though, the permanent members of the Security Council have expressed a united front in condemning Iraq, although there may well be strong disagreements over the issue of military force.
On Saturday, for example, the Foreign Minister Yevgeny M. Primakov of Russia, who was in Paris, issued a statement with the French Government criticizing the Iraqi behavior over the inspections and demanding that it end. But Russia could veto any Security Council measure endorsing a military response.
Barry Toiv, a White House spokesman traveling with President Clinton today in New Jersey and New York, said the Administration was hoping that Egypt would play a useful role in persuading Mr. Hussein to relent.

HEADLINE: THE 1997 ELECTIONS: THE DEMOCRAT;
Clinton Enters Final Act of Campaigns: In New York, He Backs Bid by Messinger

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

 BODY:
Recalling that Ruth W. Messinger had "stuck by me" through his own difficult New York political contest five years ago, President Clinton made a long-sought trip to Manhattan last night and vigorously urged voters to support her mayoral bid. He asserted that she had grasped the main issues confronting the city now that crime was in decline: failing schools and lingering unemployment.
For 16 minutes, with his fellow Democrat beaming at his side, Mr. Clinton issued what was in effect a call to Democrats to come home and support their party's candidate. He did not once mention or criticize Ms. Messinger's Republican opponent, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, but instead rolled out, with a national perspective and his own distinctive political edge, the case that Ms. Messinger has been making about the problems of New York City. 
 "I say to you, I believe if I were mayor of New York City," Mr. Clinton said, "I would say my three priorities are: I'm going to get the unemployment rates down to the national level, I'm going to fix our schools and I'm going to give these kids something to do after school to keep them out of trouble."
Mr. Clinton's visit on behalf of Ms. Messinger came two days before the election, on a day in which he tended to two serious tasks for his Democratic Party -- helping to elect a member of Congress from Staten Island and a governor of New Jersey. Ms. Messinger's opponent, Mr. Giuliani, yesterday kicked off a marathon bus trip through the five boroughs.
Although the polls show him far ahead of Ms. Messinger, the Mayor said he felt obliged to go out and ask his constituents for their votes. And he did all day and into the night, crisscrossing the city and waving at startled pedestrians and drivers while hanging on to the back rail of the bus. Page B4.
Although Mr. Clinton's appearance came just 35 hours before the polls open, and against the counsel of some White House advisers who, based on polls, contended that such a visit would be a politically damaging waste of time, Mr. Clinton left no doubt about his sentiment when he mounted the stage.
In a familiar setting -- a hotel ballroom at the Sheraton New York, a traditional stop on any Democratic campaign in New York -- he recalled how Ms. Messinger had endorsed his campaign when he was a little-known Governor from Arkansas, and stuck with him during some of the most difficult months.
"Through all the tough times, when I was going through my own particular New York marathon in 1992, she stuck by me," he said. "And I'm standing with her tonight."
It was, by any measure, an emotional high point for Ms. Messinger, coming after what her friends have described as six of the more difficult months of her career.
After months in which Ms. Messinger has encountered difficulty finding Democrats from New York to endorse or campaign with her, she stood by the side of a President as many of the Democrats who avoided her stood in the crowd. After weeks in which she frequently walked into embarrassingly empty campaign venues, she was in a ballroom so crowded that fire marshals stopped letting people in 20 minutes before Ms. Messinger and Mr. Clinton appeared, leaving hundreds of people outside the metal detectors.
And after weeks in which Ms. Messinger's press entourage often consisted of a solitary reporter and no television crews, she gazed out at a dozen television cameras, some of them feeding to live broadcasts.
Aside from clearly providing a lift to Ms. Messinger and her campaign staff, the effect of the President's visit on the election, coming so close to a vote and at a time when many polls show Mr. Giuliani heading for a strong victory, is an open question. At the very least, it brings her money: Ms. Messinger's aides said she raised between $150,000 and $200,000 from private receptions in which contributors paid either $1,000 to hear a speech or $5,000 for a chance to have their photo taken with Ms. Messinger and Mr. Clinton.
But if history is any guide, Mr. Clinton's appearance in New York last night -- and his repeated and obviously intentional emphasis on Democratic values -- could help Ms. Messinger among Democrats who many pollsters said were otherwise likely to stay home. Several analysts said it could also dissuade Democrats who were planning to vote for Mr. Giuliani, but with misgivings.
Given the lead that Mr. Giuliani appears to have in polls, that might do little to change the outcome of the race. But it could help to make it closer, which could be a problem for Mr. Giuliani, whose aides in recent days have been predicting that Mr. Giuliani would score a triumph of historic proportions, one that would allow him to leave the city, if he chose, and run for higher office.
In what has become fairly standard fare for Mr. Clinton's encounters in New York, his speech was interrupted -- at its height -- by a man protesting Mr. Clinton's policies on AIDS. As the crowd tried to yell down the protester with chants of "Ruth, Ruth," Mr. Clinton, as is his practice in these kind of encounters, hushed the crowd and said the man, who was not immediately identified, should be allowed to speak. "This is a serious issue," Mr. Clinton said. "But we can never get to the facts if you're just screaming. And I can't win a screaming match today."
Mr. Clinton, after recounting for his audience the political history that he shared with Ms. Messinger, cast the election along party lines, with an obvious eye to the five-to-one Democratic edge in New York. "I'm very proud to be a Democrat," the President said. "And I am proud to be part of a party that has a broad tent and that is inclusive and welcomes all kinds of people."
In his speech, Mr. Clinton offered innovative, if late, advice to Ms. Messinger on how to deal with what has been Mr. Giuliani's most overriding political strength: crime. He said Ms. Messinger should, in effect, share credit with Republicans for it, saying that the reduction in crime was good, and the result of policies adopted by both parties.
"Let me begin by saying I think it's a good thing that crime has come down in New York," Mr. Clinton said. "And I don't think that any Democrat should criticize any legitimate effort that brought it down. After all, remember, the first aggressive community policing, and the first drop in the New York City crime rate, began when David Dinkins was Mayor."
He said a decline in crime was "a good and noble thing."
"That is an American ideal," he said. "That does not belong to either party."
The audience, which included Mr. Dinkins, laughed and applauded.
The Presidential visit nearly did not happen at all. Several of Mr. Clinton's advisers had argued against investing any of Mr. Clinton's time in a race that most Democrats consider hopeless, particularly against a Republican, Mr. Giuliani, who has sided with Mr. Clinton on a number of important legislative battles and appears far more popular than Ms. Messinger. When Vice President Al Gore came to New York two weeks ago to speak at a Democratic fund-raiser, he did not criticize, much less mention, Mr. Giuliani once in his speech. Ms. Messinger and Mr. Gore sat at separate tables.
But as Mr. Clinton noted, Ms. Messinger was one of his first supporters when he ran for President in 1992. She endorsed him in February 1992 while Mr. Clinton, then the Governor of Arkansas, was buffeted by reports about difficulty in his marriage and about the lengths to which he went to avoid the draft. When Mr. Clinton came to New York for his difficult primary in the state, Ms. Messinger was often at the front of his stage, leading him through what he described again last night as one of his most difficult periods.
Ms. Messinger apparently reminded Mr. Clinton of that when he came to New York in September to address the United Nations General Assembly and to attend the opera. During that two-day visit, under strong pressure from Ms. Messinger's aides, the White House agreed to allow Mr. Clinton to pose with her for a picture at the Downtown Manhattan Heliport.
It was there, Ms. Messinger said, she asked him to do more. "I asked him if he would schedule some time to come in for some kind of fund-raising and campaign activity," she said yesterday. "He said he would find the time to do it."
It seemed, accordingly, a fairly emotional moment for Ms. Messinger. Seven hours before Mr. Clinton arrived, Ms. Messinger, who has had trouble in recent days rounding up crowds, was inviting everyone she met to come out for her rally. "A special friend is coming into town on my behalf," she said at the Union Baptist Church. "His name is William Jefferson Clinton."
There is some precedent to Mr. Clinton's visit here on behalf of a mayoral candidate. In 1993, he gave one of the most-noted speeches of his first term when he came to New York to help Mr. Dinkins. Then, he asserted that Mr. Dinkins deserved re-election because of his record, but was in trouble partly because "too many of us are still too unwilling to vote for people who are different than we are."
His remarks electrified the race, casting it in stark racial terms, and generated weeks of debate. Mr. Dinkins went on to lose to Mr. Giuliani by fewer than 50,000 votes.

HEADLINE: OPERA REVIEW;
Revitalization of a Production and a Company

BYLINE: By BERNARD HOLLAND 

 BODY:
I have no idea how the New York City Opera is doing financially this season, but onstage it is cheering us all up. A lot of the company's longtime well-wishers had more or less given up on what seemed to be a slide into artistic and economic oblivion. The procession of sloppy productions of the obvious and ill-advised adventures into the avant-garde were, at any rate, hardly promising.
Opera intendants almost always begin new jobs with seasons designed by their predecessors, so this fall reflects Paul Kellogg's first real empowerment over the city opera's repertory and its productions. Handel's "Xerxes" on Saturday night appeared as the latest constituent in a plan that actually seems to be working. 
 Mr. Kellogg begins with a happy inheritance: a handful of recent and honorable productions of the Puccini-Donizetti-Verdi literature devised to satisfy a company's need for a workable standard repertory. With the status quo more or less in hand, he has taken to flooding us with new and interesting things: recently Gluck's "Iphigenie en Tauride," next week "The Voyage of Marco Polo," by Tan Dun, and on Saturday Handel's serio-comic opera, here in a credible redesign and translation by Stephen Wadsworth.
While these productions are new to us and to the company, they are not new at all (the exception being the homegrown "Macbeth" that opened the season). "Iphigenie" comes by way of Mr. Kellogg's other opera company, Glimmerglass in Cooperstown, N.Y.; "Marco Polo" has had prior outings in Europe.
Similarly, although the Skylight Theater in Milwaukee and the Santa Fe Opera would resist the designation, the two companies have been the test kitchen for Mr. Wadsworth's "Xerxes," providing a chance for bad ideas to be discarded and the good ones to be shipped on to us in New York.
There is a time change in the setting, from Herodotus to the England of George II. Thomas Lynch's fixed set (no scene-ending curtains, just blackouts) is a wall framed by the obligatory plane tree and a two-story house. The tree is nicely gnarled; the pale brick identifies old England as clearly as if it were a written label.
Given the rhythms and colors of two very different languages, Mr. Wadsworth has had to demolish the Italian original and create something new. His English is American but not obtrusively so; it is often clever; it is also prone, especially in the last two acts, to overly cute rhyming effects.
What separated Saturday's "Xerxes" from efforts like it in the recent past was not just the finish of the production but the world-class casting. The City Opera has always been a house for American singers, but that principle has too often turned it into a postgraduate workshop for the promising and ill-prepared.
Lorraine Hunt in the title role was stunning, David Daniels's Arsamene scarcely less so. Amy Burton was a first-rate Romilda, Jan Opalach a sturdy Ariodate. As Atalanta, Susannah Waters had her hectic moments but did well. James Bobick's comic acting as Elviro never quite made up for a straying sense of pitch.
The City Opera orchestra, sounding so disconsolate in past years, seemed enthusiastic and energetic. George Manahan conducted using sensible compromises between historical fact and contemporary practice. The strings were modern, but there were John Beeson's harpsichord and Richard Kolb's lute biting at the heels of every attack.
Old and new also inhabited the vocal styles: clear rhythms, quick tempos, but big, dramatic singing too. Of special note was the use of cadenzas not for technical display but as a vehicle for emotional outburst. Mr. Wadsworth leans on the comic aspect of "Xerxes," but Ms. Hunt's splendid extroversions -- white hot but very much in control -- brought back the human unhappinesses Handel's opera projects as well. Mr. Daniels and Ms. Burton used similar opportunities.
The plot of "Xerxes," a story of mismatched lovers, requires powers of explanation that are probably not worth the effort or the space.
The final reconciliations are not convincing, but hanging vividly and disquietingly over the proceedings is a ruler's total power over the lives of those around him.
Saturday's audience was large, knowledgeable and wildly enthusiastic. This was not the City Opera's mom-and-pop "La Boheme" crowd, but one more liberally sprinkled with younger, hipper listeners, the type found more often these days across the river at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. The signs are good.
 
XERXES
 
Opera in three acts by George Frideric Handel, libretto by Nicolo Minato and Silvio Stampiglia; conductor, George Manahan; director, Stephen Wadsworth; sets by Thomas Lynch; costumes by Martin Pakledinaz; lighting by Peter Kaczorowski. Performed by the New York City Opera at the New York State Theater.

HEADLINE: In Congress and White House, Debate Begins on How to Use Future Budget Surpluses

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2

 BODY:
After decades in which huge Federal budget deficits cast a shadow over politics and the economy, Congress and the White House face the possibility that the Government will begin running surpluses in the next few years, and a heated debate is already breaking out over what to do with the money.
Many conservative Republicans want to dedicate all or most of any surpluses to paying down the mountain of debt accumulated over decades of wars, recessions and fiscal profligacy. Other Republicans are pushing for tax cuts. 
 Members of both parties are eagerly promoting more spending on roads, bridges and other politically appealing construction projects. Many Democrats lean toward additional spending on education and health programs.
Both White House officials and members of Congress are pondering how surpluses could help address the looming shortfall in financing for Social Security retirement benefits and the Medicare system of health insurance for the elderly.
That the debate is taking place at all strikes some officials as premature, given that the budget deficit, while falling rapidly, has not been eliminated and may never be if the economy falters. Even if the economy remains robust, just talking seriously about surpluses could erode the political will needed to bring the budget into balance, they said.
"We need to stop hyperventilating and complete the job of balancing the budget," said Representative John R. Kasich, the Ohio Republican who is chairman of the House Budget Committee.
The rapidly improving fiscal situation has nonetheless opened the door to a wide-ranging consideration of policy and political priorities as the glow of prosperity is beginning to alter the way official Washington is addressing the nation's long-term problems.
The deficit for the Government fiscal year that ended Sept. 30 was $22.6 billion, its lowest level since the early 1970's. If the economy remains strong, many analysts say, the budget could show a surplus within the next several years and continue to do so for years to come.
"For 15 years or more, the most important question you could ask about a public policy idea was what its effect was going to be on the budget deficit," said Franklin D. Raines, the White House budget director. "Now you have to ask what an idea's contribution to the country is going to be and how does that compare to other options."
In its broadest terms, the debate is dominated by two camps. One considers reducing the national debt to be the best use of any surplus, likening the nation's fiscal condition to that of a consumer who has learned not to use a credit card so much but still must muster the discipline to pay off the card's balance. The national debt is $5.3 trillion, and interest payments on it account for 15 percent of all Federal spending.
The other camp believes that there are other more pressing uses for the money, like tax cuts, transportation projects, higher Pentagon spending, school system improvements and access to medical care.
"Maintaining a surplus for use in reducing the national debt is good policy but bad politics," said Robert D. Reischauer, a fellow at the Brookings Institution in Washington and former director of the Congressional Budget Office.
"It would help increase the productivity of the work force and national living standards, help keep interest rates down and significantly reduce the fraction of the total budget that goes to debt service," he said. "But those types of benefits are very distant and diffuse, and politicians want concrete rewards and immediate ones. So it's natural for this debate to begin, and it's likely to intensify."
When Speaker Newt Gingrich presented his views on how to use the surplus to the House Budget Committee several weeks ago, he provided a perhaps unintentional look at how expansive a political appetite there is for new and expensive initiatives.
Mr. Gingrich started by saying that Congress should do whatever it takes, including cutting Federal spending further, to eliminate the annual deficit and push the budget into surplus. Then, he said, the country should push to run an annual surplus "large enough that a reasonable recession doesn't stop it" for use in paying off the national debt.
But Mr. Gingrich went on to lay claim to a slice of any surpluses for other uses, starting with a tax cut every year. Then he called for increased spending on science, the military and transportation. And last, he noted Congress's responsibility to shore up the Social Security and Medicare programs.
Mr. Kasich responded, somewhat wryly, by telling Mr. Gingrich that his proposals were "a tall order, you will have to admit, for a surplus that is yet to materialize" and that any surpluses that do materialize might never be big enough to pay for Mr. Gingrich's entire wish list.
"I think you are pushing the envelope with what you propose, but nevertheless, I think it is the kind of debate we need to have," Mr. Kasich told Mr. Gingrich.
There is no shortage of proposals to debate. Representative John A. Boehner of Ohio and Senator Spencer Abraham of Michigan, both Republicans, have introduced a bill that would set aside any revenue collected by the Government beyond that projected in the balanced budget deal negotiated by Congress and President Clinton earlier this year. The money would be reserved primarily for tax cuts or to pay for the costs of a fundamental overhaul of the tax code, another Republican priority. But the legislation would bar the use of any of the money for new spending programs.
Representative Mark W. Neumann of Wisconsin, a Republican, has introduced a bill that would cap increases in Federal spending at one percentage point below the rate of increase in tax revenues and mandate that two-thirds of the resulting surplus be applied to paying off the national debt and the other third to tax cuts.
"I feel pretty strongly that we have a moral and ethical responsibility to pay off the debts we've run up in the last 15 years," Mr. Neumann said.
But Representative Bud Shuster, a Republican from Pennsylvania who is chairman of the House Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure, is leading a push for more spending on highways and other transportation projects.
Democrats in Congress, wary of being tagged as tax-and-spend liberals, have shied away from detailed proposals for increased spending. But their leaders, including Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, have made clear that they see health, education and transportation as priorities.
The White House has taken a hard line against using any unexpectedly high tax revenues to finance spending programs before the budget is balanced. But Administration officials have begun meeting to discuss how to use any consistent surpluses. Officials said the options included things like tax incentives to reducing the emissions that cause global warming, more spending on education, training and health care, and getting an early start on fixing Social Security.
"Our general approach," said Gene Sperling, the director of the White House's National Economic Council, "is to take a deep breath, don't spend money you don't have and, if it does turn out that you have sustainable surpluses, to think long and hard about what would be best for the economy and average families."

The speaker -- who called Mr. Gingrich's proposals "a tall order, you will have to admit, for a surplus that has yet to materialize" -- was Representative John M. Spratt Jr. of South Carolina, the ranking Democrat on the committee, not Representative John R. Kasich, the Ohio Republican who is the committee's chairman.
"I think you are pushing the envelope with what you propose," Mr. Spratt said, "but, nevertheless, I think it is the kind of debate we need to have."

HEADLINE: Of Chinese Painting, and the Art of a Book Deal

BYLINE: By GAYLE FELDMAN 

 BODY:
When Margaret Thatcher went to Beijing to sign the 1984 accord that sealed Hong Kong's fate, one of the symbolic offerings she was given by the then-boss of the Chinese Communist Party, Hu Yaobang, was a Chinese-English dictionary.
Last week, when President Jiang Zemin of China came calling on President Clinton, one of the official presents he brought to Washington was a $75, lavishly illustrated book in English entitled "Three Thousand Years of Chinese Painting." 
 As Mr. Jiang returns home, and Americans and Chinese ponder the future of their mutually puzzling relationship, bookstores in both countries will be preparing to sell that book, the first of a 75-volume joint venture project covering art, language and culture, which is being published by Yale University Press and the Foreign Languages Press in Beijing.
The project is unusual in both its scope and in the nature of its collaboration, which involved both Chinese and Western scholars. It is not a straight commercial proposition -- outside financing from the National Endowment for the Humanities, the Henry Luce Foundation and various individuals in Asia and America provided about half of the $545,000 cost of the book and the project to date.
But the venture holds lessons for any American publisher interested in doing business in China, and is a sign of the new kinds of relationships being forged there.
For almost 20 years, American publishers have coveted the vast potential market in China. A few of the established international houses and textbook and reference publishers like John Wiley & Sons, Springer-Verlag of Germany and Oxford University Press have spent years cultivating relationships with the Chinese and selling them scientific and technical books or English-language teaching materials.
"In the early 1980's, John Wiley's revenues from China were as high as $1 million in one year resulting from book and journal purchases Chinese libraries made with World Bank loan money," said Deborah E. Wiley, a senior vice president of the company.
During that period, large American trade publishers like Random House, a unit of Advance Publications, Bantam and Harper & Row -- now HarperCollins, a division of the News Corporation -- along with some smaller publishers, went on forays to China, but many declined to enter the very foreign publishing market they found there. There was no copyright law, the retail price of books was very low, the state-controlled distribution network was bogged down in bureaucracy and marketing was nonexistent.
Bantam did sell some English-language paperbacks in tourist hotels and state-run foreign languages bookstores. Peter Mayer, the former chairman of Penguin, the publishing arm of Pearson P.L.C., negotiated an agreement licensing paperback reprints of such Penguin classics as "Jane Eyre," "Wuthering Heights" and "Women in Love." But, he said: "It was never meant to be lucrative. We thought by having a publishing relationship in China eventually there would be real opportunities for buying and selling books."
James Peck, the executive editor of the Yale-Foreign Languages Press project, said that part of the difficulty in doing business in China in the 1980's was that "trade publishers could not find a way to overcome the problems of China not having copyright and not being able to pay the foreign publisher and author royalties in foreign currency."
For example, he said that Bantam sold "Iacocca" to one Chinese press, but multiple pirated versions were brought out by others.
Rights sales for individual titles have been growing, however, since China passed copyright legislation and, in 1990, acceded to the Berne international convention, which requires that the Chinese publisher obtain copyright from the copyright holder and that the contract between them specify the financial responsibilities for the sale of the book.
The most desirable titles, like "The Road Ahead" by William H. Gates 3d have fetched royalty advances of $50,000 or so. Elton Welke, the publisher of Microsoft Press, said that after Berne, "the relationship with the Chinese was more comfortable, it became easier to work together."
The Chinese also pay for books associated with American films. Huang Youyi, the vice director general of the Foreign Languages Publishing Administration, who is responsible for the Yale-Foreign Languages Press series on the Chinese side, said that books based on "The English Patient" and "The Bridges of Madison County" have been hits.
The Yale project had deep roots and shows the importance of long-term personal relationships in dealing with China. Mr. Peck did graduate work in Chinese at Harvard in the 1960's and then, as an editor at Random House Inc.'s Pantheon Books, published a number of books about China and wrote two himself.
Mr. Peck recalled that in 1985, Robert Bernstein, then the chairman of Random House, "asked me to look into why Random had been unable to establish a publishing relationship with China; I recommended that we adopt a much more flexible approach about royalty payments and copyright questions and that we link up with two publishers, one of whom was the F.L.P."
But Mr. Bernstein was removed as Random House chairman in the fall of 1989 and Mr. Peck also left the company. Only a few contracts had actually been signed. The next spring, Mr. Bernstein mentioned the groundwork that he and Mr. Peck had laid to John Ryden, director of the Yale University Press. Eventually, "The Culture and Civilization of China" series was conceived and a contract signed at the end of 1991.
All publishing in China is ultimately state controlled (apart from the illegal trade in pirated or banned material), and forging personal connections within China has proved useful to some other publishers.
During the last two years, Simon & Schuster, a unit of Viacom Inc., set up an office in Beijing. Bertelsmann A.G., the German media company whose divisions include the American publishers Bantam, Doubleday and Dell, set up a joint-venture direct sales operation, a book club and other ventures in Shanghai.
Foreign publishers are learning that they need to employ Chinese and Americans who can straddle both worlds. Martin Maleska, president of Simon & Schuster International, said, "By putting people on the ground there we better understand the needs of this emerging information market."
