HEADLINE: Computers Model World's Climate, but How Well?

SERIES: The Warming World -- Confronting climate change.

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS 

 BODY:
TOM'S RESTAURANT at 112th Street and Broadway in Upper Manhattan is right out of "Seinfeld." But six floors above, Dr. Makiko Sato and Dr. James E. Hansen are conjuring up a bigger world from the innards of what looks like a slightly oversized personal computer. This is no ordinary computer, however. It contains the earth's atmosphere and oceans, albeit in mathematical form, interconnected to create a virtual global climate system.
About 20 of these ocean-atmosphere climate models now exist, four times as many as a decade ago. They are the principal tools available to researchers who are trying to understand how the global climate is changing. By pumping data on temperature, winds, solar radiation, ocean currents and a host of other climatic factors into a model and then setting it in motion, scientists can simulate what could happen over time if emissions of heat-trapping greenhouse gases increase. 
 These simulations are the basis of predictions that the average surface temperature of the earth will rise substantially and disrupt the world's climate in coming decades unless there are reductions in the emissions of greenhouse gases like carbon dioxide, which is produced by the burning of fossil fuels like coal and oil.
The models' forecast -- a unanimous one -- has been accepted uncritically as gospel by some environmentalists and even some scientists and dismissed as all but worthless by some opponents of emissions reductions. Most experts take a middle stance, saying that while the models are getting more realistic all the time, they remain relatively crude versions of reality whose findings should be interpreted with care.
So how useful are the models as policy guides for the nations of the world as they prepare to meet in Kyoto, Japan, on Dec. 1 to negotiate cuts in emissions of greenhouse gases?
One hint materializes from the computer above Tom's, one of several like it in the offices of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's Goddard Institute for Space Studies. Dr. Sato, a physicist and climate researcher, punches keys, and world maps appear on her computer's monitor. In vivid colors ranging from yellow to orange to dark red (for degrees of warmth) through shades of blue (for degrees of cold), maps on the right of the screen show the pattern of global temperature changes the computer climate model "predicted" for the period 1979 to 1995. Maps on the left show the changes that actually took place.
The picture presented by the comparison is clear: In broadest terms, the computer got it right; the world as a whole warmed, and the Northern Hemisphere warmed most. But it also got a lot of the regional details wrong. The computer said that eastern Canada should have warmed substantially, for instance, but, instead, it cooled a lot.
Not a lot of stock should be placed in a single "run" of a single model, or even in many runs. But many runs of many models present the same picture suggested by the maps on Dr. Sato's screen: that the models show a general global fidelity to reality but also pervasive regional error. They also continue to yield the same general conclusion their much cruder predecessors first yielded nearly two decades ago: that a doubling of carbon dioxide concentrations in the atmosphere would raise the earth's average surface temperature by three to eight degrees Fahrenheit. The wide range is a measure of the differences among model projections, and thus of the uncertainty inherent in climate modeling.
A doubling of carbon dioxide concentrations is expected late in the next century if the world pursues business as usual. To get an idea of the magnitude of the models' forecast, one should consider that the world is five to nine degrees warmer now than in the depths of the last ice age.
Despite the models' inability to simulate the regional details of climate change, the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, a group of scientists advising the climate negotiations under United Nations auspices, says its confidence in the models is growing. Not only have the models become more sophisticated and detailed, the scientists say, they have also successfully passed some important reality checks by simulating actual climate changes with reasonable accuracy.
The models are exhibiting "a progressive convergence toward what has happened in nature," said Dr. W. Lawrence Gates, a climatologist at the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory in California who has long been a leader of systematic international efforts, including those of the intergovernmental panel, to evaluate the models.
For making long-term predictions of climatic change on a continental scale or greater, Dr. Gates said, "the ensemble of existing modern models is reliable" and "provides a firm scientific base for policy."
Not everyone agrees. Some skeptics, like Dr. Richard S. Lindzen of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, have always considered the models worthless as prognosticators, and still do. "I'm not saying the model output bears no resemblance at all to nature; in the gross figures, it looks plausibly similar," Dr. Lindzen said. But that, he said, "does not give you forecast ability."
No model, by definition, will ever match the real world perfectly. "It's never going to happen," said Dr. Hansen, the director of the Goddard Institute. A decade ago, Dr. Hansen became the first scientist to go on record before Congress and say that the greenhouse effect was probably the cause of global warming.
Models will always fail to mimic nature exactly, he says, even though today's smaller but much faster computers make possible a precision unapproached by the lumbering mainframe that occupied an entire floor above Tom's some 20 years ago, when the Hansen team became one of the first to simulate global climate -- and even though still faster computers are just over the horizon.
For one thing, the atmosphere's normal internal churnings are to some extent unpredictable; some variations are never repeated exactly. As Dr. Hansen put it, "the climate in any year is like a snowflake; no two are alike." The same can be said for decades and centuries. For another thing, the atmosphere is far too complex to be completely captured in any computer program. The essence of modeling is to simplify but to retain the processes most important in driving the climate.
Nevertheless, proponents of the models say, they are the most powerful tools available for analyzing climate. While the incessant pouring of greenhouse gases into the air by industrial activity constitutes an experiment of sorts, there is no way to know how it will turn out without waiting for several decades. Why turn to computers? The atmosphere is simply too complex for any other mode of analysis, and the virtual climate made possible by computers is far closer to reality than any model that might be generated in anyone's head, the model proponents say.
Some things about climate are simple and certain enough, needing no computer analysis. Scientists know, for instance, that a doubling of carbon dioxide, by itself, would warm the earth's surface by about two degrees. They also know that atmospheric concentrations of the gas are increasing as a result of industrial activity.
But simplicity ends there. The warming touches off feedback processes, some of which increase the warming and some of which decrease it. For instance, a warmer atmosphere melts snow and sea ice, both of which cool the planet by reflecting sunlight; less ice and snow means further warming. On the other hand, warming also increases low-level clouds, which cool the planet.
Modeling is in large measure an exercise in representing enough of these competing influences faithfully enough to estimate their net effect. The most important of the feedback influences, perhaps, involves water vapor, the most powerful greenhouse gas of all. An atmosphere warmed by carbon dioxide produces more vapor, and this amplification is critical to the models' forecasts of future warming.
A climate model is a computer program containing mathematical equations that express fundamental laws of atmospheric physics. These laws govern the interlinked workings of the sun, atmosphere, oceans, land and other elements of the climate system. The various feedback influences are also expressed mathematically. The computer calculates the extent to which the basic physical laws dictate changes in things like temperature and precipitation over time and under different conditions. For instance, modelers can introduce any sort of "forcing" influence they want -- increasing greenhouse gases, for instance -- to see what would happen over decades and centuries.
One big limitation of the models in predicting the climate decades ahead is that despite the growing speed of computers, they are unable to calculate climatic changes everywhere in the atmosphere. Instead, they make the calculations only at widely separated points. The points form a three-dimensional grid typically rising 10 or 12 miles above the earth. A typical spacing between grid points is about 150 miles horizontally and less than half a mile vertically. This "resolution," as scientists call it, is about twice as fine as a decade ago. But it still misses many processes that happen between grid points -- cloud formation, for example. So modelers approximate these factors as best they can.
Coarse resolution is also the major reason why the models are not very good at simulating climate at the regional scale. They simply miss too many small-scale climatic influences, like topography, vegetation and regional atmospheric churnings. Some modelers have developed techniques for overcoming this. For instance, they might model only part of the ocean-atmosphere system, using much more closely spaced grid points, to get a better fix on regional changes. That approach has been successfully employed, for instance, in predicting the comings and goings of El Nino, the vast pool of tropical Pacific water that disrupts weather around the world.
In another technique, modelers take the general results of a global climate model and use them to construct a second model of higher resolution for a limited region. Researchers at Pennsylvania State University have so far successfully used this "nesting" technique to reproduce observed precipitation patterns in the Middle Atlantic region.
As computers become more advanced, the resolution of models continues to improve. Researchers at a number of Federal laboratories are collaborating in the development of a next-generation model using several computers operating in parallel. The ocean part of the model has a horizontal grid spacing of less than 20 miles, which researchers believe is necessary to represent fine-scale ocean eddies and currents.
It is only in the last few years that models have included deep-ocean processes, which are critical to the climate system's functioning. The ocean, for instance, absorbs both carbon dioxide and heat, transports heat from one part of the planet to the other and provides moisture to the atmosphere.
An even bigger limitation of the models than coarse resolution is the incomplete knowledge of the atmosphere's functioning, Dr. Hansen says. Dr. Gates agrees, saying, "How the natural world works -- that's always going to be our problem."
Still, the models have been steadily incorporating more and more features of the climate system. One of the most important, in terms of model realism, has been the effect of tiny solid particles and liquid droplets suspended in the atmosphere. The modern economy produces a lot of these aerosols, as they are called, most notably sulfur dioxide droplets emitted by industry. Aerosols cool parts of the planet by reflecting sunlight. Before this effect was included in the models, they consistently produced more global warming than was being observed. Afterward, the model representations and the observations agreed more closely.
With the aerosol effect factored in, the intergovernmental science panel estimates that the average global temperature will rise by two to six degrees in the next century, with a best estimate of about three and a half degrees, barring cuts in greenhouse emissions. The warming will continue after that, the panel says.
The biggest gap in knowledge, many scientists believe, is that the net effect of clouds on the planet's temperature is still unknown. While low-level clouds reflect heat, high-level clouds trap it. Moreover, experts do not fully understand how water vapor behaves when the atmosphere warms. The amount by which vapor amplifies the warming therefore remains uncertain.
Dr. Lindzen has long maintained that the models simply get the physics of the water vapor feedback wrong, at least at high altitudes. The United Nations panel says the amplification clearly takes place at lower altitudes but concedes the uncertainty about higher altitudes.
Even if such uncertainties are somehow resolved, modelers will never be sure that they have included all the information necessary for realism. "With any models, what you never know is what you haven't put in," said Dr. Jeremiah P. Ostriker of Princeton University, who comes at computer modeling from a different perspective, that of an astrophysicist who uses models to study the cosmos. The best reality check, he said, "is to see how well you can match the real world."
By that standard, on the plus side, mainstream scientists say the models reproduce the main features of present-day climate, including the seasonal cycle, the comings and goings of monsoons, the seasonal shift of major rain belts and storm tracks, the average daily temperature cycle and many large-scale features of ocean circulation.
In the last two years, Dr. Gates said, models have for the first time reproduced the magnitude and frequency of the climate system's natural internal fluctuations on several time scales. "A number of them now have simulated variability that looks realistic," he said. But, he said, the unpredictability inherent in these fluctuations makes it impossible to predict their timing, and always will.
The models have also reproduced, at least in general outline, the changes in global climate observed in the last century. These include not only a general global warming of about one degree but also broad patterns of temperature change, both geographically and vertically, through the atmosphere.
When the Mount Pinatubo volcano erupted in the Philippines in 1991, sending aloft a global haze of planet-cooling aerosols, the Goddard model predicted that the cooling would be about one degree at its low point and would last about two years. That is what actually happened. To many experts, that indicates that the model faithfully reflects the climate system's sensitivity to heating and cooling influences from outside -- whether they be aerosols or greenhouse gases.
Models have also simulated the climate of the last ice age and come up with an average global temperature about seven degrees lower than today's, well within the cold period's actual temperature range.
But the models do not always match reality this well. One major shortcoming, for instance, is that the global models fail to simulate accurately the major temperature swings associated with El Nino. And there is that biggest deficiency of all: the failure to predict climatic change accurately on a regional scale.
In sum, the models are still cloudy crystal balls. But they are getting clearer, and they offer some answers.
"Despite all the uncertainties, I think you can make useful estimates" of climatic change using the models, said Dr. Andrew P. Ingersoll, a planetary scientist at the California Institute of Technology who employs them to investigate the climates of other planets.
"You just have to be aware of the uncertainties," he said. "It's just like any other scientific process."
 
Warming World
This article is one of a series that have appeared since Aug. 12 on the science, politics and economics of climate change with the approach of an international meeting in Kyoto, Japan, beginning Dec. 1 to discuss limits on greenhouse gases.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Makiko Sato and James E. Hansen looking over their work using computers to predict the world's weather. (Edward Keating/The New York Times)(pg. F6)
 
Chart: "A Better Crystal Ball"
Scientists can precisely measure the increase in heat-trapping greenhouse gases, like carbon dioxide, in Earth's atmosphere. But they cannot say precisely what climate changes, if any, the increase will produce. Conditions in the atmosphere depend on a vast array of factors -- winds, clouds, ocean currents and so on -- that are fiendishly difficult to quantify. Still, the increasing power of computers has enabled climatologists to improve their ability to make numerical models of climate change.
 
So far, climate models do far better globally than locally.
A climate model at NASA Goddard Institute for Space Studies, left, predicted average global surface temperature changes from 1979 to 1995.
 
Over all, the predictions corresponded pretty well to temperatures measured during that time. But in particular localities, there were large differences between predicted and observed readings.
 
Effects and counter-effects
A major task of climate models is to calculate the net effect of competing processes and influences, shown below. Some enhance global warming; others retard it.
 
1. A global grid . . .
Climate model-builders start by laying a grid over the surface of the Earth. They extend the grid into three dimensions, up into the atmosphere.
 
2. . . . of layered cubes
Each box in the grid is allotted a given amount of heat, air pressure, water vapor and the like.
 
3. Then, based on the principles of physics, the computer predicts how these elements will interact over time if one variable -- emissions of greenhouse gases, for example -- is changed.
 
?. Puzzles in the clouds
The process is complicated by gaps in scientific knowledge. For example, warming on Earth would cause more water to evaporate, producing more clouds. But some clouds reflect sunlight, which might in turn cause the planet to cool. The net effect is unclear.
 
?. Only some of the carbon emitted through the burning of fossil fuels turns up in the atmosphere, and scientists would like to know where the rest of it goes. Some of it ends up in seawater and soil.
 
(Sources: James E. Hansen, NASA Goddard Institute for Space Studies;Atmosphere, Climate and Change Scientific American )(pg. F1)

HEADLINE: Fluor Sees Plunge in Profits Of $100 Million for the Year

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 3

 BODY:
The Fluor Corporation said today that it expected profits for its new fiscal year to fall about $100 million, some 25 percent to 30 percent, below Wall Street estimates because of deteriorating business conditions, partly as a result of the financial turmoil in Asia.
The announcement stunned Wall Street, and Fluor's stock fell $3.875, or 9.4 percent, in heavy trading, closing at $37.25. 
 Shares of Fluor and other construction and engineering companies have taken a beating in recent weeks because of the economic uncertainty in Southeast Asia, which has been a major market for some of these companies, as they construct roads, railroads, power plants and factories.
But Lisa Boyette, a spokeswoman for Fluor, said the biggest reason for the earnings shortfall was that competitive pressures were cutting profit margins in many parts of the company's business. "Asia plays into it a bit, but it's a much bigger picture than that," she said.
She said the company had not had any projects canceled or postponed in Asia, which accounts for about 20 percent of its backlog. "However," she said, "what we now anticipate is that projects that haven't been awarded yet could slow down" as customers take a "wait and see" attitude in light of severe currency devaluations and slowing growth in the region.
Michael S. Dudas, an analyst with UBS Securities in New York, said the situation "is more a fundamental internal problem," unique to Fluor.
"The size of the shortfall is what's the shocking aspect to everyone here," he said. "This may cause some people to think about whether the company needs to have a major restructuring."
Fluor, based in Irvine, Calif., said it expected its operating profits for its engineering and construction subsidiary, Fluor Daniel, to range from $225 million to $250 million in the fiscal year that ends in October, 1998, about $100 million below estimates. Per share earnings for the parent company, it added, are likely to be 75 cents to $1 below current estimates of $3.30 to $3.75 a share.
This is only the latest in a string of setbacks for Fluor, whose stock was trading at twice its current level in February and for more than $53 as recently as Oct. 21.
In May, the company, whose revenues of about $11 billion make it the biggest American construction company by some rankings, announced it would take a $120 million provision for cost overruns on two big power plant projects. It also took a $20 million charge for layoffs and other moves intended to cut $100 million a year in costs.
In a statement today, Fluor's chairman and chief executive, Leslie G McCraw, said the projected earnings were "unacceptable" and that the company would move more toward high-margin markets and take various cost-cutting measures.

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3

 BODY:
Rates on United States savings bonds declined effective today. Series EE bonds issued on or after May 1 of this year will earn 5.59 percent annual interest this month through April, down from 5.68 percent in the previous six months. The rate on Series EE bonds issued from May 1995 through April 1997 fell to 4.53 percent for the next six months, down from 4.63 percent. These bonds will earn more if held for five years.

HEADLINE: Two Reports Show Strength in Economy

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3

 BODY:
Two economic reports showed today that manufacturing unexpectedly strengthened in October and personal incomes rose in September, signs that the economy might not be slowing enough to keep the Federal Reserve from raising borrowing costs.
A third report showed that construction spending fell unexpectedly in September, posting its biggest drop in almost a year as builders spent less on hotels, office buildings, schools and hospitals. But even with the decline, most analysts expect construction will proceed at a high level for months to come. 
 Taken together, the statistics increase the possibility that the Fed could raise the overnight bank lending rate to guard against accelerating inflation, providing last week's rout in the stock market does not hurt consumer confidence or spending. The fourth quarter is "likely to see strong industrial production numbers, so any slowdown will have to come from the consumer sector," said Ian Shepherdson, an economist at HSBC Securities Inc. in New York.
In financial markets, Treasury bonds fell after the reports, a sign that traders were less confident about the outlook for interest rates. The decline in bonds also reflected a broad shift of money into stocks, which helped the Dow Jones industrial average soar 232.31 points, or 3.12 percent.
The most closely scrutinized of the reports was the October manufacturing survey by the National Association of Purchasing Management, the freshest data on the economy's health.
An index derived from survey results rose to 56 last month from 54.2 in September, led by orders and production. Analysts had expected a decline to 54.1.
A reading of 50 or more in the index means manufacturing is expanding, while a reading below 50 signals a contraction. Employment and exports also strengthened.
Another index in the survey that measures prices, considered as an indicator of inflation, rose to 55.9 in October from 54.7. Industries reporting improved business conditions in October ranged from petroleum and paper to electronics, the report showed.
Personal income showed no sign of deterioration in September. Income climbed four-tenths of a percent in September after rising six-tenths of a percent in August, Commerce Department figures showed. Consumer spending also increased in September, rising two-tenths of a percent after climbing three-tenths of a percent in August.
The news on personal income and spending was less of a surprise because it was already evident in third-quarter statistics on the gross domestic product issued Friday by the Commerce Department. The economy grew at a stronger-than-expected 3.5 percent annual pace in the third quarter, helped by an annualized 5.7 percent third-quarter surge in consumer spending -- the biggest increase since the first quarter of 1982.
The Commerce Department report on construction showed spending declined 1.1 percent, to an annual pace of $595.8 billion in September, the biggest drop since outlays fell 1.2 percent last December. Analysts had expected a gain of five-tenths of a percent. But the news had little impact, partly because it was overshadowed by the strength of the purchasing survey and personal-income reports.
In addition, analysts said the outlook for higher construction spending in the coming months was good, because the vibrant economy was generating record tax revenues for public works projects and the supply of housing was falling.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Strong Stocks And Economy Hobble Bonds

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
The prices of Treasury securities fell yesterday as strong economic data raised concerns about inflation and as a strong rebound in stocks pulled money out of the bond market. The losses came despite increased confidence that the Federal Reserve would not raise short-term interest rates at next week's monetary policy meeting.
The price of the 30-year bond fell 23/32, to 102 9/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 6.21 percent, from 6.15 percent on Friday. 
 Bond investors were alarmed by a report of strong manufacturing conditions from the National Association of Purchasing Management. Its monthly index rose unexpectedly, to 56 points in October from 54.2 a month earlier.
The report showed that prices were up, too, though analysts said that broader inflation was still a long way off. Nonetheless, traders believe that investors will put off making major purchases until after next Tuesday's meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee. Before the meeting, a number of reports, including employment data for October, will provide a clearer picture of the economy's direction. The jobs report is scheduled for Friday.
Yesterday's losses in Treasury securities mounted in the afternoon as stocks rose sharply, with the Dow closing at 7,674.40, up 232.31 points. All last week bonds had capitalized on the turmoil in world stock markets, as investors fled to the safety of United States Government securities. With yesterday's gains in stocks, some of that money was pulled out of bonds again.
Kenneth J. McCarthy, founder of the Economic Intelligence Company, an economic consulting and forecasting firm, said that despite the recent volatility in stocks, declines would not be prolonged or severe given the general soundness of the economy.
"The only reason rates have dropped this low is the uncertainty surrounding equity market prospects in the U.S. and abroad in the next few weeks," Mr. McCarthy said. "Once equity markets settle down, we expect interest rates to rise."
Amid all the coming economic reports, the Treasury will be conducting a $35 billion quarterly debt refunding, adding the additional burden of supply to the market's concerns. As a result, prices of securities are likely to remain contained, with investors demanding a risk premium before they buy, analysts said.
But Doug Burtnick, managing analyst at Technical Data of Boston, said that while prospects for the refunding auctions were uncertain, the general outlook for the market was not entirely negative.
"In general, weakness will be viewed by longer-term investors as a buying opportunity," he said. "Last week's global equity debacles still hold the potential for providing a longer-term drag on the world economies and in the long haul, should keep inflation in check."
Results at yesterday's auction of Treasury bills were better than expected, with the rate for a three-month maturity averaging about 5.12 percent, up from 4.97 percent a week ago and the six-month maturities at 5.13 percent, up from 5.08 percent.
In when-issued trading ahead of today's $14 billion sale of new three-year notes, which begins the quarterly refunding, dealers were offering them at a price to yield 5.75 percent, up from 5.66 percent on Friday. Tomorrow's $11 billion of 10-year notes were offered at a price to yield 5.91 percent, and Thursday's $10 billion of 30-year bonds, 6.17 percent.

HEADLINE: October Auto Sales Weak Except for Newest Designs

BYLINE: By ROBYN MEREDITH 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Nov. 3

 BODY:
People shopping for a new car last month were ready to plunk down money for the hottest new or redesigned models, leaving auto makers with lackluster sales for all but the freshest designs.
The Chrysler Corporation said today that its sales fell 8.3 percent in October, the first month of the new model year. But its newest sport utility vehicle, the brawny Dodge Durango, sold briskly, as did its new four-door version of the Dodge Ram pickup truck. 
 Honda's redesigned 1998 Accord sold briskly during its first month on the market, helping the company's sales increase 11.2 percent in October. "Sales the first month out of the gate are fantastic," said Dick Colliver, a Honda executive vice president.
David L. Littmann, the senior economist at the Detroit-based Comerica Bank, said that Honda's brisk sales of the Accord combined with weaker sales at other auto makers showed that American consumers were attracted to extensively redesigned models, rather than vehicles that change little from year to year. "Unless you have a new vehicle, a new product, then your market share is going to erode," he said.
Chrysler is counting on the introduction of two new sedans -- the Dodge Intrepid this month and the Chrysler Concorde by December -- to lift its sales out of the doldrums.
"The overall market may still be a bit soft, but we're pleased at what we're seeing and confident about the coming months," said James P. Holden, Chrysler's executive vice president of sales and marketing. Chrysler's car sales fell 13.3 percent in October while sales of its sport utility vehicles, mini-vans and pickup trucks fell 6.2 percent.
The General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company, which are scheduled to report their October sales results Tuesday, are each expected to report declines of up to 5 percent. For the nine manufacturers reporting results today, sales dropped 2 percent.
Several reported increases in October. Nissan said its sales rose 4 percent. Subaru said its sales rose 17 percent, Volvo 9.7 percent and Kia 55.7 percent.
But others posted declines. Isuzu said its sales fell 24.8 percent, Mitsubishi 16.5 percent and Land Rover, a unit of BMW A.G., 24.6 percent.
The weakness in sales comes after months of ferocious competition in the auto market that have slowed the rise in light-truck prices and actually produced a drop in prices of new cars. On average, prices for new light trucks rose only seven-tenths of 1 percent in the 12-month period ended in September, while prices of new cars actually fell by an identical seven-tenths of 1 percent, according to Labor Department figures. By comparison, the overall Consumer Price Index rose 2.2 percent in the period.
Auto makers have tried wooing buyers with generous rebates and discounted leases along with lower prices, but sales remain soft. "The consumer is alive and kicking," said David M. Garrity, a Smith Barney auto analyst. "When consumers have more choices, things become a little more difficult" for manufacturers.
With all the rebates offered to help spur sales, car dealers are not complaining much. Stephen Peck, the sales manager at a Dodge dealership in Baltimore, said that sales were up 22 percent from October 1996, mainly because of strong sales of light trucks and deep discounts on the prices of the Neon and Stratus sedans.
The Dodge Durango full-sized sport utility vehicle was an instant success, he said, while the Dodge Ram Quad Cab full-sized pickup, which has a four-door passenger compartment, appeals to a wider audience than the farmers who used to buy pickups. "We're getting a very nice mix of consumers, including professionals as well," Mr. Peck said.
Alan Sweetow, the general manager of a multifranchise dealership in Escondido, Calif., said that the redesigned 1998 Honda Accord sedan had been very successful while the CR-V sport utility vehicle, introduced last winter, was continuing to sell well. At his dealership, sales of Hondas and Mazdas were up, while Acura sales fell, but only because of a shortage of new cars, Mr. Sweetow said.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
A Clinton adviser argues the economic case for self-regulation of sales pitches in cyberspace.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
THE Clinton Administration's point person on Internet issues is lobbying Madison Avenue to help insure that a policy providing for the self-regulation of cyberspace -- including sales pitches aimed at children -- withstands strong, sustained challenges.
"What you are doing is essential to the success of the Administration's strategy," Ira C. Magaziner, senior adviser to President Clinton for policy development, said yesterday at a conference about youngsters and on-line advertising. "The tremendous economic benefits of the Internet will not work if we don't get efficient industry self-regulation on issues like privacy and content, especially in the children's area." 
 "If you fail, we will have to go the legislative route," he added. "That gets caught up in the political process and will be less rational and efficient."
About 100 people heard Mr. Magaziner as he gave the keynote address at the conference, held at the World Trade Center in lower Manhattan. The conference was sponsored by the Children's Advertising Review Unit, an organization that is part of the longtime voluntary self-regulatory process of adjudicating advertising disputes.
In April, the children's unit issued voluntary guidelines on Internet marketing to junior consumers. That has become a contentious topic, with parents complaining about what they perceive as disingenuous appeals to their sons and daughters for data in exchange for trinkets or E-mail signed by cartoon characters.
The guidelines include recommendations that advertisers disclose why they are requesting information from children and what will be done with it. Three months after the guidelines were issued, President Clinton disclosed his worldwide economic commerce strategy, which was based on a position paper from a task force headed by Mr. Magaziner.
The position paper was surprising for its forthright advocacy of self-regulation instead of governmental intervention, primarily because Mr. Magaziner was the architect of the Clinton health care plan, which failed after being criticized for relying too heavily on regulatory bureaucracy.
One reason that cyberspace warrants a laissez-faire approach, Mr. Magaziner said, is that "interactivity gives you the unique ability to empower people, parents, schools and libraries to protect themselves."
Mr. Magaziner acknowledged that there had been protests about the new policy. "People say: 'You're just being a shill. You're leaving the Internet open to let industry do all this terrible marketing to children,' " he said. " 'How can you do that, particularly as Democrats?' "
"People get afraid of change," he said, "afraid of something their kids understand better than them."
But, Mr. Magaziner asserted, he is responding to a larger, more damaging fear, which has hampered the growth of "the new digital economy": the fear that "governments would step in and overregulate, overtax and overcensor the Internet and strangle development."
Electronic commerce will be "the engine of growth for the world economy and the U.S. econony in the next quarter-century," he added, saying, "If we get in and regulate it, we'll just mess it up."
Those who want to police on-line content should "look to the private sector for the means," Mr. Magaziner said, perhaps in the form of "brand-name filters," software developed by organizations like the Children's Television Workshop or the Christian Coalition.
He added that it was "essential that children's privacy be protected and children not be exploited, that information is not gained from children without parental permission."
Asked by a member of the audience if that was a "practical impossibility," he replied: "When a C.E.O. really wants to do something, then it gets done. What we are saying to C.E.O.'s is that if you think the Internet will be a business opportunity, make this a priority."
The Children's Advertising Review Unit is administered by the National Advertising Review Council, formed by the Council of Better Business Bureaus and three organizations: the American Advertising Federation, the American Association of Advertising Agencies and the Association of National Advertisers.
On-line ads for children "offer some exciting opportunities for creativity and innovation," said Walter J. O'Brien, president of the review council and vice president of the Better Business Bureaus, but the "consequences of even a small misstep can be significant."
"Are we up to the challenge Ira issued today?" he asked. "I think we are, but if we aren't, we'll get beaten down" by Government regulation.
Mr. O'Brien said he would pursue a request from Mr. Magaziner that the children's unit ask the European Union to follow the American de minimis approach to Internet regulation, rather than adopt Government strictures.
Elizabeth Lascoutx, vice president and director for the children's unit, said the voluntary guidelines had worked well since April, adding that "we're working on about 30" questions about on-line children's ads.
"The real challenge," Ms. Lascoutx said, "is that a lot of Web publishers and developers don't come out of advertising. Though they're responsive when we get to them, they don't have any background on self-regulation."
Jeffrey Perlman, senior vice president for government affairs at the American Advertising Federation, said he saw a similar problem in dealing with World Wide Web sites put up by fans or entrepreneurs who advertise, promote or sell popular toys and collectibles.
"They're people who don't intend to do anything wrong," he said, "but they don't know what to do."

HEADLINE: Long Behind, Louisville Is Experiencing a Surge

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 31

 BODY:
Almost as a symbolic affirmation of this city's resurgence, Muhammad Ali is coming home.
After 11 years in Berrien Springs, Mich., Mr. Ali and his wife, Lonnie, have announced they are moving back to Louisville, the city of their births, to supervise the development of the Muhammad Ali Center, a museum to celebrate the athletic, humanitarian and spiritual aspects of his life. 
 For Kentucky's largest city, the timing could hardly be better. After decades as the heart of a slumbering region largely known for the Kentucky Derby, bourbon and Louisville Slugger baseball bats (which until last year were made in Indiana), Louisville is awakening. With the 1990's have come new cultural attractions, new businesses and, for the first time in decades, population growth, with nearly one million people now living in a seven-county area that includes the city.
Growth has also brought the Louisville area new problems. Mayor Jerry E. Abramson said that though the overall crime rate had dropped in recent years, the number of homicides had increased as a result of a new epidemic of crack cocaine. Drug dealers who have saturated big-city markets, Mayor Abramson said, are now looking to smaller cities like his for customers.
In each of the last two years, the Louisville police have recorded about 60 murders, twice the total of any previous year, and "better than half of them," Mr. Abramson said, "are directly related to drugs."
But unlike other regions, where an economic boom and population growth have led to sprawl, driven up real estate costs, accelerated life styles -- and even attracted a criminal element -- metropolitan Louisville has largely retained its folksy appeal, leisurely pace and affordable prices. This is a town, after all, where most everybody calls Mr. Abramson Mayor Jer.
"A lot of people live here happily because we're not Atlanta or Nashville," said Paul A. Coomes, a professor of economics at the University of Louisville, making the customary comparisons used by local officials in their business recruitment campaigns.
Just as larger cities like Baltimore, Pittsburgh and Las Vegas periodically reinvent themselves to stay economically viable, smaller cities are engaged in their own competition, which in many ways is more intense. There are more of them.
Here at the crossroads of the South and Midwest, Louisville has struggled for years with regional cities like Indianapolis, Nashville and Cincinnati to attract businesses, young professionals and a highly educated work force.
By some measures, the others have always been winning, with larger and more cosmopolitan populations. Indianapolis has 752,000 people, according to the United States Census Bureau for 1994; Nashville has 505,000; Cincinnati, 358,000, and Louisville only 270,000. It is unlikely that Louisville will overtake its larger neighbors in population any time soon.
But many people here say the combination of Louisville's location, relatively low real estate costs and growing number of theaters, museums, sports arenas and other diversions, is helping the region catch up. This year alone, 204 companies have located or expanded in the metropolitan area, adding 10,532 jobs, according to the Kentucky Economic Development Office. The region has sustained that pace for more than five years and now has an unemployment rate below 4 percent.
"We had an image problem to overcome," said Michael P. Bosc, vice president of the Greater Louisville Chamber of Commerce. "We had the image of Kentucky as hillbillies, and we needed the world to know we had a lot more than bourbon, horse racing and tobacco."
Like many other regions of the country, northern Kentucky was devastated by the recession of the 1980's. As 40 percent of the regional economy, manufacturing was hit particularly hard. Plants closed, and 35,000 people lost jobs.
To stanch the losses, elected officials and leaders of the business community began pushing to diversify the economy. That included plans for a $600 million expansion of the Louisville airport to add passenger terminals and two new parallel runways. One has been completed and the other is expected to open in December.
Around the same time, the region got a huge boost from United Parcel Service, now the state's largest private employer, which had bought its first seven cargo jets in 1981, based them in Louisville and hired 250 people to run the company's new two-day air service. Today, U.P.S. flies 207 planes and employs 14,000 workers in the area.
"It's not been chopped liver," Mr. Abramson, 51, a Democrat who was elected to a record third four-year term in 1993, said in an interview. "We have had a continual evolution but in a managed growth way. We haven't created traffic difficulties and the growth has not overwhelmed our infrastructure. Things are good."
In addition, area residents have many more amenities than people living in cities of comparable size have, including an orchestra, an opera company, repertory theater, children's theater, the Kentucky Derby Museum, a baseball bat museum that opened a year ago, a new waterfront and the annual Humana Festival of New American Plays. Scheduled to open within a year are a downtown baseball stadium for Louisville's minor-league team, the Redbirds, and a football stadium on the University of Louisville campus.
One person eager to be part of the resurgence is Mr. Ali, 55, the former heavyweight boxing champion whose 88-acre estate in Michigan is for sale.
"I have family here; he has family here," Mrs. Ali said after a news conference to announce plans for the center. "Muhammad has always felt ties, links and identification with people in this city. This is home. This is our base."
Mr. Ali, who speaks barely above a whisper because of the effects of Parkinson's disease, said he hoped to find a home on 25 acres.
Why even that many, he was asked?
He flashed a devilish grin and said, "No neighbors."

HEADLINE: Clinton Tosses A Late Pitch In Virginia

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: ALEXANDRIA, Va., Nov. 3

 BODY:
In a final effort to aid the Democratic candidate for governor of Virginia, Donald S. Beyer Jr., President Clinton came to Northern Virginia today and urged voters to reject the tax cuts promised by Mr. Beyer's Republican opponent, James S. Gilmore 3d.
Mr. Clinton called the Republican's plan to phase out the annual tax that Virginians pay on cars and trucks "a brilliant ploy" for focusing on what many state residents consider a "pain in the neck." But he told a lunch-time crowd that the instant pain relief of a tax cut could harm the state in years to come. Some economists estimate that the Gilmore plan could cost the state as much as $3 billion a year. 
 "This is going to be like one of those meals you order and you're hungry 30 minutes later. Or it's going to be like something you do, and afterward you are so proud of yourself," Mr. Clinton said under a sparkling sun in Alexandria's Market Square.
This was the second straight day that Mr. Clinton had tried to shore up the chances of a Democrat running for governor. On Sunday, in Edison, N.J., he joined James E. McGreevey, who is virtually deadlocked in a race with the Republican incumbent, Christine Todd Whitman, who is seeking a second term.
But here in Virginia, the only other state with an election for governor this year, Mr. Clinton's appearance might have come too late. After running virtually even with Mr. Gilmore for months, Mr. Beyer, the Lieutenant Governor, has fallen behind in every major statewide poll in the last two weeks, by as many as 12 points.
Democrats here are also fighting to maintain control of the state House of Delegates. They hold a 53 to 46 advantage with 1 independent who often votes with Republicans. The state Senate is tied at 20, and although no Senate elections are being held this year, the lieutenant governor's vote breaks any tie. The Republican candidate for lieutenant governor, John H. Hager, is running even with the Democrat, L. F. Payne, a former Congressman.
Political analysts around the state said that much of the reason for Mr. Gilmore's lead was his success in selling his tax cut plan, which has overshadowed almost every other issue either candidate has tried to discuss.
In arguing against the plan as a sure way to drain state resources for improvements in education, the environment and transportation, Mr. Beyer has promoted a less expensive change in the car tax, a tax credit of up to $250.
At the same time, Mr. Beyer has been unable to link the Gilmore car tax and its possible consequences in unambiguous language, as Mr. Clinton did so nimbly in his 15-minute speech today.
"Think how you felt every time in your life when you did something you knew wasn't quite so, wasn't quite right, selfishly gratifying, and you felt lousy the next day," Mr. Clinton said. "And think how you felt every time in your life you were tempted to do something that was selfish, and you didn't do it, and the next day you felt wonderful."
After the President's speech, Mr. Beyer praised him for synthesizing issues, which he, as the candidate, had struggled to do.
"That's why," Mr. Beyer said, "he's the President."

HEADLINE: THE 1997 ELECTIONS: THE CHALLENGER;
By Subway, Ferry and Bus, Seeking Votes

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN 

 BODY:
Ruth W. Messinger turned to public transportation yesterday in a final 19-hour quest for votes, riding 10 subway lines and the Staten Island ferry to campaign in all boroughs. Energized by what she called "a huge emotional boost" from President Clinton's visit on Sunday, Ms. Messinger urged Democrats to "take back City Hall and move New York City into the 21st Century."
Ms. Messinger rode parts of all the three old subway systems -- the BMT, IRT and IND -- and walked from college campuses to shopping districts, from pizza parlors to housing projects. With her focus still on education and the schools, she told everyone who would listen, and even some who would not, to ignore pollsters' predictions and to vote for her today against Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. 
 She began on the E train in Jamaica, Queens, and went on to ride the 1, 2, 4, 5, 7, B, D, F, and N subway lines, the Staten Island Rapid Transit line and an S51 bus, all in an effort to meet as many voters as possible and to offer a populist contrast to Mr. Giuliani's 48-hour bus tour on a chartered motorcoach.
"It made sense to me to travel the way most New Yorkers travel and to be able to talk to people on the trains as we move from place to place," Ms. Messinger said, while riding an F train from 34th Street in Manhattan to Park Slope in Brooklyn.
Comparing her journey with Mr. Giuliani's, she added, "It means that instead of retreating to a bus, and traveling alone with staff between stops, I am constantly able to visit and talk to people."
Although most subway riders graciously accepted the handbills that Ms. Messinger and her campaign aides offered, and some said that they and their families would vote for her, not everyone was convinced.
Forrest Surl, 32, of Windsor Terrace, Brooklyn, questioned her about unemployment, housing and welfare for about 10 minutes, but said later that their conversation had not changed his mind. "I am decided," he said. "I am going the other way."
At each stop, Ms. Messinger was joined by prominent Democrats, beginning at 7:15 A.M. at the Archer Avenue/Parsons Boulevard subway station in Jamaica with the Rev. Al Sharpton, her opponent in the Democratic mayoral primary.
Fernando Ferrer, the Bronx Borough President who has been one of Ms. Messinger's most loyal Democratic supporters since he dropped his own brief bid for the mayoral nomination, mocked some of Mr. Giuliani's campaign ads as he introduced Ms. Messinger at a rally at La Guardia Community College in Long Island City, Queens.
"There's another commercial, Rudy Giuliani works for you 20 hours a day," Mr. Ferrer said. "You know, he's there at every water main break. He fights a lonely war against terrorism. My God, he's ready to catch a falling kitten out of a tree. Tomorrow, tomorrow let's give that man a vacation."
On a sparkling day that followed 48 hours of rain, Ms. Messinger made other stops at City College in upper Manhattan, in the Hub shopping district in the South Bronx and in Park Slope and downtown Brooklyn. Emerging from the F train at Ninth Street and Seventh Avenue in Park Slope, Ms. Messinger ducked into a corner pizza shop where David N. Dinkins, the former Mayor, was munching on a slice as he waited for her.
Together with Mr. Dinkins and City Councilman Stephen DiBrienza, Ms. Messinger walked Seventh Avenue, greeting school children and their parents and signing autographs, like one for Kristen Lashley, a 13-year-old eighth grader. "To Kristen," Ms. Messinger wrote. "For a better city."
Later she campaigned at the Staten Island Ferry Terminal and, after crossing on the ferry, at a housing project in Staten Island. Throughout the day, she spoke frequently of being rejuvenated and energized by her rally with President Clinton on Sunday night.
For Ms. Messinger, whose second term as Manhattan Borough President ends this year, yesterday's subway tour was the culmination of nearly a year of scurrying across the city, mostly by car and van, in her uphill challenge against Mr. Giuliani, the Republican incumbent. She acknowledged yesterday that the task has not always been easy.
"Every time I go out, it's the same thing -- and that is, how many more voters can I reach, how many more voters' questions can I answer, how many more voters can I convince to get involved?" she said. "There are days when that goes really well and there are days when it goes less well. But that's precisely what a campaign is all about.
"I am very, very pleased with how we have done."

HEADLINE: Wealth of Mine Barons Turns to Dust at Source

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: LEADVILLE, Colo.

 BODY:
Guggenheim Berlin, Guggenheim Bilbao, Guggenheim New York, Guggenheim Venice. Why not a Guggenheim Leadville?
Leadville, as the name implies, is not chic. Perched at 10,152 feet, it is a hard-knocks mining town, claiming a little fame as the highest incorporated city in North America. 
 More than 135 years of a "get rich and get out" mining ethic has left two legacies. The population has dwindled to a tenth of its 1880's size, and the Environmental Protection Agency has declared the entire town a Superfund site.
Some holes that environmental engineers are plugging today produced the cornerstone of the Guggenheim fortune a century ago -- silver and lead worth $268 million in 1997 dollars.
"The Guggenheim fortune was started right here in Leadville," said Carl Miller, a third-generation resident who represents the area in the State Assembly. "It sure would be nice if they looked back at this community, which is struggling through the hardest times in its history."
In 1989, Mr. Miller wangled the only Guggenheim donation seen here in modern times, $25,000 to the National Mining Hall of Fame and Museum.
For their part, officers and spokesmen for the four Guggenheim foundations, all based in New York, said few projects in Leadville would meet the criteria stipulated by the bylaws of their foundations. One promotes modern art, a second grants midcareer fellowships, another studies criminal justice and the last supports research on violence and aggression.
Another response might be that everyone else did it.
Since 1860, mines in Leadville and elsewhere in Lake County have disgorged, at present-day prices, $12.5 billion in gold, silver, lead, copper, zinc and molybdenum, according to the Colorado Geological Survey, a state agency. All of this in a county that has real estate valued at a total of $53 million.
Marshall Field used some of his Leadville mining profits to start his retail business in Chicago. Charles H. Dow turned financial lessons that he learned as a newspaper reporter and mine manager here into a Wall Street news service, Dow Jones & Company.
Charles Boettcher parlayed a hardware store here into a Denver-based industrial empire. James J. Brown, a gold mine superintendent, also moved to Denver, building a showcase city house for his unsinkable wife, Molly Brown.
"Nobody who made their money here did anything for this place," Municipal Judge Neil V. Reynolds said with a view befitting his status as a fifth-generation resident. "Mining is a community of occupation, not a community of place, like farming."
Boom and bust has marked the West's economy for generations.
"The history of the West is, to some extent, the history of exploitation," former Gov. Richard Lamm said. "First the fur trappers, then the miners. We are building the 'match belt,' economies that flame brightly, then are snuffed out, leaving us with a hole in the ground surrounded by a ghost town."
Even today, with Denver emerging as a national center for cable television and mutual funds, the gothic tales that hang over mining towns like Leadville feed a lingering Western distrust of Eastern capital.
In New York recently, an employee of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation mused vaguely in his Fifth Avenue office: "Leadville? Wasn't that copper?"
But in this alpine village, the family legacy remains as alive as the aging timber head frames above the Guggenheim silver mines that figure in a tourist guide, "The Routes of the Silver Kings." Local politics are still controlled by descendants by the Slovenian miners brought here over a century ago by Meyer Guggenheim, the family patriarch.
Leadville's last working mine and largest private employer, the Black Cloud, is run by Asarco, a company that the family founded and controlled for decades.
In the 1880's, Leadville, with 30,000 people, was the second largest city in the state after Denver. Its latest bust occurred a decade ago, when alternative processes were developed for the use of the mineral molybdenum to harden steel. In a few years, the work force at the nearby Climax Molybdenum mine, an enterprise not owned by the Guggenheims, fell from 3,000 people to 20.
The mine had paid 85 percent of Lake County taxes, and the closing devastated schools and the wider community.
"We have buckets catching drips in all the buildings," Superintendent Peg Portscheller said of leaking roofs in the Lake County schools. The wiring is so bad that overhead projectors cannot be used in some classrooms, she said, and heating is uneven.
Aging window frames have separated from walls, allowing miniature snowdrifts to form in several classrooms during snowstorms. An average of 10 feet of snow falls every winter, a period that nearly coincides with the school year.
The 1,400 students in the district reflect changing demographics, as 44 percent are from low-income families and receive free lunches, 46 percent are Hispanic and 59 percent graduate from high school.
The collapse of mining has meant an end to what people call "a family wage," $45,000 a year plus benefits for a miner who put in a 40-hour week. To match that, families have to move away or send two breadwinners northward over the Continental Divide to take low-wage jobs as dishwashers, housekeepers and janitors in the ski resorts.
But, just as babies are routinely given supplemental oxygen at birth here because of the altitude, Leadville natives seem to be suckled on a healthy dose of class resentment that extends to their view of the Guggenheim name that is paraded in more elegant corners of the world.
In fact, the museums were not all built with Guggenheim money. The Bilbao museum in Spain was financed by the regional Basque government; Deutsche Bank A.G. agreed to pay construction and operating costs for the museum in Berlin, which is in the bank's headquarters.
A working-class holdout in the Rockies, Leadville has a main street where people can buy a dishwasher, fill a doctor's prescription, pawn a hunting rifle, refill a propane canister, have an automobile repaired and buy a miner's cottage for $63,000.
By contrast, a neighbor to the west, Aspen, is a town where the average sale price of a one-family house last year was $1.4 million. To the north are Vail and Eagle County, with an assessed real estate value of $1.3 billion.
Gold-plated Vail is not always subtle in its attitude toward Leadville.
"One year, all of a sudden, our births jumped, from 85 a year to 110," Judge Reynolds recalled. "It turned out that the Vail hospital was steering the Mexican women, the Medicaid cases, over the pass to us."
A few years ago, Vail residents voted against a cemetery in town. Apparently a field of tombstones was deemed bad publicity for the ski industry. So Leadville continues to provide mortuary services for Vail.
"The Vail clinic would call up and say, 'Come after dark to the back entrance and don't use the hearse,' " recalled Judge Reynolds, who moonlighted a few years back with the local funeral home.
With that history, residents come up with cautious wish lists when they hear that a Deutsche Guggenheim is to open on Nov. 7 on the Unter den Linden in Berlin.
"The Guggenheims should remember their roots and do something for the town that gave them a launching," said Douglas Teeter, a native who recently returned to open an art gallery on the second floor of a clapboard house. "Maybe they could help the Leadville Arts Council sponsor trips for high school students to go down to Denver to visit the art museum."

HEADLINE: Casino Ship Suspends Cruises, Saying 12-Mile Rule Has Hurt Business

BYLINE: By VIVIAN S. TOY 

 BODY:
A casino ship in Brooklyn that offered short offshore gambling cruises has suspended operations, putting an abrupt halt to a venture that the Giuliani administration had feared would lead to a flotilla of such ships in the waters around New York City.
Executives of Bay Casino, which ran the ship from Sheepshead Bay, said a legal interpretation by a Federal prosecutor that ships must travel at least 12 miles off shore before gambling is allowed, instead of just 3, had made the venture unprofitable. 
 The company said in a statement that it could "no longer sustain its success operating at 12 miles," but would pursue its lawsuit to overturn that requirement. The company's boat, the Liberty I, which had been sailing 12 miles to sea since mid-October, last sailed at midnight Friday.
The 12-mile limit increases the time of the trip from 25 minutes to 90 minutes each way, the company has said, making it less attractive to customers and forcing the company to cut back from three trips a day to two.
Company officials said they could not sail during the winter months unless the 12-mile rule was revoked, but planned to resume the cruises next spring even if that limit remained. They said the ship could sail more quickly and comfortably in the spring because the seas are calmer.
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has tried to limit the so-called cruises to nowhere, which he has said are unlikely to provide much economic benefit to the city and are vulnerable to the influences of organized crime.
The Mayor had urged the United States Attorney in Brooklyn, Zachary W. Carter, to enforce the 12-mile standard on gambling ships in the hope that such a rule would deter companies from offering the cruises. In response to the Mayor's request, Mr. Carter issued his interpretation of the Federal law governing offshore jurisdiction, saying that ships had to sail 12 miles offshore before gambling was legal.
Gambling-industry analysts have said that a 12-mile limit could discourage other companies from trying to set up such operations in New York. In fact, a business leader in the Rockaways said yesterday that a company hoping to sail a catamaran on gambling cruises starting next spring would drop the proposal if the 12-mile ruling stood.
The suspension of cruises by the Liberty I means that about 200 employees will be laid off.
Bay Casino asked a Federal District Court judge in Brooklyn last month to reinstate the three-mile rule. At a hearing last month, lawyers for the company said that the 12-mile requirement had forced the company to cut the number of cruises from three to two a day and had cut the company's daily revenue in half. The judge, Allyne R. Ross, is reviewing briefs from both sides and has said that she would decide as quickly as possible.
Mr. Giuliani, who was busy campaigning across the city yesterday, would not comment in detail about Bay Casino's decision.
Rudy Washington, Deputy Mayor for Community Development and Business Services, also would not respond to questions, citing the pending litigation. He issued a statement saying simply that officials were aware of Bay Casino's decision and adding, "The city would like to reiterate its support for the 12-mile limit as interpreted by U.S. Attorney Zachary Carter."
Mr. Carter's interpretation is based on legislation passed by Congress last year to extend the nation's territorial jurisdiction to 12 miles for law-enforcement purposes, as part of an anticrime and antiterrorism bill. His office had obtained an interpretation from the Department of Justice in Washington that backed his position applying the 12-mile rule to gambling cruises.
Lawyers for Bay Casino disputed the rule, noting that the 12-mile requirement had not been invoked in Florida, where similar cruises sail out of Miami. Officials from the United States Attorney's office in the Southern District of Florida said they had never been asked to look into the issue.
Wilfredo Fernandez, special counsel to United States Attorney Thomas E. Scott in Miami, said the Brooklyn rule had prompted his office to review the law but they had not yet reached a decision.
"The Justice Department has said that the legislation is valid and that the limit is 12 miles," he said. "So the question now is: How and when do we enforce that law and are we going to prosecute people who violate the 12-mile rule?"
Joseph Kelleher, executive vice president of Bay Casino, said yesterday that reservations had dropped off considerably because of the longer sailing time. He said the company was in the process of canceling about 3,500 reservations that had been made for trips into next year.
"We still believe that Sheepshead Bay is one of the most advantageous spots to operate a casino from," he said. "We're waiting for a favorable decision in court, but we plan on reinstating service in spring, at either 3 or 12 miles." He said that milder weather in the spring would allow the ship to sail to the 12-mile limit more quickly.
Councilman Anthony D. Weiner, who had opposed Bay Casino's cruises because the operation introduced traffic and parking problems into his district, said the company never had a very good relationship with the city because it chose to keep its gambling plans secret until its opening.
"I don't think anyone is ever happy to see a business fail, but some of their wounds were self-inflicted," he said. "Maybe the good that will come of this is that other businesses will learn it is better to work with the Mayor and the community than against them."
Before United States Attorney Carter issued his ruling last month, city officials said they had received more than two dozen inquiries from other companies that wanted to set up similar cruises. Officials from several of those companies did not return phone calls seeking comment yesterday.
But Louis Caucig, president of the Rockaway Chamber of Commerce, who has been negotiating with a firm in Florida that plans to sail a 230-foot catamaran off the shores of Rockaway, said that the company would sail next spring only if the legal limit for off-shore gambling reverted to three miles.
"They're watching closely to see what happens with this," Mr. Caucig said. "And if it stays 12 miles, everybody loses."
Jason N. Ader, a gaming analyst at Bear Stearns & Company, said the 12-mile limit made the trip very unappealing for passengers because of the length of time needed to get into legal gaming waters and because of the rougher waters the ships encounter when they get farther from shore. "There's no question," he said, "that this is going to be a real deterrent for anyone considering coming into the market."

President Clinton won the support of the Senate minority leader, Thomas A. Daschle, for the renewal of the White House's special authority to negotiate trade deals. The support greatly enhances the President's prospects in the battle for "fast track" powers. A1
 
Palestinians Absent From Talks
Key Palestinian negotiators failed to show up in Washington for talks with their Israeli counterparts. Low-cost foreign competition and the shift from manufacturing to service jobs have led to declining membership in labor unions over the last 10 years in most industrial countries, according to a report by the International Labor Organization. The drops were sharpest in Central and Eastern Europe. A14
 
AIDS Programs Get Backing
The AIDS epidemic is on the verge of exploding in China, India and Eastern Europe, said the World Bank, which pledged to spend hundreds of millions of dollars to support needle exchange, condom distribution and other controversial prevention programs. The epidemic has infected an estimated 23 million people and killed 6 million more. A10

Prime Minister Chavalit Yongchaiyudh of Thailand resigned after weeks of protest sparked by the country's financial crisis. President Rene Preval of Haiti has nominated Herve Denis, an economist who has also been a theater director, as Prime Minister, and Mr. Denis has accepted, the semi-official Haitian Press Agency reported. The post has been empty for five months since Rosny Smarth resigned. Mr. Denis, 58, was Information and Culture Minister in the Government of former President Jean-Bertrand Aristide. If Mr. Denis is approved, it will end a long-running political crisis in which several Ministers left their posts after Mr. Smarth resigned during general strikes called by groups against privatization.

G.E. Cashing In Stake In Lockheed Martin
General Electric is cashing in its 13 percent stake in Lockheed Martin for $2.8 billion, which amounts to a big profit. For reasons that are not entirely clear, however, Wall Street seems to think that is good news for Lockheed Martin.

HEADLINE: At Levi Strauss, A Big Cutback, With Largess

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
Levi Strauss announced a drastic cutback yesterday to eliminate a third of its American manufacturing jobs. But in an extraordinary gesture of largess, the jeans maker coupled the bad news with a generous severance package that included extended benefits and even cash rewards for employees who find other work.
The retrenchment, which will close 11 factories in four states, reflected some of the same global cost pressures that have led other domestic manufacturers making mass-market products to reduce their reliance on American workers. 
 At the same time, however, the privately owned San Francisco company seemed to go out of its way to show that it was trying to cushion the blow on the affected communities. It also injected a measure of egalitarianism into the severance plan by giving the lowliest paid worker some of the same help that other companies had historically reserved for severed executives and other high-salaried people.
Levi said it would spend $200 million on the 6,395 affected workers, or an average of $31,274 each, for employees whose salaries range from the legal minimum of $5.15 an hour to about $12 an hour, or $25,000 a year at the high end of the pay scale.
"We're doing this because we believe it is the right thing to do for our employees," said Gordan Shank, president of Levi Strauss Americas. "Our employees have served us for a long time and this decision is not because of them, but a decision we had to make because of circumstances. We wanted to make sure that we provided them with an appropriate level of support to help them transition" to new work.
The workers will be paid for the next eight months, but will not have to report for duty once goods now on the factory floors are finished, Mr. Shank said. In addition, workers will collect three weeks of pay for each year worked. They will get company-paid health benefits for 18 months, incentives to take early retirement and up to $6,000 each for education, moving or job training.
Unlike most severance packages, which require workers to stay to the last day to collect, workers are eligible even if they find a new job tomorrow, Mr. Shank said. Indeed, workers will get a $500 bonus check as soon as they find new work.
The Levi Strauss Foundation will grant $8 million over the next three years to the eight communities where the plants are situated, about one-sixth of the corporate foundation's grant-making, Mr. Shank said.
The severance packages were negotiated with the Union of Needletrades, Industrial and Textile Employees, known as Unite, and the United Food and Commercial Workers Union, which represent only a fraction of the workers losing their jobs. Bruce Raynor, executive vice president of Unite, called the package "by far the best severance settlement apparel workers have ever gotten."
This is not the first time Levi Strauss has cut workers to reduce costs. Last February, it eliminated 1,000 white-collar jobs, 350 through layoffs, to reduce overhead by $80 million annually.
The cuts also come against a backdrop of generally improved economic prosperity in this country and fewer of the large-scale corporate layoffs seen in recent years.
Through September of this year layoffs are down 22 percent compared with 1996, according to Challenger Gray & Christmas, a Chicago firm that helps displaced workers find jobs.
To some degree, Levi's cutbacks reflect intense competition in the jeans market, created partly by improved technology that has expanded the varieties in denim and other clothes. Levi Strauss, which had sales of more than $7.1 billion last year, has seen its share of the denim clothing market shrink. The company said the cutbacks would bring its manufacturing capacity in line with North American demand.
Part of the competition is from department stores, which have developed their own brands like J. C. Penney's Arizona jeans. Levi Strauss now has about about one-fifth of the jeans market.
Other competitors such as Guess and Gitano, which make jeans abroad, have invested in high-quality factories and highly trained crews to produce quality pants, said Isaac Lagnado, president of Tactical Retail Solutions, a marketing consulting company. "Levi has quite a bit higher cost structure," Mr. Lagnado said. He said the company's Dockers brand, owned by half of American men, was under assault from "a lot of near-Dockers that are perfectly well manufactured and sell for $15 or $20," less than Levi Strauss wants to charge.
After the layoffs, Levi Strauss will operate 26 factories in the United States and Canada employing 12,213 people. Another 12,000 people work in salaried jobs in those two countries. The company said it had about 13,500 people working overseas.
Levi Strauss will close three of its four factories in El Paso, where it is the largest private employer, and one other Texas plant. It will also shutter two factories each in Arkansas and New Mexico and three in Tennessee.

HEADLINE: Newark to Make School Into a Center of Family Services

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS 

DATELINE: NEWARK, Nov. 3

 BODY:
In an effort to make a public school a full-service place for children and their parents, school and city officials here today unveiled the Camden Middle Community School, which would offer after-school programs for children as well as job training, family counseling and health and aerobics classes for their parents.
"Providing a safe haven up to 9 P.M. for children after school was our first goal," said Mariko Lockhart, state director of Communities in Schools of New Jersey, a nonprofit group that helped plan and coordinate the program services. "But beyond that, we saw a need for recreation and education programs for parents." 
 By most accounts the program is unique in that it goes beyond the usual after-school effort for children whose parents cannot be home when they get out of school.
The program also marked a rare moment of cooperation between the administration of Mayor Sharpe James and officials of the local school system, which was taken over by the state Department of Education two years ago. Mayor James and other city officials have criticized the state takeover for supplanting the locally elected school board with a superintendent appointed by a Republican, largely white administration in Trenton.
The city's award of $350,000 to the school over the next two years was the first expenditure from a $2.9 million Federal grant the city won in 1995. It was awarded as part of the competition for Federal funds under the Department of Housing and Urban Development's empowerment zone and enterprise community program, which channels money for economic development and a variety of social services available to poor neighborhoods.
The new program at the school on Camden Street echoed a project undertaken there more than 30 years ago. That earlier federally financed experiment was aimed at better tailoring the school's curriculum to the needs of poorer inner-city areas and building parents' involvement with the schools and with their children's education.
That project included a child-parent center in a nearby storefront that stayed open day and night even during the 1967 riots, which hit that part of the city particularly hard.
The school's new programs will start in two weeks, and registration for parents and children will begin this week, said the principal, Josephine McDowell.
The 600-student school is in the city's Central Ward, once the city's poorest, and half its fifth to eighth graders are bused in, drawn from other poor areas of the city. More than 90 percent of its pupils are from families with incomes low enough to qualify their children for free or reduced cost lunches.
Mayor James commended the school as part of a "holistic approach" to education that he said harkened back to a simpler time when schools stayed open late with the help of volunteer teachers and parents. But regulations and labor contracts made it impossible for teachers to work those hours without pay. "The programs disappeared, more kids were on the street getting in trouble and dropping out," he said.
Don Marinaro, an assistant superintendent of Newark schools who represented the state-appointed city superintendent, Dr. Beverly Hall, grudgingly acknowledged in an interview that there had been tension between the school system and City Hall, but added, "Feelings are one thing and results are another."
The Camden School project could be a model for future collaborations with the city, including other community schools, he said.
Among the planned after-school programs for children will be homework assistance, karate, double dutch rope jumping, computer classes, sports and a program that promotes learning through the planning and completion of business ideas.
Among the services available for parents are family counseling from a social worker, computer literacy programs and health screening programs to help parents better care for themselves and their children.
