HEADLINE: Missing New Jersey Girl Is Found Slain; a Boarder Is Charged

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: PISCATAWAY, N.J., Nov. 3

 BODY:
The body of a 10-year-old Piscataway girl who had been missing since Saturday night was found today and a man who had been living in her family's house was charged with murder, the authorities said.
The body of the girl, Lauren Rel yea, was discovered about 9 P.M. in a van behind a strip mall, said Robert Gluck, the Middlesex County Prosecutor. 
 Mr. Gluck said the police arrested Yusaf Hagans, 24, a boarder at the Relyea home, and charged him with murder.
The girl was last seen on Saturday playing in the front yard of her house on Charlton Avenue, Middlesex County officials said. The girl's mother told the police that she thought Lauren had gone to spend the night at a friend's house. But when the fifth-grader didn't return the next day, her mother's boyfriend called the police.
Police officers, firefighters and emergency service workers had been searching for the girl today in a wooded area near her home.
The authorities said they did not know if the girl had been sexually assaulted. An autopsy is scheduled for Tuesday, Mr. Gluck said.
The girl was identified through photographs, he said.
Police officials say Mr. Hagans took the girl for a walk and then killed her using a blunt object. The suspect put the girl's body in a van, then tried to dispose of her clothes, Mr. Gluck said. Police officers found shoes and other pieces of her clothing near the mall.
Mr. Hagans had been a boarder at the Relyea house for about three months, Mr. Gluck said. He was a friend of the girl's brother and knew that the family took in boarders. Mr. Hagans lived in the house with the girl's mother, the mother's boyfriend and four other children, he said.
Mr. Hagans, an unemployed Plainfield native, is expected to be arraigned on Wednesday, Mr. Gluck said.
The investigation is continuing.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Lauren Relyea had been missing since Saturday night. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: New Jersey Daily Briefing;
Public TV Seeks New Income

BYLINE: By STEVE STRUNSKY 

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
It will not run commercials, but New Jersey Network, the state's public television system, is exploring ways to raise revenues in the face of cuts in state financing, network officials said yesterday. 
 In 1989, the network received $9 million of its $12.7 million budget from the state. The state now provides $3 million, even as inflation makes the network more costly to operate, said Ronni Weyl, a spokeswoman for the network. In addition to seeking help from corporations and foundations, the network recently began renting space at its Trenton studio and offering a media consulting service. The station is down to 150 staff members, from a high of 230 in 1989.

HEADLINE: Clinton Wins Support on His Trade Authority

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3

 BODY:
After weeks of lobbying, President Clinton today virtually secured Senate renewal of the trade negotiating authority that he has called a centerpiece of his economic policy.
Mr. Clinton won over the support of Thomas A. Daschle, the Senate minority leader, on the so-called fast-track trade legislation. 
 Mr. Daschle announced his backing today, the day before a key Senate vote. The Administration now hopes to use his conversion to help rally Democratic support in the House, where the President still faces an uphill fight.
Mr. Daschle made his statement surrounded by Cabinet officials. They said Mr. Clinton would take a range of actions aimed at winning over legislators from agricultural states and Democrats worried about losing out to developing countries with lower wages and less stringent environmental laws.
The announcement was part of a major lobbying drive as the President fights for the legislation, which he has called crucial to taking the lead in the global economy.
Every President since Gerald R. Ford has made good use of fast-track powers -- which give Congress the right to approve or disapprove trade agreements but not modify them. The authority has helped bolster the Presidential negotiating position with foreign governments on trade deals. Administration officials have said they view this battle to renew the power as one of the most significant legislative confrontations of President Clinton's second term.
"We are now at a crossroads with respect to the strategy of opening markets around the globe," Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin said today.
With Mr. Daschle's help, the Administration is counting on winning the 60 votes necessary in the Senate to defeat Democrats who are trying to block the trade measure from coming to a vote either on Tuesday or later in the week. Mr. Clinton met tonight with two separate groups of Democratic Senators to try to shore up their votes for the trade legislation.
The White House hopes to use Mr. Daschle's support to offset the opposition of two House Democratic leaders, Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri and Representative David E. Bonior of Michigan. The measure is to come to a vote in the House on Friday.
Mr. Clinton let the power expire in his first term rather than seek a vote that would divide Democrats as he headed into a Presidential election.
Organized labor, a heavy contributor to Congressional Democrats, opposes the President. It argues that the Administration is unwilling to use its ultimate weapon -- the threat of trade sanctions -- to safeguard American jobs against foreign nations, which produce cheaper goods because they do not abide by labor and environmental regulations.
The White House and opponents of the trade legislation are both focusing their efforts on a small group of Democratic Senators and a larger group of Representatives who are undecided or who may be persuaded to switch sides.
The A.F.L.-C.I.O. plans to run commercials on CNN this week opposing the legislation, which the union president, John J. Sweeney, said today could "lead to a race to the bottom" in worker protections.
America Leads on Trade, a business coalition, announced today that it would run newspaper advertisements on Tuesday in 43 cities identifying 67 members of Congress who are undecided or against granting the authority.
The White House has adopted a two-pronged strategy to win votes. Administration officials worked on a set of policy proposals aimed at winning over critics. And the President and Vice President courted members of Congress individually.
"We're doing wholesale and retail and direct marketing over the next week," a senior White House aide said. "We'd be on QVC if we could find a way," the aide added, referring to a cable shopping channel. "We know we've got an uphill fight here."
The measures announced today were focused on winning support from Mr. Daschle and four to six other Senators, Administration officials said.
While Mr. Daschle said of the Senate vote, "This is not a done deal," opponents and supporters of the measure said that Mr. Daschle's conversion now virtually assured victory in the Senate.
But opponents like Senator Byron L. Dorgan, Democrat of North Carolina, have said they will use all of the Senate's arcane parliamentary procedures to stretch out the process as long as possible.
While the Republicans will be providing Mr. Clinton with the bulk of his support in the House, the Speaker, Newt Gingrich of Georgia, has said he has about 150 supporters, meaning that the President will have to carry about 70 Democrats in the House vote Friday.
But the Administration is thought to have only about 40 Democratic House votes, and Mr. Gingrich would have trouble producing any more Republicans. Some conservatives are demanding that he win concessions from the White House.
To appease Mr. Daschle and win over others, the Administration said today that it would provide Congress with a review of labor and environmental practices and laws of trading partners when it submitted future trade agreements negotiated under fast-track authority. It also pledged that the Labor Department would make a similar review of the practices of the partners in the 1993 North American Free Trade Agreement.
In addition, the Administration said it would try to push international organizations to emphasize worker rights in developing nations, paying particular attention to child labor. Officials said environmental groups might be allowed to take part in dispute settlements at the World Trade Organization.
In a separate letter to Mr. Daschle aimed at farm-state lawmakers, the Clinton Administration agreed to collect data on livestock imports from Canada and take steps to promote American products. One plan was to develop guidelines for the voluntary labeling of meat products from the United States.
Mr. Gephardt, a Missouri Democrat, dismissed Mr. Clinton's latest promises, saying, "This is just one of the deals the administration will be touting this week to try and win votes. What they should do is pull their fast track proposal and go back to the drawing boards."
Later this week, the President plans to announce a separate package worth more than $500 million over five years to help displaced workers and communities hurt by global trade. But opponents dismissed that plan, too, as merely repackaging of programs that did little to lessen the effects of the North America Free Tree Agreement.

HEADLINE: Metro Business Briefs;
Garment-Maker Promotion

BYLINE: By LISA W. FODERARO 

 BODY:
The thousands of small- and medium-sized clothing manufacturers in New York City are the focus of a new $1 million marketing program intended to promote the local fashion business, the program's sponsors are expected to announce today.
The financing will come from the United States Department of Commerce, the Fashion Center Business Improvement District -- a nonprofit organization that promotes the garment center in the West 30's -- and the Garment Center Industry Development Corporation, a nonprofit economic development agency. 
 The new program, New York Fashion International, will promote New York-based clothing manufacturers through an international advertising and direct-mail campaign aimed at Europe, Asia and South America. It will also encourage international clothing buyers to take advantage of the support services offered by the Fashion Center Business Improvement District.
In addition, the program will expand the presence of made-in-New-York clothing at fashion fairs in Europe by recruiting New York clothing makers to attend.
"The stuff that comes out of New York has a tremendous cachet overseas, more so than it does domestically," said Barbara Blair Randall, executive director of the Fashion Center Business Improvement District. "But a lot of the New York-based manufacturers don't export. It's kind of a new world for them."
Clothing is the city's largest manufacturing sector, employing 100,000 people and producing almost $20 billion a year in goods, the improvement district said. LISA W. FODERARO

LENGTH: 1246 words

HEADLINE: Workers Detail Slips In Energy Dept.'s Data

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3

 BODY:
Hazel R. O'Leary stood proudly in front a chart depicting the Department of Energy's success in awarding contracts to minority-owned companies.
Ms. O'Leary, then the Secretary of Energy, had reason to look ebullient as she appeared at a conference on minority business development in the spring of 1996. According to the chart, her department had increased the number of dollars invested in minority businesses by 59 percent during her tenure. 
 But there was one problem: the chart was misleading.
The huge jump in contracts for minority businesses, according to current and former Energy Department employees as well as internal agency documents, was achieved by comparing different sets of numbers: the number of all minority prime contracts, as well as subcontracts, in the 1995 fiscal year was compared with only the number of minority prime contracts in previous years. If Ms. O'Leary's chart had looked at comparable data, the increase would have been 42 percent.
The erroneous chart is one example of what the employees say was a pattern by the Energy Department under Ms. O'Leary of routinely manipulating statistics to inflate her record on contracting with small businesses and businesses owned by women or members of minorities. Current and former department employees say the deception, spearheaded by officials who are still on the job, was motivated by a desire to burnish the department's image, even if it meant providing inaccurate figures to the White House, Congress and the public. Ms. O'Leary, the first black to head the department, had made it a priority to increase the number of minority- and female-owned companies in the energy field.
The misleading statistics "gave the impression to the general public and small businesses in particular that we're balls of fire," said Roy Chavez, a procurement analyst at the department. "But it's deceptive."
Charges of misuse of figures are being investigated by the department's inspector general. A draft of the inspector general's final report was provided to The New York Times by people who oppose the Administration's plan to use a method of counting called statistical sampling in the 2000 census. These critics say that the manipulation of figures at the Energy Department means that the Administration cannot be trusted to take an accurate sampling for the decennial population count.
A review of the draft report and interviews with current and former employees disclose a pattern of inaccuracies that included:
*Using figures that reflected department goals rather than actual achievements.
*Including contracts for all small businesses -- including those owned by white men, for example -- when computing the dollar value of contracts awarded to companies owned by women and members of minorities.
*Reducing the total dollar amount of Energy Department contracts to make the part awarded to small businesses seem larger.
Paul L. Terban, the former deputy director of the Office of Small and Disadvantaged Business Utilization at the department, said he and Mr. Chavez had often pointed out inaccuracies, only to be ignored.
"Their stock line every time I said that's wrong was, 'Don't you want us to look good?' " Mr. Terban said.
A spokeswoman for Ms. O'Leary, who left her job to return to the private sector after President Clinton's first term, said she would have no comment on the accusations. But the spokeswoman, who would not allow her name to be used, said: "We take these allegations seriously. The Department of Energy is committed to accuracy in accounting and statistical representation and fair treatment of its employees. The inspector general has been investigating this, and we want to let him complete his investigation and issue a final report in order to assess appropriate steps."
Corlis Moody, director of the Office of Economic Impact and Diversity at the department, who was -- and still is -- responsible for statistics on small businesses and businesses owned by women and members of minorities -- did not respond to requests for an interview or to written questions submitted to her.
Mr. Terban said he had first begun to suspect that department officials were misusing numbers three years ago, when reporters called him to ask about a department press release that said it had "awarded more than one-half billion dollars in contract awards to minority- and women-owned businesses during fiscal year 1994."
When Mr. Terban checked on that, he found that in calculating the figure of $500 million, department officials had double-counted companies owned by women who were also members of minorities.
 In a statement of its goals for the 1995 fiscal year, the department said it wanted to increase its small-business contracts to "more than 34 percent" of all contracts; it put that number at 25 percent for the 1994 fiscal year. But internal department documents indicate that the 25 percent figure was the department's goal for the 1994 fiscal year, not what it actually accomplished. In reality, only 18 percent of the department's contracts went to small business in that fiscal year.
Even the department's goals for the 1995 fiscal year rested on shaky statistics. In calculating the relative value of total contracts it would give to small businesses, department officials excluded salaries and expenses paid to large prime contractors.
 Without the $7.7 billion paid to these prime contractors, the $3 billion in contracts to small businesses added up to more than 34 percent of the total, as outlined in the 1995 performance statement. But with prime contractors counted, the part of small business contracts dropped to 18.4 percent, only slightly more than in fiscal 1994.
Moreover, the performance statement for the 1995 fiscal year was submitted unchanged to President Clinton and signed, even after department officials received a letter from the Small Business Administration informing them that their figures had been calculated incorrectly and asking the officials to submit revised figures.
"What it means is that they essentially lied to the President," Mr. Terban said.
The draft report indicates that Ms. Moody said the failure to correct the figures before the President signed the document had been an "oversight" and that once the document had been endorsed, she had not known how to correct it. But department officials failed to use the next year's performance agreement to rectify the false impression.
The draft inspector general's report also says Ms. O'Leary may have used misleading charts and graphs in making public presentations on the department's performance in awarding contracts. While current and former employees say the misleading charts were probably used, the inspector general's office could not say so with any certainty.
A chart prepared for presentation at a Congressional Black Caucus conference in July 1995, suggested that the department had awarded $3 billion to companies owned by women and members of minorities in the last year of the Bush Administration but that it had "delivered" about $4.5 billion to such companies during the 1994 fiscal year, in the Clinton Administration.
But the figures for the Bush Administration represent the agency's contracts with all small businesses -- not just those owned by women and members of minorities -- in the 1992 fiscal year. In contrast, the Clinton figures are the Energy Department's goals for small business in the 1994 fiscal year.

CORRECTION-DATE: November 5, 1997, Wednesday

She was Brooke Anderson, director of the Office of Public Affairs at the department -- not the spokeswoman for Energy Secretary Hazel R. O'Leary quoted elsewhere in the article.

HEADLINE: Food Stuff

BYLINE: By Florence Fabricant

 BODY:

Soup That's Like a Model T: Have Any Size You Want
 Add David Bouley to the growing list of soup purveyors. But Mr. Bouley is going his own way in offering soup to go in the retail area at Bouley Bakery, 120 West Broadway (Duane Street). 
 Unlike the rest of the soup chefs around town, he gives just two choices each day and one size (12 ounces). Soups are dispensed from a homey Creuset pot instead of a steam-table kettle, and the only accompaniment is a roll baked on the premises. Most soups, like the thick, earthy organic golden wild rice soup with morsels of duck confit, are $4.95; vegetarian selections are $4.25.
 
Three Pies (One Bites Back)
 Rethinking a classic has led Maury Rubin, above, the owner of City Bakery, 20 East 17th Street, to make a trio of pumpkin pies.
First there is his conventional take on the autumn dessert, which he makes with fresh pumpkin from the Union Square Greenmarket bolstered with some of the canned variety. It is very gently seasoned. Another pie is enriched with almond praline paste, giving it a sweetly caramel flavor and smoother texture. The eye-opening Asian variation tastes assertively of fresh ginger with a touch of coconut and other spices. Nine-inch pies are $18; individual 4-inch ones are $4.
 
A Ratte by Any Other Name
 Several years ago James Huston, the man who brought the Yukon Gold potato to the American table, successfully started cultivating the prized French ratte potato in Oregon, using the same methods and plant stock as Jean-Pierre Clot, who grows the ratte in Burgundy. The potato is the favorite of the chef Joel Robuchon. Mr. Huston gave it a prettier name, La Reine. But when he discovered that a line of citrus fruits already carried the trademark name La Reina, he changed the name to Princesse, which is how it is now being sold.
 
Where Ground Beef Is King
 Does it come as a surprise that the United States can claim the title of ground-beef capital of the world? In a study of 1,000 people age 13 to 65 in each of 35 countries in April by Roper Starch Worldwide, a market research company in New York, 34 percent of Americans said they had eaten ground beef in the previous 24 hours. Argentina came in second, at 22 percent.
The overall average is 15 percent, but in developing countries, the only residents questioned were residents of urban areas, where Roper analysts speculated that consumption of ground beef is higher than in the countryside. The margin of sampling error in the study, which was done in face-to-face interviews, was less than 1 percentage point over all, although the poll takers said it represented only about a quarter of the world's population. The study was financed by Roper, along with Coca-Cola, the Discovery Channel and Philip Morris.
Consumption of canned and frozen vegetables was also highest in the United States, 25 percent. Russia was second with 21 percent. But Americans ate less pizza (16 percent) than did Italians (18 percent) or Argentines (20 percent). Consumption of beef other than ground beef was highest in Argentina. Americans ate less fish, fresh vegetables, pork, eggs and rice than the overall average. As for pasta, they were about average, 26 percent, but far behind Italy, where 71 percent of respondents said they had eaten pasta in the previous day.
 
Oil Worth a Bumper Sticker
 When people in the organic-farm movement say "think globally, buy locally," they probably do not have Villa Pillo extra-virgin olive oil in mind. This lovely herbaceous oil, with a nice piney scent and the merest hint of a peppery bite, comes from an estate in Tuscany owned by John and Kathe Dyson, who own Millbrook Vineyards much closer to home, in Millbrook, N.Y. Mr. Dyson's bumper sticker may proclaim "I Love New York," the slogan he invented, but it is clear that he also loves Tuscany. The oil, in a 17 1/2-ounce flask, is $20 at Grace's Marketplace, 1237 Third Avenue (71st Street), and $16.99 at the winery in Millbrook.
Barneys New York has also introduced an extra-virgin olive oil, from the Macie estate in the Chianti region of Tuscany, and sells it under the Fred's at Barneys New York label. This oil is richer and more viscous than the Villa Pillo oil, with a warm, nutty flavor that would make it excellent to drizzle into a vegetable soup or gloss onto a slice of pecorino cheese. The oil is $21.
 
As if Sweets Weren't Serenity Enough
 
DELICACY is the abiding theme at Minamoto Kitchoan, a new Japanese shop selling wagashi -- high-quality sweets usually accompanied by tea -- on West 49th Street at Fifth Avenue. It is the first New York branch of a company that has more than 200 shops in Japan. The setting is serene, and the sweets are artistically arrayed in sweeping glass cases.
The uninitiated probably should select individual pieces, often made with bean pastes or seaweed-based jellies, rather than the beautifully packaged assortments, which can cost $95. The kimono-clad clerks offer helpful explanations about confections like oribenishiki ($2.20), a feathery rice cake with a mousselike filling, or kurihouka ($2.50), a mouthful of chunkier bean paste enclosing a candied chestnut. An oval box with four ounces of golden, sugary candied chestnuts, kuriamanattou, is $16.
Though not intended as a clever imposter, koshi-an, a bean paste, does make the smooth, mellow filling of the tender tsuya spongecake buns ($2 each) look like chocolate. But nothing in the shop is made of chocolate.
Minamoto Kitchoan will ship its confections throughout the United States ($13 for the first pound; $1 for each additional pound). Information: (212) 489-3747.

HEADLINE: First, Don't Compete

 BODY:

To the Editor:
The New York State Medical Society's opposition to independent nurse practitioners is shameful (Week in Review, Nov. 2). This opposition violates Hippocrates' admonition to "first, do no harm." Because most independent nurse practitioners provide lower-cost basic medical services than do doctors, legal prohibitions on the spread of these practitioners raise the price of medical care. Higher prices cause some people who would otherwise seek treatment for ailments to refrain from doing so. 
 Apparently the New York State Medical Society reinterprets Hippocrates' admonition to mean, "first, do no harm to physicians' incomes."
 
DONALD J. BOUDREAUX
President, Foundation for Economic Education
Irvington-on-Hudson, N.Y., Nov. 3, 1997

HEADLINE: South Bronx Suburbia

 BODY:

To the Editor:
A Nov. 2 news article points out that the selling prices of single-family houses in Charlotte Gardens in the South Bronx have risen from $49,500 in 1985 to $185,000 in 1997. Yet you do not recognize that the 1985 selling price was far lower than the actual cost to build each house. 
 Construction alone was $81,000 per unit, excluding land and site preparation. Factored together with continuing subsidies, including losses to the city related to the lowest possible use of land that once housed thousands of families, it is hardly fair to characterize Charlotte Gardens as an economic success -- except for the 89 original families who are understandably pleased with their potential windfalls.
The long-term economic consequences of imposing suburban houses on high-density urban areas is problematic, to say the least.
The extreme de-urbanization of Charlotte Gardens was not repeated elsewhere in the city, for good reasons.
 
RICHARD PLUNZ
New York, Nov. 3, 1997
 
The writer directs the urban design program at Columbia University.

HEADLINE: Linking Sudan to Rights Abuses and Terror, U.S. Adds Penalties

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 4

 BODY:
President Clinton, seeking to pre-empt Congressional action, imposed sweeping new sanctions on the Sudan today, for alleged sponsorship of terrorism and human rights abuses.
The new penalties went far beyond previous prohibitions by blocking access to all Sudanese assets in the United States and barring a wide range of financial transactions, officials said. 
 The United States has only $70 million in annual trade with the Sudan, including $50 million in American exports, American officials said. Therefore, the move "is more a statement of principle than anything else," an official said.
"The United States has imposed sweeping new economic sanctions against the Government of Sudan because of its continued sponsorship of international terrorism, its effort to destabilize neighboring countries and its abysmal record on human rights," Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright said in making the announcement.
"We take these steps because the Government of Sudan has failed to respond to repeated expressions of concern or to the imposition of lesser sanctions."
The action provides exceptions for some activity considered essential to American interests, like imports of gum arabic, a key ingredient in candy and some other products, like ink. It is not expected that there will be any exception for American oil investment in the Sudan, a senior American official said.
The United States contends that Sudanese officials aided those responsible for an 1995 assassination attempt against President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt. It has also accused the Sudan of providing a refuge and training for Islamic guerrillas.
Experts and some published reports have raised suspicions about whether the Sudan is trying to acquire a chemical weapons industry, but the United States has refused to comment on that question.
The State Department spokesman, James P. Rubin, said he hoped that the President's move would make it unnecessary for Congress to legislate sanctions, which could tie the Administration's hands even more.
"We tend to not, as a matter of practice, support sanctions put in place by Capitol Hill because of the fact that they normally lack flexibility," he said.
The sanctions took effect today after Mr. Clinton signed an executive order under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act blocking Sudanese assets in the United States, believed to total millions of dollars, and banning bank loans and American exports to the Sudan. Imports from Sudan were also barred.
Ms. Albright said sanctions aimed to deprive the Sudanese Government "of the financial and material benefits of U.S. trade and investment, including" oil. But "to insure flexibility, the Administration will consider issuing licenses on a case-by-case basis for activities that are in the U.S. interest," she added.
Mr. Rubin said that for certain specific commodities, like gum Arabic, the Administration would consider issuing licenses for "some limited activities important to us," he said. A coalition of American businesses has lobbied hard against sanctions that would hit the trade in gum arabic.
A senior American official said the Administration would strictly review the requests for exemptions. American companies have 30 days to divest themselves of investments in the Sudan or apply for a special license, officials said.
The Sudan is one of seven nations that Washington accuses of sponsoring worldwide terrorism and having poor human rights records.

HEADLINE: Auto Makers Report Weak October Sales

BYLINE: By ROBYN MEREDITH

DATELINE: DETROIT, Nov. 4

 BODY:
The Big Three American auto makers reported weak sales in October, giving the industry a slow start in the first month of the new model year.
The General Motors Corporation said today that its sales fell 4 percent last month compared with the corresponding period a year earlier, mostly because of weak sales of vans, small sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks. The Ford Motor Company said today that its sales dropped 2.1 percent last month, as a sharp drop in mini-van sales outweighed rising sales of large sport utility vehicles like the Expedition and the Lincoln Navigator. The Chrysler Corporation announced on Monday that its sales fell 8.3 percent in October. 
 Though a number of Japanese and European auto makers reported strong results for October, Detroit's weakness pulled down sales for the industry as a whole by 1.6 percent from a year earlier. The seasonally adjusted annual rate of sales reached just 14.7 million, compared with 15 million in September and 15.5 million in both August and July. "The industry over all is perhaps softening up a little bit," said Donald R. DeVeaux, G.M.'s director of North American market analysis.
Robert L. Rewey, Ford's group vice president for marketing, sales and service, said, "The U.S. economy has been remarkably stable during the current expansion and gives every indication that it will remain so in 1998."
Wall Street analysts were less optimistic. "There is a mild slowdown taking place and it could be a harbinger of a weak fourth quarter," said David Bradley, an auto analyst at J. P. Morgan Securities Inc.
John A. Casesa, an auto analyst at Schroder Wertheim & Company, said the weak sales suggested that auto makers would soon pile on more rebates and discounted lease deals to spur sales. The October results "add more evidence to the view that the best is behind us" after four years of healthy auto sales, he said.
Helped by their popular small sport utility vehicles and redesigned family cars like the Toyota Corolla and Honda Accord, Japanese auto makers reported stronger sales in October. The Toyota Motor Company said today that its sales rose 2.9 percent last month, while the Honda Motor Company said on Monday that is sales rose 11.2 percent. "The Japanese have the best of all worlds," said Jack V. Kirnan, an auto analyst at Salomon Brothers. "They are bringing out new products in both the car and truck sectors that seem to be in sync with what American customers want -- the Big Three are in more of a defensive mode."
Other auto makers today posted mixed sales results for October. The Mazda Motor Company said its sales rose 5.7 percent; Mercedes, the unit of Daimler-Benz A.G., said sales jumped 81.8 percent; the Hyundai Motor Company said sales rose 9.9 percent, and Porsche A.G. said sales jumped 69.6 percent.
But Volkswagen A.G. sales fell five-tenths of 1 percent and the company's luxury unit Audi saw its sales fall 10 percent; sales at the Suzuki Motor Corporation plunged 29.4 percent; sales at BMW A.G. fell 3.2 percent, and sales at Jaguar, the Ford unit, dropped 6 percent.
General Motors saw its car sales slip one-tenth of 1 percent compared with weak car sales in the period last year, while its sales of pickup trucks, vans and sport utility vehicles fell 8.5 percent, which Ronald L. Zarrella, vice president of sales, service and marketing, called disappointing.
G.M.'s midsized cars mostly sold briskly, particularly newer models like the Chevrolet Malibu and Pontiac Grand Prix. However, customers seemed bored by the company's small cars. Sales of the Chevrolet Metro -- formerly the Geo Metro -- plunged 49 percent, while sales for the Saturn division dropped 17.1 percent. Sales of its medium-sized sport utility vehicles were weak.
Ford's car sales dropped 2 percent, while the maker's truck sales fell 2.2 percent. The auto maker's stars were the giant sport utility vehicles -- the Ford Expedition and Lincoln Navigator. The end of October marked the first full year of Expedition sales, which reached 222,300. But mini-van sales in October were weak -- sales of the Ford Windstar dropped 24.8 percent, while sales of the Mercury Villager dropped 32.3 percent. Sales of Ford's family sedans, the Ford Taurus and Mercury Sable, rose 15.1 percent and 30.3 percent, respectively, mostly because corporate fleets and rental car agencies waited for the new model year to buy more cars.

HEADLINE: Economic Data Point to Future Growth

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 4

 BODY:
An index intended to forecast the economy rose again in September, pointing to further growth in the months ahead as the expansion heads toward its seventh year.
The Conference Board, a business research group, said today that its index of leading indicators rose two-tenths of 1 percent, the fifth consecutive increase, and matching analysts' estimates as well as matching the average for the four previous months. 
 Recent turmoil in the markets and economies of Asia and Latin America, however, has clouded the outlook, analysts said. They said there was a risk that lower American exports and other fallout from overseas could make an expected slowdown in the United States economy even slower.
"The safest bet is that it will be a moderate drag but not a pothole," said Robert G. Dederick, consultant to Chicago's Northern Trust Company. "But it's too soon to tell."
None of the 10 components of the predictive index yet reflected the Asian turmoil, Michael Boldin, the Conference Board's project director, said today.
Economists at Chase Manhattan were also reassessing prospects for the domestic economy next year, concluding in a special report that "expansion will slow to a below-trend pace of 1 percent to 1.5 percent," or as much as a percentage point less than it had expected before the Asian crisis.
The company also said that inflation risks would recede and that the Federal Reserve might preside over a substantial decline, perhaps a percentage point, in short-term interest rates.
"A lot of the signs point to slower growth," James Glassman, a Chase economist, said in an interview, citing among other things the likelihood of lower exports and less vigorous business investment as well as the existing shortage of qualified workers and the shrunken savings rate.
Six of the components of the leading indicators advanced at the latest tabulation, the main positive contributors being lower first-time claims for unemployment benefits and an expansion of the M-2 money supply. This monetary gauge includes savings accounts and money market mutual funds as well as currency and checking accounts.
Lesser upward impetus came from increases in permits for building, higher stock prices as measured by the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, a rise in the value of new factory orders for capital goods and a negligible rise in the University of Michigan's survey of consumer expectations.
The three forces of restraint, none very strong, were lower factory orders for consumer goods; a narrowing of the interest rate spread between overnight money and 10-year Treasury bonds, and somewhat speedier deliveries of goods by corporate suppliers.
The final component, the length of the average workweek, was unchanged for the month.
During the six months through September, the Conference Board also calculated, the predictive index advanced nine-tenths of 1 percent, with seven of the components higher.
Two companion indexes, one intended to move at the same time as the economy at large and the other only with a delay, rose three-tenths of 1 percent and one-tenth of 1 percent, respectively.
The coincident index for August was revised to show a gain of two-tenths of 1 percent, one-tenth of a point less than initially reported. The lagging index maintained its August gain of three-tenths of 1 percent.

HEADLINE: Auto Giants Build a Glut of Asian Plants, Just as Demand Falls

BYLINE: By ROBYN MEREDITH

DATELINE: DETROIT, Nov. 4

 BODY:
Shoppers have deserted car dealerships across Southeast Asia since the region's currency crisis began last summer, while investors who have lost fortunes in plummeting stock markets have flooded the used-car market with late-model luxury cars.
The world's auto giants do not seem to care. Even though some industry experts insist they should pull back, General Motors and Ford Motor are busy building huge new assembly plants in Thailand and preparing to open up to five more factories in Southeast Asia and China. And Toyota and Honda are dealing with the crisis with temporary production cutbacks rather than changing their basic strategic plans. 
 Although the tiger economies of Southeast Asia have turned to alley cats this fall, the American and Japanese auto makers that have rushed to build factories say they are mostly undaunted. While auto executives weigh whether to retrench, none have yet closed a factory or canceled expansion plans. Just as amateur investors mainly stood pat as world markets gyrated last week, auto makers insist they are in the Southeast Asian markets for the long haul, and some even see silver linings in the economic storm clouds.
"When the currencies settle down, as they will, I think they may have a greater competitive advantage," said Alexander J. Trotman, chairman and chief executive of Ford. The United States is even sending cars, not soldiers, to Vietnam. Ford's new factory there opens on Thursday.
But some Wall Street analysts worry about this Panglossian view. "This industry is suicidal," said Maryann N. Keller, an auto analyst at Furman Selz, a New York investment banking and brokerage firm.
She is concerned because the auto industry already has more worldwide capacity than it needs and more factories continue to be built. G.M.'s factory in Rayong, Thailand, is scheduled to open in early 1999 and now has steel girders in place but no roof. "They should just stop it," Ms. Keller said. "This isn't going to be a 12-month problem in Thailand."
Indeed, John F. Smith Jr., G.M.'s chairman and chief executive, said in an interview published on Monday in Automotive News that the company was weighing whether to alter its plans for the Thai factory, perhaps by building less expensive cars.
Mr. Trotman, like other auto executives, reasons that the region's falling currencies will make wages, investments and locally bought parts less expensive in dollar terms. But at the same time, demand for new vehicles has plunged from Thailand to South Korea to Indonesia, while the remaining sales yield fewer dollars and yen in profits for auto makers because the local currencies have weakened.
Japanese auto makers also remain optimistic. "We are not changing our strategies in response to a short-term economic recession," said Takanori Sonoda, head of Honda's Detroit office.
The traditional response to a glut of locally produced cars -- to increase exports -- may not work in Southeast Asia. Neither Honda nor Toyota plans to start selling cars built in Southeast Asia in the United States, mainly because the smaller, stripped-down cars built there are more suited to developing markets. Any increased auto exports from Southeast Asian countries would most likely be sold in other emerging markets, if demand remains strong enough.
G.M., which aims to double its share of the Asia-Pacific market to 10 percent by 2005, is convinced that Southeast Asia is still worth betting on. "You have to roll the dice," said J. T. Battenberg 3d, president of G.M.'s auto parts division, which since 1992 has opened 23 factories in the region -- 15 in China, 4 in South Korea and 3 in Malaysia and 1 in Indonesia. "A country that may seem to be not a good investment today -- maybe North Korea or Vietnam -- tomorrow may be."
Not only is G.M. completing work on its factory in Thailand and preparing to build Buick Regals in Shanghai, it is negotiating for permission to add mini-van production in Shanghai and to open at least two more assembly plants in China.
One would be a joint venture in Shenyang in northeastern China with a local partner, First Auto Works, to develop a truck-based vehicle. G.M. is also lobbying the Chinese to choose it, not Honda, to build a small "people's car" in Guangzhou, said a G.M. spokesman, Michael Meyerand.
Ford is also seeking 10 percent of the Asian market within 10 years, and it already has factories in Malaysia and Taiwan. After its new Vietnam factory opens on Thursday, its van factory in China opens in December and next summer it is scheduled to turn out its first pickup trucks in Thailand. It may also add a factory in the Philippines.
Conspicuously absent from large-scale production is the Chrysler Corporation, which has four, mostly smaller factories in East Asia. Last year, Chrysler dropped plans to open a factory in Vietnam when the Government allowed a dozen other auto makers to build assembly plants, despite the country's small market for cars.
Long before the region's current problems, Chrysler decided to expand in South America instead of East Asia because South American governments imposed fewer trade restrictions and were not using heavy government assistance to local companies, as Indonesia and Malaysia have done.
In the short term, Wall Street analysts said that while the end of Southeast Asia's remarkable economic climb was bad news for the Big Three, the impact on profits would be minimal. "The earnings out of Asia might be 2 or 3 percent of total earnings," said David Bradley, an analyst at J. P. Morgan Securities Inc. And the stocks of the Big Three have not been hit any harder than the overall market in the last week or so.
The other danger is that the turmoil in Southeast Asia will spread to other developing markets, particularly in South America, pushing countries like Brazil and Argentina into a recession. The Big Three have bigger operations there, and thus have much more to lose.
But in Southeast Asia, Japanese auto makers are likely to take the hardest hits because they have more factories. Honda has cut production in half at its large factory in Thailand, and Toyota has gone from two shifts working seven days a week to one shift working three days at both its Thai factories and reportedly is considering shutting the factories for the rest of the year. The direct effect of the Asia crisis could trim the Japanese auto industry's operating profits by up to 5 percent, estimated Stephen Volkmann, a Tokyo-based analyst with Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter. Auto sales in Thailand plummeted 77 percent in September.
Auto makers might be forced to invest more in a poorly performing region because the factories that produce their cars tend to be joint ventures. Their smaller, local business partners may run into financial trouble and turn to deeper foreign pockets to keep factories open.
While auto makers remain optimistic, not everyone agrees they should be. Thailand is headed for a recession, and elsewhere in the region, growth is slowing, said Nariman Behravesh, chief international economist at Standard & Poor's DRI.
"You get caught up in the euphoria and your risk tolerance goes up," Mr. Behravesh said. "There is going to have to be some shake-out in the auto industry in Asia sometime in the next three to five years."

HEADLINE: AT&T Will Simplify Its Pricing Structure

BYLINE: By SETH SCHIESEL

 BODY:
The AT&T Corporation, the leading long-distance telephone company, said yesterday that it would sharply simplify its pricing, making it easier for millions of residential users to figure out the price of a long-distance call.
As of Saturday, AT&T said, it would reduce to three from 33 the number of different rates paid by residential customers who do not subscribe to a special calling plan. In doing so, the company leapfrogged its major rivals as they also seek to attract customers with straightforward pricing. 
 The change was the first significant move for AT&T since C. Michael Armstrong, former head of the General Motors Corporation's Hughes Electronics unit, became chairman at the start of the month.
Analysts said that changing AT&T's pricing structure could hardly begin to solve all of the company's problems, but they added that many initiatives are expected during Mr. Armstrong's tenure.
"These are some of the earlier and easier changes the company will make," said Linda B. Meltzer, an analyst for UBS Securities. "It really matches what the industry is seeing in terms of simplicity."
After the pricing changes take effect, distance will no longer factor into what AT&T's 80 million residential customers pay for a basic interstate telephone call.
AT&T, which now charges customers based on a complex formula involving three time periods and 11 "mileage bands," will move instead to a flat rate for each of the three time periods -- days, nights and weekends -- no matter how far the call travels within the United States.
Some consumer advocates said that AT&T was actually reneging on a previous promise to reduce rates. Under the new plan, the periods from 7 A.M. to 8 A.M. and from 5 P.M. to 6:59 P.M. become parts of the highest-price time period, rather than parts of lower-priced "night" and "evening" periods.
"I think this is a major scam," said Gene Kimmelman, co-director of Consumers Union, a consumer advocacy group. "Now the rates are going to go up for a lot of people, and I think the F.C.C. should investigate."
The change will not affect business customers, whose basic rates already do not fluctuate with distance, or AT&T's residential customers who subscribe to an optional calling plan like One Rate, which offers a flat price around the clock. Analysts estimate that about half of AT&T's clients belong to such plans.
"The most powerful motivator we've seen in consumer markets, not just in telecommunications but really across consumer markets, has been the benefits a company reaps if they simplify things for their customers," said Jack McMaster, a vice president in AT&T's consumer long-distance division. "We took a look at the price schedule, and it was essentially more confusing than it needed to be."
But minor confusion persists in AT&T's executive suites. Mr. Armstrong's arrival apparently has not stemmed the tide of senior executives who have chosen to quit the company in favor of smaller operations.
Ron J. Ponder, AT&T's chief information officer, said yesterday that he plans to leave to become president and chief executive of Beechwood Data Systems, a small private company based in Clark, N.J., which makes software for telecommunications systems.
It is the economics of fiber optic networks that has produced the flat-rate pricing now becoming familiar to long-distance customers. Once a pulse of light is traveling along a hair-thin strand of glass, it does not cost very much to keep the pulse going.
"They've finally made a rate structure that reflects reality," said Scott Wright, an analyst for Argus Research, a high-technology consulting firm in New York. "Technology has certainly helped accentuate a truth in telecom pricing, and that is that the incremental cost of going another mile when you're talking about long-distance calls is virtually nil."
From 7 A.M. to 6:59 P.M. during the workweek, AT&T will charge a flat interstate rate of 28 cents a minute. From 7 P.M. to 6:59 A.M., the company will charge 16 cents a minute. During the weekend, the rate will be 13 cents a minute.
Under AT&T's current basic fare schedule, domestic interstate rates range from 13 cents a minute for a night or weekend call to a nearby location to as much as 29 cents a minute for a transcontinental call during a workday.
In September the MCI Communications Corporation, the No. 2 long-distance carrier, changed its basic rate structure to two mileage bands from 11. MCI also charges different rates for each of three time periods, for a total of six possible prices from 5 to 29 cents a minute.
The Sprint Corporation, the third-largest long-distance company, maintains 13 mileage zones and three time periods in its basic price system, for a total of 39 rates, ranging from 13 to 35 cents a minute.
At least half of MCI and Sprint customers subscribe to special-rate programs.

HEADLINE: U.S. Stock Indicators Up as Hong Kong Falls

BYLINE: By SHARON R. KING

 BODY:
Wall Street loosened its link to international equity markets yesterday, as stocks finished modestly higher despite another selloff in Hong Kong.
Following a 4.21 percent decline in Hong Kong's main market index, the Hang Seng, the Dow Jones industrial average and other market barometers reversed early declines. Investors focused on reports that some American companies would not be as negatively affected as originally expected from Asia's downturn, analysts said. 
 "After a week of introspection, investors realized that the impact on our market should not have been as dramatic due to something that happened in Thailand or Latin America," said Larry Rice, chief investment officer at Josephthal Lyon & Ross. "We are the safe haven for the world's economies. In periods of uncertainty, we are the place to be."
After gaining more than 232 points Monday, the Dow closed at 7,689.13, up 14.74 points, leaving it just 26.28 points away from its close on Oct. 24, the Friday before its 554-point drop.
Other indexes saw smaller gains. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index inched up 1.77 points, to 940.76. And while technology stocks, which had been battered in the recent selloff, saw lots of buying interest yesterday, the Nasdaq composite index eked out just a 1.17-point gain, closing at 1,631.15.
While stocks continued to climb, Treasury prices were lower for the third consecutive session. Bond prices were weighed down by concerns over the market's ability to absorb new supply as the Treasury began its quarterly refunding with the sale of $14 billion of new three-year notes.
The 30-year bond dropped 16/36, to a price of 101 25/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, rose to 6.24 percent, from 6.21 percent on Monday.
The dollar rose against the Japanese yen but was lower against many European currencies. The dollar rose to 122.15 yen, from 121.32 yen on Monday, but fell to 1.7228 marks, from 1.7351 marks. The British pound rose to $1.6844 from $1.6773, its highest level since July.
In the stock market, some technology issues gained yesterday as investors searched for stocks that fell sharply in last week's market rout. Dell Computer, which fell 14 percent last week, gained 2 7/16, to close at 85 11/162.
In addition, the Philadelphia Oil Service sector index rose to a new high of 139.81, buoyed by expectations that oil prices could increase on unrest in the Middle East.
AMF Bowling closed at 21 3/4 during its first day of trading. The bowling center operator climbed 2 1/4 from its initial offering price of 19 1/2.
In the Treasury market, while there was good demand for the auction of three-year notes, today's $11 billion auction of new 10-year notes and tomorrow's $10 billion auction of new 30-year bonds are considered to be harder sells. In when-issued trading yesterday, the 10-year note was being offered at a price to yield 5.96 percent, and the 30-year bond was being offered at a price to yield 6.21 percent. HEADLINE: Clinton Wins Senate Test On Trade-Negotiating Bill

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 4

 BODY:
President Clinton won a round in his drive to renew expanded trade negotiating authority when the Senate voted today to shut off stalling tactics by dissident Democrats.
The Senate voted 69 to 31, nine more votes than necessary, to break a filibuster and bring the trade legislation to the floor. The margin showed that the Senate has the votes to approve the legislation later this week, and the President had been pressing for just such a decisive outcome in order to put pressure on the House of the Representatives, where he still faces an uphill struggle. 
 Democrats -- and even some Republicans -- said today that the strength of the vote in the Senate was likely to help Mr. Clinton's case in the House, where a vote on the issue is scheduled for Friday.
Appearing in the White House Rose Garden just minutes after the Senate vote, President Clinton, flanked by his entire economic team, praised what he called the "bipartisan coalition" in the Senate. "The world economy is clearly on a fast track," he said. "If we don't seize these opportunities our competitors surely will. An 'America last' strategy is unacceptable."
The Senate Majority Leader, Trent Lott, said the support for the legislation had been stronger than expected.
Almost as soon as the Senate acted, Administration officials turned their attention to the House, where senior Democratic leaders have broken with Mr. Clinton and are leading the opposition. With 26 Senate Democrats joining the 43 Republicans to bring the trade legislation to the Senate floor, Rahm Emanuel, President Clinton's senior adviser, said the vote should demonstrate to House Democrats that "you can be pro-trade, a good Democrat and the sky won't fall in."
Just as in 1993 when he pushed the North American Free Trade Agreement through Congress, Mr. Clinton has been forced to rely largely on Republican votes on an issue that fractures the traditional Democratic coalition.
Organized labor, a heavy contributor to Congressional Democrats, strongly opposes the measure, and the two House Democratic leaders, Representatives Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri and David Bonior of Michigan, are leading the fight against the President.
This afternoon, the two legislators, along with Representative Maxine Waters, a California Democrat, unveiled a new objection to the bill. They argued that increased trade with Mexico was also leading to increased drug trafficking. "The bulk of drugs smuggled into the U.S. is produced in South America -- some of the same countries that are in line for trade expansion," Mr. Gephardt said. "We must be prepared for this prior to commencement of negotiations."
The administration scrambled to answer that argument.
Even with today's vote, the Senate still has to pass through numeorus procedural hurdles before it can bring the fast track legislation to a final vote later this week. Opponents plan to try to amend the legislation to add in new United States negotiating objectives such as restrictions on child labor.
Opening debate, Senator William V. Roth, Jr., a Delaware Republican, said that unless the President had the authority to negotiate a trade agreement that cannot be amended by Congress, the United States would lose its leverage. "Without the ability to take a seat at the negotiating table, we will be giving up the ability to shape our economic destiny," Mr. Roth said.
Opponents of the measure argued that the Clinton Administration's trade policy was resulting in a growing trade deficit -- particularly since Nafta was passed in 1993. Saying that every year the merchandise trade deficit is getting "worse not better," Senator Byron L. Dorgan of North Dakota asked, "is this country moving in the right direction?"

HEADLINE: Union Misgivings on Nafta Are Clinton's Latest Worry

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 4

 BODY:
Four years after the Clinton Administration said it would prod Mexico to improve workers' rights through agreements made along with the North American free trade pact, many Democrats and labor unions say results have been scant, complicating the White House's efforts to win new trade-negotiating authority.
Just as it did in campaigning for the free-trade zone with Canada and Mexico in 1993, the White House is promising Democrats that it will do all it can to improve the labor and environmental standards of the nation's trading partners, even if strong opposition from Republicans prevents making these improvements a condition of access to the American market. 
 Those promises, along with other efforts to woo Democrats, helped the Administration win a critical procedural victory today in the Senate on the so-called fast-track legislation. But the fate of the legislation remains unclear in the House, where organized labor is making an all-out push to stop it.
One key reason for the reluctance of many House Democrats to back the measure is that the Administration's assurances about pushing for labor and environmental reforms in other countries ring hollow to them, given the outcome of the White House's similar efforts in the wake of the North American Free Trade Agreement.
The lesson of Nafta, they say, is that labor and environmental issues must be at the heart of trade agreements, not relegated to hard-to-enforce side agreements or other pacts like the "executive initiatives" the Administration is now pledging to implement.
"The Nafta experience indicates that we need to tackle labor market and environmental issues directly, not indirectly," said Representative Sander M. Levin, Democrat of Michigan.
Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the Democratic leader, said labor and environmental issues "need to be addressed in the core text of trade agreements, not as an 'executive-initiative' afterthought."
"If they are in the core text, commitments made can be enforced," said Mr. Gephardt, who is leading the opposition to the fast-track measure. When the President has fast-track authority, Congress may only agree to approve or disapprove trade agreements but not amend them.
In particular, the skeptics point to the Nafta side agreement on labor issues.
To some degree, the limitations seen by its critics were inherent in its structure. Formally known as the North American Agreement on Labor Cooperation, it was not intended to judge or punish companies for their labor practices. It did not seek to create common labor standards among Mexico, Canada and the United States. It provides for the possibility of sanctions only in extreme cases where one of the three governments signing the agreement has shown a pervasive pattern of failing to enforce its own labor laws.
In the United States, the agreement is administered by an eight-person staff in the Labor Department with an annual budget of about $800,000. Mexico and Canada each have a similar office, and the three countries together pay for a small "secretariat" in Dallas.
In nearly three years, seven complaints about Mexican labor practices have been filed with the American office, plus one filed with the Mexican labor authorities about Sprint, an American company operating in the United States. In none of the cases has the outcome gone beyond private meetings at which American officials have expressed their concerns about Mexican labor practices to their counterparts in the Mexican Government.
Since the provisions are intended only to push the Governments involved to enforce their own existing domestic labor laws, no direct action has been taken against any of the employers involved.
American officials said it was unrealistic to believe that Mexico -- or the United States or Canada, for that matter -- would have agreed to an international process that would supersede domestic labor laws and give the United States the authority to impose sanctions on companies operating in Mexico.
Given the nature of the provisions, they said, the process has had more impact in Mexico than it is given credit for. And they said the provisions should be judged not by what labor groups hoped that they could accomplish -- bringing wholesale changes to Mexico's deeply rooted economic and political systems -- but by the more modest goal of serving as a prod to Mexico to take labor issues more seriously.
"It's contributed to an unprecedented level of scrutiny of Mexican labor law and allowed for a process of review and public discussion that has contributed in some important ways to debates already occurring within Mexican society on these same matters," said Andrew Samet, deputy undersecretary for international affairs at the Labor Department.
"It's obviously not intended to create a substitute mechanism for U.S., Canadian or Mexican labor law," he said. "It's also not designed inherently to provide any additional recourse to adjudicate individual rights."
But labor rights groups take a much dimmer view of the agreement. They point to cases like the one prompted by a bitter clash between management and employees at the Sony videocassette plant just over the Texas border in Mexico during 1994. To labor activists, the dispute was a perfect example of how the Mexican Government and big companies had long discouraged the creation of independent unions. The Labor Department investigated their complaint.
The Labor Department heard reports that Sony had terminated workers who tried to organize a new, more assertive union. It listened to stories about the police beating workers who protested against the company's tactics. Despite statements from Sony that it had obeyed the law and that the labor groups were distorting what had happened, the Labor Department ultimately found, in April 1995, that there were "serious questions" about the way the workers had been treated.
And then it recommended the strongest action available to it: closed-door talks between the American and Mexican labor Secretaries, which led to public workshops in both countries on union organizing and certification.
The dismissed workers were not reinstated. The organizing effort at the plant remains stalled.
Labor groups said the initiatives pledged by the Administration to deal with labor and environmental issues in any trade deals reached under fast-track authority would be similarly toothless. They said the Administration should have taken a tougher stand with the Republican majority in Congress and insisted on making sure labor and the environment were as central to trade agreements as issues like fighting piracy of computer software and movies.
"Unless these things are enforceable within the context of the trade agreement, they are paper tigers," said David A. Smith, the policy director for the A.F.L.-C.I.O.

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Clinton praised the Senate yesterday for voting to allow fast-track legislation to reach the floor for a vote. He and Vice President Gore returned together to the White House from the Rose Garden. (Stephen Crowley/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Colorado Storm's Toll in Cattle Staggers Beleaguered Industry

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE

DATELINE: HOLLY, Colo., Nov. 3

 BODY:
On a treeless plain, midway between Wild Horse Creek and Deadman Ditch, a front-end loader appeared on the horizon today, laboring slowly as it dragged two dead cows and carried a third in the front scoop.
"That cow there in the front was my nephew's bucket calf; he raised it from a bucket," Dale Seufer said sadly as he watched the loader drop on the ground the full-grown brown Hereford that had been hand-fed as a calf. Nearby, 37 other cows, calves and yearlings lay frozen in positions of rigor mortis, awaiting a truck from a rendering plant in Kansas. 
 The late October blizzard that swept across the Eastern Plains of Colorado last week killed more than people. Hitting at a time when calves are being weaned from their mothers and cows from the South are entering feedlots, the freezing rain, blinding snow and shrieking winds killed about 50,000 cows in Colorado and Kansas, the heaviest toll since a spring blizzard in 1957.
"It's so big I can't skin them all, and I have men skinning 600 a day," said James Davis, general manager of National Byproducts. Based in Garden City, Kan., this rendering company grinds cow carcasses into bone meal and sells the hides for low-quality leather.
But last week's toll in cattle, Colorado's worst cattle kill in 40 years, will barely be noticed in a market where there are 101 million cows in the nation's herds. Earlier this year, when blizzards and floods killed about 500,000 cows in Montana and in the Dakotas, consumer beef prices barely ticked up for the summer barbecue season. The nation's per capita beef consumption has dropped by one third over the last two decades, keeping beef prices low.
But for Colorado's agriculture, the frozen cows piled at ranch gates around here constituted one more body blow to a beleaguered industry.
"Colorado is losing 90,000 acres a year in agricultural land to development," said Bob McLavey, the state's Deputy Commissioner of Agriculture. "Agriculture right now is in tremendous competition with urban growth."
Over the last 40 years, the number of ranches in Colorado has dropped by half, to about 10,000.
Two milestones, one economic and one cultural, illustrate the state's gradual shift.
In the mid-1990's, the value of Colorado's manufactured exports surpassed the value of its agricultural production.
A decade earlier, in the mid-1980's, Colorado had moved from being a state with more cows than people to being a state with more people than cows. Using this yardstick of Old West status, South Dakota has a ratio of 5 cows for every 1 person, Nebraska's ratio is 4 to 1, and Montana and Wyoming have ratios of 3 to 1. Colorado has 0.8 cows for every 1 person.
"With the population increase, the California influence is having more and more play in Denver," said Kent Lebsack, executive vice president for the Colorado Cattlemen's Association, a ranchers' group.
At the National Western Stock Show, in Denver, organizers have stopped stringing up half carcasses in refrigerators, believing that the display offended visitors more than it educated them about cuts of meat. In Wheat Ridge, a Denver suburb with a pastoral name, several residents recently tried to force a neighbor to sell her 22-year-old mare, arguing that the town's odor ordinance took precedence over zoning rules that allow horses.
In a statewide referendum last year, 75 percent of voters on the Eastern Plains rejected a ban on trapping coyotes. But the ban was approved, largely on the strength of urban votes.
Out here, in a Colorado far from the mountain playgrounds of the tourist brochures, the loss of almost 10 percent of the region's cattle herd is a cataclysmic event.
"It's going to continue to force out the small producers, who, unfortunately, are often the younger ones," said Leonard Pruett, the regional livestock extension agent for Colorado State University. Estimating southeast Colorado's cattle losses at $15 million, Mr. Pruett added, "There will be more than a few ranchers who will have a day of reckoning with their bankers."
Ranching has long been central in Colorado's big-sky country.
Holly, with only 877 people, grew up around the three-story headquarters of the town's namesake, the Holly Land and Cattle Company. The county, Prowers, was named for John Wesley Prowers, a 19th-century cattle baron who once controlled 400,000 acres on both sides of the local stretch of the Arkansas River. In Lamar, the county seat, the biggest hotel is the Cow Palace, and at the county courthouse, local cattle brands are incised in wall friezes. In neighboring Wiley, the expression is: "Down Wiley way, it's kids and hay."
While Rocky Mountain Colorado is blanketed with national forests, ranching Colorado is dotted with national grasslands. In this open country, 200 miles southeast of Denver, the prairie overwhelms individual state identities.
From Holly, it is quicker to drive east to Garden City, Kan., than to go west to the Wal-Mart in La Junta, Colo. It is just as easy to drive south to Goodwell, Okla., to enroll at Panhandle State University than to drive west to Pueblo to study at the University of Southern Colorado.
With an altitude almost 2,000 feet lower than Denver's, Holly is the lowest town in Colorado, a place where winters are mild and four-wheel drive vehicles are seen as superfluous.
The recent storm and its aftermath left memories likely to last for years.
"I've never seen anything like this, and we have been ranching for years and years," said Dorothy Seufer, the family matriarch, who came with her husband to ranch here after World War II. Of the 350 cows, calves and yearlings in her family's herd, the blizzard killed 110.
The snow here was so deep that some animals suffocated. Others wandered over snow-covered barbed wire fences and then drifted until, desperate for water, they walked to irrigation canals, fell through the ice, and drowned.
"That's a $2,500 bull right there," Mrs. Seufer said, nodding to one of 13 dead animals half submerged in snowdrifts in the Amity Canal. "What a horrible death."
Although Colorado's Governor, Roy Romer, a Holly native, ordered National Guard helicopters to drop hay to cattle stranded on the Eastern Plains last week, state and Federal financial aid now seems as far away as spring calving season. Blizzard insurance was of little help to ranchers who had it. Most policies went into effect on Nov. 1 -- one week after the storm.

GRAPHIC: Photo: A loader hauling a dead cow to a pile of dozens stacked at the gate of the Seufer ranch near Holly, Colo. The ranch lost 105 cattle. (Kevin Moloney for The New York Times)
