HEADLINE: Tough Guy at Treasury;
Rubin's Point Man on Policy Is in Tune On Economics, Off-Key on Politics

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER and LOUIS UCHITELLE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 4

 BODY:
At times in the last few weeks, it has seemed as if the hand and mind of Lawrence H. Summers could be found lurking beneath the surface of just about every tangled problem facing the White House.
When President Clinton finally declared America's position on global warming last month, Mr. Summers, the Deputy Treasury Secretary, led the economic camp that won the day over the State Department and the Environmental Protection Agency, scaling back America's commitments on its emission of pollutants. He did it with detailed arguments about the potential -- and unknowable -- costs to American industry if Mr. Clinton committed to aggressive targets, with no escape clauses. 
 But a day later, it was Mr. Summers's turn to lose a major battle. The onetime economics professor, now one of the more influential voices in the Clinton Administration, and his boss, Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin, badly misjudged the political landscape. For months, Mr. Summers had headed the Treasury Department's effort to rescue the Internal Revenue Service from itself. He recruited a proven manager, instead of the traditional tax lawyer, as commissioner, and forced the scrapping of a huge computer project that had gone wildly awry.
He was so caught up in the internal fixes, in fact, that he underestimated the effectiveness of a carefully orchestrated Republican onslaught to loosen the Treasury's hold over the I.R.S. Facing overwhelming pressure from both parties, Mr. Rubin and Mr. Summers were forced to accept an oversight board to supervise the agency.
The I.R.S. battle was remarkable because in Washington these days, Mr. Summers rarely loses -- or even gives much ground. The youngest academic ever to receive tenure at Harvard, at age 28, he has turned into one of Washington's shrewdest political infighters. Rarely do economists make the transition from university life to Government as successfully as the 42-year-old Mr. Summers has. Indeed, no one else in his generation has been in Washington for as long, or in a series of such high-profile posts.
Along the way, he has bruised more than a few egos, from Republican members of Congress who complain they have been lectured on economic principles as if they were classroom dullards, to Administration colleagues who have felt some sharp bureaucratic elbows. In recent months, as Mr. Summers's authority and world view have expanded, he has clearly tried to tone down.
"I've learned that being precisely analytically accurate is neither necessary nor sufficient for being constructive in Washington's debates," he said recently over lunch a block from the White House. "After being a professor of political economy, I guess now I'd give more weight to the political than to the economic than when I first got here."
It has been an uneven transition. He was the principal architect of the successful 1995 bailout of Mexico -- but he was also a lightning rod for Congress's anger about the use of $12 billion in American funds, all of which have been repaid. "Congress did not want to approve so huge a loan and then take the blame if Mexico failed to repay, and Larry became an excuse for saying no," said a Democratic Congressional aide involved in the negotiations. "He was insensitive to the political issue at stake. He told the members they had to approve the bailout; they had no choice. Well, members of Congress always have a choice."
In the end, the President made the loan on his own authority.
In the last few weeks, he has devoted most of his time to the Administration's efforts to contain the economic crisis in Southeast Asia. Mindful of the sensitivities in Congress, though, he made sure this time that the International Monetary Fund took the lead and that America's exposure was limited to $3 billion in a "second line of defense" for Indonesia. Nonetheless, some colleagues back in academia warn that austerity measures that worked in Mexico may not fit the problems of the Southeast Asian economies.
Often he has been called in to play the heavy. When the I.M.F. was blanching in August at forcing Thailand to disclose fully its key financial transactions, Mr. Summers forcefully reminded officials at the fund that Washington could still effectively pull the plug on the aid package for Bangkok. The I.M.F. backed down.
And Mr. Summers is never far from the levers of power. When Mr. Rubin and Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, have their weekly breakfast, he is the only other person present -- and he often does much of the talking.
The issue now is where Mr. Summers is headed. There is no question he is eager to break out of Mr. Rubin's long shadow: he angled, unsuccessfully, for the presidency of the World Bank. (The job went to the financier James Wolfensohn.)
He also considered becoming chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers earlier this year (plenty of academic prestige, he decided, but not enough influence), and he was judged too confrontational to become the consensus-seeking head of the National Economic Council.
Many consider him a contender to become the next Treasury Secretary, should Mr. Rubin decide to return to New York before the end of the current term. Mr. Rubin himself is among Mr. Summers's boosters.
"He has an incredibly sensitive political mind, as well as being a brilliant economist," said Mr. Rubin, who first met his deputy when they worked on the failed 1988 Presidential campaign of Michael S. Dukakis. "He is extraordinarily equipped to function at the intersection of economics and political reality."
Should Mr. Rubin decide to call it quits, however, there are other contenders to become the next Treasury Secretary, including Franklin D. Raines, the director of the Office of Management and Budget. And there are still questions -- usually uttered off the record -- about whether Mr. Summers's sometimes impolitic style could prevent him from moving to the other side of the elegant, antique-filled suite he shares with Mr. Rubin. He is frequently the target of a lot of political vitriol, in part because he will say things in public that Mr. Rubin will not.
"Bob is legendary for speaking in an extraordinarily restrained way," Mr. Summers said, when asked to compare his style with Mr. Rubin's. "But if you thought about my speech pattern, you'd go through a lot of other adjectives before you got to restrained and unprovocative."
Mr. Summers, in short, is not one of those people about whom Washingtonians or economists have neutral opinions.
State Department officials fume that Mr. Summers seized the Mexican crisis, and now policy toward Southeast Asia, without adequately consulting them. In turn, Mr. Summers has offered blistering assessments of the State Department and Central Intelligence Agency's economic analysis in an age when currency devaluation can often be destabilizing.
He is also the subject of criticism in the economics profession. One longtime antagonist of Mr. Summers, Fred Bergsten, the president of the Institute for International Economics, calls him "turf conscious" and "not a strategic thinker."
Mr. Summers's style put him in conflict with another prominent Ivy League economist, Alan Blinder of Princeton, who came to Washington in 1993 as a member of the Council of Economic Advisers and then was named vice chairman of the Federal Reserve. Mr. Blinder holds views on economic matters similar to Mr. Summers's. Nevertheless, Mr. Blinder turned down an invitation from President Clinton to be chairman of the council in the second term. He did so in part because he would have found himself in almost daily policy discussions -- and confrontations -- with Mr. Summers.
The council job finally went to another university economics professor, Janet Yellen, who once taught economics to Mr. Summers. She works closely with him now but stays largely out of the limelight.
"He is a brilliant economist," says Laura D'Andrea Tyson, a former chairwoman of the council. "He has strongly held views. He is ambitious. He debates down to the last minute. He gets exasperated with people who he feels don't understand. But finally he is a team player."
Those arguments usually take place as the stout Mr. Summers downs Diet Cokes, apparently his main source of sustenance as he races between the White House and the Treasury. His staff is constantly feeding his voracious appetite, too, for statistics, and he is intolerant of what he calls "standard, government-issue, we-should-have-a-partnership talking points" when meeting finance ministers and other officials from around the world.
And Mr. Summers is often trotted out by the Administration to put its spin on the day's confluence of market tumult and political maneuvering. Usually those conversations begin with Mr. Summers's asking the first question, to gauge just how much he will have to reveal.
"So," he says casually, "what are you hearing?"
Often, what reporters are hearing are tales about Mr. Summers. He outraged Republicans earlier this year when he declared that their effort to wipe out the inheritance tax amounted to "utter selfishness." Mr. Rubin, who clearly agreed with him but would not put it so bluntly at a time the Administration was trying to cobble together a budget deal, stuck his head in Mr. Summers's office the next morning, unable to resist inserting the needle.
"I told him that I didn't really mind what he said," recalled Mr. Rubin, a man whose own sizable estate is nothing to sneeze at. "But I said my son was really angry."
On a long flight to Hong Kong last month, Mr. Summers's aides delighted in finding evidence of the policy wonk at work: a full page, in Mr. Summers's hand, of indecipherable equations, doodled during a meeting on computer encryption, an issue that has divided the Treasury, the intelligence agencies and the Commerce Department.
Instantly, the page was circulating from seat to seat. "I was trying to work out some of the principles of encryption," he said, smiling sheepishly. It's a wiser way to pass the time, he suggested, "than other things I could be caught doing at meetings, like rolling my eyes."
Other participants in those meetings say there is no question Mr. Summers is a powerful voice, sometimes even disagreeing with Mr. Rubin. He pressed, over Mr. Rubin's initial objection, for inflation-indexed Treasury bonds, something many economists have been urging for years. He is a free trader, skeptical of the argument that competition from low-wage countries pulls down American wages. He argued for milder application of trade sanctions against Japan in the automobile dispute in 1995. He holds that America's labor force is fully employed today, and that long-stagnant wages are beginning to rise, although the statistical evidence is in dispute.
While his political antenna can sometimes miss signals, Lawrence Henry Summers comes to economics naturally. He is the child of economists and the nephew of two Nobel laureates in economic science -- Paul Samuelson on his father's side, Kenneth Arrow on his mother's. He earned his Ph.D at Harvard in 1982, and made his name with contrarian papers demonstrating how some previously held economic thesis was off base.
But academia is receding. Mr. Summers's life is increasingly rooted here -- his wife, Victoria, is a tax expert working at the I.M.F., and his weekends are spent between tennis games ("I'm better than you'd think, looking at me," he says) and playing with his children -- 7-year-old twin daughters and a 4-year-old son.
As for Mr. Summers's future, here is a leading indicator: He just sold his house in the Boston suburbs.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Supreme Court Allows Retail Price Ceilings
The Supreme Court ruled unanimously that a manufacturer or supplier does not necessarily violate Federal antitrust law by placing a ceiling on the retail price dealers can charge for its products.
The ruling, on a lawsuit by a gasoline dealer against his supplier, overturned a disputed precedent that regarded limits on retail markups as illegal price fixing. Page A1. 

German Steel Giants in Friendly Deal
Germany's two biggest steel companies, Krupp-Hoesch and Thyssen, announced a friendly merger, less than eight months after Krupp caused a nationwide furor by attempting a hostile takeover that would have accomplished the same end. D9.
 
Disappointing Month for Detroit
The Big Three American auto makers reported weak sales in October, giving the industry a slow start in the first month of the new model year. Sales fell 4 percent at General Motors and 2.1 percent at Ford, though they rose strongly at Japanese auto makers. D8.
 
ITT and Hilton To Share Data
ITT and Hilton Hotels reached a cooperation pact and agreed to exchange information, one day after Hilton sweetened its offer for ITT, which has a deal to sell itself to a rival suitor, Starwood Lodging Trust. The developments sent ITT's stock higher as expectations of a bidding war grew. Market Place. D12.
 
Economic Gauge Shows Growth
The Conference Board's index of leading economic indicators rose two-tenths of 1 percent in September, matching analysts' expectations. D2.
 
AT&T to Streamline Rates
AT&T said that it would sharply simplify its pricing, making it easier for millions of residential users to figure out the price of a long-distance call. AT&T said it would reduce to 3 from 33 the number of different rates paid by residential customers who do not subscribe to a special calling plan. D6.
 
U.S. Stocks Up as Hong Kong Drops
Stocks rose slightly in the United States, despite another selloff in Hong Kong, as investors focused on reports that the negative impact to some American companies from Asia's downturn could be less than expected. The Dow industrials closed at 7,689.13, up 14.74 points. Treasury prices fell, lifting the yield on the 30-year bond to 6.24 percent from 6.21. The dollar rose against the yen but was lower against many European currencies. D12.
 
Weak Results in Managed Care
Two managed care companies, Oxford Health Plans and Aetna, reported unexpectedly weak third-quarter financial results, providing new signs of trouble in the industry. D2.
 
A Sticking Point on Trade
Four years after the Clinton Administration said it would prod Mexico to improve workers' rights through agreements made along with the North American free trade pact, many Democrats and unions say results have been scant, complicating the White House's efforts to win new trade-negotiating authority. A8.
 
French Truck Blockade Continues
Truckers blocked highways across France for a second day. Union negotiators and representatives of a big employers' organization agreed to go back to the bargaining table, but the truckers said they would not take down their barricades. A4.
 
F.B.I. Informant Refuses to Answer
Mark D. Whitacre, the F.B.I. informant who secretly taped Archer Daniels Midland executives in an important price-fixing investigation, invoked his Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination a dozen times during a Federal court hearing. D10.

HEADLINE: U.S. IS BUYING MIG'S TO STOP IRAN DEAL

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 4

 BODY:
The United States announced a novel tack today in its years of efforts to stop advanced weapons from spreading to unfriendly countries: buying them first.
Secretary of Defense William S. Cohen said the United States had bought 21 Soviet-era MIG-29 fighter jets from a former Soviet republic for fear that they would end up in the hands of Iran. Fourteen of them, officials said, were the most advanced model made -- MIG-29C's -- capable of carrying and launching nuclear missiles. 
 Officials refused to say how much the United States had spent. They said the deal followed months of secret, frantic negotiations that began in February after the Government of Moldova informed the United States that Iran had expressed interest in buying up its newly decommissioned air force.
In the last two weeks, the Pentagon has furtively sent teams to Moldova, a small East European republic, to disassemble the jets, pack them into huge cargo planes and then fly them to the United States. The bulk of Moldova's old air force now sits at Wright-Patterson Air Force Base in Ohio.
The Pentagon bought the jets under a program that has spent $1.8 billion since 1993 to help Russia and the other former Soviet republics dismantle nuclear weapons and improve nuclear safeguards so that materiel does not fall into the hands of nations the United States considers to be rogues. While the program was used in 1994 to buy up more than half a ton of bomb-grade uranium from Kazakhstan, it had previously not been used to buy weapons.
The United States has long accused Iran of seeking to acquire weapons of mass destruction, including nuclear weapons, as well as the means to deliver them.
Mr. Cohen, speaking at a news conference at the Pentagon, said it was "a fair assumption indeed" to assume that Iran would continue its efforts to purchase planes like the MIG's, as well as other advanced weapons, from other countries.
"To have this kind of aircraft with a nuclear capability of deploying a weapon of mass destruction -- it seems to me it's in our overall interest to see to it that it doesn't fall into their hands," he said.
Iran's military is large but has fallen behind technologically. Its most advanced fighter jets are F-14's that the Shah of Iran purchased from the United States in the 1970's, an official said. The MIG-29's, considered on a par with some of the best American fighters, would have significantly enhanced its air power, the official added.
Of most concern to Washington, they would also be able to deliver the nuclear weapons that officials have long suspected Iran of trying to develop. While Iran accepts full inspection from international monitors, American officials have accused it of using civilian nuclear reactors to try to make nuclear arms.
Beyond denying Iran the jets, the deal also was something of an intelligence coup for the Pentagon. While the United States has acquired MIG's in the past, these advanced MIG-29C's are the first to fall into American hands, the officials said.
Because of the diplomatic sensitivities, Mr. Cohen said Russia had been told of the sale and, evidently, had done nothing to prevent it.
Mr. Cohen and other officials said the Pentagon would study the planes and even use them in training exercises, though not fly them in combat.
He and other Pentagon officials said they had agreed with Moldova not to disclose the price of the deal. An official said that the going rate on the world market for a MIG was as high as $30 million, but that "we paid much less than that."
The officials also said the United States did not want to set a price it was willing to pay, in the event others come on the market. "I don't see it as a precedent that we're now going to buy all the stray MIG's on the market," the senior official said.
In addition to a cash payment, the United States also agreed to give Moldova surplus military equipment, like trucks, as well as surplus food and relief supplies. As part of the deal, the United States also received more than 500 missiles for the planes and spare parts.
Moldova, nestled between Ukraine and Romania, has struggled economically ever since its independence from the Soviet Union in August 1991. After deciding to decommission its air force, the MIG-29's quickly became a lucrative export.
The officials said Moldova's military leaders had told the United States that several countries had expressed an interest in buying the planes. Iran's interest caused the most worry. Iran sent agents to a base in Marchulesti to inspect them late last year, the officials said.

HEADLINE: High Court Says Price Ceilings And Some 'Fixing' Are Allowed

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 4

 BODY:
In one of its most important antitrust decisions in years, the Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that a manufacturer or supplier does not necessarily violate Federal antitrust law by placing a ceiling on the retail price a dealer can charge for its products.
The ruling overturned a much-disputed 29-year-old precedent that regarded limits on retail markups as illegal price-fixing, a violation of the Sherman Antitrust Act. 
 No manufacturers announced any immediate plans to test the ruling, and it is unclear how soon the change might be felt by consumers because the legality of markup limits will now be determined case by case. Some consumer advocates said the Court simply shifted some power away from retailers in a decision that could result in diminished competition. But the Court's action was widely welcomed by manufacturers, who said it could eventually lead to lower consumer prices.
Under the ruling, for example, auto makers, freed to limit markups on popular models, might be able to keep dealers from selling them for more than the amount listed on the sticker. Computer manufacturers might be able to prevent retailers from charging exorbitant prices on hot-selling machines.
"We see this as pro-consumer; this will help to insure that the benefits of a manufacturer's pricing will be passed on to consumers," said Max Gates, a spokesman for the American Automobile Manufacturers Association in Washington.
Writing for the Court, Justice Sandra Day O'Connor said that there was "insufficient economic justification" for prohibiting the practice, which is known as resale price maintenance.
A manufacturer's inability to limit markups, she wrote, can actually harm consumers by leading to higher prices and to monopoly behavior by dealers who serve exclusive territories.
Justice O'Connor also noted that it remained illegal for manufacturers to impose minimum prices on dealers -- a version of price-fixing that is still automatically prohibited.
The decision grew out of a lawsuit by a gasoline dealer against his supplier, which had sought to limit prices by requiring the dealer to rebate to the supplier any excess over the allowed markup of 3.25 cents a gallon.
Reflecting the stakes involved, an unusually high number of briefs were filed on both sides of the case, State Oil Company v. Khan, No. 96-871. Organizations including the American Automobile Manufacturers Association, the National Association of Manufacturers and the Business Roundtable, representing the chief executives of 200 large corporations, all urged the Court to overturn the 1968 precedent.
The Justice Department and the Federal Trade Commission also urged the Court to overturn the 1968 ruling, Albrecht v. Herald Company. Joel I. Klein, the Assistant Attorney General for antitrust, told the Court that the ruling had done "considerably more harm than good." Ceilings on prices are "likely to be pro-competitive," Mr. Klein said during the argument, which took place Oct. 7.
For the Court to issue a decision of this significance less than a month after the argument indicates the Justices' confidence in repudiating a categorical approach to antitrust law, which had already been deeply eroded in other contexts. For example, in 1977 the Court overturned another important antitrust precedent and ruled that a manufacturer's use of exclusive dealer territories did not automatically violate the Sherman Act.
In contrast to the prior rule, which made all markup limits illegal, today's ruling means such limits will be evaluated by the Federal courts under what is known as the rule of reason, which requires a case-by-case examination of the economic and competitive impact.
In other words, the decision today does not automatically validate all markup limits. The permissible boundaries will be defined gradually as the Federal courts decide cases brought by disgruntled retailers.
The American Petroleum Institute, the trade group representing the oil industry, noted in welcoming the ruling that the decision did not mean markup limits were necessarily lawful. But the group said the ruling "does give the suppliers additional leeway in assuring that their products are marketed in a competitive manner."
On the retailers' side, organizations of automobile and gasoline dealers as well as the attorneys general of 33 states filed briefs urging the Court to hold the line. The Service Station Dealers of America, representing gasoline retailers in 14 states, told the Court that abandoning the absolute rule against setting maximum prices would give suppliers "coercive power over existing franchisees and dealers."
The states' coalition, led by New York and including Connecticut and New Jersey, told the Court that a retreat from its historical "condemnation of all forms of price-fixing" would "launch buyers and sellers in all markets, now governed by clear rules of conduct, upon a sea of doubt."
The Newspaper Association of America filed a brief, joined by The New York Times and other newspapers, that urged the Court to overturn the 1968 precedent. The brief said newspapers often found themselves at odds with their distributors because each was motivated by a different incentive: the distributors wanted a maximum profit per copy, even if the result was fewer sales, while the newspapers typically wanted to maintain or increase circulation, the basis for advertising rates.
The 1968 decision itself grew out of an effort by a newspaper publisher to grant exclusive territories to independent carriers who would not exceed the publisher's desired price.
The tension between newspaper publishers and distributors is mirrored in many other economic sectors where a retailer's desire for higher profits may conflict with a manufacturer's goal of greater volume. Unable to set markup limits, many manufacturers have used other tools to control their retailers' behavior, like consumer rebates and direct advertising, which makes it difficult for a retailer to exceed an advertised price.
The decision today overturned a 1996 ruling by the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit, in Chicago. That court ruled reluctantly that a gasoline supplier's effort to set maximum allowable retail prices was an antitrust violation. The appeals court said that while the Supreme Court's 1968 precedent was "unsound when decided" and "inconsistent with later decisions," lower courts had to follow the law until the Justices themselves overruled it.
Some industry experts said the decision today would probably have little effect on products like gasoline. Most dealers set their prices based on local competitive conditions, and if they set prices too high, other stations tend to force them down.
The ruling's impact on auto prices is also unclear. Although it could give auto makers additional leverage in preventing dealers from charging more than the list price, dealers historically have found ways to maximize their profits.
Some dealers are skilled at preventing manufacturers from discovering big price markups. One method, for example, is for a dealer to sell a popular car to a friend at list price and let the friend resell it immediately at a higher price to someone waiting for the car, with the dealer and friend splitting the difference.
Even if auto makers try to make use of the Court's ruling, "the dealers will come up with a way to get around it," said George E. Hoffer, an economics professor at Virginia Commonwealth University who specializes in auto dealership issues.
Some consumer advocates were decidedly pessimistic that the Court's ruling would result in lower prices. Rather, they said, it might just diminish a merchant's ability to determine prices.
Edwin S. Rothschild, the energy policy director for Citizen Action, a Washington-based consumer group, said the Court was "reinventing the Middle Ages; that retailers are not free, that they are serfs."
"This is America," he said. "You're supposed to be able to price goods to attract people or not attract people. That's supposed to determine whether you stay in business or not. Why should we give control to the wholesalers?"

HEADLINE: THE 1997 ELECTIONS: MAYORAL RACES;
For Incumbents in Cities, Celebrations Came Easily

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE

 BODY:
A parade of incumbent mayors were swept back into city halls across the nation yesterday, capping a remarkably calm campaign season in cities that only a decade ago were bastions of political upheaval.
Mayors coasting to re-election included Rudolph W. Giuliani of New York, Dennis W. Archer of Detroit, Sharon Sayles Belton of Minneapolis, Tom Murphy of Pittsburgh, Norm Coleman of St. Paul and Thomas M. Menino of Boston. 
 Both Democratic and Republican mayors were triumphant yesterday in contests that were notable for the lack of overarching issues. In many cities, the races were downright lackluster.
Contrary to past election campaigns, when candidates clashed over unemployment, racial conflict and all manner of other issues, most of the 223 mayoral races around the country this year were unusually smooth.
The lack of contention was perhaps a reflection that voters are relatively content or, at least, have turned more realistic about what mayors can accomplish. Even in some big cities that were considered all but ungovernable a decade ago, incumbent mayors did not have to campaign particularly hard.
In their campaigns, many incumbent mayors touted their cities declining crime rates and improved economies. In St. Paul, for instance, Mr. Coleman pledged city money to build a $130 million arena, and scored points for landing a professional hockey team. He also reminded voters that he lured a software company out of Minneapolis by promising to raze a city block and build the company a new headquarters through city subsidies.
"I know we are moving in the right direction for strong neighborhoods and a vital downtown."
All in all, the voting yesterday was quite a contrast to that of four years ago, when there was dramatic turnover at city halls in Boston, Detroit, Atlanta, Miami and elsewhere.
One of the few lively races was in Miami, where Mayor Joe Carollo came close but did not avoid a runoff on Nov. 13 with his opponent, former Mayor Xavier Suarez. Mr. Carollo drew 49.6 percent of the vote to 47 percent for Mr. Suarez.
Leading the pack of old faces that were returned to power was Mayor Giuliani, a Republican who never seemed threatened by his Democratic challenger, Ruth W. Messinger, and overwhelmingly won a second term.
One of the more interesting races was in Minneapolis, where Mayor Sayles Belton fought off a challenge from Barbara Carlson, an independent who was married to the state's Republican Governor, Arne Carlson. Ms. Carlson was a talk show host who had a reputation for saying or doing anything, and wrote a book called "This Broad's Life," which contained details about her sex life.
In St. Paul, across the river, Mayor Coleman, a Republican, had an easy re-election even though he switched parties only last year. His opponent in the Democrat-Farmer-Labor party was Sandy Pappas, a state senator.
Mayor Menino of Boston had an even easier campaign: He was the first incumbent mayor in the city's history to face no opposition in the general election. He, too, won a second term.
Mr. Menino, a Democrat, became Boston's first Italian-American mayor in 1993 when Raymond L. Flynn resigned to become Ambassador to the Vatican. Mr. Menino was president of the City Council when he was elevated to the mayor's office.
Any opponents he might have had this year were scared off not only by his large war chest but also by his substantial popularity: He registered a 74 percent approval rating in one recent poll.
In Detroit, Mayor Archer won a second term by a wide margin in a nonpartisan election. The one-sided race there was in marked contrast to that of four years ago, when Mr. Archer, then a Michigan Supreme Court Justice, won a scrappy election to succeed the combative Coleman A. Young, who had been Mayor for 20 years but decided to retire four years ago. (Mr. Young has a history of antipathy toward Mr. Archer but did not make an endorsement in the race this year.)
Mr. Archer, who was opposed yesterday by Ed Vaughn, a State Senator, was the beneficiary of a reviving local economy and a perception that Detroit was on its way back. He assiduously courted President Clinton, and early in his administration Detroit was one of the cities selected for a Federal empowerment zone, with tax breaks and other benefits amounting to $100 million. In his first term, unemployment fell in Detroit, and, by his estimate, $5.8 billion in new projects were begun.
Mayor Paul Helmke of Fort Wayne, Ind., president of the United States Conference of Mayors, recalled being in Charlotte, N.C., recently for a meeting with that city's Mayor, Pat McCrory, when Mr. McCrory ducked out for a candidates' debate.
"Ordinarily when you've got a debate with your opponent, you're blocking off the whole day to get rested," Mr. Helmke said, "get makeup and work the themes."
But Mr. McCrory was gone only a half-hour, Mr. Helmke said, "kind of like going out to make a phone call."
Mr. McCrory won yesterday.

HEADLINE: THE 1997 ELECTIONS: THE MANDATE;
Mayor Now Has a Mandate to Aim High

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE

 BODY:
For much of the last four years, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has enjoyed portraying himself as the embattled quarry of New York City's Democratic establishment, scuffling for every victory and succeeding despite vast battalions of "old-fashioned politicians" arrayed against him.
As of last night, that image of siege, never entirely accurate, is obsolete. 
 With his definitive victory over the Democratic emblem, Ruth W. Messinger, the Republican outsider has absorbed and become the city's establishment, suddenly finding himself an undisputed national figure with far greater power to remake the government of New York City.
He did not win by the historic margins his aides had predicted, and he failed to do as well among African-Americans as he had hoped. Early returns showed him trailing by a substantial margin in the Bronx, and barely winning in Manhattan. It will be difficult for him to claim convincingly that his re-election has truly unified the city.
But having amassed his mandate with significant help from many of the Democrats who campaigned against him in 1989 and 1993, Mr. Giuliani now has the freedom and the political capital to broaden his reputation beyond that of a former prosecutor who made the city's streets safer.
And because he simultaneously becomes the city's first official lame-duck mayor -- the result of the 1993 term-limits amendment -- he must fulfill the high hopes expressed in yesterday's vote in only four years or less, intensifying the pressure to produce decisive, dramatic accomplishments equal to the drop in crime that dominated his first term.
"The expectations for this man are unbelievably high," said Frank Luntz, who conducted Mr. Giuliani's internal polls during the campaign, and who has worked for other Republican candidates around the country. "Our polls show that he has the highest credibility rating, to do whatever he wants to do, of any public official I've ever seen."
Just what he will choose to do, however, has become the political mystery of the moment. Mr. Giuliani, who has not even committed himself to serving out the full four years of his last term, has been loath to discuss the direction of the next term beyond saying he will build on his accomplishments and will begin a big effort to reduce drug use. Even his closest advisers seem uncertain which of two roads he will take as he approaches a decisive moment in his political career.
Will he give greater rein to his inclination to act as the city's disciplinarian, seeking more mayoral control and pursuing a conservative agenda of further cuts in city spending and new anticrime efforts? Or will he chart a broader course, seeking a legacy larger than improved public safety and focusing on issues like education, housing, and finding jobs for those on welfare?
His Republican advisers, including longtime friend Peter J. Powers, Deputy Mayor Randy L. Levine, and Guy V. Molinari, the Staten Island Borough President, hope he will now take some bold steps to the right to solidify his party credentials in preparation for an eventual run for United States Senate, or even higher office.
Although his purely executive temperament makes it unlikely he would enjoy being one of 100 senators, such a position may be the kind of intermediate step he needs if he has dreams of a national ticket someday. In either case, appealing to upstate New York voters or those in a Republican Presidential primary requires different political calculations from those he has made as mayor.
Now that he is unfettered by the need to appeal to the largely Democratic city electorate, Mr. Giuliani is being urged by those within his party to make large cuts in city spending, cut taxes even further, privatize city services and overhaul the City University system.
"If he's looking at moving up the ladder, he has to establish his Republican credentials more than he has," said Mr. Molinari, a co-chairman of the Mayor's campaign. "The fact that he endorsed Mario Cuomo will never be forgotten by some people in the party. So he has to take out his Republican credentials and polish them up a bit, and I think he can take more aggressive steps now."
On the other side of the spectrum, more liberal advisers, including Raymond B. Harding, leader of the Liberal Party, and Fran Reiter, the re-election campaign manager, want him to pursue a broader course. Many of the Democrats who supported him want the Mayor to build on his increasing acceptance in black and Hispanic neighborhoods to become known as someone who united the city, improved its school system, and reduced police brutality along with crime. This school of thought holds that Mr. Giuliani should try to become the true reincarnation of Fiorello H. La Guardia, reaching further into neighborhoods like those in the Bronx that rejected him yesterday.
"I believe he will broaden his focus," said Mr. Harding, the Mayor's senior political adviser, noting that he did much better among African-Americans than he did in 1993 (though he still received less than a fifth of their vote, according to exit polls). "So he's a long way there already, and this kind of mandate is the capstone of that effort."
To a lesser degree, this debate has run throughout the Mayor's first term, and it seems likely that he will now continue to chart his own instinctive course between these polar arguments. Although a team of four or five advisers is preparing a draft agenda for his second term, Mr. Giuliani has made it clear in recent weeks that he shares Mr. Harding's desire for a warmer reputation as a unifier, however contrary that may be to his widespread image as an imperious steam whistle.
Softening his image has its own political advantage, even if it may not sit well with orthodox Republicans. New Yorkers may appreciate a large helping of hot sauce with their Mayor, but other regions may have a far different reaction to Mr. Giuliani's particular style.
In the most passionately delivered passage of his acceptance speech last night, he described New York as a city with "open arms," and said the next four years would be dedicated to reaching all New Yorkers, even those who had not been touched by his successes in his first term. "No New Yorkers should be left out," he said. "No New Yorker should be left behind."
That doesn't mean, however, that there won't be some Draconian decisions in the years ahead. The Mayor's aides say privately that they expect him to mount a full-blown campaign against the current operation of CUNY's two-year colleges, which he believes have wrongly served in effect as remedial high schools. He is likely to intensify what one aide calls a "bloodbath" confrontation with the Port Authority, working to wrest the city's airports from the authority's control, and possibly to get New York State out of the agency altogether.
Near the end of his term, he has said, he may once again begin an effort to win mayoral control of the school system from Albany, once it is clear he is doing so for future mayors.
And, because he enjoys defying low expectations, he intends to pour enormous resources into his antidrug campaign, pushing the Police Department to demonstrate clear results in a fight that has bedeviled mayors and presidents. That would be the kind of achievement that could get him an appointment as Attorney General and a leg up on a national political ticket, a goal many of his supporters hope he will pursue. If he combines that with similar aggressiveness in improving education or reducing unemployment, it might also produce the kind of legacy for which mayors are long remembered.

HEADLINE: THE 1997 ELECTIONS: THE GOVERNOR;
GIULIANI SWEEPS TO SECOND TERM AS MAYOR; WHITMAN HOLDS ON BY A RAZOR-THIN MARGIN

BYLINE: By JENNIFER PRESTON

 BODY:
Gov. Christine Todd Whitman narrowly won re-election to a second term last night, beating back a surprisingly strong challege from a Democratic opponent who tapped into voters' anger over the high cost of automobile insurance and property taxes.
"This is truly a wonderful victory because it speaks to all that we have been doing for the state of New Jersey, this Republican team, for the last three and a half years," Mrs. Whitman told a cheering crowd at the Princeton Marriott about 12:40 A.M. today. "I look forward to being Governor for the next four years to build on what we have done." 
 Minutes earlier, the Democrat, State Senator James E. McGreevey, smiling but subdued, stood before a hushed crowd at the Woodbridge Sheraton Hotel and offered a gracious concession speech.
"We put middle-class New Jersey issues at the front of the burner and, God willing, we will address these issues with this Legislature and this Governor over the next four years," he said.
With 99 percent of election districts reporting in unofficial returns, the vote was 1,108,863 for Mrs. Whitman and 1,086,679 for Mr. McGreevey. Murray J. Sabrin, the Libertarian Party candidate, had 111,924 votes. An estimated 41 percent of the residents who were eligible to vote turned out at the polls, just below the 42 percent that turned out four years ago.
Mrs. Whitman began her statewide political career as the little-known Republican who nearly toppled then-Senator Bill Bradley, a Democrat, in 1990, wounding his political standing outside New Jersey. In a striking replay of that race, Mr. McGreevey's unexpectedly fierce challenge may have damaged Mrs. Whitman's future in the Republican Party. Four years ago, she defeated Gov. Jim Florio by only one percentage point, about the same margin of victory in this contest.
Polls suggested that Mrs. Whitman won by solidifying her support among her Republican base in the final 10 days of the campaign and by making a strong showing among female voters across the state. She also captured enough votes among traditional Democratic voters in the state's cities, overcoming vigorous efforts by Democrats and organized labor leaders to get Mr. McGreevey's supporters to the polls.
Only six months ago, Mrs. Whitman was considered unbeatable in this race. The state's economy was humming. She had fulfilled her promise to cut the state's income taxes by 30 percent. And she was a prominent and influential leader in the national Republican Party.
But she found herself locked in a close contest with Mr. McGreevey, a little-known Democratic challenger who tapped into a reservoir of voter discontent over two problems that Mrs. Whitman had not addressed in her first term: rising automobile insurance and property rates.
Mr. McGreevey, a 40-year-old State Senator and former assistant prosecutor who is also Mayor of Woodbridge, won a hard-fought primary in June to win the Democratic nomination and surprised even his most ardent supporters by running a feisty and focused campaign. He kept Mrs. Whitman on the defensive for much of the race by relentlessly hammering her record on auto insurance. He rarely strayed from his message that he was the candidate who better understood the needs of "working and middle-class families."
Mr. McGreevey's campaign strategists viewed the race as Whitman versus Whitman, and did little to try to promote Mr. McGreevey himself or to tell voters much about his record as Mayor of Woodbridge, where he restored integrity to what was widely considered a corrupt and poorly managed local government.
The New Jersey governor's race drew national attention not only because Mrs. Whitman's political future was threatened but also because the state's volatile electorate has long been a fairly faithful gauge of what is on voters' minds from coast to coast. Four years ago, when taxes dominated the campaign, politicians across the country watched as New Jersey voters unseated an incumbent governor, Jim Florio, because he raised taxes, and they elected Mrs Whitman because she pledged to lower them.
The prospect of a Democrat's toppling the national Republican Party's biggest tax-cutting star spurred both national Republican and Democratic Party leaders to pour resources and to direct millions of dollars into the state.
Because Governor Whitman is among the most prominent members of the Republican Party's moderate wing, some Republican conservatives looked on with a smug sense of satisfaction at the struggle she was having for a second term. But national Republican leaders viewed her re-election as critical for the party's future. Republicans and Democrats alike followed Mrs. Whitman's lead in cutting taxes.
For Democrats, an upset in New Jersey would have given them the momentum they are looking for to make significant gains in next year's Congressional and gubernatorial contests, a point underscored by President Clinton at a McGreevey rally in Edison on Sunday when he said the New Jersey race was about "the direction that we have to take into the next century."
Mrs. Whitman's apparent victory last night may not be enough to undo damage that this fall's close race may have on her national standing. Her inability to glide easily to a second term put her future on a national ticket in doubt, some political analysts say, adding that it raised questions about whether she could continue to play an effective role in pushing the national Republican Party in a more moderate direction.
The close contest also raises questions about whether tax cuts alone and her brand of moderate Republican politics are the right mix for a party that is now deeply divided between its conservative and more moderate wings.
Mrs. Whitman found that her moderate Republican views were threatening to cost her badly needed votes from the more conservative wing of the party. She spent most of her time in the final days of the race campaigning in Republican strongholds with Republican leaders, who represent the other end of the ideological spectrum on social issues. She offended conservatives by vetoing legislation earlier this year that would have banned certain late-term abortions, pushing through a pension borrowing plan and failing to lobby hard for other items on the conservative agenda, like school vouchers.
But Patricia Harrison, co-chairwoman of the national Republican Party, dismissed speculation that Mrs. Whitman's hard-fought campaign had diminished any future political ambitions that Mrs. Whitman may have or impaired her ability to help shape the party's future.
"Winning is winning," Ms. Harrison said. "One would like huge margins, but winning is winning. New Jerseyans, like New Yorkers, are very independent. New Jersey is mostly a Democratic state. It is really a triumph for her to be re-elected. Christie Whitman is a leader in the Republican Party and it is up to her where she chooses to go with that."
Steven Grossman, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, sharply disagreed. "It is clear to me that there are several lessons here," he said. "This election is one in which Christie Whitman should have sailed to an easy victory. Yet it was a highly competitive situation because I think the Republican Party is a party at war with itself. Jim McGreevey has done what Whitman, unfortunately, did to Bill Bradley. A race that was this tight winds up wounding one of the very few reasonable voices within the Republican Party."
A turning point in the campaign for Mrs. Whitman, both sides say, is when she confronted voters in a television advertisement 10 days ago, and apologized for not doing more in her first term to lower auto insurance and property tax rates. In the 30-second spot, she told viewers that she heard their complaints in this campaign and she promised to address their concerns, if given another chance.
To the dismay of some of Mrs. Whitman's closest advisers, Mrs. Whitman never shied away from talking about the state's auto insurance problem. She said she ignored her campaign staff's advice because she believed that the electorate would become more angry with her if she did not acknowledge their concerns. She frequently cited her 1990 Senate campaign against Senator Bill Bradley, a Democrat, and his refusal in that race to discuss Gov. Jim Florio's $2.8 billion income tax increase earlier that year. She said that is why she believed she came so close to almost toppling him.
But her insistence on repeatedly discussing the problems of auto insurance and property taxes, her two biggest vulnerabilities, played right into the strategy of her Democratic opponent.
Mr. McGreevey talked of little else in this campaign, except for education. He used Mrs. Whitman's failure to bring down auto insurance rates and property taxes as evidence that she didn't understand the struggles of working and middle-class New Jersey families. "I'm on our side," he said, at every campaign stop.
But despite Mr. McGreevey's feisty campaign, it was not enough to persuade New Jersey voters, in the end, to take a chance on someone new. While a majority of voters consistently told pollsters they were deeply dissatisfied with Mrs. Whitman for not reducing their auto insurance and property tax bills, they continued to give her overall high marks as Governor.
The voters also said they liked Mrs. Whitman personally. Their anger never rose to the level that it did in 1990 against Governor Florio after he pushed through a $2.8 billion tax increase. Much of the animosity against Mr. Florio had subsided by the time he ran for re-election, but it was still there. Mrs. Whitman won by only 26,000 votes.
In addition to Mr. McGreevey's strong showing in the polls, the Whitman campaign also faced another challenge that further complicated the Governor's re-election bid: the candidacy of Mr. Sabrin, the Libertarian gubernatorial nominee. Mr. Sabrin, a professor at Ramapo College, was the first third-party candidate in the state to qualify for taxpayer financing for his campaign. As a result, he earned a place at the three televised debates and had enough money to buy media time to reach voters.
Mr. Sabrin, who opposes abortion rights, caused Mrs. Whitman particular difficulty among some conservative members of her own party.
Mrs. Whitman spent the closing days of the campaign emphasizing her tax cuts, making direct appeals to female voters and fighting hard to regain her standing with conservatives.

HEADLINE: THE 1997 ELECTIONS: DEFEAT;
In Messinger Camp, an Air of Subdued Resignation

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

 BODY:
As Ruth W. Messinger entered the Sheraton New York Hotel's New York Ballroom last night to deliver what might be her last speech as a politician, there was no aura of anticipation. The returns, showing a wide margin of victory for Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, offered no hope. The mood was resigned, the crowd subdued. A deejay played Elton John's "I'm Still Standing" -- the Messinger campaign's theme song -- as she climbed onto a platform with family and Democratic elected officials gathering behind her.
"First let me say how proud I am to be the first woman nominated by the Democratic Party for the office of mayor of the City of New York," she said, reading a speech she had worked on for days. Her eyes welled with tears and her lips quivered, but she did not cry. "Somewhere out there a little girl is watching this and this message is for her. I didn't become mayor tonight, young lady, but you will." The crowd cheered and chanted her name. "If just by reaching for it, just by giving it all I had I showed you that it could be done, I have succeeded," she continued. 
 For Ms. Messinger, the speech marked what could be the end of a political career that has spanned more than two decades, taking her from a community school board on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, to the City Council to the Manhattan borough president's office. Close aides said Ms. Messinger has no intention of running for public office again and that she wrote her speech with that in mind, to define her beliefs and her motivations.
"I got into this race because I love this city and I worry about its future," she said. "These issues and the real people touched by them have been important to me all my life, they are part of my personal commitment to social and economic justice."
She went on to warn that if Mr. Giuliani did not pay more attention to issues ranging from school overcrowding to unemployment, New York would "become a city of permanent winners and permanent losers with hardly anyone in between."
Even forseeing defeat, she campaigned until the last possible minute, at subway stations and stores in Brooklyn. The last planned event, a walking tour through housing projects in East New York with the Rev. Al Sharpton, was curtailed because her aides expected the race to be called early. Instead, she shook hands with voters in fast-food restaurants and left for the hotel.
In her suite, Ms. Messinger changed from the blue blazer she had worn all day to a pink one. Close supporters and elected officials milled about as she sat with her husband, her parents, Marjorie and Bill Wyler and her three children, Daniel, Miriam and Adam, and they posed for photographers. Somewhat hoarse, she drank a glass of tea.
Having lost the biggest race of the year, albeit by a smaller margin than some Giuliani aides had predicted, many Democrats talked throughout the night about the need to give their party a new direction. "I think there needs to be a major reassessment after this campaign," said Councilman Sal F. Albanese of Brooklyn, who opposed Ms. Messinger in the mayoral primary. New York's Democratic Party "needs to take stock of itself," Mr. Albanese said, "and think about what it really stands for."
Former Mayor David N. Dinkins, who campaigned with Ms. Messinger in Brooklyn until just before the polls closed, praised Ms. Messinger and said the Democratic Party needs "to look at those would-be Democrats who deserted the party and Ruth."
Aides said that Ms. Messinger had not yet considered a life out of public office. "There is life after public office," said Mr. Dinkins, who has a weekly radio show and teaches at Columbia University. "She'll be damn good at whatever she does."

HEADLINE: THE 1997 ELECTIONS: LONG ISLAND;
Races Leave Republicans Still Holding Major Offices

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT

DATELINE: GARDEN CITY, N.Y., Nov. 4

 BODY:
Republican incumbents swept most contests on Long Island today as voters handily re-elected County Executive Thomas S. Gulotta in Nassau, District Attorney James M. Catterson Jr. in Suffolk County and Republican majorities in the Legislatures of both counties.
And in a hard-fought race that reverberated in Albany, the Republicans also retained the State Senate seat in the Seventh District, most of which is in North Hempstead. The victory of Michael Balboni, an Assemblyman from Mineola, over Doreen E. Banks, a member of the North Hempstead Town Board, brings the Republican majority in the Senate back up to 35, compared with 26 Democrats. 
 In early returns, Mr. Balboni led Ms. Banks 4,358 to 2,813.
The seat was formerly held by Michael J. Tully Jr., a Republican, who died in August. Both sides spent hundreds of thousands of dollars on the race, which was the only election today for the State Legislature.
Nassau Democrats' hopes of winning additional clout in the County Legislature appeared to have failed: they gained no seats and appeared to be on the verge of losing one. Going into the election, the 19-member Legislature was held by the Republicans with a lead of 13 to 6.
With 15 percent of the returns in, County Executive Gulotta led by a 2-to-1 ratio for a record-tying third term as Nassau's chief official. His big victory, after his relatively narrow victory four years ago, may help him win a spot on a statewide ticket next year. Publicly, he has been silent on that possibility, however, and last week he even pledged to complete his third term.
Mr. Gulotta entered the campaign with the odds in his favor. Crime is at a 26-year low, the economy is improving, welfare rolls are down and county taxes have leveled off. His party has a 3-to-2 advantage among voters and a legendary county political organization. He used the powers of incumbency to make an endless string of new programs and proposals.
Mr. Gulotta raised nearly $4 million to flood the airwaves and mailboxes with campaign promotions, concluding with a handwritten letter from his wife, Betsy. Critics said most of the contributions came from county contractors and employees.
The Democrats put their hopes on Supervisor Lewis J. Yevoli of Oyster Bay, a politician with a reputation as a scrappy underdog able to beat Republicans. But he feuded with the Democratic County Chairman, Stephen J. Sabbeth, calling for his removal after Mr. Sabbeth was indicted on charges related to his business affairs.
Although Mr. Yevoli made the rounds of Long Island Rail Road stops and community group meetings in his campaign, he lost the money-raising competition with Mr. Gulotta by a ratio of about 20 to 1. As a result, he failed to reach the county's 1.3 million residents through the mass media.
Some Democrats complained that Mr. Yevoli's disappointing efforts and poor showing dragged down the rest of the ticket.
Also elected on the Republican slate were District Attorney Denis Dillon, Comptroller Frederick E. Parola Jr. and County Clerk Karen V. Murphy, all incumbents, and the new chairman of the Board of Assessors, Assemblyman Charles O'Shea. He will succeed Abe Seldin, who is retiring after 24 years. In Oyster Bay, Town Attorney John Venditto, a Republican, was leading Democrat Dal LaMagna in early returns to succeed Mr. Yevoli as Supervisor.
In Suffolk, the focus was on the District Attorney's race and the pugnacious style of the Republican incumbent, Mr. Catterson. His critics accused him of abusing his powers to bully other public officials. He denied the accusation, made no apologies and argued for re-election based on his high conviction rate of 96 percent and falling crime rates.
Several top Republicans crossed party lines to endorse Mr. Catterson's Democratic challenger, Theodore Scharfenberg, a former prosecutor on Mr. Catterson's staff. But Mr. Scharfenberg and his party raised only a small amount of campaign money.
Mr. Catterson led by about 56 percent to 44 percent with about 34 percent of the votes counted.

HEADLINE: THE 1997 ELECTIONS: REFERENDUMS;
Oregon Stays With Its Law On Suicides

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES

 BODY:
Oregon voters refused yesterday to repeal the country's only law allowing doctor-assisted suicide, first passed three years ago but never put into effect because of a series of legal and political challenges.
With more than half the state's precincts reporting, the repeal effort, one of more than 50 ballot initiatives decided across the country in the day's voting, was going down to defeat by a ratio of better than 3 to 2, according to The Associated Press. 
 Backers of the failed repeal effort, among them the Roman Cathiolic Church and a number of anti-abortion groups, indicated that they would continue the fight by filing more court challenges to the law.
In another major initiative vote, in Washington State, stricter gun controls were soundly defeated by a 2 to 1 ratio after gun advocacy groups, notably the National Rifle Association, outspent control advocates by better than 3 to 1.
The control proposals would have required gun owners -- at least one of every five Washington residents -- to pass an examination or take a safety course to get a gun license. Also proposed was a requirement that would have forced gun dealers to equip all new guns with trigger locks.
Gun advocates, who viewed yesterday's vote as a major victory in a long, hard national fight, fought the proposed legislation by warning that the real, hidden goal of control advocates was to eventually register and then confiscate all handguns.
Also in Washington yesterday, voters defeated a proposal that would have made the the state the third in a year to legalize medical use of marijuana and other drugs. The Associated Press said the measure was being defeated by a 3-to-2 ratio.
With yesterday's vote in Oregon, the state in effect reaffirmed its 1994 decision that made it the first place in North America to legalize doctor-assisted suicide. Similar proposals have been turned down in Washington and California.
But unlike various proposed measures, the Oregon law does not allow doctors to give lethal injections. They are limited to prescribing a lethal dose of drugs to a patient who has been given six months or less to live by two doctors, is of sound mind and has made a written request to die.
Once a decision has been made to end a life, there is a 15-day waiting period until the prescriptions can be written.
Yesterday's vote was somewhat surprising. In 1994, the first time Oregon voted on assisted suicide, the measure passed, barely, 51 percent to 49 percent. That law held up in a series of court challenges, including one that the United States Supreme Court refused to hear last month.
Polls before yesterday's balloting showed that voters were angry at the Oregon Legislature for throwing a voter-approved measure back at the electorate. It was the first time in Oregon history that a measure which had been voted into law by citizens was returned for reconsideration by the Legislature.
Assisted suicide had the support of Oregon's popular Governor, John Kitzhaber, a Democrat who is also a physician. It was opposed by the major medical organizations, including the powerful American Medical Association, and by the Catholic Church, which spent more than $1.5 million in the repeal effort.
In other voting on ballot initiatives yesterday, proposals to impose new laws on timber cutting and to extend voting rights to mentally ill people under guardian care were rejected in Maine, and in the Southwest, Navajo Indians rejected an effort to allow casino gambling on their reservation, the nation's largest.
The Maine voters refused to buy arguments from timber companies and some environmentalists that the proposed new cutting laws would limit destruction of the nation's largest remaining and most valuable forests.
Nor would they accept arguments that it was archaic in the 1990's for a state to be involved in deciding whether a person under a guardian's care was too mentally ill to be allowed to vote.
In voting in Arizona, Utah and New Mexico, Navajos rejected casinos despite arguments by proponents that the flow of gamblers' cash would help give the tribe a badly needed economic boost.
In Minneapolis and Pittsburgh, in another sign that citizens in some cities are growing wary of anteing up for fancy new sports facilities, voters balked at giving carte blanche approval for construction of new stadiums.
Those in the 11-county Pittsburgh area rejected by a 3 to 2 margin a sales tax increase that would have paid for new football and baseball parks. In Minneapolis, they voted 2-1 to require the city government to get their permission in order to spend more than $10 million on a new stadium.

HEADLINE: Russians Are Springing Up All Over;
Few medium and large American ballet troupes lack emigres.

BYLINE: By JENNIFER DUNNING

 BODY:
Ellen Tharp wanted to start a ballet company on Staten Island. But where to find dancers? A Russian cabdriver who had been an engineer at home gave her an idea. Why not advertise in Novoye Russkoye Slovo, the Russian-language newspaper, and on Russian cable television? The response was overwhelming.
Many of the dancers had performed with leading dance companies in Russia. "Most were living in Brighton Beach and working in nightclubs," Ms. Tharp recalled in an interview at her studio in the New Dorp Moravian Church. "I got two beautiful Moiseyev boys, a Bolshoi boy, two Kirov girls, another boy from the Bolshoi Opera and a girl from a Georgian ballet company. They spoke almost no English. We communicated in ballet language." 
 Only one of the original Russian recruits will dance when the Staten Island Ballet performs on Saturday at Kaye Playhouse at Hunter College, on 68th Street between Lexington and Park Avenues in Manhattan. "Right now I'm really low on Russians," Ms. Tharp, who is not related to the choreographer Twyla Tharp, said. But they come and go and she knows they will return. "There is such a supply of them," her husband, Paul, said.
The dancers pouring by the score into the United States from Russia and the countries that once made up the Soviet Union are performing, teaching and even running companies, filling the ranks of troupes from New York to California and from Minnesota to Texas. They are not the first Russian dancers to immigrate, or even the most notable or gifted. Immersed in the traditions of czarist and Soviet classical ballet, they have much to give American ballet but also much to learn. What stands out about them is their number.
"The calls and videos are endless, endless," Martin Fredmann, director of the Colorado Ballet and a leading ballet Russophile, said with a groan that was not entirely unhappy. "And my dancers give me more videos and resumes. I have a big box marked 'Russians.' "
The current westward flow of Russian dancers began in an atmosphere of relative relaxation in 1990, a year before the dissolution of the Soviet Union. "That was the first year Russian dancers could sign contracts," said Eldar Aliev, a former member of the Kirov Ballet who now directs Ballet Internationale of Indianapolis. "Before that, we belonged to the company." Now there were choices, Mr. Aliev said, though they often had to be fought for. From early in this century, Russian dancers have dropped out during American tours to settle in the United States and teach or start companies of their own. The age of the great Soviet defectors began with Rudolf Nureyev in 1961 and continued into the mid-1970's with Natalia Makarova, Mikhail Baryshnikov and other dancers from the leading Soviet companies, the Bolshoi and Kirov Ballets.
A look at the original cast of a 1971 Kirov version of "The Creation of the World," which was revived by its choreographers Natalya Kasatkina and Vladimir Vasiliyov for presentation last month by Ballet Internationale, suggests the extent of the outflow. Three of its four leads -- Mr. Baryshnikov, Valeri Panov and Irina Kolpakova -- have since established careers in the West. The fourth, Yuri Soloviyev, died a suicide in the Soviet Union in 1977.
The restaging was the idea of Eldar Aliev, who joined the Indianapolis company in 1992 and became its artistic director in 1994. Mr. Aliev insists that he has no interest in creating "a little copy of the Bolshoi or the Kirov." Eight of his 25 dancers are Russian.
A third of the 33 dancers in the Colorado Ballet are Soviet-trained, and the company has three Russian teachers, three Russian pianists and one Russian balletmaster. Eight of American Ballet Theater's 77 dancers are Russian. A small company called the Russian Ballet was founded in 1995 in Wilmington, Del., with a core of stranded Russians from the touring Donetsk Ballet of the Ukraine.
In a random sampling of 20 medium and large ballet troupes in 18 states, only 5 have no Russian dancers, teachers or ballet masters. Eleven have more than one Russian member, and the number jumps to 18 at the Colorado Ballet. Most of the dancers are male principals or soloists with some performing experience with the Bolshoi and Kirov. Many drift from company to company, perform as guest artists with more than one troupe or teach at several schools.
 
A Hunger to Learn New Kinds of Dance
Dmitri Kouznetsov, a hip 25-year-old member of the Colorado Ballet, performed with two other troupes before moving to Denver last year. He immigrated five years ago, in part because of his curiosity about the United States and to avoid military conscription. At home in Tblisi, Georgia, he danced three performances every week and had his own coach. "There is not so much time to learn stuff here and not so many performances," he said. He was encouraged to come by a Georgian friend who had danced at a Jackson, Miss., competition and stayed on to direct Ballet Mississippi for a year.
The earlier lure of artistic freedom has been replaced by a hunger for new kinds of dancing. Vladimir Malakhov is performing with Ballet Theater at City Center this week and next in works by Balanchine and Mark Morris, for example, and will dance with a former Alvin Ailey star, Desmond Richardson, in a new piece by the Spanish choreographer Nacho Duato. Mr. Malakhov will return the favor with the all-Russian "Diaghilev Celebration" on Nov. 17 at the New York State Theater, in which he will perform with Igor Zelensky, a Bolshoi dancer who danced recently with the New York City Ballet.
And the eight Russian dancers in the Wilmington troupe will perform a somewhat unorthodox new version of "The Nutcracker" by Robert LaFosse, a principal dancer with the New York City Ballet, in December.
"I would like to stay here and dance," Mr. Kouznetsov said. "It has been hard sometimes. The language, the different culture. But I'd like to experience more styles here, dance Balanchine and modern and jazz."
The Russian dancers at the Colorado Ballet will soon learn Martha Graham's "Appalachian Spring." In the spring, Ballet Internationale will perform Agnes de Mille's "Rodeo" and Paul Taylor's "Company B," inspired by the wartime Andrews Sisters songs to which the dance is set.
The United States is still seen as the land of gold-paved streets. "It is hard for them to understand that money isn't there for dance as it is in Russia," Mr. Fredmann said. "They don't understand they have to be responsible for their art here, signing autographs and doing school performances. You have to be willing to go out and beg, to give your art away.
"The first thing the Russian boys do when they get here is buy the biggest, most outrageous American used cars that get eight miles to a gallon and break down all the time. They all have accidents. As the years go on, the cars get smaller and smaller and more practical."
Mr. Fredmann has become a keen observer of the Russians' integration into the United States. Speaking of the male dancers, he reflected, "They have to have things. Dancing becomes secondary, but it is the only thing they know how to do. The women we've had really work hard. They want to dance. But the men were being brought up at a time when their country was falling apart. It is a lost generation, especially the men. They seem not to care to dance, though I'm not sure that they just don't want to show their feelings."
Ms. Tharp has been told by some of her Russian dancers that they are afraid to return to their country for fear the borders will again close. They also fear black-market crime. She still shudders over an incident that revealed to her the desperate poverty and economic confusion the dancers have left behind.
A gifted Russian ballerina auditioned for the Staten Island company, bringing along her husband, who spoke what Ms. Tharp describes as "restaurant English," as her translator. When she told them what she could pay, the two went into an intense and argumentative huddle. Sadly, the director explained that the fee was all she could afford.
Another huddle, then the husband turned to her. "O.K.," he said. "But when do we have to pay you?" Ms. Tharp was stunned. "I suddenly realized that they came from a black-market system where if you couldn't find a job you paid to work."
For all the difficulties of adjustment many of the dancers face, the two dance worlds are ultimately not so different, Victoria Lebedev, a choreographer for the Staten Island Ballet, said. Konstantin Uralsky, who is teaching at Hartford Ballet after directing the Ballet Iowa, now defunct, for five years, agreed. "I am who I am," he said. "I do what I did before and what I believe I have to do. I will work any place in the world. But the United States is home now."
The opportunities for work are decent but not unlimited here. Not every director of an American ballet company is a Russophile. The Houston Ballet recently took on its first Russian company member, though the Bolshoi ballerina Nina Ananiashvili performs with the company as a guest artist.
"I never found any good ones," Ben Stevenson, the artistic director of the Houston company, said. "There are. But obviously they stayed in New York. They didn't swim as far as Houston." The dancers who did come his way wanted to be hired as principal dancers, too, whatever their background and whether or not they could dance anything but the classics.
 
Admiring the Grace Of Their Arabesques
Still, he does admire Russian dancing for its balance and its emphasis on the upper body. "They don't just dance upright. They have a wonderful line in the air, a curve to their arabesque. They also have very soft plies. Their landings from jumps are secure."
Mr. Fredmann lovingly recalls the Russians he saw dancing from the 1950's into the 70's in performances that "didn't deal in small statements." Even today, he said, the Russians dance with unusual passion. "They all seem to have a special kind of madness that is charming at its best though at worst very trying," he said.
While he admires their classical technique, he said, many Russians have little feel for the continuous lyrical flow of dancing. "And Russian men don't particularly like to partner. They don't want to stand behind the women."
One of the Russians' greatest gifts to the United States may be their teaching of traditional classical ballet technique and style. The great Kirov ballerina Alla Osipenko is a teacher and coach at Kirk Peterson's Hartford Ballet. Ms. Kolpakova teaches at Ballet Theater and Ballet Internationale. And Oleg Vinogradov, former director of the Kirov, heads the largely Russian staff of the Universal Ballet Academy in Washington. Vladilen Semyonov, who trained Mr. Aliev at the Kirov, now heads the Indianapolis company's academy and offers free seminars to teachers and dancers there and in nearby satellite schools.
Many American ballet directors feel the cachet of the Russian dancer is beginning to wane as less experienced performers flood the market. But the letters, telephone calls and videos continue to come, often prompted by word of mouth.
Mr. Stevenson said he gets tips from an unusual source. "I get letters from people saying that they were on holiday in Omsk and met the most wonderful dancers on a train. Or they met a choreographer on the plane. We're subscribers, they say. We know you'll take them in."
