LENGTH: 1468 words

HEADLINE: At Home With: Jane Jacobs;
Urban Hero

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA 

DATELINE: TORONTO

 BODY:
BECAUSE Jane Jacobs believes nothing should ever be thrown out, she uses a World War II experiment to hold open her front door. It is a smooth wooden block, a model for a fuel tank that would fit in the wing of a fighter plane.
Her late husband, Robert, designed the tank during the war. Now it is a doorstop that Ms. Jacobs, 81, uses whenever she burns the toast or wobbles to her front porch to sit on a white garden chair and do what she does like no one else: observe the city. 
 Hard to believe though it may be for New Yorkers who still connect her dumpling face to Greenwich Village, it's been nearly 30 years since Ms. Jacobs, in a flash of disgust, left the city she had so passionately defended and took refuge here in what she once called "the most hopeful and healthy city in North America."
Albany Avenue, the shady street lined with comfortably worn brick houses where she has lived since shortly after leaving New York, is not as eclectic or, as she puts it, "full of pizazz" as the Village streets she wrote about so vividly in her first book, "The Death and Life of Great American Cities" (1961), perhaps the most important book written about cities in the 20th century.
But in the way each front porch overlooks the sidewalk and hugs its neighbors, it does have the human scale she championed in that book and those that have followed. The semi-detached houses, constantly renovated and haphazardly remodeled through most of this century, may not win any design awards but they affirm the adaptability she urged cities not to take for granted.
Perhaps most of all, her 95-year-old brick half house and the other homes on Albany Avenue show the spirit of serendipity that her arch-critic, Lewis Mumford, called "higgledy-piggledy unplanned casualness" but which she and her followers have used as a shield against the widespread destruction of American cities.
Now reliant on a $10 bentwood cane to help her creaky knees, Ms. Jacobs cuts just as unassuming a figure as she did when she fought against boondoggles like the Lower Manhattan Expressway, which would have wiped out much of what is now SoHo.
"I can't flatter myself that the book made a great deal of difference, or these things would have stopped in the early 1960's; but they didn't," she said in an interview at the dining room table of her capriciously decorated home, where track lighting surrounds turn-of-the-century sconces and a porch glider has found new life as a sofa.
In her view, megaprojects and slash-and-burn urban renewal did not lose favor until the mid-1970's, when they "demonstrated by themselves that they were stupid, extravagant and unworkable."
"Insofar as the book or I have made a difference," she said, "it's by maybe helping to show why such things didn't work and that alternative things can be done."
Despite her fear of overstating the book's impact, "The Death and Life of Great American Cities" has already influenced at least two generations of architects, city planners and municipal officials, and in mid-October was the popular focus of a weeklong symposium held in Toronto on her and her work.
"She's affected the way I and a lot of people like me think about cities," said Patrick McGuire, an urban economist at Hobart and William Smith Colleges, who has been bringing undergraduates to Toronto and New York on comparative field trips for 16 years. "She provides the basic tools for optimism, not pessimism, that cities can work."
But in her latest battle against what she sees as the wrongheadedness of public officials, Ms. Jacobs was unable to stop the local government's headlong rush to have Toronto follow the path New York City took a century ago. Several separate municipalities around Toronto will be combined into one megacity.
Although the beveled glass front door of her house still bears a "No Mega City" sign, the new super city -- which at 2.3 million people will be larger than any American city but New York, Chicago and Los Angeles -- will come into existence Jan. 1.
"These are worrisome times," she said about the changes she fears could rob Toronto of its great strength: diversity on a workable scale. Although her toughness and tenacity -- traits easily attested to by legions of New York City officials -- have not diminished with the years, some of her early ideas can now seem dated.
During the symposium she suggested the core city of Toronto should simply secede from the megacity, which is essentially what she concluded in an earlier book about the French-speaking province of Quebec's future in Canada. It was vintage 60's radicalism, the kind of direct confrontation that worked when urban renewal projects threatened entire neighborhoods. Although her remark made headlines locally, no one took her suggestion seriously.
Still, in her long career, Ms. Jacobs has stared down plenty of foes at least as pushy as the province of Ontario. She was arrested in New York City in 1968 in a protest against the proposed expressway across lower Manhattan. Not long after moving here, she prevented a wrecking crew from tearing down a beloved old house in an action that may have helped Toronto from repeating the mistakes of New York.
She calls herself "a very traditional person who believes in 'Home Sweet Home.' " Anyone coming across her during the Depression -- when she moved from Scranton, Pa., to New York without a college degree and became an exceedingly courteous young writer -- would have sensed her affection for home. But at times she also acts like an urban minuteman, taking on any developer or elected official she thinks is out to ruin people's homes.
The disparity between those two images throws everyone except Ms. Jacobs. "You think people who love home ought to be namby-pambies, or that I should just be some little old lady with white hair who simpers?" she snaps, revealing a bit of the attack dog who has so bedeviled officials. One of them, a former New York City housing administrator named Roger Starr, said, "What a dear, sweet character she isn't."
Reminded of that, Ms. Jacobs retorted, "I won't say what I think about Roger Starr." Then she abruptly did so.
"I think he's a foolish man," she said. The two of them often clashed because Mr. Starr, who later became an editorial writer for The New York Times, backed slum clearance to resolve problems like the need for low-income housing.
"My biggest beef with Jane was that she didn't recognize how complicated these things were," Mr. Starr said. "In her anger against all this, she felt the people who were doing these things were being destructive when they were simply trying to solve problems."
When she packed up and left her Greenwich Village brownstone in 1969, Ms. Jacobs said publicly it was to protest the war in Vietnam. But she also had grown tired of the fray in New York.
"I had work that I wanted to do," she said. She completed "The Economy of Cities" (1969) but the constant battles in New York made other writing difficult.
Ms. Jacobs's writing is marked by strikingly original observation and clear thinking about cities and, later, more broadly about economics. When she is writing here in her second-story study, pounding away on a 40-year-old Remington typewriter borrowed from her daughter-in-law, who lives down the street, Ms. Jacobs said she needs to shut out the diversions of the neighborhood.
But much of her work, as opposed to her writing, is done right on Albany Avenue, where knots of boys often rush past on their way to the private school down the block that uses the recycled foundation of an unfinished Anglican cathedral for classrooms.
"Everybody knows her," said Sid Adilman, an entertainment columnist for The Toronto Star who has lived opposite Ms. Jacobs for almost 30 years. "She talks to everybody. I don't think that the house painter who works around here knows her as the author of a famous book. He just knows her as Jane."
Last year Ms. Jacobs's beloved husband and partner, Robert, died. But she does not let the intense grief prevent her from working. She will say little about the new book she's writing other than that "it's just another book on economics."
Ms. Jacobs had to give up her American citizenship when she became a Canadian citizen in 1973. She said she now feels not like a New Yorker but a Torontonian, and when she mentions Canadians or their urban policies, she says "we."
Although she has not visited since receiving an award in 1988, she said she still is fond of New York City, to which she dedicated her first book. She described it then as the place "where I came to seek my fortune and found it."
She now gets regular reports about New York from friends. "Everything I hear says it's been improving quite a bit lately," she said, "and I'm very glad to hear that."

HEADLINE: Modern Masters of Collecting;
From One Couple's Treasures, One Important Auction

BYLINE: By CAROL VOGEL 

 BODY:
For the last two weekends, more than 1,000 people a day have been visiting Christie's Park Avenue salesroom. Dealers and collectors, museum experts and art lovers, they have been drawn by an extraordinary group of works by just five artists: Picasso, Jasper Johns, Robert Rauschenberg, Frank Stella and Eva Hesse. They were collected by Victor and Sally Ganz, a quiet Manhattan couple who spent their Saturdays perusing galleries wherever they happened to be.
Their collection (were they alive, they would surely bristle at the word, calling it pretentious) is being sold at Christie's on Monday night. It is conservatively estimated to be worth $125 million, making it the most expensive single-owner sale ever. And if the enthusiasm from the art world is a measure, this may well be one of the most important auctions of 20th-century fine art in history.
 
 Mr. Ganz, who died in 1987, ran D. Lisner & Company, his family's costume-jewelry business. He was not a rich man, by the standards of today's tycoons. Nor was his wife, Sally Wile Ganz, a benefactor of educational and cultural organizations who died in January. During 50 years, they bought economically, spending under $2 million on the art that is now being sold. The Ganzes were willing to take risks that less talented collectors would not have. They had sure eyes and an uncanny talent for choosing just the right work. They became known as collectors who never made a mistake.
Rather than putting together an encyclopedic collection, as others of their generation tried to do, they spent 50 years buying the work of their five favorites. Next week's sale includes 115 paintings, drawings, sculpture and prints. "What is unusual about this collection is how rigorously formed it was," said Christopher Burge, chairman of Christie's in America. "They concentrated on the work of very few artists but in depth, and they were intellectually involved in everything they bought."
The Ganz sale kicks off two weeks of the biggest fall auctions in New York. Art by masters like Modigliani and Matisse, Cezanne and de Kooning, with an estimated value of about $500 million, makes it one of the most promising seasons since the boom years of the late 1980's.
Christie's is not the only auction house to offer a single-owner sale this fall. Sotheby's has two. The first is from the estate of Evelyn Sharp, the hotel owner who died in April; she amassed a collection worth about $60 million of works by Picasso, Modigliani, Matisse and Braque. It is being sold two days after the Ganz collection, on Wednesday evening. On Nov. 20, Sotheby's is selling the Keir Collection, a remarkable group of 12th- to 14th-century medieval enamels, named after a house that the seller, Edmund de Unger, once owned in Scotland.
Both Sotheby's and Christie's have more than their reputations at stake this fall. In order to secure these collections in what has become a fiercely competitive climate, both houses have had to strike expensive deals. Sotheby's has given Mary Sharp Cronson, the daughter of Evelyn Sharp, a guarantee (an undisclosed sum promised to the seller regardless of a sale's outcome). It has also guaranteed several paintings in its general Impressionist, modern and contemporary art sales.
To get the Ganz property, Christie's has invented a more complex strategy. While officials at the auction house refused to discuss the financial details, the catalogue for the auction says in small but bold letters, "Christie's has a direct financial interest in all property in this sale."
To insure these sales get attention, both auction houses expanded their marketing efforts. Sotheby's has hired the stage director Robert Wilson to design an exhibition that will include live models as part of the promotion of the Keir Collection.
Christie's has designed a special museumlike installation to show off the Ganz collection; it includes a high-tech rubber floor and computer screens, like A.T.M.'s, that spew out information on the collection at the touch of a finger. Christie's has also had the Ganz collection on view for an unprecedented period, both at its Park Avenue galleries and at its annex at 308 East 59th Street, where the paintings were on private view for a month.
While both houses have produced lavish hardbound catalogues, Christie's has gone further. Besides its 210-page, all-color $80 catalogue, it has published a $100 book, "A Life of Collecting: Victor and Sally Ganz," that includes essays by John Richardson, the author and Picasso biographer; Maya Picasso, a daughter of the artist, whose mother, Marie-Therese Walter, was the subject of many of the portraits, and Michael FitzGerald, chairman of the fine arts department at Trinity College in Hartford and a Picasso scholar.
 
'No Special Spotlights'
The story of the Ganz collection is a remarkable tale of passion and foresight. Those who knew the couple say they were a perfect team. Both read voraciously, and both loved looking at art. They lived in a duplex apartment on Gracie Square surrounded by their purchases.
"My parents were very conscious about the way each work of art played against each other," said Kate Ganz, one of their daughters. "Yet they had no special spotlights or fancy frames. They never had any curatorial help."
Mr. Ganz made his first purchase in 1941, just before he was married. For $7,000, he bought Picasso's "Dream" (1932), a portrait of Ms. Walter asleep in an armchair, considered one of the artist's most powerful portraits. Experts say the painting is worth around $30 million.
"The Dream" was the beginning of what Mr. Ganz called his "love affair with Picasso," a preoccupation that lasted 15 years, when he bought only Picassos: paintings, drawings, prints and sculptures. By the end of his life, he had put together the largest private collection of Picassos in the United States.
"Victor always said 1941 was a turning point in his life," said Mr. Richardson, who is writing a four-volume biography of Picasso and had been a friend of the Ganzes for 40 years. "He bought 'The Dream,' went into analysis and married Sally all within six months."
Another important milestone in their collecting lives came in 1948 when they decided to try to meet Picasso. While staying in Monte Carlo, the couple drove to Golfe-Juan, France, where they made friends with a bookseller who lived next door to Picasso. They learned that every morning, around 9, the artist passed the bookshop on his way to his studio. The next day, they waited at a nearby cafe, and when they saw Picasso go into the shop, they followed him. They introduced themselves, telling them how they had bought "The Dream" and enjoyed a long chat.
They did not visit Picasso again for another 22 years. Yet he often talked to mutual friends about the Ganzes, asking what they had bought. He was reportedly fascinated with their purchases because they were not interested in collecting his pretty, more commercial works. Instead, they bought challenging ones, some of which were painted during the war years.
Among the more haunting were "Cat and Bird" (1939), which depicts an angry cat holding a bird in its mouth and is thought to be worth $6 million to $7 million. Another, "Still Life with Sausages" (1941), a dark painting of the period showing what formerly would have been a typical French lunch at a time when little food was available, is estimated to bring $700,000 to $900,000. In the same palette, painted a year later, is "Reclining Nude," which shows Dora Maar, one of Picasso's mistresses, lying in the artist's studio on the Rue des Grands Augustins, where he painted the famous "Guernica" a few years earlier.
 
Picasso Series, Bought and Divided
Mr. Ganz also bought the entire series of Picasso's paintings after Delacroix's "Femmes d'Alger" done in 1954 and 1955. The series was begun just four weeks after Matisse died, and his influence on Picasso is evident. "Even if Victor had had the cash to buy the more expensive, small Blue Period or classical Picassos, he would have still bought the tough pictures," said Mr. Richardson.
After he bought the entire series of 15 works for $212,953, Mr. Ganz realized he might have gone a bit over his head. He sold all but five to dealers and museums for about $138,000. (Four of the "Alger" paintings that he kept are up for sale on Monday night.)
After that, Mr. Ganz decided that Picasso was getting too expensive. So he broadened his collection, buying the work of Mr. Johns and Mr. Rauschenberg, then in their 30's, and later Mr. Stella and Hesse. The couple still kept collecting Picassos, too, but only when the right one came up at the right price.
Among the classic images for sale at Christie's is Mr. Johns's "White Numbers" (1959), which carries a $5 million to $6 million estimate, and his "Corpse and Mirror," a 1974 diptych in his well-known crosshatch style, estimated to sell for $3.5 million to $4.5 million. The Rauschenbergs include "Red Interior" (1954), an elegant example of the artist's Combine Series. The Ganzes bought the painting straight from Mr. Rauschenberg for $11,000 in 1967. Now it is being offered with a $3 million to $4 million estimate.
At the time the Ganzes were buying paintings by Mr. Johns and Mr. Rauschenberg, other collectors were, too. But the one artist Mr. Ganz truly discovered was Hesse, the German-born American sculptor who, by the time she died of brain cancer at 34 in 1970, had left an indelible stamp on Minimalism.
On a Saturday in November 1968, the Ganzes were doing their usual tour of Manhattan galleries. Mrs. Ganz, whose feet hurt, left her husband and went home. He continued on his rounds, stopping by a Francis Bacon show at the Marlborough Gallery, which he described as "filled with wealthy collectors, chatting away like a giant cocktail party."
He left and went around the corner to the Fischbach Gallery, where Hesse was having her first show. He was immediately absorbed in the strange and unusual sculptures fashioned from materials like fiberglass, rubber tubing and metal screens, and ended up buying three. Her works are now among the most sought-after of the 1960's.
"My father was not a young man when he discovered Hesse, yet even though it was tough stuff, he didn't flinch," said Tony Ganz, his son. "Everyone thought he'd lost his mind, even curators. They didn't get it."

Another of their works, top right, was Robert Rauschenberg's "Rigger" (1961). (Photographs from Christie's)

HEADLINE: Federal Protection for a Vanishing Turtle

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5

 BODY:
Help is on the way for a species of small, brightly marked turtles that are rapidly disappearing from the wild, partly because of their popularity as pets.
The species, bog turtles, can fetch up to $2,000 a pair on the black market overseas, prompting the United States Fish and Wildlife Service to declare them threatened, subjecting traffickers to stiffer fines and imprisonment. 
 "During the last five to 10 years, an increasing number of bog turtles have been advertised for sale, and prices have increased substantially," the agency said on Tuesday.
The turtles are popular because of their size and the distinctive orange, yellow or red blotch on each side of the animal's head. There may be only a few thousand of the turtles left in 12 states from Massachusetts to Georgia.
Although the states in which the turtles are found already make it a crime to harm the animals, scientists say Federal protection is needed against smugglers.
The Fish and Wildlife Service declared the turtles threatened, one step short of endangered, and put the designation into effect immediately instead of allowing the customary 30 days.
Anyone who captures, harms or transports a threatened species faces up to $50,000 in fines and up to one year in prison for each offense.
Conservationists say the designation should serve as a catalyst for private donations. But the designation also calls attention to the turtles' popularity as pets, which the Fish and Wildlife Service recognized in refusing to publish the specific locations of the species.
In the northern states -- Massachusetts, Connecticut, New York, New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Delaware and Maryland -- the bog turtle population has shrunk by more than 50 percent in 20 years.
Scientists blame land development for reducing the turtles' natural habitat, a situation that is exacerbated by the illegal pet trade.
Domestically, a bog turtle can sell for $250 to $450, but there are reports of the animals fetching $2,000 a pair in Japan.
In the southern states -- Virginia, North Carolina, South Carolina, Tennessee and Georgia -- the turtles are not in immediate danger, but Federal officials are declaring them threatened there as well to halt further commercial harvesting.

HEADLINE: And Why Not a Guggenheim Leadville?

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "Wealth of Mine Barons Turns to Dust at Source" (front page, Nov. 4): While I have often tried to think of ways in which Leadville, Colo., might regain its luster, you gave us something to dream about. Imagine: a community saved by art! And while the idea of a Guggenheim Leadville seems farfetched, we might recall that the idea of creating a ski area in Vail was no less farfetched a mere 35 years ago, and likewise the idea of saving the mining town of Aspen with skiing 50 years ago. 
 As a native of Vail, I was disappointed by a few things your article missed. The first is your contention that Vail and Aspen have ever treated Leadville or its residents as second class. The old families of Vail and Aspen are well aware that we would not have achieved success without the help of Leadville.
Further, you gloss over Leadville's strongest asset: its sense of community. A few years ago the town had the foresight to spurn outside interests and vote down the gambling that three other former mining towns jumped on as a means to save their exhausted economies.
The result in those places is as expected: an increase in real estate values drove out the locals, and the casinos now sit empty because gambling is not nearly the draw it once was.
 
JONATHAN STAUFER
New York, Nov. 4, 1997

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Head Shot

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

 BODY:
When you think about how the U.S. should respond to Saddam Hussein's latest attempt to evade U.N. sanctions, just keep this in mind: Saddam Hussein is the reason God created cruise missiles. Cruise missiles are simply the only way to deal with him.
Saddam is up to something serious this time. He has apparently concluded -- from the U.S. efforts to tighten the sanctions around him, from recent in-your-face denunciations of him by Madeleine Albright, and from the fact that the new chief of the U.N. weapons inspection team in Iraq is turning out to be just as tough as his predecessor -- that the U.N. sanctions on Iraq are not going to be lifted, whether Saddam is a good boy or a bad boy. Whatever he does, the U.S. intends to find a way to keep the U.N. sanctions noose around his neck until one of his generals or one of his relatives terminates him with extreme prejudice. 
 Therefore Saddam is no doubt asking himself: "If my choices are sanctions with constant U.N. weapons inspections or sanctions without the U.N. weapons inspections, let's have sanctions without them. Let's precipitate a crisis that will either undermine the U.N. inspections regime or force the U.S. into retaliating against me, so I can kick the U.N. inspectors out altogether. At least then I'll be able to hold onto the poison gas, Scuds and anthrax weapons that I've been hiding all over the country and that the U.N. is now closing in on."
But that's not the only reason Saddam precipitated a crisis now -- by blocking any further U.N. weapons inspections in Iraq unless the six U.S. members of the inspection team are removed. He also smells where the wind is blowing in the Middle East -- in America's face.
There are powerful magnetic forces that are pulling Iraq out of its isolation. Syria would like to get closer to Iraq in order to counter pressure on Damascus from Turkey and Israel. Egypt would like to see Iraq back in the Arab fold to counter Iran and put more leverage on Israel. The European oil companies, sensing that the U.S. sanctions on Iran are collapsing, want to use this moment to end the blockade of Iraq.
Moreover, precipitating a confrontation between Iraq and the U.S., just before the Middle East economic conference in Doha, Qatar, on Nov. 16, and the Islamic conference in Teheran on Dec. 9, is like a two-for-one sale for Saddam. America's Arab allies are already wary about going to the Doha meeting with Israel, and a fracas between the U.S. and Iraq in the gulf right now would make the Arabs even more wary. At the same time, any U.S. military action in the gulf would embarrass the new Iranian Government in Teheran, which has been probing, ever so delicately, for an improvement in relations with the U.S.
When you add it all up, you can only conclude that if not this week, then next week, if not next month then the month after, Saddam Hussein has powerful reasons to try to push those U.N. inspectors out. Therefore, one of three things is going to happen, and I hope it is the third. The first is that Saddam will now back down, satisfied that he has drawn the attention of the Arab world and the Europeans -- and maybe even won their sympathy -- over the fact that the U.S. intends to keep the sanctions on him whether he misbehaves or not.
The second possibility is that the U.S. will back down and remove its inspectors from the U.N. team, as Saddam is demanding. This would allow the U.N. inspections to continue, but only until the Iraqi leader precipitates another crisis.
The third option is that Washington will call his bluff. But if the U.S. does take military action against Iraq again, it cannot be just to obliterate those sites where he is still hiding weapons -- although that's important. The U.S. has to try to destroy him too. Because the worst of all worlds would be if we destroy his weapons but he survives and throws out the U.N. inspectors. He would then be able to rearm without anyone watching inside Iraq. And he will try to rearm.
Given the nature of world politics today, and given America's feckless allies, the U.S. will get only one good military shot at Saddam before everyone at the U.N. starts tut-tutting and rushing to his defense.
So if and when Saddam pushes beyond the brink, and we get that one good shot, let's make sure it's a head shot.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Some Experts Say Inflation Is Understated

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

 BODY:
An economic report from Washington last week could hardly have brought cheerier news to investors shaken by turmoil in Asia. In spite of brisk economic growth, the Government's most comprehensive measure of inflation rose at the slowest pace since 1964. Strikingly, though, not all the interpretations of the data are sanguine.
Some analysts suggest that the report, covering the third quarter of the year, really amounts to a last hurrah for the inflation-resistant economy that drove the stock market to record highs. "Inflation has been camouflaged by manna from heaven," argued Robert Gordon, a widely respected economist at Northwestern University whose research focuses on the links between growth and prices. 
 Depending on who's talking, everything from a strong dollar and stable health costs to changes in the way the price index is put together have conspired to keep inflation in check. And at least in the view of Mr. Gordon, "onetime factors can't protect price stability much longer."
On first impression, the latest numbers seem guaranteed to smooth the brows of anxious policy makers and investors. Solid gains in exports, business investment and personal consumption powered the American economy to a 3.5 percent annual growth rate in the third quarter, a full percentage point more than mainstream economists have contended is sustainable without creating shortages and bottlenecks in production.
Meanwhile, the price index for domestic output as a whole -- the "deflator" for the gross domestic product -- rose at an annual rate of just 1.4 percent, the lowest in 33 years. And if food and energy (traditionally volatile components of the index) are excluded, prices rose by a mere 1 percent.
This combination of strong growth and stable prices is no surprise to converts to the "new paradigm," people who believe that tightening markets for labor need not cause a wage and price spiral in an era of weak labor unions, productivity-obsessed corporate executives and fierce competition from imports. Indeed, the buzzword on Wall Street is deflation.
Many market analysts, reacting to economic stagnation in Japan, competitive currency devaluations in Southeast Asia and a worldwide glut in manufacturing capacity in autos, petrochemicals and electronics, have decided that inflation is a bugaboo of the past. "We're in a new world of flexible prices" in which markets react quickly and decisively to the gap between supply and demand, concluded Bruce Steinberg, an economist at Merrill Lynch.
Or maybe not. Barry Bosworth, an economist at the Brookings Institution, sees the decline in inflation as "transitory." Profit margins have been exceptionally high, he explains, thanks to unanticipated cost savings and unexpectedly strong sales. But corporations flush with cash have now set their sights on increasing market share, generating a hiatus from upward pressure on prices.
For this pause to endure, output per hour would have to grow at least as rapidly as wages. And while "predictions of a productivity revolution in the making have been around since the 1980's, I don't see any evidence of long-term gains," Mr. Bosworth said.
William Dudley, chief United States economist at Goldman, Sachs, buttresses this view. Medical care consumes one dollar out of eight spent in America. And after a decade of rapid increases, medical insurance premiums have recently been growing at roughly the cost of living, giving business a breather on outlays for fringe benefits.
But the era of stable medical costs "looks like it's ending," Mr. Dudley argued. Profits at health maintenance organizations have fallen through the floor: Aetna and Cigna recently reported losses, while Oxford Health Plans, which had been considered the industry model, just took hundreds of millions of dollars in write-offs. Not surprisingly, health insurers are now hinting broadly at big premium increases down the road.
By the same token, price stability has gotten help from the rising dollar, which discouraged American businesses from raising prices for fear of losing sales to imports. Now, depreciation of the Southeast Asian currencies and a glut in manufacturing capacity in the region could mean more of the same.
But Mr. Dudley suggests that the inflation-tempering impact of deflation in Southeast Asia will be offset by currency appreciation elsewhere. The weakening of the dollar against the yen, mark and pound gives American producers some room to raise prices in markets still dominated by European and Japanese corporations.
While Mr. Bosworth and Mr. Dudley discount signs that the inflation trend is improving, Mr. Gordon of Northwestern has a far grimmer story to tell. For starters, Mr. Gordon estimates that purely technical changes in the way the Bureau of Labor Statistics has assayed prices in the last few years have cut the measured rate of inflation by half a percentage point. This is a onetime change, and thus won't help to dampen measured inflation in the future.
More important, he suggests, the benefits from falling computer prices have been exaggerated. Statisticians have long wrestled with the problem of measuring deflation in this industry, where quality is improving rapidly and new products are frequently introduced. For example if today's basic desktop PC, a 200-megahertz Pentium machine with 2-gigabyte hard drive, 16 megabytes of memory and a super-speed CD-ROM, cost 20 percent less than a 120-megahertz machine with a 486 processor, a 600-megabyte hard drive and 8 megabytes of memory did in 1995, how much has the price of computers declined?
In the past Washington calculated annual price declines of about 10 percent, which many experts considered too low. The latest figures show computer prices falling at nearly 30 percent annually, and Mr. Gordon argues the pendulum has swung the other way. If he is right, a mere return to a long-term trend rate of 15 to 20 percent would show in the price index as an uptick in inflation.
The exhaustion of Mr. Gordon's "manna from heaven" could spell big trouble ahead. Economists generally hold that when unemployment falls below a certain level, competition for workers will begin to push up wages and prices. Mr. Gordon estimates that the combined impact of favorable but temporary factors lowered this level of unemployment consistent with price stability by a full percentage point. Thus, while economists have recently been inclined to believe that 5 percent unemployment is consistent with stable prices, the Gordon analysis implies that the magic number is closer to 6 percent.
There is no evidence that the Federal Reserve has reached the same conclusion. If Mr. Gordon's message does gets through, though, it could bring a pre-emptive strike in the form of an increase in interest rates this winter. And even if the Fed is reluctant to act in the midst of currency and securities market crises in far-flung corners of the world, it will have a fine excuse to tighten monetary policy on the likely news of an uptick in measured inflation in coming months. "Rising medical care costs led to Fed tightening in the late 1980's -- and to the recession of 1990," Mr. Gordon reminds.

GRAPHIC: Graph: "A Different Look at Inflation"
Robert J. Gordon, an economist at Northwestern University, argues that the current measures of inflation are artificially low. His analysis remvoes food and energy, which are volatile, and computers and medical care, which have fallen sharply in recnet years but may not in the future. After making these adjustments and reverting to the Labor Department's pre-1991 metholology on other prices, he finds current annual inflation to be above 3 percent and rising. Graph track the Government's published inflation rate and the adjusted inflation rate, since 1985. (Sources: Robert J. Gordon, Northwestern University; Commerce Department)(pg. D2)

HEADLINE: Orders Rose At Factories In September

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5

 BODY:
Orders placed with manufacturers unexpectedly rose in September for the fourth consecutive month, the Government said today in a report that reflected an expansion of business investment in factories and equipment.
Demand for metals, industrial hardware and high technology led the gain of four-tenths of a percent in factory orders, while demand for aircraft and automobiles retreated from a month earlier, Commerce Department figures showed. In August, orders climbed 1.2 percent, and analysts had been expecting a decline of two-tenths of a percent in September. 
 Factory inventories, a gauge of expected demand, rose two-tenths of a percent in September after rising four-tenths of a percent in August -- the ninth consecutive monthly increase in inventories.
"Firms have accelerated capital spending plans," said Cary Leahey, chief United States economist at High Frequency Economics Ltd. in Valhalla, N.Y. "Capacity growth in manufacturing is increasing."
The Government's data were the latest in a series of reports that reflected economic stamina before the plunge in the stock market Oct. 27 because of financial turmoil in Asia. Although the market has largely recovered, questions persist about whether the Asian crisis could hinder the American economy in coming months.
Some economists warned that the large-scale business investment reflected in today's report could also pose a problem for the economy -- now in the seventh year of the current expansion -- if consumer demand cools in the current fourth quarter and in early 1998.
"That's a classic case in the later stages of a business expansion," said Robert Dederick, an economic consultant at the Northern Trust Company in Chicago. "Business gets all fired up and adds to capacity for demand that never shows up."
Signs have already emerged that consumer spending, the economy's primary engine, is slowing in the aftermath of a surge in the quarter ended Sept. 30, said a former Federal Reserve Board governor, Lyle E. Gramley, an economist at the Mortgage Bankers Association of America.
Over the last two days, for instance, the Big Three auto makers reported that sales fell in October.
September's increase in new orders to a seasonally adjusted $336.475 billion followed a revised 1.2 percent gain in August to $335.040 billion. Previously, the Government estimated August orders rose 1.3 percent, to $335.457 billion.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Securities Rise in Price

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
The prices of Treasury securities snapped a three-day decline yesterday, after the second part of the Government's quarterly refunding of debt showed decent results.
The 30-year bond rose 9/32, to a price of 102 2/32. Its yield, which moves opposite to its price, was down to 6.22 percent, from 6.24 percent on Tuesday. 
 In the quarterly refunding, the Government sold an $11 billion auction of 10-year notes at an average yield of 5.955 percent, down from 6.205 percent in August and the 5.043 percent on Feb. 6, 1996.
Analysts said the demand was solid, but the market still has today's 30-year bond auction to contend with, as well as tomorrow's employment report for October.
At the auction, the bid-to-cover ratio -- the total number of bids compared with the amount of securities being sold -- was 2.24 to 1, which measures up well with the historical average of 2.22 to 1 for the 10-year note. Despite the solid demand, Robert Pugliese, senior vice president and director of the fixed-income department at J. W. Charles Securities Inc. in Boca Raton, Fla., said he did not see much interest from small investors with the yield below 6 percent, "especially with bank certificates of deposit yielding about 6.25 percent."
"Basically," he added, "the Street is paralyzed by the new strain of the Asian flu, whose symptoms are apprehension, confusion and the loss of money. The remedy is a large dose of patience and most people are taking a wait and see attitude in front of the employment number."
Ahead of the auction, hedge funds and foreign investors were buying Treasuries, prompting investors who had made bets that the market would drop further to buy securities to cover their losses. The market was also helped early by comments overnight by the Bank of Japan governor, Yasuo Matsushita, who suggested that a Japanese rate increase was unlikely over the near term. Higher interest rates in Japan would make investments there more attractive.
With the bond market still focused on the recent volatility in world equity markets, economic data pointing to a vibrant United States economy, with low inflation have been largely ignored. But Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management, said the bond market could not get away from economic fundamentals for any sustained period of time.
Yesterday, however, the market largely ignored a report that factory orders in September rose by more than expected, four-tenths of 1 percent, the fourth straight monthly increase. Mr. Fine said, "Factory orders on a trend basis continue to demonstrate buoyancy, which bodes well for fourth-quarter growth." Nonetheless, he said that because of the recent swings in stock prices, he expected the Federal Reserve to keep interest rates steady at the meeting of its policy-making committee next week.
Elsewhere, municipal bonds were little changed yesterday, with the $511.8 million by the Los Angeles County Public Works Financing Authority the largest deal priced yesterday. Underwriters led by Paine Webber priced the debt to yield 4.1 percent for an issue due in 2000, up to a maximum 5.39 percent for a bond due in 2019.

HEADLINE: Charivari: Boutique Blues on West 57th Street

BYLINE: By LISA W. FODERARO 

 BODY:
Jon Weiser, the man who has raised the fashion consciousness of New Yorkers more than a few notches over the years, is holding court in his multilevel store on West 57th Street, a minimalist monument to au courant clothing. "Isn't that Marky Mark?" he asks, peering toward the entrance from a space displaying nubby charcoal jackets for $680. Apparently, it isn't.
Except for a slight paunch, Mr. Weiser exudes the youthful positivism of the good old days. It was a time, not long ago, when Andy Warhol, Jacqueline Onassis and all manner of clotheshorses would venture into one of the Charivari stores to see the latest handiwork of avant-garde designers from Japan to Britain. 
 There's still the occasional celebrity, but these are definitely not good days for Charivari.
The company, which was started by Mr. Weiser's mother, Selma, as a dress boutique on the Upper West Side 30 years ago and grew to encompass six stores and a wholesale business, filed for bankruptcy in late September. In recent years the Charivari presence has shrunk as, one by one, the stores have closed. The flagship store on 57th Street is now the only one left.
But in the more prosperous 80's, it was Charivari's wildly original designs that would make even frumpy, fashion-illiterate New Yorkers stop in their tracks and stare up at the store's soaring glass window displays that seemed to dot the Upper West Side.
"In a quick glance you knew exactly what was happening in a season because they always had the latest of the latest merchandise," said Robert Beauchamp, the former fashion director of Esquire and GQ magazines. "Charivari certainly had an effect on the way New Yorkers dressed and their attitudes toward wearing clothes. It was the first to embrace Japanese fashion and was in the forefront of bringing it to New York City."
So what happened?
According to Mr. Weiser, whose voice becomes weary as he wonders where to begin, everything that could go wrong did go wrong.
"The big mistake is that we never sat down like normal business people and had a 5-year plan or 10-year plan," said Mr. Weiser, who runs the company with his sister, Barbara. "We dealt from our guts and our emotions. Our biggest strengths were merchandising and buying and creating the whole environment. But business is business."
The company, the siblings now realize, opened too many stores on the Upper West Side: there were five within 13 streets of one another at one point. It never opened a shop in SoHo despite the store's ultramodern, downtown sensibility. It also sank profits into expansion rather than create a financial cushion.
When the Weisers opened a store on Madison Avenue at 78th Street in 1992, they located the shop a bit north of the high-fashion hub and also lost control of the costs. As a result, there was not enough money left for promotion. And the shop still took customers away from the 57th Street Charivari.
Nor did it help matters that the store opened after the recession had cast a pall of consumer insecurity over the New York economy. "If I had a magic wand, I would make the Madison Avenue store disappear," Mr. Weiser said. "We were just very, very unlucky there," Ms. Weiser said.
Members of the fashion industry and former Charivari employees say the company was, to a certain extent, a victim of its own success. Charivari was selling clothes by Versace, Dolce & Gabbana, Prada, Yohji Yamamoto and Matsuda well before those designers had their own boutiques in Manhattan.
"Why go to a department store when you can go to Versace's own store?" asked Kurt Fulton, an artist who worked at Charivari in the early 1980's, first as a sales clerk and later as a store manager and buyer. "If you're a label-oriented person, the whole scene is the label and where you bought it."
After Selma Weiser had a stroke in 1990, the Weisers took over the company. The stroke left her unable to participate actively in the business, a blow, since she had been a buffer when her children disagreed.
Mr. Weiser, who is president, and Ms. Weiser, the executive vice president, are trying to pay off their creditors under Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. Three Italian apparel manufacturers had banded together to force Charivari into an involuntary bankruptcy in late August. The company then decided to file voluntarily.
The company has $6.3 million in liabilities and $1.3 million in assets. Most of the $6.3 million is actually owed to the Weisers, who put up their own money to help bail out the business.
As word has spread this year of Charivari's financial problems, some designers have abruptly canceled deliveries. In January, Mr. Weiser spent two days in Milan negotiating a $700,000 men's wear order with Prada, the Italian fashion house. But at the end of February, Prada decided not to fill the order.
"It was the end of the buying season," Mr. Weiser said. "How was I going to replace hundreds of thousands of dollars of merchandise when the season was finished?"
But despite the drumbeat of bad news, he and his sister seem determined to survive. ("I'm convinced the world wants us to exist," Ms. Weiser says.) The first priority is to insure that the 8,000-square-foot store at 16 West 57th Street regains its previous productivity. In the last five years, sales at the store have dropped to $6 million from $8 million.
The Weisers are also talking about expanding, but this time outside New York. They are considering forming a partnership with a fashion designer and opening up one Charivari in each of several large cities in the United States and abroad.
Envisioned, too, are styles that are more accessible and affordable, private-label clothes using the Charivari name that would supplement the designer clothing. Down the road, expect Charivari-brand T-shirts.
"A Charivari T-shirt would be cut differently and have an asymmetrical neckline or whatever," Mr. Weiser said. "We stand for smart design, but I think the stereotype some people have of our clothes is that they can only be worn to a Halloween party."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Jon and Barbara Weiser at their remaining Charivari store on West 57th Street in Manhattan. (Frances Roberts for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: A Touch of College Life, But at $1,900 a Month;
34 Graduates of One Business School Wind Up Living at One Columbus Place

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON 

 BODY:
Steve Audi, a 29-year-old investment banker with a 1997 M.B.A. from the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School, can pound a broom on the ceiling of his Manhattan apartment and communicate with two other 1997 Wharton graduates, who live one floor above him. And he discovered recently that he could speak into the air vent in his kitchen and talk to another classmate from Wharton, Nadine Orosa, whose kitchen is one floor below his. They could chat through the duct work, Mr. Audi suggested, and stay in touch.
Julius Sarkozy -- same Wharton class, same Manhattan apartment complex -- talks to a former Wharton classmate on the telephone in his building. If each of them stands in exactly the right place in their respective living rooms, they can see each other through their windows and wave. 
 New York is full of improbable tales, and surely this is one for the books. Partly by chance and the vicissitudes of a tight housing market, and partly because of the hiring needs of New York City's surging economy, 34 members, or about 5 percent, of last spring's graduating class at Wharton ended up living at One Columbus Place, an apartment building on the Upper West Side near Columbus Circle.
The residents of what they have come to refer to as Wharton House -- or Wharton North or the Wharton Dorm -- are the first to admit that there is something funny about dozens of them living in such close proximity. They are, in certain ways, all alike: a certain shared demeanor, an articulate, polished confidence, an inevitably bullish outlook.
"I get in the elevator in the morning and everybody looks just alike, and I look around and I think, 'That could be me,' " said one Wharton alumnus, Jonathan J. Lawrence, an associate at Houlihan Lokey Howard & Zukin, an investment banking firm.
By day, they surge out in their conservative suits -- hunter-gatherers at the cutting edge of corporate Manhattan. At night and on weekends, they are once again simply young people, single, for the most part, and living in New York City for the first time in their lives.
"It's a nice social base," said Dominic Trader, a Minnesota native who took a job this summer at Goldman Sachs in lower Manhattan. "If you have questions about work or life in New York, it doesn't hurt to be able to walk up one floor, or talk through the vents in the bathroom."
No one planned this. Indeed, more than a few of the Wharton graduates said they recoiled in horror when they began to realize this summer what had happened -- that dozens of students' decisions, reached independently, to rent apartments here might reproduce the dormitory life they had just left. The building, comprising 729 rental units in two connected towers at Ninth Avenue and 59th Street, opened in the spring, just as final exams were ending.
"One group said it would be great to be near each other, another said it would be a bad thing -- that the last thing you need is a little Wharton in New York," Mr. Trader said.
But the timing -- so many apartments available just when they were needed -- was fortuitous, and word of mouth did the rest. Students who came from the Philadelphia campus to look for housing kept returning with the same dismal report, that apartments were scarce and expensive. Other graduates were drawn to the building by its technology -- it is one of the first new residential buildings in Manhattan to provide high-speed Internet service to every apartment. Rents were also fairly reasonable by the standards of the neighborhood, starting at about $1,900 a month for a one-bedroom apartment.
Officials at the Brodsky Organization, which built the complex, said that because of the location, near Lincoln Center, they had expected more tenants involved with the arts, or -- because of the building's technology -- with the so-called New Media industries of the Internet.
Instead, they got graduates from some of the top business schools in the nation. In addition to the Wharton contingent -- by far the largest M.B.A. group in the building -- there are about 20 M.B.A.'s from Harvard's class of 1997 and about 20 from Columbia. Because the Brodsky Organization got Federal housing money to help construct the building, 20 percent of the apartments were reserved for low-income residents.
The economy of New York also played a role. Nearly 30 percent of the 764 students in Wharton's graduating class landed jobs in New York City this year, tying 1994 as the highest percentage since 1990, according to the school. And those jobs were heavily concentrated in just two fields -- consulting and investment banking. That pushed the group together, too.
David Berdon, a strategic technology consultant who grew up Scarsdale and now lives in the complex, said he pops in to watch television with various classmate-neighbors in the building three nights a week or so -- something he couldn't imagine in any other New York apartment building. "And I have found myself more than once in my pajamas and slippers in the elevator going to watch a football game," he said.
But that easy familiarity and constant contact also breeds a kind of hot-house environment, residents say, in which "elevator sightings" -- who is with whom or who brought a new friend home the night before -- become grist for endless rounds of gossip.
"Everybody is in each other's business 24 hours a day," Mr. Berdon said. "It's sort of like freshman year in college: you know everybody's business, who's sleeping where and with whom."
In particular, said some of the dozen or so women in the Wharton group, many of the male classmates took on a kind of brotherly role that wasn't always welcome.
"They ask you where you're going, who are you going out with, when you will be back," said Margaret Pastuszko, a health care industry consultant who was raised mostly in Philadelphia. "It's both reassuring and annoying -- reassuring because there are always people around you who care, annoying because you're trying to get away from home and you can't."

GRAPHIC: Photos: BY DAY -- David Berdon and Jonathan Lewis, former classmates, leave their apartment complex each morning for the corporate world. AT HOME -- They didn't plan it, but 34 former Wharton School classmates are now living in the same apartment complex on the Upper West Side. (Photographs by Norman Y. Lono for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Courage on Trade

 BODY:
President Clinton accurately portrays tomorrow's vote in the House on "fast-track" as crucial to his ability to maintain America's leadership in world trade. A favorable vote would provide him with the authority to negotiate agreements that Congress can reject but not amend. But irresponsible political forces in both parties stand in his way.
Some House Republicans who favor free trade refuse to hand Mr. Clinton a victory without getting something in return, like an agreement to weaken his plan to develop national tests for students. Hostage-taking would be unworthy if it threatened a policy that means so much to America and the world -- not to mention an issue that is wholly consistent with Republican economic principles. 
 But it is Mr. Clinton's Democratic colleagues, led by the minority leader, Richard Gephardt, who are largely responsible for the President's troubles. Many know that fast-track is the right policy but are terrified of political retribution from organized labor. The same protectionist forces that opposed Nafta are engaged in the same fear-mongering argument that trade threatens American jobs. The claim was absurd then and remains absurd today, as is obvious to anyone who notes that the economy is operating near full employment. The purpose of trade is to put fewer workers in low-paid industries, like textiles, and more workers in high-paid ones like aircraft manufacturing. That, along with low prices that flow from foreign competition, makes almost everyone better off.
The opponents also argue that free trade will encourage developing economies to trample on workers' rights, including the right to bargain for better wages, and weaken their environmental laws in order to give their products a competitive boost. But the bill gives Mr. Clinton authority to negotiate sanctions against countries that lower their standards to attract foreign investors or affect trade.
The choice facing the House tomorrow is simple but momentous. It can succumb to needless fears and petty politics. Or, if it can summon up the courage, it can give the President the tools he needs to main American leadership in a global economy.

HEADLINE: Editorial Observer;
And Now, a Few Bracing Notes From the Land of Electoral Reality

BYLINE: By GAIL COLLINS 

 BODY:
The 1997 elections are over, and the American people have delivered a resounding message: Don't touch anything! You might break it! From sea to shining sea, the voters demonstrated their unshakeable determination to keep things exactly the same, right down to Christine Todd Whitman's election margin. The blessings the nation has enjoyed in the Age of Clinton -- plummeting crime, soaring stocks -- seem so inexplicable that the public apparently fears any tinkering, no matter how unrelated, might set the whole structure tumbling. If the fall of the value of the Thai baht could cause the Dow Jones industrial average to teeter precariously, who knew what might happen if Cincinnati said yes to a new elephant house, or the Navajos O.K.'d a casino? Voters looked at referendum options, progressive or reactionary, and came to the same consistent conclusion. Whatever was standing yesterday was good enough for tomorrow, be it assisted-suicide laws in Oregon or affirmative action in Houston or the right to bear arms without safety instruction in Washington. Leave it alone! Go play someplace else!
For those of us who missed voting for Dwight Eisenhower, it was a fascinating moment. So this is what the 1950's were like. No official was marginal enough to toss out and risk angering the gods of prosperity. For the first time since the Tea Party, Boston's Mayor ran unopposed. The Republican Mayor of Waterbury, Conn., got re-elected by a margin as large as Rudolph Giuliani's despite what wire reports called "claims he fathered an illegitimate child and snide suggestions about a recent meeting in a parking lot with a 25-year-old female city worker." "Smut doesn't work! The issues work!" cried the Republican town chairman after the results were in. (The issues, the Mayor said later, were a rising economy and falling crime.) 
 What worked, of course, was the nationwide impulse to let sleeping dogs lie. But inevitably, people who regard politics as something other than a spectator sport required a more expansive lesson, and most of them came up with some variation on the theme of taxpayer revolt. The best example of taxpayer rage, however, was Virginia, where a gubernatorial race centered on automobile taxes drew fewer people than the election of 1985, which was held while a good slice of the state was under water. Meanwhile, over in New Jersey, voters showed their gratitude to the Republican, tax-slashing Governor Whitman by burning her national aspirations at the stake before grudgingly permitting her to leave the office furniture where it is for another four years.
Speaking of national aspirations, Mayor Giuliani, clearly giddy over being the pundits' flavor of the month, delivered a re-election victory speech that was practically an audition for the 2000 Republican Convention. But what will his party make of his dramatic call for a society in which no one was left out or left behind? For voters in the Republican Presidential primaries, inclusion is a concern that resonates even less than automobile taxes. Except for law and order, the Mayor is a disaster on the social issues that drive the nomination process. He is in favor of gun control, gay rights, freedom of choice on abortion and welfare for immigrants. Are the party's Southern fundamentalists ready for a nominee who dressed up in drag and romped around in front of a roomful of cameras as "Rudy/Rudina" at a press club variety show? Although New York City appears very happy to leave private life private these days, Mr. Giuliani remains a politician who celebrates his re-election sans family, whose wife appears at the polls alone and cheerfully vows she will "continue to take good care of the landmark home I'm privileged to live in."
Mr. Giuliani's best chance of moving out of the local arena would seem to be through the U.S. Senate, where the Democrat Daniel Patrick Moynihan might prove an attractive target if he runs for re-election in the year 2000. But where would an urban Republican like Mr. Giuliani fit into the Senate, where his party is the voice of the West and the South, and its fundamental agenda is the moving of resources away from the East and the cities? Anyone who believes that the Republican Party has a real chance of taking root in urban America had only to watch the Mayor deliver his re-election speech from a crowded podium crammed with a careful mix of politicians of every party, gender and race, photo props memorable only for their uncompromising forgettability.
Meanwhile, the Democratic mayoral hopeful Alan Hevesi assured his supporters that the Republican occupation of City Hall was only "a temporary aberration from the norm." Mr. Hevesi was attempting to encourage the faithful, but for the hapless voters in one-party cities around the nation, it sounded more like a threat. He might as well have delivered a few bars of "Nowhere to run to, baby, nowhere to hide."

LENGTH: 1133 words

HEADLINE: Trade Pact Free-for-All: Behind the Hyperbole

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5

 BODY:
Here is what President Clinton and his aides say will happen if Congress fails on Friday to give him new power to negotiate trade agreements around the world:
America's leadership in the world will suffer. The growth of exports -- and the jobs they create -- will slow. Asian and European nations will speed up their invasion of Latin America, this country's economic backyard. Nations will refuse to negotiate with Washington. 
 And today, perhaps desperate to scare up votes that are still eluding him in the House of Representatives, Mr. Clinton even violated the iron-clad White House rule about never predicting Wall Street's reaction to Washington. Passage of the awkwardly named "fast track" legislation, he said, would have "a very positive impact on the stock market here and around the world," a statement that opens up the question of whether the bill's defeat could trigger another global sell-off.
Mr. Clinton's opponents, including many of the Democrats who have been closest to him over the last five years, are equally apocalyptic. Give President Clinton authority to negotiate successors to the Nafta agreement, labor leaders say, and wave goodbye to hundreds of thousands of American jobs. Wages will decline. Air and water pollution will choke the Western Hemisphere.
Could this much really be riding on one tortuously complicated piece of legislation? Especially one that only sets out guidelines for negotiating with other countries? Almost certainly not, the experts all say.
"There has been a lot of hype, as there always is when it comes to the crunch," said I. M. Destler, a professor at the University of Maryland who has chronicled Congress's efforts to set trade policy. "This time, the hype is on all sides."
At the same time, there is little doubt that the vote in the House on Friday will determine a lot about President Clinton's freedom to carry out the centerpiece of his foreign policy -- his drive to open foreign markets, on American terms, in the three years remaining in his term. And at home, it will determine whether Democrats and labor unions and environmentalists will be able to sustain a debate over what America's priorities should be when reaching trade deals abroad.
As in many debates on foreign policy in Congress, much of this is about symbolism. And the Administration is probably close to the truth when it argues that the rest of the world is looking at the fast-track vote as a sign of whether the United States will continue on its path of driving the world to liberalize markets or whether it will back away for fear of the domestic repercussions.
"The growth and stability of the global trading system are predicated on open and expanding global trade," said Robert Hormats, the vice chairman of Goldman Sachs, one of the global companies that have entered the debate in Congress to counter an anti-fast-track campaign led by labor unions. "And if the signal is that the process is going to stop, or be reversed, it would be a bad sign -- not only to other countries, but to every stock market around the world, at a very sensitive time."
The question Congress will be voting on is not whether Washington will stop negotiating trade accords. Mr. Clinton's "fast track authority" -- which gives the President the power to negotiate trade accords, then present them to Congress for a yes-or-no vote -- lapsed more than three years ago. Yet since that time the United States has reached more than 100 trade pacts.
But almost none of those agreements required changes in American laws, so they were never brought to Congress for approval. Most involved one-on-one confrontations with Japan or China or the European Union for market openings, the kind of negotiations that have replaced arms control talks as the theme of diplomacy in the 1990's.
The agenda for trade negotiators over the next few years, however, is more complex. There are a raft of agreements with the nations that make up the World Trade Organization -- over financial services, trade in telecommunications and computer services, and the endlessly hard-fought problems of opening agricultural markets -- that will require Congressional action. And Mr. Clinton knows that his hand is weakened if he cannot guarantee that Congress will not reopen every deal to protect a Boston software house or a huge grain conglomerate.
To his frustration, however, he has been unable to make the case that he should be trusted to strike those accords in a way that helps American workers more than it hurts.
The President's closest aides concede that Mr. Clinton's credibility was hurt by exaggerating the potential benefits of the North American Free Trade Agreement when it was struggling through Congress in 1993. Academics dispute whether the pact hurt American workers, wages and the environment, or whether it actually had a negligible effect. But no one argues it was a blazing success.
So, without Nafta to brag about, the Clinton Administration's strategy has been to elevate the argument over fast track into a question of American leadership.
They have argued that America's economic success is a key element of its power abroad. "For a year now I've been hammering at the same message: trade happens," said Charlene Barshefsky, the United States Trade Representative. "The only question now is who writes the rules. And I say America has never been in a better position to write rules than it is today."
Translating economic clout into diplomatic clout is a hard message to get across, however. And it has been made more difficult by the absence from the fray of Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright, who has given two or three fairly rote speeches on the subject, but has hardly moved it to the top of her agenda.
Labor unions and others warning of fast track's dangers have an easier time making their case. Lori Wallach, who directs the Global Trade Watch operations of Public Citizen, Ralph Nader's organization, has constantly reminded Congress of "President Clinton's bait and switch on worker assistance and environmental programs" to ease any pains caused by Nafta. The Administration concedes many of those efforts were insufficient, but vows to do better this time.
"The real act of courage here," she said, "would be to admit that we need new, forward-looking ways to think about trade that puts the effects on workers ahead of the effects on, say, intellectual property rights."
But negotiations are by definition a two-way process, and success in that redefinition requires a willingness by America's trading partners to allow the United States to insist on changes in minimum wage laws and pollution standards abroad. That is not likely to happen soon and, of course, opens the way for other countries to seek the same here.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Toy Market Sees Green and Purple Holidays

BYLINE: By DANA CANEDY 

 BODY:
That annoying purple dinosaur has teamed up with Bill Gates, that first-time dad, to go interactive. Holiday Barbie has a dye job -- she is a brunette for the first time. And youngsters are bonding in a big way with electronic key chains that need to eat, sleep and study.
An unusually wide range of hot toys is on the market this year, including some updated classics and several newcomers. They are expected to make children's holiday wish lists longer. 
 Action figures tied to blockbuster movies like the rereleased "Star Wars" series and the "Batman and Robin" sequel are already vanishing from store shelves. Plush toys have made a comeback, helped by the popularity of Beanie Babies and last year's hit, Tickle Me Elmo.
"There are a lot of new things happening in the toy business, including the move toward interactivity, which is creating a renewed sense of interest," said Martin Romm, an analyst who follows the toy industry for Credit Suisse First Boston. "There are good basic toys and new components of the industry that capture consumer attention. The outlook is pretty favorable."
To be sure, toy manufacturers and retailers know that shoppers, who are often as fickle as their 2-year-olds, can turn a promising selling season into a loser. But this year, the industry is counting on the broad mix of popular playthings to keep merchants from pinning their hopes on a few standout toys that may be out of stock by Thanksgiving.
And with more for consumers to choose from, toy merchants hope to do better than the measly profits that have marred some previous fourth quarters, when they do more than half their business. That would also help reduce the number of costly post-holiday markdowns of duds.
Factor in the favorable economy and the stock market gains for most of the year -- recent market gyrations notwithstanding -- and toy makers and sellers are cautiously optimistic that this year's holiday sales will top last year's.
The Toy Manufacturers of America, which measures the value of toys shipped, said it expects to exceed last year's $14.5 billion by at least 5 percent. David Miller, president of the trade group, said if toy retailers' sales kept up their performance so far this year, the gain would be higher.
Michael Goldstein, the chief executive of Toys "R" Us, said, "This is the first year in several years that we have had a lot of hot items for Christmas." Parents are already lining up for Holiday Barbie, from Mattel Inc., and the newly interactive Barney, from the Microsoft Corporation.
The 16-inch stuffed Barney moves its arms and legs, croons 17 songs and plays games like peek-a-boo. But at $100, it is not cheap. For $65 more, buyers get a transmitter that allows interactive Barney to interact with Barney television episodes or videotapes. Additional software and videos can push the price higher.
"One concern is the price point," said Jim Silver, publisher of the Toy Book, an industry publication. "If you buy all of the pieces with it, you can end up spending $250, and that's not the type of item everyone can afford."
Despite the price, Mr. Goldstein said, "My prediction is it will be sold out by mid-December."
Of course, toy stores are selling as many stuffed animals that tickle, wiggle and giggle as they can, hoping to re-create last year's Elmo frenzy. One popular item featuring an Elmo pal, Sing and Snore Ernie, from Tyco Toys Inc., already has parents scouring toy stores.
"It started with many parents remembering last year's Tickle Me Elmo," said Kelly Disque, a spokeswoman for F.A.O. Schwarz, which has endured a run on the items. "Parents are trying to get in early to beat the rush."
High technology is also on the hot list. Anyone who has not heard of cyberpets must be living in a virtual world. Parents want to kill the things. Teachers have banned them from classrooms. And a company in Massachusetts is even offering free day care for them.
The cyberpets, which live in plastic eggs and cost about $15 each, are Tamagotchi, manufactured by the Bandai Company Ltd.; Giga Pets, made by Tiger Electronics, and Nano Pets, made by Playmates Toys. The creatures require almost as much care as the youngsters who cannot seem to get enough of them. Their owners must feed them, administer medicine if they are sick and clean up after them to keep them from going belly up.
The appeal of the less than warm and fuzzy devices? "There is the instinct to nurture," Mr. Miller said. "And while a round computer chip is not a nurturing device itself, it is an intellectual kind of nurturing. It's a nice marriage of technology and the 20th-century version of hugging."
The craze is such that Bandai has installed a pause feature on the pets to keep them from creating deadbeat parents out of youths whose devices die while they are in math class.
As for Holiday Barbie, which sells for about $35, consumers apparently like her new do. "The Holiday Barbie sells every year, and I think they just wanted to do something different," Mr. Silver said. "In the first weekend they sold over 100,000 pieces alone, and that was over a month ago."
Movie tie-ins continue to be big business.
"Hasbro is doing very well behind our three big movie properties of the year, 'Star Wars,' 'Jurassic Park: The Lost World' and 'Batman,' " said Tom McGrath, a spokesman for Hasbro Inc. "In particular, 'Star Wars' is red hot."
Part of the reason is the appeal to parents who watched the movies years ago and want action figures as collectibles, while their children simply want to play with them.
Not all toy categories are hot. Board games remain a tough sell. And radio-controlled cars are not big this time around. "I think some of the higher-priced vehicles are not as strong," Mr. McGrath said. "They are losing ground to the CD-ROM or hot movie property-type purchases."
Even the early favorites have a down side. Mr. Romm of First Boston pointed out that the industry could be hurt by short supplies of popular toys.
"The issue has always been for the toy companies making sure they have the good products in ample supply at the time consumers need them," he said. "That's clearly an important aspect which really puts a lot of pressure on toy manufacturers for on-time delivery, because it is a very narrow window in which they have to operate."

HEADLINE: Metro Matters;
Sharpton And Coalitions Old and New

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT 

 BODY:
ALMOST from the beginning, Ruth W. Messinger was stuck between a rock and Al Sharpton.
To many white and particularly Jewish voters, Mr. Sharpton represents evil in a jogging suit. In their minds, he will be -- possibly forever -- the incendiary champion of Tawana Brawley and the man who labeled a Jewish store owner in Harlem a "white interloper." 
 To many black voters, on the other hand, Mr. Sharpton is a man who gives voice to the voiceless. In their eyes, he has grown and matured as a politician, and has earned the right to be taken seriously.
Obliged during the campaign to choose between spurning Mr. Sharpton, embracing him or trying to play at some coy combination of the two, Ms. Messinger opened wide her arms. By the last days of the race, she appeared all over the city in his company, frequently posed with him for the cameras and even printed palm cards featuring his endorsement.
Mr. Sharpton says he has no illusions about why she made the decision she did.
"Ruth always said she wanted my enthusiastic support," he explained in an Election Day interview in his former campaign office on Eighth Avenue. "In fact, she called me at home one night during the court battles over the runoff and said, 'You know we need to work together.' Some people on my side had mixed feelings, some people on her side had mixed feelings. People say, well, there are some Jewish voters who don't like Sharpton. But she was polling badly in the Jewish community anyway."
"It wasn't like she was here," he continued, raising his hand to the level of his forehead to represent her standing in the polls, "and if I got involved she was here," he said, dropping his hand to his waist. "She was here anyway. So the question was could I help pump her up on the other side?"
After two mayoral elections that were more or less explicitly about race -- Dinkins v. Giuliani I and Dinkins v. Giuliani II -- this year's mayoral campaign may have seemed blessedly to be about something else: crime and the quality of life, according to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, education and unemployment, according to Ms. Messinger.
But the results demonstrate that New York City politics, even when ostensibly focused on other issues, is still very much a matter of black and white. If you were white, according to exit polls, you were almost four times more likely to vote for Mr. Giuliani than for Ms. Messinger. If you were black, the figures were reversed.
Though she is a woman, Ms. Messinger got only 45 percent of women's votes, and though she is Jewish, she got only a quarter of the Jewish vote. By contrast, she received almost four-fifths of the black vote.
The results confirm on a city level what political analysts at the national level have said since the days of George S. McGovern: that the old urban alliance between white ethnic and black voters has given way to an almost reflexive antagonism.
Whether Ms. Messinger's choice to embrace Mr. Sharpton contributed to her defeat or prevented an even worse rout on Tuesday is tough to gauge. But almost certainly her choice and his conduct have raised Mr. Sharpton's standing in a party where even the short now stand tall.
GIVEN that Mr. Giuliani delivered his victory speech with several erstwhile Democratic stalwarts craning their necks to get into the picture, Mr. Sharpton can -- justifiably -- present himself as a virtual pillar of party loyalty.
"Now I am in an unusual position," he said, "of looking at some of my liberal critics and saying: 'What happened to certain union leaders and what happened to certain leading Democrats? You call me opportunistic?' I mean some guys and ladies that I absolutely thought would be out there with their unions and all I saw in photos with the Mayor. It wasn't Al Sharpton that was missing."
Mr. Sharpton said he believed those who deserted the Democratic party should be punished -- an ironic turn for someone who has rarely been accused of being a team player. And he argues that his loyalty -- and, more significantly, the loyalty of black voters -- means that he can expect to play a larger role in the party in the future, if not as a candidate, then as a broker.
"The Senate race is next year, the Governor's race is next year, and we're going to have our say," he said. "And we should. We've been the ones who have been loyal to the party. Should I now have to ask somebody who was either missing in action or on the other side, 'Can I come in the room?' I don't think so."
