HEADLINE: THE 1997 ELECTIONS: THE TREND;
With Big Issues Absent, The Little Things Count

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

 BODY:
Forget the post-mortems about ideological shifts, Republican revivals or which candidate had the most money. The legacy of the off, off-year elections on Tuesday may simply be this: Think small.
The issues that ultimately drove this week's elections for governor -- automobile insurance rates in New Jersey and a state car tax in Virginia -- had never before been in the forefront of those states' politics. That they became such central concerns, according to surveys of voters leaving the polls, underscores two realities about the current state of American politics: Voters are relatively content, so elections these days are not turning on huge issues like unemployment. That has left room for issues that were seldom talked about even a few months before the election to rise to the top of the political discourse. 
 The success of narrow pocketbook issues is a nod to the strategy perfected by President Clinton in last year's election, when he seized on small but powerfully symbolic issues like school uniforms. It also reflects the waning of ideology in today's politics; it is a time when both parties are struggling to come up with defining issues.
"If the economy were in trouble, I don't think we'd see these issues nearly as dominant as they were on Tuesday," said former Representative Vin Weber of Minnesota, a prominent conservative. "The population is pretty happy right now; people can afford to be concerned with secondary issues."
Advisers to James S. Gilmore 3d, the Republican who was elected Governor of Virginia, said they believe he won by an unexpectedly large margin over Lieut. Gov. Donald S. Beyer Jr. because he effectively seized on an issue that was potent with many Virginians: He vowed to eliminate the state's unpopular annual tax on cars and trucks.
In New Jersey, advisers to Gov. Christine Todd Whitman said State Senator James E. McGreevey, her Democratic rival, came so close to ousting the popular incumbent because he also found an issue that incensed ordinary voters: the state's high automobile insurance rates.
Politicians and strategists around the country, Republicans and Democrats alike, said in interviews yesterday that if the economy held and there were no other burning new issues, the hunt for the small-bore issues might become a hallmark of next year's races for Congress and governor.
"You have to pick a particular burr under the saddle," said Gov. Howard Dean of Vermont, chairman of the Democratic Governors Association. "And I think Gilmore and McGreevey did it very effectively."
Mr. Dean said he would advise Democratic candidates next year to look for issues that touch voters.
"It will be different in different states," he said. "It could be hog farm regulations in Iowa, tort reform in Alabama and the Confederate flag in South Carolina."
Gov. Tommy G. Thompson of Wisconsin, a Republican who is up for re-election next year, agreed that the victory of Mr. Gilmore in particular was "a lesson for all Republicans."
"You've got to make the issues understandable," Mr. Thompson said, "so they can be internalized. A family could understand that if they voted for Gilmore they were going to get a reduction in their taxes on the car. People could internalize that."
Another attraction of these narrower issues is that they have a populist cast and can be easily understood by voters. And they meet the needs of politicians who, in these days of fiscal austerity, do not dare propose high-cost measures.
That there were hard-fought races over issues that had not been on the radar screen in Virginia and New Jersey also underscores a relative contentment among voters with the status quo. In both states, the exit polls found, voters were overwhelmingly satisfied with the state of the economy. And despite Mrs. Whitman's close call, the bottom line is that in New Jersey and Virginia and in Staten Island's special election for the House of Representatives, Republicans retained the seats.
In New Jersey, the exit polls showed, nearly nine of 10 voters said the issue of automobile insurance was important in making their choice for governor. And Mr. McGreevey won the votes of three out of four voters who said the high cost of auto insurance was the No. 1 issue. In an interview on her campaign bus the week before the election, Mrs. Whitman, said, "If there was something I could do differently, that I would go back and revisit, it was how we decided to address auto insurance at the very beginning."
In Virginia, there was no specific question about the car tax. But 83 percent of voters said taxes in general was the most important issue.
J. Brad Coker, president of Mason-Dixon Political/Media Research, which conducted polls in Virginia and New Jersey, said his research suggested that Mr. Gilmore would have had a tighter race had he not emphasized the car tax, and that Mr. McGreevey would not have been able to mount such a competitive race without the auto insurance issue.
Next year, Mr. Coker said, "you'll see a lot of digging and scratching for gimmicks that work with the average person. It should be a good year for focus group research."
John McLaughlin, a pollster for Mr. Gilmore, warned that candidates should not be too quick to seize on a taxation issue as a silver-bullet.
"They really have to be careful," Mr. McLaughlin said. "It really has to be something that benefits people. People have to feel you're sincere, and it has to touch people in their daily lives."
An example was last year's Presidential campaign, when Bob Dole's across-the-board tax cut proposal was not taken seriously by many voters because, polls showed, they feared it would be unaffordable.
The automobile insurance and car tax issues were not the only factors driving the voting in New Jersey and Virginia. In Virginia, Mr. Gilmore's election also seemed to be an endorsement of his Republican predecessor, George F. Allen, who was prohibited by law from seeking consecutive terms.
In New Jersey, another reason for Mrs. Whitman's close call was that many conservatives abandoned her for rejecting their issues. Most notably, Mrs. Whitman's veto of a ban on a type of late-term abortion helped drive up support for a third-party, anti-abortion contender.
"You don't stick a hot poker in the eye of your base," said Scott Reed, Mr. Dole's campaign manager last year.
Given her bare victory, many Republican politicians yesterday spoke less of Mrs. Whitman as a future Presidential contender. One after another, they said they saw her instead as a future member of the Cabinet in a Republican Administration.
But former Senator Bill Bradley, a New Jersey Democrat who was wounded politically after he was almost upset by Mrs. Whitman in 1990, asserted in an interview before Election Day that the size of a winner's margin was not so important.
"I always believe if you win by one point, you're still the champion," said Mr. Bradley, who once played with the New York Knicks. "That's the way it was in basketball. That's the way it is in politics."

HEADLINE: THE 1997 ELECTIONS: THE PARTIES;
Evolving From Ideology Toward Pragmatism

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

 BODY:
The decisive re-election of a Republican mayor in a Democratic city on Tuesday was, for all its breadth and drama, something short of a sudden transformation of New York City's politics. Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's election was more the culmination of a slow evolution that began 20 years ago: a triumph of nuts-and-bolts pragmatism over the ideology and party loyalty that once ruled elections in New York.
Mr. Giuliani was the first Republican to be re-elected Mayor since Fiorello H. La Guardia in 1937. He defeated Ruth W. Messinger, his Democratic challenger, by 16 percentage points, accruing margins that cut a swath across the city's electoral base. And he did it against a candidate whose history personified, almost to the point of caricature, the old-style liberal whom Mr. Giuliani blamed for many of New York's problems. 
 But for all that, Democratic and Republican analysts and elected officials said yesterday, it would be a mistake to view the election simply as the latest sign of the decline of the Democratic Party, or as evidence that New York is not as left-leaning as its reputation. If anything, Mr. Giuliani's election signaled something more subtle and potentially a lot more profound: that New York mayoral politics is moving away from ideology altogether.
Today, it is performance and pragmatism, more than ideas and party affiliation, that matter most in mayoral elections, analysts said. The shift became pronounced when Edward I. Koch took office almost 20 years ago. Even before that, though, other Democratic mayors were often less ideological than they pretended, notably the practical Robert F. Wagner, who ran the city from 1954 to 1965. And it was, after all, La Guardia himself, Mr. Giuliani's hero, who once declared that there is no Democratic or Republican way to pick up the garbage.
The trend has now been brought to fruition by Mr. Giuliani, who grasped and expanded on Mr. Koch's success. And based on conversations with Democratic consultants who are already preparing for the mayoral race in 2001, the next wave of candidates will likely try to position themselves more as managers than as party ideologues.
"It's the breakdown of old party lines," said Roy M. Goodman, the veteran Republican State Senator from Manhattan, reflecting a widely held view yesterday. "Performance counts. It's potentially a shift of tectonic consequences."
Mr. Giuliani, to judge him by his actions these last few years, is a Republican in party only. He is a Republican (and a former Democrat) who surrounded himself with Democrats at every opportunity during his campaign. He ran on the Liberal Party line. He endorsed a Democratic Governor, Mario M. Cuomo, three years ago and went to Washington to lobby on behalf of a crime bill pressed by a Democratic President. He attacked Republicans again on Election Night for trying to curb the rights of legal immigrants.
Further, while some political analysts have argued that the Messinger campaign represented the last gasp of liberalism in the city, that interpretation may miss the real point of the mayoral campaign. Jim Andrews, who was Ms. Messinger's senior campaign consultant, contended that Mr. Giuliani in effect co-opted liberalism, testimony to his growing political sophistication.
When Mr. Giuliani first ran for Mayor in 1989, David N. Dinkins undercut him by reminding voters that his Republican opponent had once opposed abortion rights, and by recalling his service to a Republican President, Ronald Reagan. By this election, Mr. Giuliani had established himself as firmly in favor of abortion rights, for gun control, sympathetic to immigrants and even, in the last weeks of the campaign, in favor of domestic partnership benefits for gay couples, a position that is quite far afield from conventional Republican doctrine.
As a result, Judith Hope, the chairwoman of the State Democratic Party, was hard-pressed yesterday to offer political distinctions between Mr. Giuliani and another politician who has always run extremely well in New York, President Clinton, a Democrat. "I think they're both part of a new generation of politicians who are seen as problem-solvers first and partisan operatives second," Ms. Hope said.
There is, of course, a partisan element to Mr. Giuliani's success in redefining the way elections are waged in the city. His aggressive efforts to reduce crime and welfare have already forced Democrats to alter their positions to account for the popularity of Mr. Giuliani's achievements.
Still, Mr. Giuliani made certain that the election turned on a debate over, in effect, how well he had run the store. Despite Ms. Messinger's best efforts, the discussion focused on issues that do not necessarily have liberal and conservative sides: Are the streets safer? Is the city more prosperous? Is its government more efficient?
And while some may be tempted to view Mr. Giuliani's re-election as heralding a major shift toward the political center in New York, that does not appear to be borne out by the facts.
Surveys of voters leaving the polls Tuesday and after the previous two mayoral races show no sign that New Yorkers are changing appreciably. People who called themselves Republicans made up 19 percent of the electorate on Tuesday, compared with 17 percent four years ago. Democrats made up 61 percent, up from 59 percent four years ago. Even as Mr. Giuliani won re-election, New Yorkers were solidly returning to office a Democratic comptroller, Alan G. Hevesi, and a Democratic public advocate, Mark Green.
This new emphasis on performance in government -- and the push for smaller government -- has been to the disadvantage of Democrats in general, and Ms. Messinger in particular. Although Ms. Messinger tried to distance herself from her political roots during the campaign, throughout her career she was closely identified as a liberal advocate of activist government.
Manfred Ohrenstein, a Manhattan Democrat and the former minority leader of the State Senate, argued yesterday that this image was the single most profound problem facing the Democratic Party today.
"The election returns of 1993, 1996, and 1997 obviously show that the Democratic Party in this state at this point has not shown people that we can manage the government," he said. "And that's what we need to do. We have to convince the public that we are serious about managing four items: crime, quality of life, fiscal management and economic development. None of these issues are Democratic or Republican."

HEADLINE: THE 1997 ELECTIONS: THE MAYOR;
GIULIANI CREDITS MINORITY VOTERS FOR WIDE MARGIN

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY 

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani turned his attention yesterday to his second term, beginning the process of revamping his cabinet and claiming a broad mandate from New Yorkers, including increased support from many black and Hispanic neighborhoods that shunned him four years ago.
Mr. Giuliani, who on Tuesday became the second Republican in 60 years to win a second term as the city's mayor, made a campaign-style lap around the city during the day to thank voters in a voice still raspy from his final stumping of the race. At a news conference at a predominantly black church school in Queens, he sought to cast the election in historic terms, contending that his improved showing among minority residents was a sign of the breadth of his victory. 
 "The fact is the change in the minority vote created a difference between a narrow victory and a very large one," Mr. Giuliani said. "And I am very appreciative of that." The Mayor received 20 percent of the black vote, according to interviews with voters, compared with 5 percent in 1993.
While the Mayor eagerly offered his assessment of the election, he gave little hint of how he wanted to translate such strong backing into policies for the next four years, hewing to his strategy during the campaign of focusing more on his accomplishments than his plans.
The Mayor did say he was taking the first steps toward putting together a new administration, explaining that he was formally seeking the resignations of most of his commissioners. He exempted the five commissioners whom he said he was definitely keeping on, declaring that they had done outstanding work: Police Commissioner Howard Safir, Fire Commissioner Thomas Von Essen, Sanitation Commissioner John J. Doherty, Correction Commissioner Michael P. Jacobson and the Commissioner of Investigation, Edward J. Kuriansky.
Mr. Giuliani said he expected that he would eventually reappoint most of his department heads after evaluating each agency's record, but his announcement added to the swirl of speculation surrounding the shape of a new Giuliani administration.
Most of the questions focused on Mr. Giuliani's four deputy mayors, whose resignation he did not request but whose performance he is reviewing.
One question is whether Fran Reiter will rejoin the administration after stepping down as Deputy Mayor for Economic Development to run Mr. Giuliani's campaign.
Her successor, Randy L. Levine, originally said he would work for the Mayor for only a year because he wanted to return to his job as chief labor negotiator for Major League Baseball, but Mr. Levine has not indicated in recent weeks whether he still intends to leave.
The Mayor's senior aides said he had not reached any decisions on his staff and probably would not do so for several weeks. And after a virtually unbroken week of barnstorming across the city and a heavy schedule throughout the campaign, some aides wondered whether their tireless boss would finally take a vacation.
When asked about that possibility at the news conference, Mr. Giuliani joked, "You want to get rid of me, huh?"
Mr. Giuliani seemed clearly pleased by the final results of Tuesday's election, which showed that the Mayor had won 57 percent of the vote, to 41 percent for the Democratic candidate, Ruth W. Messinger, the Manhattan Borough President. The Mayor won every borough but the Bronx.
Turnout, though, was among the lowest for any mayoral election in recent decades, with 38 percent of the registered voters casting ballots.
Besides taking 20 percent of the black vote, Mr. Giuliani received 43 percent of the Hispanic vote, up from 37 percent in 1993, according to exit polls. His share of the white vote was 76 percent, compared with 77 percent in 1993, the polls said.
While Mr. Giuliani hailed his improved showing in black and Hispanic neighborhoods, an analysis of the voting shows that his base of support was similar to what it was in 1993. He received a greater percentage of the black and Hispanic vote, but the increase in the actual black vote was less marked because black turnout dropped significantly from 1993.
He attributed his failure to win a majority of black and Hispanic votes, as well as Ms. Messinger's success in the Bronx, to "traditional voting patterns," saying that people in an overwhelmingly Democratic city were accustomed to voting for Democratic candidates.
"This city has a very, very strong historical pattern of voting," he said. "And we haven't changed that, but we have made it much more competitive."
He added that though the turnout was low, he believed that the final tally reflected the overall views of the people. "I don't think the result in the election would have been much different" if every registered voter had cast a ballot, he said.
The parochial school that Mr. Giuliani visited was the Allen Christian School in St. Albans, Queens, which was founded by the Rev. Floyd H. Flake, a Democratic Congressman who was one of Mr. Giuliani's most prominent black supporters during the campaign.
In an indication of Mr. Giuliani's burgeoning national standing, Mr. Giuliani said at the news conference that he had received congratulatory calls from two Republicans who are considering running for President in 2000, Jack Kemp and Dan Quayle. And yesterday afternoon, Mr. Giuliani taped a skit for David Letterman's "Late Show."
Mr. Giuliani also spoke about the election in light of his predecessors, noting that his margin of victory was just below that of the last Mayor to be re-elected as a Republican, one of his idols, Fiorello H. La Guardia. He contended that he was relieved that he had not beaten La Guardia's record.
"I am kind of happy about that because his picture stands behind me and I don't want him to get angry at me," Mr. Giuliani said. "He's given me a lot of good advice."

HEADLINE: THE 1997 ELECTIONS: Man in The News -- Vito John Fossella Jr.;
City Hall To Capitol

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5

 BODY:
Within 24 hours after voters had transformed him from an obscure city councilman to the newest member of Congress, Vito J. Fossella Jr. had received three standing ovations from fellow House Republicans, been sworn in by Speaker Newt Gingrich and voted to overhaul the Internal Revenue Service.
Mr. Fossella's resounding victory on Tuesday over a Democrat who was seen as a formidable opponent landed the 32-year-old Staten Islander squarely on the national political stage. His election, aided by more than $1 million in assistance from the national Republican Party, was celebrated by G.O.P. leaders not only as a sign of the party's appeal, but as a harbinger of victories in next year's midterm elections. 
 "I want to be able to hit the ground running," Mr. Fossella said early this morning on a sunrise flight to Washington. "I feel a certain eagerness to get things in place, to begin doing the work I was elected to do."
Few would have predicted such a role three years ago when Mr. Fossella, then a 29-year-old lawyer who had worked in the mayoral campaign of Rudolph W. Giuliani, won a special election to fill the Council seat of Alfred C. Cerullo 3d, who was appointed to a job in the Giuliani administration.
Conservative on a host of issues, from abortion to affirmative action, Mr. Fossella was one of just a handful of Republicans on the Council and seemed decidedly out of step with his colleagues in the heavily Democratic body.
There were few, if any, who considered him a contender for much in New York City politics beyond his Council position -- representing one of the city's most conservative bastions -- or for a position within Staten Island.
But that was before May, when Susan Molinari announced she was resigning the Congressional seat that had been in the Molinari family since 1981 to take a position as an anchorwoman on a CBS television program.
Championed by his primary political benefactor, Guy V. Molinari, the Borough President, Mr. Fossella mounted an impressive campaign against the Democrat, Eric N. Vitaliano, a 15-year Assemblyman, ultimately winning nearly two-thirds of the vote. Besides Staten Island, the district includes the Brooklyn neighborhoods of Bay Ridge and Bensonhurst.
In his three years on the Council, Mr. Fossella developed a reputation as a hard worker and an avid student of legislation, although he was not among the body's most outspoken members.
"He's smart, and he took the job very seriously," said Kenneth K. Fisher, a Democratic City Councilman from Brooklyn, "He's articulate, practical and a little judgmental. He hasn't identified himself with many larger issues that I can think of, except for the landfill."
Indeed, it was a bill introduced in the Council by Mr. Fossella to close the Fresh Kills Landfill, a 3,000-acre garbage dump on Staten Island, that provided him with his highest visibility.
"He got a lot of points on Staten Island for introducing the bill to close the dump," said Councilman Jerome X. O'Donovan, a Staten Island Democrat.
But Mr. O'Donovan, like many Democrats, questioned how independent Mr. Fossella would be of Mr. Molinari -- the Borough President refers to Mr. Fossella as a son -- and predicted that the new Congressman would likely be "pretty much another soldier in Newt's army."
Mr. Fossella shrugged off such criticism with a laugh. "Guy is a strong fighter for Staten Island, and I have a good working relationship with him," Mr. Fossella said. "Does that mean that I can't be independent? Of course not. When I have disagreements with him, or whenever I might have disagreements with the Speaker, I'm not afraid to state it publicly. But the fact is that very often we do agree."
In addition to his ties to Mr. Molinari, the new Congressman was a political protege of the late Michael J. Petrides, a member of the city's School Board and a Staten Island political strategist. It was Mr. Petrides who led Mr. Fossella to join the 1992 re-election campaign of Representative Molinari and, the following year, the mayoral campaign of Mr. Giuliani.
Vito John Fossella Jr. was born on March 9, 1965, in Staten Island and grew up in the comfortable, middle-class South Beach section. His father is a former city official who became a successful construction engineer, and his mother is a florist. Mr. Fossella, the fourth of seven children, was a basketball player at Monsignor Farrell High School, where he got his first taste of politics in the student council.
He attended Iona College in New Rochelle, then transferred to the University of Pennsylvania, where he earned a degree in economics in 1987. He worked as a management consultant with Deloitte & Touche, the accounting firm, then went to law school at Fordham.
In 1990 he married Mary Patricia Rowan, a second vice president at Chase Manhattan Bank. They have a 2-year-old son, Dylan, and are expecting their second child, whose due date was Election Day.
Politics has been something of a family pastime for Mr. Fossella. His father served in various appointed positions in the city administrations of Mayors Edward I. Koch and Abraham D. Beame, and his uncle, Frank Fossella, was a City Councilman for four years, until he was defeated by Ms. Molinari in 1985. Mr. Fossella's great-grandfather James A. O'Leary represented Staten Island in Congress, from 1936 until his death in 1944.
Still, Mr. Fossella broke with tradition by becoming the family's first Republican. "It happened when I was 25 and, even though I was a Democrat, I found myself voting more and more for Republicans," he said. "For the most part, my family reacted well. But still, I would love to have been a fly on the wall."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The newest United States Representative, Vito J. Fossella Jr., was joined yesterday by his wife, Mary Patricia, and House Speaker Newt Gingrich at the Capitol Hill Club in Washington before Mr. Fossella was sworn in. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times)

SECTION: Section B; Page 5; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

HEADLINE: THE 1997 ELECTIONS: THE SUBURBS;
Contrasts for Democrats Are Stark in 2 Counties

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT 

 BODY:
In the traditional Republican bastions of New York City's suburbs, Tuesday night's election tallies signaled stark contrasts in Democratic fortunes: a stunning victory in Westchester but crushing losses in Nassau.
Exuberant Democrats in Westchester were celebrating Andrew J. Spano's lopsided victory for the top prize of county executive, which he won by a margin of about 17 percentage points over his Republican opponent. They also made gains in the county's Board of Legislators. 
 But glum Democrats in Nassau County were licking their political wounds, having been swamped in their countywide races by ratios of more than 2 to 1 and having suffered the defeat of several Democratic incumbents in local posts.
"Westchester is a Democratic county now," said a campaign consultant, Hank Morris, "but Nassau is still rock-solid Republican."
For years, Democrats had been making inroads in both counties, but in different ways.
Westchester's Democrats had been gaining as changing demographics gradually tipped the county's voter enrollment in their favor until they now lead Republicans by 44,000 registered voters. But that underlying political shift had been masked as popular Republican incumbents like County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke continued to hold sway.
Nassau's dynamic was different. With Republicans holding a 3-to-2 enrollment edge, the Democrats made only modest headway picking up new voters. But through pluck and luck, they had managed to score victories at the polls to the point where they now hold 43 local offices, up from 17 in 1990.
The Nassau Democrats succeeded despite facing what is considered the toughest local Republican organization in the nation, the Nassau County Republican Committee, with its legendary party discipline, fund-raising capacity and fine-tuned field operation, complete with its own printing plant.
But on Tuesday, everything changed.
In Westchester, with Mr. O'Rourke retiring as County Executive, the Democrats capitalized on their new majority by electing Mr. Spano to succeed him.
But in Nassau County, it was the Republican organization that -- like a sleeping giant -- roared back to life. County Executive Thomas S. Gulotta rolled to a landslide re-election over his Democratic opponent, Lewis J. Yevoli, winning by 67 percent to 31 percent, and Mr. Gulotta's running mates did almost as well.
The Nassau Republicans ousted several Democratic incumbents, including a city councilman in Glen Cove, two North Hempstead Town Board members and a county legislator. They also won the Oyster Bay supervisor's post, from which Mr. Yevoli is retiring, and a vacant State Senate seat.
Nassau and Westchester are major political entities in statewide politics, and they have special symbolism to the current Republican hierarchy. Nassau is the home of Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, and Westchester is home to Gov. George E. Pataki.
"The campaign to retake the Governor's office has begun in Westchester County," said the state's Democratic chairwoman, Judith Hope, after Mr. Spano won.
Westchester differs from Nassau, said Mr. Morris, the campaign consultant, because it has more urban pockets where Democrats have built more of an organization, and because it has more swing voters.
Recalling the Republican heyday in Westchester, Alfred B. DelBello, the only other Democrat ever to have won the county executive's post there, said that "when I came in," the Republicans had 50,000 more voters than the Democrats. His election was considered an anomaly.
But the Republicans have hardly conceded Westchester. The county party, headed by State Senator Nicholas A. Spano, who is no relation to Andrew, is still a major force. Several of its incumbents ran well on Tuesday, including District Attorney Jeanine F. Pirro, who was re-elected by a wide margin.
"What's happening is that sooner or later, the Democrats are taking over, but the Republicans still outspend them like mad," said Andrew A. Beveridge, a sociology professor at Queens College and a former Democratic leader in Westchester.
In both Nassau and Westchester Counties, personalities, issues, tactics, money and infighting all played roles in Tuesday's results.
The campaign of Andrew Spano's Republican opponent, Ted Dunn, never caught on with the voters. Mr. Dunn is the Mayor of Rye, but his patrician image as a Harvard graduate and retired millionaire from Wall Street did not seem to appeal to working-class Republicans or Democrats.
Although Mr. Dunn spent large sums of his own money, his negative television commercials drew criticism as being distorted, and they apparently backfired. The ads were prepared by Arthur Finklestein, a frequent consultant to conservative Republicans.
Another Republican consultant, Michael R. Edelman, said it was a mistake to use "slash and burn negative politics" in the suburbs. He said, "You can't, in an area that is so sophisticated and becoming more Democratic, present a politician who comes across as just being another mean Republican."
In Nassau, Mr. Gulotta, the County Executive, raised nearly $4 million and apparently spent it well, flooding homes with television commercials and mail. Mr. Yevoli raised only about $200,000.
Mr. Gulotta may have been unbeatable to begin with. As an entrenched incumbent based in Hempstead Town, which has a majority of Nassau County's population, he has cultivated countless civic groups over the years.
Four years ago, after big deficits and tax increases, Mr. Gulotta had a hard-fought re-election challenge. But this time, everything seemed to fall his way: an improved economy, more stable county finances, reduced crime, declining welfare rolls and rising employment.
Despite Mr. Yevoli's reputation as a tough underdog, he apparently failed to get his message across in the news media.
"If the old Lew Yevoli, the scrappy, energetic, tireless Lew, had waged this campaign," Mr. Morris said, "he would have given them a hell of a fight. Unfortunately, he retired before the election."

HEADLINE: THE 1997 ELECTIONS: THE GOVERNOR;
Whitman Pleased at Victory In New Jersey, However Slim

BYLINE: By JENNIFER PRESTON 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Nov. 5

 BODY:
Gov. Christine Todd Whitman put the bravest and most optimistic face possible on her narrow victory today, saying that the election that almost ended her political career was, in fact, a triumph.
Her portrayal was clearly rendered with an eye to keeping her national standing in the Republican Party and maintaining her ability to lead the Republican-controlled Legislature in her second term. Both have been damaged by her near-defeat, political analysts said. 
 The first sign that Mrs. Whitman may face difficulties with the state's Republican legislative leaders came just two hours after she described her re-election as an affirmation of her record and the national Republican Party's tax-cutting agenda. And it came on the very issue that nearly vaulted Mrs. Whitman's Democratic opponent, State Senator James E. McGreevey, into the State House: the high cost of automobile insurance in the state.
The Senate President, Donald T. DiFrancesco, a Republican, said he did not plan to push through Mrs. Whitman's proposal to reduce auto insurance rates, which she had promoted throughout her campaign. He said that he was not opposed to her plan, but that he wanted to look at other options, including a proposal that Speaker Jack Collins of the Assembly, a Republican, is working on.
Nor did Mr. DiFrancesco promise swift action by lawmakers, saying that he did not know whether legislation to reduce rates would be approved during the lame-duck legislative session later this year. "We could or we may not," he said.
At the town hall in Woodbridge, where he is Mayor, Mr. McGreevey said he intended to keep the pressure on Mrs. Whitman and the Legislature to reduce auto insurance premiums. He also said that he would "most probably" seek the Democratic gubernatorial nomination four years from now. Page B4.
Although Mr. McGreevey was a virtual unknown in the state when he began this year's race for governor, he came within a percentage point of toppling Mrs. Whitman on Tuesday. With nearly 100 percent of the precincts counted today, Mrs. Whitman led by about 27,000 votes in the unofficial tabulation. She had 1,126,727 votes to Mr. McGreevey's 1,099,321. Murray Sabrin, a Libertarian candidate, had 113,836 votes, and all others had 65,338.
But Mrs. Whitman, using her own arithmetic, said today that she did not view the margin as a one-percentage-point victory. She noted that she is the only New Jersey Republican to win a statewide race since 1985. She also pointed out that Republicans make up only 20 percent of the state's registered voters and that President Clinton won the state by 17 percentage points last year.
"I am just extraordinarily pleased with what we did, that we turned around a 17-point plurality by Bill Clinton last year to a one point plurality for this administration, which is an 18-point shift," she said.
Mrs. Whitman said that she was not troubled that 53 percent of the electorate cast votes for her opponents. "I find it very rewarding that I am standing here as Governor-elect," she said. "It's only the people who don't understand the state of New Jersey that would think there would be some huge mandate. Would every governor seeking re-election love to be carried into office on the shoulders of an adoring electorate? Of course, you would. But that's not reality; that's not what happens. And it certainly doesn't happen in a state like this. This is a significant victory."
She also dismissed questions about whether the close contest may have tarnished her image as a national Republican leader and her future political prospects. "I don't care," she said. "I only care about the state of New Jersey. That's all I ever have cared about."
Each of Mrs. Whitman's three statewide races has been close. She defeated Governor Florio in 1993 by the same 1 percent margin that she achieved over Mr. McGreevey on Tuesday. In 1990, despite being outspent by a margin of more than 10 to 1, she narrowly lost a challenge to Senator Bill Bradley by 3 percentage points, wounding Mr. Bradley's national standing. When she was asked today if Mr. McGreevey may have done to her what she did to Mr. Bradley, she responded, "Gee, not at all."
Cliff Zukin, a veteran pollster and political science professor at Rutgers University, said that Mrs. Whitman's national standing, along with her power over the Legislature, was most definitely diminished by her poor showing at the polls on Tuesday. "People are going to take her less seriously," he said.
Mr. Zukin also offered another view of Mrs. Whitman's arithmetic. "The same forces that gave Bill Clinton a 17-point win should have given her a 17-point win: popular incumbent, chief executive, good economy, low unemployment, crime going down," he said.
Both Democratic and Republican national party leaders invested heavily in the New Jersey governor's race, hoping to help set the stage for Congressional and gubernatorial contests next year. The race was also closely watched by conservative leaders in the Republican Party, who disagree with Mrs. Whitman's support for abortion rights and viewed her struggle to win re-election as vindication that their beliefs are the direction in which the party should be moving rather than toward Mrs. Whitman's brand of moderate Republican politics.
But Mrs. Whitman said that the party was big enough to accommodate Republicans with varying views on abortion. "That's an important message for some people," she said. "But it's not the only issue on which people go to the booths and vote." She noted that prominent Republicans, like the former Vice President, Dan Quayle, who oppose abortion rights, campaigned on her behalf. She said that "sends a message that this party is bigger than that."
"We agree on 90 percent of the things and this party is bigger," Mrs. Whitman said.
Gov. Terry E. Branstad of Iowa, who is the chairman of the Republican Governors' Association, stood at Mrs. Whitman's side today to emphasize his point that her victory illustrated voters' approval of the Republican approach to government. He said that Republican victories in gubernatorial races in New Jersey and Virginia four years ago were a "precursor of the tidal wave victory we had across America in 1994."
"The Democrats wanted to turn that around in this election, and that's why they put in so much effort in here," Mr. Branstad said. "Despite that, your outstanding Governor won re-election."
Today, Mrs. Whitman did not offer any specifics on what areas would be her focus in a second term, beyond the issues of auto insurance and high property tax rates, which also dominated Mr. McGreevey's campaign. She said that she would look to reduce property taxes by encouraging the state's municipalities to consider sharing more services and programs. On auto insurance, she vowed that she would keep her promise in this campaign to make sure that rates are reduced for drivers.
Even though her own party will continue to dominate the Legislature, after beating back a vigorous challenge by Democrats, she may have difficulty winning approval for any plan that limits lawsuits arising from car accidents. About a quarter of the state's lawmakers are also lawyers. The New Jersey chapter of the Association of Trial Lawyers of America contributed more than $350,000 to incumbent legislators in this fall's campaign.
She said that she was not wedded to her proposal, and planned to meet with legislative leaders next week to discuss whatever options they may have to bring down rates. Mrs. Whitman spent much of today taking phone calls from well-wishers and giving television and radio interviews.
By contrast, four years ago, Mrs. Whitman arrived at the State House on the morning after she defeated Gov. Jim Florio to announce that she was beginning work immediately on keeping her campaign promise to cut state income tax rates.
Mrs. Whitman said that she would outline her agenda for her second term in January, when she unveils her budget and makes her inaugural address and annual speech to the Legislature. She said that she did not know whether she would make any changes in her cabinet, but that she had appointed a transition team to help shape her administration.
Since New Jersey does not allow governors to serve more than two successive terms, she was asked how she felt about being a lame-duck governor.
"People better be a little careful of this lame duck," she said with a broad smile. "She's got four years to quack."

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Trizec Hahn Adds An Office Building

BYLINE: BY CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
The Trizec Hahn Corporation, the Canadian real estate company, announced yesterday that it had purchased a 35-story office building in the garment district for $59 million.
The 605,000-square-foot property at 1065 Avenue of the Americas, at 40th Street, is Trizec Hahn's fifth commercial property acquisition in the metropolitan region since January. Trizec Hahn, like several other publicly traded real estate companies, has been on a shopping spree in the New York region in the expectation of a spike in office rental rates after a long recession in the market. 
 "Trizec Hahn continues to acquire well-located assets in improving markets," said Gregory C. Wilkins, the president of the company.
The company also closed yesterday on its $159 million purchase of Newport Tower, a one-million-square-foot office building on the waterfront in Jersey City, from The Limited Inc. and the Georgetown Company. With the latest deals, the company would own six towers in the New York region with a total of five million square feet of office space.
Trizec Hahn also is a bidder for the landmark Chrysler Building.

HEADLINE: Market Place: Red-Hot Revival in Real Estate;
Overheating Is Feared With Surge in Vulture Investing

BYLINE: By LESLIE EATON 

 BODY:
In the world of professional real estate investing, no one is flying higher than Wall Street's vulture funds, which in the early 1990's swooped in to buy distressed properties whose values have since soared as the economy has recovered.
And no one is feeling more on top of the world than Blackstone Group. In five years, it has raised millions of dollars to buy real estate, produced eye-popping returns of more than 50 percent a year and snagged prominent properties including Worldwide Plaza, the office tower that occupies a block of Eighth Avenue at 50th Street in Manhattan. 
 Indeed, Blackstone has been so successful that big investors are flocking to the firm, which plans to announce today that it has closed a $1.1 billion real estate investment fund. With that much money at its disposal, Blackstone, which jokingly calls itself a stealth investor because of its low public profile in real estate, joins the ranks of Wall Street giants like Goldman, Sachs, Morgan Stanley and Colony Capital.
But for all of these firms, the air is increasingly turbulent. The rebound in almost all kinds of real estate, all over the country, means that there is far less carrion for the vultures to devour. Meanwhile, there is more competition for properties; money has been pouring into real estate investing, both through the private funds and through the public property companies called real estate investment trusts, or REIT's.
All of which is prompting some market watchers to worry that real estate may overheat even faster than is traditional in what has long been a boom and bust business. Although the funds are a relatively small force in the trillion-dollar American real estate market, they are a potent one, often serving as the catalyst that prompts other investors to move into a particular region or kind of investment.
The recovery in real estate is forcing the funds to adopt new strategies in their efforts to sustain the 20 percent or more annual returns their investors have come to expect. Not only are the funds branching out into operating companies, luxury hotels and movie theaters, they are also venturing even farther afield by starting to develop new projects from scratch. And the vultures are gaining a taste for everything from escargot to enchiladas as they search the globe for their traditional fare -- properties (or property owners) with problems.
"The way the business is moving now, you really have to learn to surf the wave," said Stephen A. Schwarzman, president of Blackstone.
He and other fund managers say their strategies have constantly been evolving to take advantage of new opportunities (which is why the funds now refer to themselves as opportunistic investors or opportunity funds, rather than vulgar vultures).
In the last year or so, "the nature of the investing has changed quite a bit, but it also changed in 1993 and 1995," said Owen D. Thomas, who heads the real estate funds at Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter, Discover & Company. "In the early days, it was mostly distressed debt, then it evolved into more of a pure real estate strategy, and more recently it has moved to operating companies and development."
To be sure, the fund operators say that they are well aware of the cyclical nature of real estate and agree, sometimes reluctantly, that investors must scale back their expectations for profits. And even though they are developing vacant land and building new projects, the funds assert, they will avoid the excesses that led to disaster in the late 1980's.
"Because we all remember what overbuilding did, we are carefully monitoring supply and demand," said Daniel M. Neidich, chairman of the investment committee of Goldman, Sachs's Whitehall real estate funds. "The money available for development today is much more focused and cautious than in the late 80's."
The funds also argue that they seldom compete directly against the REIT's, which tend to prefer the safest and most stable properties. (Shares of REIT's, which are like real estate mutual funds for small investors, are generally traded on stock exchanges.)
"REIT's will buy everything that's chocolate or vanilla, but they can't digest rocky road," said Thomas J. Barrack, chairman of Colony Capital. One of his firm's strategies is to buy properties with problems, fix them up, and then, he said, "sell them to the REIT's at phenomenal numbers."
There is evidence that the funds are still managing to find bargains, at least compared with other kinds of investors. The vultures spent $2.8 billion on big office buildings in the first three quarters of this year, and bought space for an average of $94 a square foot, according to John Lyons, the head of Granite Partners, a New York investment and research firm. REIT's, which spent $17 billion, paid $126 a square foot.
Still, funds are now paying far more for buildings than offices fetched just a few years ago. And a decade ago, when values were similar to today's levels, according to the data from the National Council of Real Estate Investment Fiduciaries, American real estate was heading for disaster.
"If you were to carbon-date the American problem, it would probably be in 1985 and 1986," recalled Richard N. Gunthel, senior managing director of Bankers Trust/Alex. Brown, a unit of Bankers Trust New York that both advises clients about distressed real estate and buys on its own account. "It seemed to Northeasterners that it was a regional dust-up in the oil patch, but that influenza spread through the country in a counterclockwise direction."
Much of the most speculative property ended up in the hands of the savings and loans that had financed it; once they went bust, the mortgages moved to the Resolution Trust Corporation, the Government body charged with clearing up the mess.
That is where Wall Street first came in. Investment bankers started buying Resolution Trust loans in bulk for relatively little money, breaking up the blocks, restructuring the loans and selling them off. "Wholesale to retail -- it was a lovely game while it lasted," said Jeffrey W. Baker, senior director of Cushman & Wakefield, the big real estate firm controlled by the Mitsubishi Estate Company.
Pension funds were attracted by the returns Wall Street was getting, but that was not the only reason they favored the funds that investment banks started to raise. State and corporate retirement plans had traditionally bought buildings directly, or through managers who were paid no matter how successful, or unsuccessful, the investment turned out to be. For many retirement plans, this strategy has been a bomb.
But Wall Street set up its real estate funds the same way it structured funds that bought stocks or private companies. The investment banks had to put up some of their own money -- so they were at risk, too -- and they hit pay dirt only if the investment was very successful. (They typically take 20 percent of the profit off the top and a pro rata share of the fund's gains.) So the interests of the managers and the investors are aligned, as they say in the investment business.
More recently, the huge run-up in the stock market -- and its recent volatility -- have also helped fuel pension funds' interest in real estate funds. "What's driving it is some concerns about the valuations of financial assets," said Kurt H. Smith, director of real estate consulting for the Frank Russell Company, which advises pension plans.
But the amount of money moving into the funds and into real estate in general is making Mr. Smith and advisers like him a little cautious. "There's a risk with so much money flowing in," he said, adding that he was keeping an eye out for the return of "ego-driven trophy buyers."
Certainly, a lot of money has come into the funds, money they must spend fairly fast. The Institutional Real Estate Letter reported this summer that eight funds were trying to raise $2.5 billion from investors, and, all told, opportunity funds had $8.5 billion on hand, which, with borrowing, would allow them to buy $34 billion of property; that is more than the $29.8 billion of office building purchases in the first nine months of this year.
What kind of property? Luxury hotels have become popular of late; Blackstone recently bought four Swissotels, including the Drake on Park Avenue in midtown Manhattan, while Colony owns both the Stanhope, at Fifth Avenue and 81st Street, and a stake in the company that runs the exotic Aman resorts in the Far East.
Suburban office buildings have fallen out of favor, but towers in downtowns remain attractive, especially if they have some sort of financial or operating problem, like outdated facilities or big vacancies.
Investing in all kinds of real estate companies is a common theme. In the past the companies were usually in trouble, but today they may be healthy concerns looking to expand or to set up joint ventures with the funds to buy property.
Colony has probably gone farthest afield in terms of the kinds of investments it makes. "We concentrate a lot on businesses that use real estate, not just on real estate businesses," Mr. Barrack said, explaining why his firm bought a chain of movie theaters in England, a race track in California, and a stake in some duty-free shops in airports.
The lean-and-mean mantra echoing through corporate America is also providing purchases for the funds, as companies concentrating on their core missions decide to stop fooling around with real estate investments. Morgan Stanley, for example, recently picked up a development called the Woodlands from Mitchell Energy.
A few more funds are even venturing into new development, where both Goldman, Sachs and Morgan Stanley have been active for some time. Together, they own Playa Vista, a planned community that is supposed to go up on the site of the old Howard Hughes airport, where the Spruce Goose was built (Dreamworks SKG, the new movie studio owned by Steven Spielberg, Jeffrey Katzenberg and David Geffen, is supposed to put its headquarters there). Colony is building a golf-course community for soon-to-be-senior citizens near Las Vegas, Nev., while Bankers Trust is financing a development of Western-style housing in Shanghai.
International investing is where many of the funds are pinning their hopes, even though, as Mr. Gunthel of Bankers Trust notes, a number of American firms that have tried it have failed. But others have succeeded; Blackstone, for example, this year bought Descartes Tower outside Paris, which is I.B.M.'s European headquarters. Latin America is proving popular, and funds have just started dipping their toes into the deeply troubled real estate market in Japan, where Goldman, Sachs recently bought a loan portfolio from a bank.
And just when all the easy pickings seemed to be disappearing, new opportunities may be about to open up from an unexpected quarter. The recent financial problems in the countries of Southeast Asia, particularly in Thailand and Malaysia, look likely to provide the vultures with some of their traditional fare.
"There haven't been any transactions yet, because everybody's trying to figure out the laws in the countries," reports John Coppedge, a senior managing director of Cushman & Wakefield in Hong Kong. "But I think it's going to happen."

HEADLINE: ART REVIEW;
Fluffing Up Warhol: Where Art and Fashion Intersect

BYLINE: By HOLLAND COTTER

 BODY:
Andy Warhol, who died in 1987, remains one of the most provocative American artists of the postwar years. It is almost impossible not to have complicated feelings about him -- as a cultural figure he was as repellent as he was attractive -- but his influence on contemporary art and thinking has been immense and continues to grow.
Unfortunately, little sense of this importance is conveyed in "The Warhol Look/Glamour Style Fashion," the tame, patchy exhibition that opens tomorrow at the Whitney Museum of American Art. Far from distilling this artist's heady but caustic essence, the show offers a dose of Warhol Lite, a blandly celebratory view of his work that feels a little too much of a piece with the art world's recent and uncritical alliance with the fashion industry itself. 
Organized by the Andy Warhol Museum in Pittsburgh under the curatorial eye of Mark Francis and Margery King, the show claims a two-fold agenda. First, it sets out to examine the role that fashion and concepts of glamour played in shaping Andy Warhol's art. Second, it seeks to demonstrate how his art, in its turn, shaped and continues to shape fashion today.
To anyone with even a glancing familiarity with Warhol's work, neither thesis is much in need of demonstration. The artist began his career as a successful fashion illustrator in the 1950's. In the 1960's his personal style -- the silver hair, the sunglasses, the James Dean leather jacket -- had as great a public presence as his art. In the 70's, he was an integral part of New York's haute couture inner circle, presided over by tutelary deities like Diana Vreeland and Halston. (Warhol painted Halston's portrait; Halston used Warhol's paintings of flowers in his fabric patterns.)
This story has often been told, and "The Warhol Look" adds little to it but a plethora of incidental details. This is far less a show of art, in fact, than of cultural ephemera. For each of the handful of Warhol paintings included, there are dozens of magazines, snapshots, souvenirs and personal relics, most of them from the Warhol Museum.
The use of such material is always fraught with problems. It can often be illuminating when assigned to footnote status (as in the Whitney's recent Keith Haring show) and even essential when used to flesh out the career of an artist working in impermanent media (as in the current retrospective of the performance artist Jack Smith at P.S. 1 in Long Island City, Queens). But in this case, its overwhelming presence tends to make Warhol's output look thin and predictable, which wasn't the case.
The show's archeological bias declares itself from the start in a row of simulated department store windows in front of the Whitney's third-floor elevator. Two are re-creations of windows Warhol designed for Bonwit Teller in 1955 and 1961 (in the second of them he used his early Pop paintings as props). A third is a version of a Barneys New York display assembled by Simon Doonan in 1989 as a tribute to Warhol the compulsive shopper, and it has a welter of Barbie dolls, cookie jars, vintage porn magazines and designer-label shopping bags that Mr. Doonan gathered from flea markets. It has been meticulously reconstituted here.
In fact, few items in any of the Whitney re-creations actually belonged to Warhol. (The paintings in the Bonwit window are 1980's copies by the artist Mike Bidlo.) Maybe that's why the results have the slightly seedy, denatured air of ethnological displays. Yet even the wealth of authentic Warholiana that lies further on in the show has a similar feel, as if it were far removed from the artist's touch, transformed into the cool, systematic data of textbook history.
The problem is evident in the first gallery, labeled "Hollywood Glamour." There is, of course, absolutely no question of the formative, enduring, devotional role this ideal played in Warhol's life and art; his painted portraits of stars are camp versions of religious icons, with the mix of reverence and amused affection that implies. But little sense of that passion comes across in the dutiful lineup of items here.
Warhol's adolescent scrapbook of fan club photos is on hand, as is his vast collection of publicity shots of Marilyn Monroe and Elizabeth Taylor, carefully arranged on the walls, and a couple of examples of the great Liz and Marilyn paintings from the early 60's hang nearby. But nothing gives off much heat, and the central placement of a 1991 Gianni Versace dress, which uses Warhol's Marilyn face, brings the temperature down even further, reducing Warhol's effect on fashion to a triviality.
The gallery documenting Warhol in the 50's is equally uneventful, with a selection of his elegant drawings and mock-ups of women's shoes surrounding a dummy dressed in a beige suit that he had custom-made for himself in Hong Kong in 1956. The point, for what it is worth, seems to be that when Warhol was drawing like a dandy, he was also dressing like a dandy.
The selection from the Factory era of the 60's has more bite, mainly because this was Warhol's most inventive period. The art he was making was extraordinary (though almost none of it is here), as was the persona he fashioned for himself, part waiflike E.T., part rough-trade punk. Judging from the show, these years, in which he established himself as an artist and filmmaker, saw his most innovative involvement with commercial fashion, and the handful of items here (a dress stamped Fragile Handle With Care; a blouse with an S & H Green Stamps pattern) give some idea of the fascinatingly perverse things he was up to.
It is in the next section, though, devoted to the theme of cross-dressing and the cosmetic refashioning of the body, that the show finally flickers to life. The material isn't exactly new, but it covers a span of 30 years and offers a focused take on the fluid nature of sexual identity, an issue crucial to understanding Warhol himself and fashion as a cultural phenomenon. The work ranges from drawings of drag queens made by Warhol in the 1950's to film and video clips of several of his gender-bending superstars, including Candy Darling, Holly Woodlawn and Jackie Curtis (seen in a hilariously raucous clip from "Women in Revolt"). It also includes a striking painting from his 1975 series "Ladies and Gentlemen," which was done in the format of Warhol's commissioned celebrity portraits but depicts black and Latino transvestites.
In the painting on view, pigment has been trowled onto the silk-screened face like a thick layer of makeup, echoing the alterations that Warhol was constantly making to his own features. For years he wore wigs to cover his baldness (several are on view here), but they were only the most obvious evidence of his lifelong experiments with changing his appearance and his sexual identity.
In a photo taken by a friend around 1952, he has worked over his own profile with pen and ink to reduce the size of his nose (he later had plastic surgery), and the same corrective process is the subject of his famed 1962 painting "Before and After," which hangs in the gallery. Polaroid self-portraits from 1981 show the artist posed in an array of Marilyn- and Liz-style wigs. And in a vitrine, one finds a sampling of the contents of the artist's bathroom shelves: a jumble of moisturizers, skin medications, hair removers, perfumes and makeup.
The words emblazoned on the gallery wall, "Drag and Transformation," could have been -- and probably should have been -- the title for the entire show. The idea of sexual mutability, with its implications of self-transcendence, is implicit in virtually everything else on view, and it helps define Warhol's most radical and subversive role, that of a homosexual artist who -- daringly for his time -- took the visual codes and attitudes of a gay subculture and recast them as mainstream art.
Exactly how that recasting took place within the context of early postwar culture and what its consequences have been are matters of considerable interest, and scholars are just beginning to address them head-on. (The art historian Kenneth E. Silver published a seminal essay in 1993; Hilton Als contributes a good one to this show's catalogue.)
In the 1970's, Warhol took heat both from the women's movement and from the gay liberation movement as a reactionary figure, one whose art perpetuated gender stereotypes and economic elitism. These accusations have since been rethought (without being resolved), but they can still be usefully brought to bear on any consideration of fashion itself.
One rarely hears such reservations raised in the art world today, however, and that's too bad. The current alliance between art and fashion bears every mark of being a marriage of economic convenience rather than one of shared sensibilities. The commercial art world, still feeling vulnerable and adrift in an uncertain time, gets support from a robust consumer industry; that profession, in its turn, picks up a little rubbed-off cultural luster. It's an exchange that should leave everyone feeling more than a little embarrassed.
Warhol, for his part, seems to have approached fashion, as he did every other aspect of his life, with ambivalence, from the position of a rapt insider who was also, at heart, an outsider, enthralled but unfooled. For this reason, among others, he is an artist whose career rewards close and repeated scrutiny. "The Warhol Look/Glamour Style Fashion" certainly has material on hand for such a project, and there's definitely a show inside this one screaming to get out. Maybe the Warhol Museum will go for it in the future, with a little more daring and a lot more art.
"The Warhol Look/Glamour Style Fashion" opens tomorrow at the Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street, and remains on view through Jan. 18. Its presentation in New York, sponsored by Bloomberg News, is accompanied by "Fashion and Film," a film and video presentation organized by Matthew Yokobosky, associate curator of film and video at the Whitney, through Jan. 11. The Warhol show will travel to the Art Gallery of Toronto (Feb. 16-May 3), the Barbican Art Gallery in London (May 28-Aug. 16), the Musee de la Mode in Marseilles (fall 1998) and the Museum of Contemporary Art in Sydney (winter 1998).

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Falls Against Pound On Surprise British Rate Rise

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News

 BODY:
The dollar tumbled against the British pound yesterday after the Bank of England surprised financial markets by raising interest rates.
The central bank had been expected to keep rates steady this month, given the recent turmoil on world markets, including London's. But the bank held to its anti-inflation policy, raising its benchmark base lending rate to 7.25 percent, the fifth rate rise this year and the base rate's highest level in five years. Britain's big commercial banks followed suit, raising their base lending rates. 
 The rise in borrowing costs comes after the Chancellor of the Exchequer, Gordon Brown, indicated last week that preparing Britain for eventual membership in a European single currency might involve lowering the current 2.5 percent inflation target. That would imply tighter monetary policy.
Mr. Brown told Parliament last week that there was no realistic prospect of Britain's joining the monetary union in the current Parliament, which could run until 2002. His announcement was attacked by business organizations, many of whose members want Britain to join the single currency soon to remove the sort of currency fluctuations that have hit exporters this year.
"It's clearly a very aggressive anti-inflation stance the bank has adopted," said David Coleman, chief economist at CIBC Wood Gundy. "This will give reason for doubt as to whether this is the last rate rise."
Indeed, expectations that the Bank of England would raise rates again spurred buying of pounds.
"The feeling is that the Bank of England may use this as a platform for many more hikes in the future," said Russ LaScala, manager of spot currency trading at Citibank. "This is a good buy zone for sterling."
Higher interest rates help the pound by making deposits and bonds denominated in it more appealing to global investors.
The pound rose above $1.69 before settling in New York trading at $1.6895, up from $1.6827 on Wednesday, and its highest level since July.
The dollar got a lift against the mark after a report showed new orders to German manufacturers unexpectedly fell 1.8 percent in September from August. The dollar traded in New York at 1.7234 marks, up from 1.7165 marks.
The dollar was little changed against the yen as concern that trade tension might arise outweighed expectations that Japan's economy was not performing well enough to prompt the Bank of Japan to raise interest rates any time soon. The dollar settled at 123.03 yen, down slight from Wednesday's six-month high of 123.07 yen.
In other trading, the Korean won fell sharply against the dollar amid concern over the country's ailing financial industry and as traders fretted that the authorities might soon abandon efforts to defend the currency.
"We see extreme pressure on that currency," said Peter Cera, an analyst with the State Street Bank in Boston. "We've seen a lot of selling. Their banking sector is very, very weak and we're in a situation where they may be running low on reserves. It's like going to the limit on your credit card."

SECTION: Section D; Page 8; Column 4; Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Asia Drop Sends Shivers Through Builders

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK

 BODY:
Engineering and construction companies the world over salivated when Southeast Asia planned some of the world's tallest skyscrapers, the world's longest building, an Asian Silicon Valley, mega-scale dams, dozens of power plants, thousands of miles of roads and numerous refineries, railroads, water systems and airports.
But with Asian financial markets in turmoil and economic growth slowing, projects are being canceled or postponed, and construction companies are seeing one of their most promising markets shrivel. 
 A typical victim is the Fluor Corporation, which announced on Monday that its earnings would be well below expectations, in part because the Asian turmoil was making customers more cautious.
"I think 20 to 30 percent of the projects that are on the drawing board will be stretched out," said Ralph DiSibio, senior vice president of the Parsons Corporation, a privately held company in Pasadena, Calif.
Gary Prendergast, an executive partner at Black & Veatch in Kansas City, Mo., agreed. "There is going to be some pain," he said.
Just how much pain, though, is open to question. It is not clear just how bad things are in Southeast Asia, where governments are still wrestling with which projects to kill.
Most construction executives say they view the problems as transitory. They plan no layoffs, though they may slow hiring in Asia.
Stocks of construction companies have been hurt, although sometimes other problems contributed. Shares of Fluor, which has internal problems, fell more than 9 percent on Monday alone and now trade at half their 12-month high. Shares of the Foster Wheeler Corporation have fallen to about $32 from a 12-month high of $48.125, and Chicago Bridge and Iron is at $16, down from $23.625.
Other companies could be hurt as well, including those that build and own power plants, like the Southern Company of Atlanta or Edison Mission Energy, a subsidiary of Edison International, the Los Angeles-area utility. One such company, the AES Corporation, has said it will shift its focus from China to Eastern Europe and Latin America.
Southeast Asia was perhaps the fastest-growing market for builders of power plants, airports, roads, rails and water systems. The World Bank once estimated that Asia would need to spend up to $2 trillion on these projects over the decade beginning in 1995.
Still, each company's exposure is not overwhelming. Fluor says that 20 percent of its backlog is in the Asia-Pacific region. The Bechtel Group, which rivals Fluor as the largest American construction company, counts about 15 percent of its business there. But the Jacobs Engineering Group has little business in Asia.
So far, non-American companies have taken the biggest hit. Hopewell Holdings, controlled by Gordon Wu of Hong Kong, took a $647 million charge against earnings after the collapse of a $3.2 billion mass-transit project in Thailand.
ABB, based in Switzerland, took a $100 million charge after it lost the contract for the Bakun Dam hydroelectric power project in Malaysia, the largest project in the company's history. Nevertheless, ABB said last month that it planned retrenchments in Europe and would focus on the Asian market.
Malaysia also delayed an airport, a highway and the KL Linear City, a 1.2-mile-long building, billed as the world's longest, that would have been built over a river in Kuala Lumpur.
Indonesia postponed 14 power plants indefinitely and put 9 others under review. It also delayed two oil refineries, 29 toll roads and a bridge. Among the delayed Indonesian projects was a $525 million gas-fired plant that would be partly owned by the Enron Corporation of Houston. Among the partners in other postponed projects are Duke Energy, California Energy, Morrison-Knudsen and Unocal.
Most companies were reluctant to discuss what projects they were bidding on and which were canceled or delayed. But it appears that scuttling of projects already under way is not the big issue -- it is delays or cancellations of future projects.
"We have not seen an impact on our current activities," said James O. Rollans, senior vice president of Fluor, based in Irvine, Calif.
Fluor officials also contend that many projects are for private providers, not for governments, and will thus be insulated from some shocks. Perhaps Fluor's biggest project in the region is a $1.2 billion contract to build a power plant in Indonesia for Edison Mission Energy.
But even private projects could suffer in a downturn. The power plants sell to state-owned utilities, and Indonesia is expected to try to lower the tariff it pays for electricity. Edward R. Muller, president of Mission Energy, said his company had had no such contact from the Indonesian Government.
The Bechtel Group, based in San Francisco, had a petrochemical project in Thailand canceled and was actively bidding to become the contractor on one of the postponed Indonesian projects, industry executives say. Jennifer Gee, spokeswoman for Bechtel Asia-Pacific, said the company, which is privately held, did not comment on such matters but was still committed to Asia.
Many of Bechtel's projects are in the Philippines, where it is building the nation's first independently owned power plant and several office towers, and owns part of the Manila water utility.
Not everyone thinks the damage will be so bad. "I just came from a construction industry presidents' forum and I didn't hear a lot of discussion about it," said Richard Beumer, chairman and chief executive of the Sverdrup Corporation, a privately held concern based in St. Louis.
Ernest Bower, president of the U.S.-Asean Business Council, said the turmoil might have a silver lining -- promoting privatization of projects and development of capital markets in Southeast Asia. Both would be good for American companies in the long run, he said.
Survivors might also find competition diminished. A slowdown "will get a lot of people who frankly shouldn't be in the business out of the business," Mr. Muller of Mission Energy said.
Many executives said that Asian nations would find a way to finance the projects because they were essential for further economic growth and because their people were demanding better life styles.
"Those genies are out of the bottle," Mr. DiSibio of Parsons said. "They aren't going to go back." He also said China's market would "dwarf all that's happening in the Far East today."
Michael S. Dudas, an analyst with UBS Securities in New York, said that "Asia exposure is manageable" for global companies. With stock prices dropping so much, he recommends shares of Foster Wheeler and Chicago Bridge and Iron.
But Tobias M. Levkovich of Smith Barney Inc., who downgraded all the stocks in the group on Sept. 4, said: "We're not ready to step in yet. The market is pretty fluid."

HEADLINE: Companies Reported Spending More on Research

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
Pushing to develop new products, or new twists on old ones, American companies increased their spending on research to $118.65 billion last year, 9 percent more than in 1995, the National Science Foundation reported yesterday. Another big jump is projected for this year as companies seek to sustain sales by offering something new to consumers.
But while companies spent more from their own pockets, the Federal subsidies they received for research fell slightly, to $20.9 billion, as they have almost every year in this decade. And while corporate outlays to develop new products took a big jump, spending on basic research has held steady at $5.5 billion to $6.5 billion a year through the 1990's, the science foundation said. As a percent of the total, it declined in 1996. 
 For 1997, the science foundation projected $130.6 billion in corporate outlays for research and development, a 10 percent rise, while the Federal research subsidy, a victim of budget cutting, is expected to fall slightly, to $20.8 billion.
Basic research is a weak link in this picture. Some economists argue that without more spending on basic research, new-product development will eventually suffer. The foundation defines basic research as an attempt to gain more comprehensive scientific knowledge "without specific product applications in mind." It is the sort of discovery process that at Bell Labs resulted in the invention of the transistor, a breakthrough technology that in turn made possible a host of new products. Most new-product development relies now on existing technologies, an approach that has not yet slowed the flow of new salable products.
"The sense that I have, in terms of working with companies, is an awakening awareness that we can grow significantly in sales volume and earnings per share through product R & D," said Stanley Jaskolski, chief technology officer at the Eaton Corporation, and president of the Industrial Research Institute, a trade association.
Eaton, for example, a Cleveland-based manufacturer of truck transmissions and other parts, recently began to market an anti-collision radar device, mounted on trucks, and is developing a miniature camera on a chip that would replace rear view mirrors, flashing on dashboard screens scenes that drivers now rely on mirrors to see. Both products are based on existing technologies.
The institute also says that its members are increasingly financing basic research at universities, while cutting back this work at corporate laboratories.
Corporate spending on research and development is heaviest in pharmaceuticals and electronics and has fluctuated with the business cycle. The $118.6 billion outlay last year compared with $108.7 billion in 1995 and $97.1 billion in 1994.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Despite Sluggish Sales, Toyota Earnings Rise

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News

DATELINE: TOKYO, Nov. 6

 BODY:
The Toyota Motor Corporation said today that earnings rose in the fiscal first half as cost cuts, growing exports to the United States and Europe, and the weaker yen made up for slack sales in Japan.
The auto maker's vice chairman, Iwao Isomura, said there was no sign that Japanese consumers' appetite for cars had begun to rebound. "I'm annoyed," he said. "Conditions are ripe for a recovery in demand, yet sales remain so sluggish." 
 The Japanese Government needs to do more to help the economy, Mr. Isomura said, and Toyota itself is trying to spur sales by introducing new cars and increasing spending on sales incentives.
Toyota, Japan's largest auto maker, is also being hurt by Thailand's economic crisis. It is the biggest seller of cars in that country, accounting for 30 percent of the market.
Toyota said yesterday that it would halt production at its two Thai factories from mid-November to at least the end of the year because of poor demand.
Toyota's pretax profit increased 26 percent in the half ended Sept. 30, to 324.56 billion yen, or $2.6 billion, from 258.50 billion yen a year earlier. Net income grew 43 percent, to 187.56 billion yen from 131.50 billion yen.
Reflecting an accounting change, sales fell 7 percent, to 3.798 trillion yen from 4.083 trillion yen. Toyota said sales would have risen a few percentage points if not for the change.
The results were for the parent company only. Toyota will report results for the complete corporate group later.
The earnings were announced after the end of today's stock trading in Tokyo, during which Toyota rose 30 yen, to 3,330 yen.
Toyota is hardly the only foreign auto maker to be experiencing problems in Thailand. The Mitsubishi Motors Corporation said today that the Thai currency's plunge had resulted in a foreign-exchange loss of 34 billion yen, or $276 million, on money it borrowed to pay for an aggressive expansion drive in Thailand.
Mitsubishi forecast that the foreign-exchange loss would result in a group net loss of 40 billion yen in the current fiscal year, which ends March 31.
Stephen Volkmann, an auto analyst at Morgan Stanley Japan Ltd., said that "it shouldn't be a big surprise that Thailand has become an expensive problem" for Mitsubishi, given that the company had made significant investments there.
Like Toyota, Mitsubishi is also struggling with weak demand in Japan. And last week, its president and chairman said they would step down because of the company's involvement in a scandal involving payoffs to racketeers.
Mitsubishi made its announcement after stock trading had ended. During the session, the company gained 16 yen, to 500 yen.
In another corporate development in Japan today, an index of Japanese bank shares fell to its lowest level in eight years, declining 2.9 percent, because of concern that a securities firm's filing for bankruptcy protection this week could add to the banks' bad-loan burdens.
The securities firm, the Sanyo Securities Company, filed for court protection from creditors on Monday.
Ken Tsubouchi, general manager of the Nomura Asset Management Company, said, "The fear is that since bankruptcies are on the rise, and banks have to foot the bill, one day it'll be too much for them to bear."
