HEADLINE: NYC;
Army Outpost At Crossroads Has New Foes

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN

 BODY:
NAME the cause, and it's better than even money that it has ignited a demonstration outside the armed forces recruiting station that sits on a traffic island in Times Square.
Usually, it is a foreign-policy issue that attracts protesters to the booth, as the station at West 43d Street is commonly called. Wars have naturally got the juices flowing, from Vietnam to the Persian Gulf, but so have lesser blips on the we're-mad-as-hell screen. 
 While these self-satisfied times aren't producing many protests, the 360-square-foot station is hardly off the hook. The terrain has shifted for New Yorkers wanting to give the booth the boot from the perch it has occupied for half a century.
One critic is Thomas K. Duane, an openly gay Councilman from Manhattan, who is unhappy with the military's "don't ask, don't tell" policy requiring soldiers to keep their homosexuality to themselves. Since a city human rights law forbids New York from doing business with anyone who discriminates on the basis of sexual orientation, Mr. Duane says that no exception should be made for the military and its occupation of a precious piece of real estate -- rent-free, at that.
The Times Square Business Improvement District can also think of better uses for the space, though it has not offered specifics. Nothing against tradition or the armed forces, said Gretchen Dykstra, the BID's president. "All of that history is wonderful," she said. But bidness is bidness, as they would say in the South. "We want it relocated," Ms. Dykstra said.
In truth, the recruiting station is likely to stay put for a while. Transportation Commissioner Christopher R. Lynn, who has jurisdiction over the traffic island, sympathizes with Mr. Duane on the "don't ask, don't tell" issue; he is openly gay himself. But he has also noted that the booth has been on the site for a long time and that the military is a way out of poverty for many young New Yorkers.
The issue probably won't die. Mr. Duane plans to rally public support and hold a Council hearing, an aide said, and the Councilman could not be more emphatic on the matter. "There's no reason why we should let such a symbol of bigotry occupy one of the most valuable pieces of real estate in the country," he said in September.
With Veterans Day approaching, perhaps it will not be deemed an offense against human rights to observe that whatever the military's failings may be, it is for many a good deal more than a symbol of bigotry. Try a symbol of national purpose.
R. Andrew Shore, a Manhattan lawyer, was sufficiently troubled last year by an editorial calling for the booth's removal that he wrote to this newspaper to say that "ending the armed forces' presence would banish some history, and a small bit of romance, from the crossroads of the world." Contacted this week, Mr. Shore did not want to get into the question of gay people in the military. But he was not alone among New Yorkers in describing the station as nothing less than "a symbol of the sacrifices that America made for the world in the 20th century."
It is also more active than some people might realize. "This is the most heavily trafficked walk-in station in the country," said Lieut. Col. John H. Bullock Jr., commander of the Army's New York City Recruiting Battalion.
THESE are good days for recruiters in the city, perhaps in part because unemployment here is 9.3 percent, nearly twice the national average. Colonel Bullock's battalion has far exceeded its quota -- its "mission," in Army jargon -- and the trend is conspicuous in Times Square, where 34 people were signed up in the past year, compared with a target of 14.
Those numbers, while not vast, are more than solid, said Staff Sgt. Lary Ruiz, the Army recruiter in Times Square. "This station is considered a powerhouse," he said. "We get young people coming in. We also get people who work in the area and are looking to change their life."
The booth itself could stand a change. It looks a little sad these days, its shabbiness made all the more conspicuous by the Disneyfication taking place around it.
Eliot Goldman, a lawyer in the area, has contacted the Army to suggest renovation ideas. "If you destroy that recruiting station, you destroy the essence of Times Square," he said, adding that the island has also long been a New York "speaker's corner." Political protest and the booth have gone hand in hand for decades.
"It serves as a rallying point," he said. "It even gives Duane a soapbox and a place to have rallies."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Times Square recruiting center.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Price of Long Bond Rises a Bit as Auctions Stir Demand

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Treasury bonds with long maturities bounced back from early weakness yesterday to finish higher for a second day, after the Government's quarterly debt refunding concluded with strong demand. Shorter maturities lagged, however, and ended the session mixed.
The 30-year bond rose 17/32, to a price of 102 19/32, while its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, fell to 6.18 percent, from 6.22 percent on Wednesday. 
 There were two Government auctions yesterday -- one of 52-week bills, the other of 30-year bonds. Dealers first pushed yields higher in the market to make sure that the new securities would be more attactive to investors. Market participants were also cautious before today's employment report for October.
In the auctions, traders saw decent demand as jitters continued in the equity markets, making Treasuries more attractive because of their relative safety. Small investors were said to be doing much of the buying in the bill auction.
In the first auction, the Treasury sold $12 billion of new 52-week bills at an average rate of 5.14 percent. In the final leg of the Government's quarterly refunding, $10 billion of a new 30-year issue was priced to yield an average of 6.201 percent.
Jack Ablin, executive vice president and head of the fixed-income department of Barnett Capital Advisors Inc. in Jacksonville, Fla., considered the auction results strong. "It's going to pave the way for solid total returns going forward in the bond market," he said.
Greg Jones, an economist with Briefing.com in Menlo Park, Calif., said that demand during the auction from domestic accounts was better than expected.
He noted, however, that the 30-year sale was the better of the two auctions. The bid-to-cover ratio, representing the total number of bids compared with the total amount of the auction, was 2.82 to 1, a very strong level, for the 30-year bond.
"Over the last 12 long-bond auctions," he said, "the bid-to- cover ratio has averaged 2.42 to 1. Today's ratio was the best in 10 years."
The market is now focused on the release of the October employment report. The consensus among economists is that the number of jobs added to American payrolls last month was about 200,000, with the unemployment rate unchanged at 4.9 percent. But Mr. Jones said he believed that even a relatively strong report might have a muted effect on the market.
"Until certain issues are resolved about effects of the Asian crisis on the U.S., yields of Government securities are not expected to venture far from where they are now over the short term," he said.
Treasuries with shorter maturities were weighed down yesterday by a surprise interest-rate increase overnight by the Bank of England. The central bank lifted its benchmark rate by a quarter of a percentage point, to 7.25 percent.
The Treasury market interpreted the move as a reminder that economic growth exceeding long-term trend levels keeps central bankers inclined to tighten monetary policy.

HEADLINE: Havana Journal;
Castro's Cigar, a Namesake, and Smell of Trouble

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER

DATELINE: HAVANA

 BODY:
There may be times when, as Freud said, a cigar is just a cigar. But when the cigar in question happens to be a Cohiba, that is surely not the case.
To Cubans, Cohibas are a symbol of revolution because they were first made for Fidel Castro and remained his favorite cigar until he gave up smoking. On Wall Street, on the other hand, they have become one of the most visible badges of material success, so cherished by tobacco lovers that Cigar Aficionado magazine recently compared a Cuban-made Cohiba to "a superb main course at a Michelin three-star restaurant." 
 But now the company that has made Cohibas here since the mid-1960's finds itself in a dispute with an American competitor that is selling a cigar with the same name and a similar logo. And as might be expected, Cuban officials are fuming, dismissing the Cohiba marketed in the United States as an inferior product that damages the reputation of the entire Cuban cigar industry.
"We think it is cheating the consumer," said Adargelio Garrido de la Grana, a lawyer for Habanos S.A., the Cuban Government's cigar export corporation. "What a mixture!" he snorted, scorning the rival Cohiba's composition, which includes tobacco grown in the Dominican Republic, Indonesia and Cameroon. "It sounds like a real cocktail."
Because of the 36-year-old American economic embargo against Cuba, Cohibas made here cannot be legally imported into the United States. But the strategy of both parties to the dispute suggests that they may be looking to the day when the embargo and the Helms-Burton Act, which last year tightened restrictions on Cuban commerce, are lifted and products made here can again be sold in the American market.
General Cigar Holdings Inc., a New York-based company, says it began using the Cohiba name in the United States as early as 1978. But it was not until this year that lawyers for Habanos formally challenged that trademark, saying its property, which takes its name from an Indian word for tobacco, had been illegally expropriated.
"It is very disconcerting that a serious company would try to appropriate the name of one of the most famous and sought-after cigars in the world by taking advantage of the inability of Habanos to enter the U.S. market," said Ana Lopez, the Cuban company's marketing director.
She described the rival Cohiba as "a fraud" that "neither offers the superior characteristics of the Habanos Cohiba nor compares with the quality of any other Cuban brand."
But A. Ross Wollen, a lawyer and senior vice president for General Cigar, said his company had acted entirely properly, and predicted that the United States Patent and Trademark Office would eventually reject the Cuban complaint, which is still pending. "We registered the name Cohiba 20 years ago, but it has had limited distribution until now," Mr. Wollen said. "Internationally, most people associate Cohiba with the Cuban cigar," he added, but "we do not intend to sell our cigar internationally. We are happy to be selling it in the United States."
Mr. Wollen also denied Cuban accusations that General Cigar was trying to deceive smokers. "Our packaging is different from the Cuban Cohiba, so we don't think consumers are confused," he said. "It is very clear in our advertisements and promotions that our cigar is made in the Dominican Republic."
But because of what the Cohiba name signifies here and around the world, the dispute has overtones that are as much political as commercial.
"Cohiba is a fruit of the Cuban revolution, and as such our most precious jewel," said Francisco Linares Calvo, president of Habanos.
In fact, Cohibas were initially produced seven years after the 1959 Cuban revolution brought Mr. Castro to power. According to a history published by the company early this year, a cigarmaker-turned-soldier began rolling cigars for a friend who was one of Mr. Castro's bodyguards. The bodyguard soon began sharing the cigars with his boss, who loved their flavor and asked for more.
At first, Mr. Castro reserved them for his own use and that of close associates, but eventually he began handing out Cohibas as gifts to heads of state and other foreign visitors, giving the brand international renown.
Habanos acknowledges that it did not begin mass selling of Cohibas until 1981. But it argues that since Cohibas were sold here in limited amounts in the 1970's on Cubana Airline flights and in special hard currency shops for foreigners, that should be enough to establish commercial marketing of the brand before General Cigar's registration.
Cuban officials also maintain that the American company was able to lay claim to the Cohiba brand name only because the economic embargo prevented them from registering the trademark in the United States. Experts say that while that argument is not likely to stand up in litigation, General Cigar's behavior raises other questions.
"The bottom line is that this does run counter to fairness," said Pamela S. Falk, author of the book "Cuban Foreign Policy" (Simon and Shuster) and Professor of International Trade and Commercial Transactions at the City University of New York School of Law. "According to international treaties, you can't take a name that is famous and has been commercially marketed and claim it as your own."
On the other hand, she added, the fundamental issue "in terms of the law is registration, so it is very unlikely the Cubans can win this one," since they "inexplicably failed to register in the United States a trademark they had registered in all sorts of other countries."
The dispute comes as Cuba has embarked on a major effort to increase tobacco production and cigar exports. Production in 1996 was about 70 million cigars, which earned Cuba more than $100 million.
Habanos declined to disclose any revenue or profit figures from the 11 varieties of Cohiba cigars it now makes. But conversations with workers during a tour of one of its factories here made it clear that the line is very lucrative.
Workers, none of whom wanted to be identified by name, said nearly all of them earn a base wage of $7 to $8 a month. A single Cohiba Esplendido cigar, in contrast, retails here for twice that amount, and can fetch up to $50 on the black market in the United States, compared with $15 for one of the rival Cohiba's Churchills.
As a result, the streets of Havana are full of hucksters trying to sell what they claim are boxes of Cohibas smuggled by employees from factories here. Most of what they offer turns out to be a low grade imitation of the Cohiba, but some, the workers themselves admit, is not.
"They steal from us," one employee said, complaining about the low wages paid by the state-owned company. "So we steal from them."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Workers in Havana making Cohiba cigars, which can sell for as much as $50 on the black market in the United States. The company that produces them is locked in a dispute with an American competitor that sells a cigar with the same name and a similar logo. Left, a Cuban cigar, bought in Montreal, and, below, an American Cohiba bought in New York. (Phillippe Diederich for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: 3 Aid Groups For Refugees Are Charged With Fraud

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO

DATELINE: ALBANY, Nov. 6

 BODY:
To the unemployed refugees who were its clients, the Albanian American Civic Association in the Bronx seemed to offer a much-needed helping hand. When they visited its storefront on Astor Avenue, they would receive stacks of brochures, chat with a "job developer" and fill out detailed forms. Then they would go home to await calls for job interviews.
Those calls never came, state investigators said. Instead, the association filed forms in 1996 fraudulently claiming to have placed two dozen refugees in jobs, in order to receive $20,000 in state funds. Yet none of the refugees received so much as a job referral, the investigators said. 
 Today, the association's job developer, Gasper Kalaj, was charged with one count of third-degree grand larceny and 22 counts of first-degree falsifying of business records, and its job placement contract was suspended by the state. Repeated calls to the association's office were unanswered.
The Albanian group was one of three immigrant-aid organizations accused today by the State Office of the Welfare Inspector General of making false job placement claims. In a 40-page report, the inspector general recounted how the groups fabricated placement records using forged letterheads, falsified signatures and fake addresses to justify receiving a total of $160,000 in state and Federal funds last year.
The inspector general, Paul Balukas, said that lax oversight by the state and the nonprofit organization it had hired to manage the placement program -- the Church Avenue Merchants Block Association in Flatbush, Brooklyn -- made it likely that the fraud his office had uncovered was being repeated across the city.
Dan Hogan, a spokesman for the State Office of Temporary Assistance, which runs the refugee job placement program, said that the three organizations had been chosen by the state and not by the Church Avenue Merchants Block Association. But he said the state had expected the merchants group to assist in overseeing the groups. The state has asked the merchants association to return $75,000, the total it feels is owed for the fraudulent cases.
Kathleen Masters, general counsel for the merchants association, said she had not seen the report and could not comment on it.
A second group accused of doctoring its records, the Vietnamese American Cultural Organization on Baxter Street in Manhattan, which had a grant of $34,000, falsely claimed successful job placements in 20 out of 37 cases reviewed by the inspector general. The investigators contend that the group forged letterhead stationery in several of those cases.
But the group's executive director, Joseph Hien, said the organization was forced to falsify documents because Chinatown restaurant owners were paying the refugees in cash off the books and had refused to sign letters acknowledging their employment. But he said the job development officer, Tony Pham, had been dismissed for falsifying documents.
The third group, the Association of Engineers and Scientists in Manhattan, which had a $105,000 grant, took credit for finding jobs for 36 people who in fact already had jobs when they visited the group's John Street office, the inspector general said. A person who answered the telephone at the group's office said no one was available to comment.

HEADLINE: New Jobless Claims Jump to 2-Month High

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6

 BODY:
The number of United States workers applying for state unemployment benefits jumped last week to the highest level in two months, a sign that job growth may be losing momentum.
First-time jobless claims rose by 16,000, to a seasonally adjusted 315,000 in the week that ended last Saturday, the Labor Department said. That is the highest level since the week that ended on Aug. 30, when claims totaled 325,000, and above analysts' expectations that claims rose by 8,000 last week to 305,000. 
 Still, the total level of new claims has remained at or below 315,000 for nine weeks -- a stretch not matched since early 1989. "The demand for labor is still very strong, and we're seeing obvious constraints on the supply side," said Scott Brown, an economist at Raymond James & Associates in St. Petersburg, Fla., before today's report.
In the previous week, claims fell by 13,000, to 299,000, initially reported as a drop of 16,000, to 297,000.
The four-week average for new claims, a less volatile measure of employment conditions, rose last week to 308,250 from 305,500 the previous week.

HEADLINE: Albright to See Arafat and Netanyahu to Try to Break Impasse

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6

 BODY:
With only modest progress after four days of Israeli-Palestinian talks here, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright is making plans to meet in Europe next week with leaders from both sides, American and Israeli officials said today.
Ms. Albright wants to show accomplishments and "real momentum" in Middle East peace efforts before she arrives at a Middle East economic conference in Doha, Qatar, on Nov. 16, the officials said. 
 Arab countries, including America's allies like Saudi Arabia and Egypt, have threatened to boycott the economic conference, or to send low-level delegations, because of the long Palestinian-Israeli deadlock that Ms. Albright is trying to crack.
But James P. Rubin, the State Department spokesman, said, "We don't feel a greater sense of urgency about the Middle East peace process because of the Doha conference."
Officials of all three sides said there was good will and seriousness at the talks this week, but no breakthroughs, especially on the larger issues. Those include Israeli-Palestinian security cooperation, a freeze on Israeli settlement activity and other provocative unilateral actions, the further withdrawal of Israeli troops from the West Bank and how to move quickly to talks on a final settlement between the two sides, including the status of Jerusalem.
On the pressing issues that matter most to the Palestinians: the troop withdrawal and final-status talks, there was no progress at all, officials said. The Israeli Foreign Minister, David Levy, could not negotiate serious alterations in the Israeli package, officials said, and the Palestinians rejected the idea of dealing with the issues as a package.
That is why Ms. Albright wants to see the Israeli Prime Minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, and the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, next week, in separate meetings, probably in London and Geneva.
The two sides also discussed smaller questions, known as "interim issues," which were supposed to have been settled 10 months ago. Those include a new airport for Palestinians in Gaza, a seaport, an industrial park and safe passage for Palestinians between the West Bank and Gaza Strip.
Officials said no agreements were concluded because the details remain complicated and all the required experts were not here. For instance, officials said, while the airport is largely resolved, there are still details to be settled over how to schedule takeoffs and landings and air rights. On the seaport, the difficult issue of how to inspect shipments to insure Israeli security has not been worked out, they said.
But Israeli and Palestinian officials were eager today not to criticize the other, and Mr. Levy and the Palestinian negotiator, Mahmoud Abbas, known as Abu Mazen, were complimentary. "It's true that we did not reach any agreement in the different areas, but I can say that we did reach a great deal of understanding and common ground on each other's needs," Mr. Abbas said.
Mr. Levy said, "I believe that our work in this week has restored trust and has provided a good basis for our continued work, and I am returning home very satisfied."
The Israeli Ambassador to the United Nations, Dore Gold, however, said today that the Palestinians were not heeding Ms. Albright's admonitions for a "time out" on provocative actions. "It's outrageous that just as Israel is taking risks to conclude negotiations on a Palestinian airport in Gaza, the Palestinians are launching a four-pronged attack on Israel at the United Nations," he said.

HEADLINE: Bronx and Staten Island Recover All Lost Jobs as Other Boroughs Lag

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON

 BODY:
The Bronx and Staten Island are the first boroughs to recover all the jobs that were lost in the recession of the late 1980's and early 90's, a report on the city's economy said yesterday.
By contrast, Manhattan suffered far greater losses in the recession than the other boroughs and has regained about 1 in 7 of its lost jobs, the study said. That performance is despite strong gains in industries like Wall Street, business services and tourism. 
 The report, issued by City Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi, suggests a David and Goliath theme for the economy over the last decade: The poorest borough, the Bronx, and its smallest, Staten Island, suffered far less and have been made whole first. The giant, Manhattan, still finds itself in a hole.
Manhattan has certainly retained its place as the main job engine. Of the 121,000 new jobs in business in the city from the end of the recession in 1993 to the end of last year, according to the most recent county-by-county figures available, more than two-thirds have been in Manhattan.
The borough's steep losses earlier in the decade and the relatively strong growth in the other boroughs, notably Queens, have resulted in a slight shift in the economic mix, the study said. In 1989, 67.2 percent of the jobs in the city were in Manhattan. By the end of last year, 65.2 percent were.
Queens, the second-largest borough in total jobs, increased its share in that period, from 13.2 percent in 1989 to 13.6 as of Dec. 31, 1996, the report said.
The study said that the Bronx was back to about where it was before the recession, as measured by total jobs, and that Brooklyn and Queens had each regained more than 40 percent of their losses.
Only Staten Island has surpassed its 1980's peak. As of Dec. 31, the borough had a record 78,371 jobs, 8,200 more than at the pre-recession peak in 1989.
The report also found a disparity between how large and small companies create jobs. The smallest enterprises, with fewer than 20 workers, have been one of the strongest contributors to growth, the study said. The tiny-company category was the only one that employed more people at the end of last year, 17,000 more, than in 1989.
Large companies, employing 500 or more people, had 109,000 fewer workers at year's end, compared with 1989. Manhattan, with many big corporate headquarters, suffered particularly in the recession, losing 135,000 jobs in the big-company category from 1989 to 1993.
Officials at the Comptroller's office acknowledged that because of methodology, the study left some questions unanswered and that some were apparently unanswerable, what economists call "statistical noise." The State Labor Department, for example, would count a company that moved from one borough to another as two entries, a loss for one borough and a gain for the other.
A company that laid off so many from its work force that it crossed the threshold into a smaller-company classification could distort the numbers as well, the officials said. Counting the performance of companies that were fluctuating in size along with the economy only approximates the roles of the different-size businesses, they said.

HEADLINE: Sour Taste of Nafta: Old Friends Become Foes

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6

 BODY:
For Representative Scotty Baesler of Kentucky, the turning point came last summer when Fruit of the Loom announced that thousands of workers in his state would be laid off and the jobs moved to Mexico, Central America and the Caribbean.
Representative Sam Farr of California is concerned about how duty-free flowers from Colombia have crippled the cut-flower businesses in his district. 
 Representative Alcee L. Hastings of Florida says that his state's tomato and citrus industries have been badly hurt by Mexican imports, and he fears further damage from imported fruit from Chile.
These Congressmen are three of a dozen or more Democrats who, at considerable political risk, voted to support President Clinton four years ago on the North American Free Trade Agreement but plan to vote on Friday against giving him the authority he wants to help him negotiate further trade pacts. Under this "fast-track" authority, Congress may only approve or disapprove trade agreements but not amend them.
These Democrats' votes could mean the difference between victory and defeat for the President.
Mr. Clinton is posing the trade matter as a central element of the country's foreign and economic policy. But in interviews, many of the Democrats who voted for Nafta and plan to vote against fast-track showed how, as is often the case with trade legislation, the lawmakers' focus is more on local concerns than on ideology or party loyalty.
"I can't afford to alienate my friends any more," said Representative George E. Brown Jr. of California, who was blasted by labor unions for his vote in favor of Nafta and who won re-election last year by fewer than 1,000 votes.
The interviews also illustrated two other important points about trade politics:
The first is that the victims of free trade -- those whose jobs move overseas or whose businesses suffer from competition abroad -- are identifiable and become important political forces. The main beneficiaries -- consumers who pay lower prices for imports or people who see their communities prosper because businesses that export products are expanding -- often do not think of their gain in political terms.
The second point is that many Democrats who voted for Nafta do not believe they have received enough political support from the Clinton Administration and business interests to offset the pressure they face from organized labor to vote against trade expansion.
In Representative Baesler's case, the underwear plants that closed are not even in his district, which is in central Kentucky around Lexington. But he is running for the Senate next year, and he needs support in southern Kentucky where the layoffs occurred.
Fruit of the Loom employment in the area has dropped to 5,000 jobs from 11,000 just two years ago. "We're being impacted by global competition," a company spokesman, Mark Steinkrauss, said last summer when the latest round of layoffs was announced. "We can do the same work cheaper somewhere else."
In an interview, Mr. Baesler explained what this meant for him politically. "People say it was Nafta that caused them to lose their jobs," he said. "I don't know if this was the case. But the companies that have benefited from Nafta have done an extremely poor job explaining this to the public, and, frankly, you get awfully tired of carrying their water."
Mr. Farr said that he was unwilling to give President Clinton a free hand on trade matters because the President had done nothing to solve the problem involving cut flowers in his congressional district around Monterey, south of the San Francisco Bay area.
More commercial flowers are grown there than in any other district in the country, Mr. Farr said, but business has recently been bad.
The reason, he said, is that 70 percent of the cut flowers sold in the United States are now imported from Colombia. Under a trade agreement meant to encourage other agricultural crops in the Andes besides those used for narcotics, Colombian cut flowers are the only ones imported that are not subject to tariffs.
"The President could change this with his signature," Mr. Farr said, "but he has not done so. He talks about job improvement, but he doesn't take any action."
Mr. Hastings said he worried about the damage that imports have done to Florida's tomato and citrus industries, where many of his constituents work. But he also said he was especially angry because neither the Clinton Administration nor the businesses in South Florida -- like banks that benefit from free trade -- helped him politically after his vote for Nafta.
"I took my bullet from labor," he said, "and they didn't come to my rescue."
Esteban E. Torres, a Democrat from Los Angeles, made the same point. "Those of us who stuck our necks out last time have been burned for nothing," he said. Mr. Torres has organized Hispanic legislators to oppose the fast-track legislation.
Nowhere is the Administration's political problem on the trade issue more apparent than it is in Massachusetts. According to Government data, Massachusetts companies exported $15.3 billion worth of goods last year, making it one of the largest exporting states.
But all 10 members of the Massachusetts Congressional delegation, all Democrats, have announced their opposition to the fast-track legislation. Three of them -- Joseph P. Kennedy 2d, Edward J. Markey and Martin T. Meehan -- voted for Nafta.
"No one opens a plant or expands one and says, 'By the way, I'm doing this because of lower barriers to trade,' " said a staff assistant who handles trade matters for a Massachusetts lawmaker. "But trade gets blamed for all the job losses."
Communications companies employ 100,000 workers in Massachusetts and benefit enormously from expanded trade, he said, and scores of high-technology companies based in the state depend on exports.
But on fast track, the aide said, "I didn't hear from a single one of them. Not a one called me."

HEADLINE: Diplomatic Approach to Iraq Is Big Risk for U.N.'s Leader

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Nov. 6

 BODY:
Less than a year after taking office as Secretary General of the United Nations, Kofi Annan may have put his reputation on the line in his first major crisis by choosing diplomacy over confrontation to deal with Saddam Hussein.
"Kofi feels this is a situation of war and peace," a diplomat who has known the Secretary General for years said this week, suggesting why Mr. Annan had not left the matter in the hands of the Security Council. "He feels a moral obligation to get involved." 
 A conciliator by nature, the Secretary General is an extremely popular administrator inside the system. Some diplomats ask, however, whether this approach will work with the world's most difficult characters.
In this case, Mr. Annan is gambling against historical odds that diplomacy might persuade the Iraqi President to end his ban on American arms inspectors rather than provoke an attack by the United States.
"This is Kofi Annan's moment of challenge," said Ruth Wedgwood, a senior fellow at the Council on Foreign Relations who specializes in the United Nations. "This is the time to stand up for the Security Council's authority. The Secretary General's offer to negotiate evades the authority of the inspection system."
Ms. Wedgwood, who is also an international law specialist at the Yale Law School, said that this gesture to the Iraqis may prove to be a "profound error."
In all its aspects, the current Iraq crisis is a cliffhanger for the United Nations, which has enjoyed one of its greatest successes in Iraq.
No on-site inspections of places where Iraqis may be producing or storing prohibited arms have taken place since Oct. 27, when Iraq ordered Americans working for the United Nations commission charged with disarming Iraq to leave the country and demanded an end to flights over its territory by American U-2 spy planes. The flights were temporarily suspended this week.
Today in Baghdad, Mr. Annan's three emissaries -- an Algerian, an Argentine and a Swede -- were still waiting for a reply to a letter they delivered on Wednesday asking Saddam Hussein to change his mind. They have been promised an answer before they leave Iraq on Friday, probably without a meeting with the Iraqi leader, the Secretary General's spokesman said today. They have, however, spoken with Tariq Aziz, the Iraqi leader's chief deputy.
If the answer is not positive, Mr. Annan said late tonight, he will end his personal intervention in the dispute and return the matter to the Security Council. Mr. Annan made the statement during a visit to Santiago, Chile, through a spokesman, Juan Carlos-Brandt.
In sending the delegation to Baghdad, the Secretary General broke with the practice of making the Iraqis deal with only the Council and its unique creation, the United Nations Special Commission, which was set up with the sole purpose of disarming Iraq. Until all prohibited weapons are destroyed, Iraq cannot hope for the lifting of crippling sanctions imposed after its 1990 invasion of Kuwait.
Saddam Hussein, knowing he has some support in the Security Council for the lifting of sanctions from France, Russia and Egypt, has seized on the Secretary General's gesture as an opening to negotiate with the United Nations by circumventing both the Security Council and the disarmament commission.
At stake is the Security Council's bold peacetime experiment in dealing with a renegade nation by effectively destroying its ability to make war. If this approach crumbles in the case of Iraq, it will not be easy for the Council to take this course again in the future.
Many diplomats say the Council's ability to impose this kind of control over a belligerent nation should not in any way be compromised.
Sir Brian Urquhart, a former Under Secretary General who has written several books about the organization, said that any weakening of the Security Council -- by the Secretary General or the member nations -- would be a grave setback, especially in the post-cold-war era when the Council was foreseen as taking on a greater global role.
"It was all supposed to have changed in 1990," he said. "The Council would be able to function as Franklin Roosevelt and everyone else thought it would function, as a fearless arbiter against aggression."
Sir Brian believes that if there is an erosion of Council authority, it is the countries who dominate it who are to blame, as opposed to Mr. Annan. In the case of Iraq, French and Russian businesses are either owed money or are promised future oil contracts. Seven years of sanctions is a long time to wait.
"The real trouble with governments," Sir Brian said, "is that for most of them the short term is more important than the long term. An oil contract is more important than worrying about in some distant future Saddam Hussein will resume his world domination program."
On Wednesday, Richard Butler, the Australian arms control expert who is executive chairman of the inspection commission, told the Security Council that Iraq was taking advantage of the break in surveillance by hiding or tampering with equipment.
Iraqis acknowledged today that they had moved some equipment out of the way of cameras in recent days but said this was to get the machinery out of range of American missiles. Were cameras disabled? Well, the Iraqis told the Security Council in a letter, one did get wrecked when an Iraqi missile blew up during tests Wednesday.
United Nations officials are not impressed by the explanations.
And today, in Washington, Secretary of Defense William Cohen reiterated the Administration's dissatisfaction with Iraq. "There is sufficient time to consider a whole panoply" of responses to Iraq's actions, Mr. Cohen said. He said those responses "could include further economic measures. They could include military as well."
Mr. Annan, in his ten months in office, has had mixed results in his efforts to break deadlocks. He has had a good working relationship with the Security Council, diplomats say. But he is also establishing a reputation for taking on intractable problems alone, even at considerable political risk to himself.
In June, he took out of the hands of the United Nations Human Rights Commission a stalled investigation into allegations of massacres in Congo, formerly Zaire. He named a new team of investigators after consulting with President Laurent Kabila, but Mr. Kabila blocked that team also and the Secretary General had to turn to Bill Richardson, the United States representative, for help.
Mr. Kabila says he has changed his mind. But the investigating team has yet to be dispatched. It is in New York awaiting the return of Mr. Annan, who is in Latin America.
There are few public officials easier to blame than a United Nations Secretary General, as Mr. Annan's predecessor, Boutros Boutros-Ghali, discovered when governments made catastrophic decisions in Bosnia, Somalia or Rwanda and then blamed him if toothless, stripped-down peacekeeping missions failed.
Stephen Schlesinger, director of the World Policy Institute at the New School for Social Research in New York, who formerly worked for the United Nations, called Mr. Annan "an accommodator" whose style of management was a positive factor in many ways because of the difference it has made to the working atmosphere of the organization at a critical moment in its history.
"Boutros-Ghali was a man who kept everybody on edge," Mr. Schlesinger said. "I remember a distinct change in the organization when Boutros left. It was like a great thorn being taken out of the body."

HEADLINE: Three States Investigating Sales Practices of Met Life

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER

 BODY:
Regulators in Florida and Texas and the Attorney General in Massachusetts are investigating whether the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, the nation's second-largest insurer, has misled tens of thousands of life insurance customers, increasing the costs of their coverage and promising benefits that many never got.
The investigations have been developing as policyholders in several states have filed suits against the company in a widening case that many lawyers say rivals the recently settled one against the Prudential Insurance Company of America, the nation's leading life insurer. Some analysts said the Prudential settlement might ultimately cost the company up to $2 billion. 
 Executives at Met Life said they were cooperating with the investigations in Florida and Massachusetts and were confident that in the end no evidence of widespread, improper activity would be found. They said they had not been notified of an investigation by Texas officials.
News of the Florida investigation was reported yesterday by The Wall Street Journal.
"I can't guarantee that 100 percent of the cases were handled perfectly," said Lawrence A. Vranka, a Met Life vice president, "but I feel that when the investigations are concluded that there will be no finding of widespread improper activity."
Mr. Vranka and other Met Life executives said they thought that no more than a small number, at most, of their more than 11.5 million policyholders might have been affected. They said the company won a lawsuit against a policyholder in California on similar allegations earlier this year, after a seven-week trial, and were confident they would prevail in the other cases.
Charges of improper sales practices have roiled the life insurance industry for the last few years. Scores of suits have been filed and hardly any of the leading life insurers have been unscathed. Florida and Massachusetts have just completed investigations of the John Hancock Insurance Company, which announced agreement last week on a settlement of a class action lawsuit. John Hancock paid $6 million in a separate settlement with Florida. Bill Nelson, the Florida Insurance Commissioner, said that his investigators were in the early stages of looking at more than a dozen other companies.
In Massachusetts, Joanna Connolly, a spokeswoman for Attorney General Scott Harshbarger, said, "We have gotten hundreds of complaints involving about 20 companies."
Most of the complaints grew out of sales in the 1980's, when interest rates were high. To compete with other investments yielding high returns, insurance companies increased the returns on their cash- value life insurance policies. In a practice known as churning, agents encouraged many customers to cash in their old policies, with low interest rates, to buy new ones that paid higher interest rates.
In some cases, customers were told that because interest rates and dividends were high, their policies would pay for themselves after seven or eight years. These were known as vanishing premium policies. When interest rates eventually fell, out-of-pocket costs increased. And premiums that were expected to vanish did not. Millions of life insurance customers have complained that their insurance agents did not fully explain to them how their policies would perform.
Met Life and other life insurers have been encouraged by a recent New York State court decision in which a judge declared that the risks of these policies were clearly described in the customers' contracts. Because the customers had therefore been informed, the judge ruled, the insurers could not be accused of deception.
Met Life executives said that after the company paid $20 million in fines and $50 million in restitution in 1994 to settle allegations that its agents had sold life insurance policies as retirement plans, they began closely monitoring sales. Now, they said, they call all new customers after 45 days to make sure that they understand what they bought and that they are satisfied with the terms.
Florida and Massachusetts officials said they began their investigations of Met Life in the spring and Texas officials said they began looking into possible violations in late summer.
Mr. Nelson, the Florida Insurance Commissioner, said, "Our primary goal is to give any and all victims the opportunity to get their money back."

HEADLINE: LeFrak Announces Plans for 189-Room Tourist Hotel in Jersey City

BYLINE: By TERRY PRISTIN

 BODY:
In a new sign of resurgence in Jersey City, Sam LeFrak, the developer, announced plans yesterday to build the first hotel on the waterfront intended for tourists as well as business travelers.
The 189-room $21 million hotel would be on a 1.7-acre site in the Newport complex that the Lefrak Organization owns next to the Newport-Pavonia PATH station. 
 An additional waterfront hotel, a 200-room Doubletree Guest Suites, is under construction. It is aimed primarily at business customers.
Lefrak is negotiating financing with the General Electric Credit Corporation, and no date has been set to begin building, the president of the company, Richard LeFrak, said.
Nevertheless, Sam LeFrak, 79, appeared ebullient at a news conference and recalled that there were many doubting Thomases in 1986, when his company started the 400-acre complex that includes the Newport Center Mall, as well as offices, condominiums and apartments.
"The vision we saw in the early '80's, when we looked upon bankrupt railroad yards and abandoned piers, not only has taken shape but continues to enhance Jersey City and the entire metropolitan area," he said.
Another company, the Cali Realty Corporation of Cranford, said it hoped to construct what would be the tallest office building in New Jersey.
From 1993 to last year, 12,000 jobs were added in Jersey City, mostly along the waterfront, said Thomas Gallagher, Director of the Department of Housing, Economic Development and Commerce.
Robert Deeley, a regional vice president of Marriott International Inc., which would operate the proposed hotel, said the company was drawn to the waterfront because of easy access to highways and other transportation.
Jersey City, like much of northern New Jersey, has a large immigrant population. Family members visiting for weddings and other events often stay in Weehawken, Secaucus or Newark, Mayor Bret D. Schundler of Jersey City said. "Now they'll be staying in Jersey City, closer to their families."
Lefrak said it would open a 138,000-square-foot food market at the site of a Bradlees discount store in Newport that closed last year.
The proposed 1.8-million-square-foot office tower, in the Harborside Financial Center and built in partnership with the Garden State Corporation, is tentatively called the American Financial Exchange. It would take shape if the developer can lease half the building, the chief operating officer of Cali Realty, Brant Cali, said. The developer has hired Insignia/Edward S. Gordon as leasing agent, Mr. Cali said.
The builder has not obtained Planning Board approval for such a large building, which Mr. Cali said would be at least 50 stories. The city already has the state's tallest office building, a 42-story tower at 101 Hudson Street, a few blocks from Harborside.
Cali bought the Harborside center a year ago for $292 million. Garden State is run by Peter Mangin of Jersey City, a lawyer, and his uncle, Frank J. Guarini, a former Congressman. Mr. Mangin is also a developer of the Doubletree.
Cali owns 2.5 million square feet in Jersey City, or 40 percent of the prime office space, Mr. Cali said, and it is 99 percent occupied.

HEADLINE: PRESIDENT ISSUES LAST-MINUTE PLEA ON TRADE MEASURE

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6

 BODY:
President Clinton, fearing defeat in his quest for expanded trade negotiating authority, made an unusual public appeal for support tonight, accusing interest groups of intimidating members of the House who might otherwise vote for the bill.
Opponents of the so-called fast-track legislation gained new ground today, prompting Mr. Clinton to cut short a trip to Texas for the dedication of the George Bush presidential library and return to Washington to lobby publicly and privately for votes. 
 Also making a last-minute appeal and gaining some promises of "no" votes was Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the House Minority Leader, who opposes the measure.
Mr. Clinton warned that defeat of the trade measure would damage the international standing of the United States and threaten growth in the domestic economy.
"A vote against fast track will not create a single job, clean up a single toxic waste site, advance workers' rights or improve the environment anywhere in the world," he said in an urgent appeal presented in the White House briefing room at the request of the House Speaker, Newt Gingrich, who is supporting the measure.
"But," the President said, "it will limit America's ability to advance our economic interests, promote our democratic ideals, our political leadership."
Mr. Clinton argued that if the House vote were taken in secret, "it would pass overwhelmingly," but he said members of Congress were under intense pressure to vote against the measure, an oblique reference to the political clout of organized labor, which opposes it. He accused House members of being more concerned about their own political futures than about national economic policy.
"The deadline concentrates our attention markedly," said President Clinton, who added that he was not asking for the vote to be postponed. "We think we can get there by tomorrow night and that's what we're trying to do," he said.
President Clinton had more than half his Cabinet fanned out across the Capitol earlier today to press wavering lawmakers in advance of the House vote on Friday.
But as Cabinet secretaries traipsed from office to office, Mr. Gephardt and Representative David E. Bonior of Michigan defiantly led their own battle.
At midday, Mr. Gephardt appeared at a news conference to showcase 15 previously undecided Democrats who had decided to vote against the measure. Representative Nancy Pelosi of California said she opposed it out of fear that global trade would lead to a "race to the bottom" unless the Administration made labor rights a negotiating point. She said she was "asking President Clinton to withdraw his request, to go back to the drawing board."
Mr. Gephardt began the day in his red-carpeted office where he described squalid living conditions on the Mexican side of the border. He said he wanted global trade to improve standards of living by committing the United States to fight just as hard for labor and environmental protections as it does for intellectual property rights. "I think you're seeing workers and middle-class families and environmentalists stand up and say this is important," he said.
Mr. Clinton decided late this afternoon, while aboard Air Force One, that he needed to take drastic measures on the issue. His decision came after Mr. Gingrich informed Erskine Bowles, the White House chief of staff, that the measure was headed toward certain defeat unless Mr. Clinton could deliver more Democratic votes.
Representative Robert T. Matsui, a California Democrat who has been working with the President, sounded less optimistic than he had a day before, saying he could bring in 45 to 55 Democrats -- short of the 60 to 70 he had predicted on Wednesday.
Early this evening Senate Majority Leader Trent Lott said that the President was short "at least a couple of dozen" votes in the House and that the situation was so dire that the Republican leadership, in consultation with the White House, might not go ahead with the vote.
The signs of trouble came early. Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin and the United States trade representative, Charlene Barshefsky, set up shop for more than an hour first thing this morning in a basement office to answer questions from undecided lawmakers. But only a handful showed up, among them Republicans Bob Schaffer of Colorado and Wes W. Watkins of Oklahoma.
Mr. Clinton has argued that the fast track authority is crucial for the United States to maintain a leading role in global trade. The legislation strengthens the President's negotiating power by allowing Congress to approve or defeat but not amend trade treaties.
At the Bush library today, the President mustered support from Mr. Bush, Gerald Ford and Jimmy Carter, and Mr. Bush said, "I am passionately committed to his position -- President Clinton's position -- on free and fair trade."
But Mr. Clinton's brand of centrist politics has left him in danger on an issue that fractures the Democratic Party, and while Mr. Gingrich and his deputies have been fighting for Mr. Clinton's trade policy, they have encountered resistance from Republicans who are seeking concessions on other issues.
"We know that the President wants fast track rather badly," said Representative Henry J. Hyde, a Republican from Illinois who wants to keep family- planning funds from going to overseas groups that counsel abortions. "And we would like him to be cooperative."
For many House members the legislation has become symbolic of a larger debate over who wins and who loses in an era of global trade when the United States is competing with developing nations with lower labor and environmental standards. And the battle has significance for the next Presidential race as well.
Patrick Buchanan, a 1996 Republican Presidential candidate, spoke out against the bill before a House committee today. And Vice President Al Gore and Mr. Gephardt are expected to be Democratic primary contenders with sharply different stances on economic policy.
Today, in his office just off the Senate chamber, Mr. Gore met with five undecided Democrats -- Nita Lowey of New York, Earl Pomery of North Dakota, Juanita Millender-McDonald of California, Lloyd Doggett of Texas and Zoe Lofgren of California. Asked if he had won over any votes, he said, "several."
Representative Lowey noted that environmental groups had come out as a block against the trade legislation. She said that she was still undecided and that voting for the bill or voting against it were "both bad choices."
Some lawmakers privately acknowledged that they were making their decisions on political grounds, loath to antagonize labor, which they believe will be more helpful to them in next year's campaign than Mr. Clinton.
John J. Sweeney, the president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. roamed easily through the corridors of the House today, greeting members and reminding them that he opposed the trade bill.
Other House members said what mattered was how their regions had fared under the North American Free Trade Agreement. Georgians were protesting that peanuts had not been sufficiently protected against diseased imports. (Former President Jimmy Carter telephoned members of the Georgia delegation to argue in favor of the legislation.) Midwestern farm state legislators were concerned about Canadian wheat imports. Representative Henry Bonilla was said to be concerned about traffic generated by trucks crossing the border from Mexico.
Representative Karen Thurman, a Florida Democrat, held lengthy talks with the Administration about her belief that the Florida citrus industry had been damaged by trade with Mexico and could be hurt further by trade agreements with Latin America. Today she said the Administration had not done enough to address the delegation's concerns. "They were nice to us," she said, "they talked and went through the hoops over it, but they kept coming back with stuff that was kind of estoric to us."
En route to Texas Mr. Clinton did what he could. He brought with him on Air Force One two Republicans considered undecided or against him -- Representative Michael Forbes of New York and John L. Mica of Florida, and tonight he invited 20 lawmakers to the White House.
Mr. Gingrich, meanwhile, put down his own rebellions. At one point he met with Republicans who wanted an iron-clad commitment from the President that he would not veto legislation on military programs. Mr. Gingrich pressed the White House for more concessions on spending bills that he could use to rally conservatives to the President's cause. But Mr. Clinton said in his White House appearance that he was trying to accommodate lawmakers on economic issues "that we can resolve honorably."

INTERNATIONAL A3-13
 
Clinton in Public Appeal For More Trade Muscle
President Clinton made a public appeal in which he accused interest groups of intimidating members of the House to vote against a trade bill that would grant him broader negotiating powers. A1
 
Crime Wave in Mexico
Mexicans frustrated by the worst wave of common crime in their memory have increasingly lost confidence in the police, and that in turn has undermined efforts to open up the country's authoritarian politics to greater democracy. A1 

Twist in Mexico Murder Case
Three doctors have been charged with the murder of Amado Carrillo Fuentes, a Mexican drug barons who died four months ago after plastic surgery, the head of Mexico's anti-drug agency said. Now the mutilated bodies of two of the doctors have been identified after being found in sealed drums along a rural highway in the southern state of Guerrero. A third body was found, but has not been identified. A7
 
Annan's Iraqi Gambit
Secretary General Kofi Annan's choice of diplomacy over confrontation in dealing with President Saddam Hussein of Iraq has been criticized as undermining the authority of the Security Council, but it reflects his personal style. A1
 
Albright Plans Mideast Talks
After little progress in four days of talks with Israeli and Palestinian negotiators, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright said she was making plans to meet separately with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel and the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, next week, probably in London and Geneva. These talks will precede a Middle East economic conference on Nov. 16, which several Arab countries, including Saudi Arabia and Egypt, have threatened to boycott because of the deadlock in talks. A13
 
Brazil Defends Currency
President Fernando Henrique Cardoso of Brazil, trying to keep inflation at bay, has raised interest rates sharply and devoted billions of dollars of reserves to defend his currency from devaluation. The strategy seems to have calmed local financial markets and helped Brazil avoid the fate of Southeast Asian nations whose currencies were routed by speculators. But it may prove unpopular with voters leading up to next year's elections. A9
 
Power Vacuum in Thailand
The resignation of Prime Minister Chavalit Yongchaiyudh has virtually stalled the management of Thailand's ailing economy. As the stock market meanders, two coalitions, each headed by a former Prime Minister, announced at almost simultaneous televised news conferences that they had gathered enough parliamentary votes to form a new government. The public just watches nervously. A11
 
NATIONAL A14-29
 
Judge Ends Nomination Over False Family Story
James Ware, a Federal District Court judge in San Jose, Calif., admitted that his brother had not been the victim of a racist murder in 1963, something he had claimed in speeches for years as a formative event in his life that made him "hungry for justice." He asked President Clinton to withdraw his nomination to become the only active black judge on the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. A1

HEADLINE: Health Care Is Too Important for Partisanship

 BODY:

To the Editor:
"Move Under Way to Try to Block Health Care Bills" (front page, Nov. 4) points up that health care reform is again being treated as a partisan issue rather than the bipartisan issue it should be. The health care system is in critical condition.
Costs are rising at twice the rate of inflation and will double in the next 10 years. The number of uninsured -- estimated to be between 41 million and 44 million -- is increasing by a million a year, and the quality of care continues to erode. 
 Competition and managed care have been promoted as solutions, yet the marketplace has done little to stem long-term cost, quality and coverage problems, which show no sign of abating.
Opponents of reform being considered in Congress contend that the proposals would increase costs even more and drive more people out of health coverage.
Yet without change in the way we deliver and pay for health care, costs will rise more rapidly and the number of uninsured will grow larger.
Partisan posturing only aggravates the problems for all Americans.
 
HENRY E. SIMMONS , M.D.
Washington, Nov. 6, 1997
 
Pres., Natl. Coalition on Health Care

HEADLINE: Give Clinton 'Fast Track,' or We'll Pay the Price

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Antitrade forces who have argued that the United States has little to gain and much to lose by granting President Clinton "fast track" authority on trade negotiations are on the wrong side of history (editorial, Nov. 6).
In 1975 United States exports represented only 4 percent of its gross domestic product. Today, after two rounds of the multilateral trade negotiation and the North American Free Trade Agreement, exports constitute 8.2 percent of a much larger gross domestic product. 
 Opponents of free trade are eager to hold up examples of American companies shifting their production abroad. But many foreign companies have opened facilities in the United States; five million Americans now work for foreign subsidiaries.
In addition, engaging South America in a trade partnership increases the likelihood that its more than 300 million consumers will buy and use American-made products. As the United States has relinquished its historic leadership in trade, Europe, Japan and Brazil have stepped up their presence in the region. These nations are seeking preferential agreements for themselves rather than to establish an open market for all.
President Clinton is right. If we turn our backs on the challenge of global competition, we will pay the consequences: higher prices and fewer choices for consumers and less secure, lower-paying jobs for our workers.
 
DAVID ROCKEFELLER
New York, Nov. 7, 1997

HEADLINE: Give Clinton 'Fast Track,' or We'll Pay the Price;
Read the Report

 BODY:

To the Editor:
President Clinton is trying to garner Congressional support for his "fast track" authority on trade agreements by proposing reviews of labor and environmental practices of potential trade partners and the parties to the North American Free Trade Agreement, particularly Mexico (front page, Nov. 4). He also wants to involve the World Bank in expanding worker rights.
No new report is necessary on Mexico's failure to comply with its obligations under the labor side agreement to Nafta. All that the President need do is to read the reports of his own National Administrative Office in the Labor Department, which detail how Mexican authorities have frustrated the attempts of Mexican workers to organize. 
 Moreover, there is no evidence that the World Bank has ever intervened with its member governments to mitigate egregious abuse of worker rights (for example, Indonesia, which the World Bank considers a "star" performer).
 
JEROME I. LEVINSON
Bethesda, Md., Nov. 4, 1997
 
The writer is professor of international law at American University.

HEADLINE: A Rising Disquiet Among the Bogs;
Environmental Worries Block Plan by New Jersey Farmers To Expand Cranberry Fields

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS

DATELINE: SPEEDWELL, N.J.

 BODY:
Steve Lee watched the rising water flood the sunken cranberry fields, gently buoying the vine-tethered crop. Then the harvesting machines rolled through, shaking the berries loose to float on the surface like a vermilion carpet.
"Some people may think it's thick enough to walk on, but I know you can't," Mr. Lee, a cranberry farmer, said. 
 Across five generations, this red harvest has brought prosperity to the 35 or so farm families who work the cranberry bogs of New Jersey's pinelands. Thanks to this swatch of wildness, the nation's most densely populated state is also the third-largest cranberry producer in the world, after Massachusetts and Wisconsin. But this year, the usual rigors and rhythms of harvest time are mixed with disquiet, and some anxiety for the future.
At issue are the farmers' efforts to make it easier to expand their 3,800 acres of fields into adjacent wetlands -- including portions of the Pine Barrens. While the proposal has the support of state environmental officials and some state conservations groups, it is opposed by Federal environmental agencies and national environmental groups, who fear that the loss of wetlands to agriculture will damage the sensitive ecology of the state's pinelands.
Recently, the Federal Environmental Protection Agency decided to put the plan on hold, pending further study. To the farmers, the decision was a rebuke to what they see as their own ecological sensitivity.
Their crop, they insist, is native to the wetlands and as much a part of it as the 84 species of birds, 14 species of mammals, 14 reptile types and 12 species of fish that thrive there. It is the perfect no-till crop and it requires the purest of waters, so by necessity, they argue, they must be good stewards of the land, careful with pesticides, herbicides and fertilizers that could contaminate the groundwater and streams and eventually their product.
The farmers are hardly crying immediate economic hardship. With an annual harvest valued at about $25 million, cranberries rank fifth among New Jersey's agriculture products. Divided among a mere 35 cranberry-growing families, it is a lucrative business. What the growers fear, though, is competition from abroad -- that their ranking and revenue will be lost to the new, spacious and less regulated frontiers of cranberry growing in Chile and British Columbia.
"It's been very frustrating," said Bill Haines, the state's largest single grower, whose 1,000 acres of production bogs amid 10,000 acres of forested wetlands account for almost a third of the total state cranberry acreage. "We have only scratched the surface of the demand, and the markets for our product and juices are growing in Europe and Canada. The thing hampering us in getting those markets is lack of product."
Michele Breyer, assistant director of the New Jersey Conservation Foundation, said her group generally supported modest expansion of the cranberry bogs sprinkled throughout and along the fringes of the 1.1-million-acre Pinelands National Reserve. The reserve, established by the national and state governments in 1978, sits atop the Cohansey Aquifer, the largest aquifer east of the Mississippi, and its commissioners, including Mr. Lee, have supported the expansion proposals.
"Cranberries are a native fruit to the wetlands and part of our culture," Ms. Breyer said. "And the farmers, with their emphasis on pure water, have an impact on protecting the wetlands. We believe in moderate expansion."
Those who are holding up Federal approval said that they were not opposed to some increase in cranberry acreage but insisted that it could be accomplished on less environmentally sensitive upland areas. They agree with growers that cranberry bogs have far less impact on the wetlands than other agricultural practices and are nothing like the developments that fill in the wetlands forever. They also concede that cranberry growing adds little contamination to the area.
But to the opponents, the issue is not contamination but the manipulation of the natural environment. "Cranberry beds are actively maintained as a monoculture and provide no structural diversity," said Cliff Day, supervisor of the New Jersey office of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service. He noted that the growing areas for the creeping vines were scraped and cleared of trees, shrubs and grasses and made inhospitable to wildlife naturally found in the wetlands.
William Neil, the associate director of the New Jersey Audubon Society, which also opposes speeding the permit process for cranberry farmers, said that the magnitude of the proposed change was significant. In the last five years, the state had lost 609 acres of wetlands to development. Cranberry farmers are seeking 300 acres, concentrated in Burlington County, over five years.
Under the proposal offered this year, the farmers were seeking a general permit to add up to 10 acres a year without going through the rigorous special permit process of the Federal Clean Water Act, which requires the approval of a host of agencies. The current system holds that every speck of wetlands is valuable and endangered, and that cavalierly allowing expansion is the slippery slope to the disappearance altogether of wetlands, Mr. Day said.
Michael Hogan, counsel to the state's Environmental Protection Commissioner, said that in exchange for approving the growers' plan, his agency had also required them to finance programs to plant endangered trees like the Atlantic white cedar in the pinelands.
"They don't destroy wetlands, but they do modify them," Mr. Hogan said. "In the process, though, they create more wetlands but they don't get any credit for that. If New Jersey doesn't position itself in the cranberry industry, the people who make the products are going to go elsewhere."
Massachusetts, with 12,355 acres of cranberry bogs, ranks first in growing the crop, followed by Wisconsin with 8,679 acres under cultivation. Expansion of the crop is strictly regulated in each of those states -- a fact that opponents of the New Jersey plan point to as evidence that a thriving industry does not require a blank check to expand.
The industriousness that seizes cranberry bogs each October contrasts with the still and nearly silent forested swamps they border. There are still many thick, pristine stands of red maple and birch, but far fewer clusters of the prized Atlantic white cedar that was harvested in the 19th and 20th centuries for building materials. The cedar trees soar upward to form a canopy that shades the forested, swampy wetlands that are thick with pygmy pines, gnarled and woody sheep laurel, and wild blueberry in its lowest lying areas.
"For every acre of cranberry bogs, we have 10 acres of woods and swamps to support it," Mr. Lee said. "We call it all a cranberry growing system and tell regulators to look at the whole thing. Then you can see the diversity of it all."
The pressure to expand is great, he said, adding that he and his brother, Abbott, had not been able to expand their 130 acres of bogs since 1985, when, he said, the Clean Water Act lumped their activity in with "mall developers and housing developers."
For Mr. Haines, with his larger landholdings, the pressure for the new permit process is not so great. He has about 140 acres of old blueberry fields into which he can expand cranberry production without government approval.
"We have the room to expand on our farm, but it is more important for the industry itself to be able to expand," he said as he sat in his office. Over his left shoulder, hanging on the wall in a simple pine frame, was a saying penned in stylish and flowing calligraphy on parchment that read, "Cranberry growers get bogged down in their work."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Cranberry workers harvesting the crop at the Lee Brothers Cranberry Farm in Chatsworth, N.J. Cranberries rank fifth among New Jersey's most important agricultural products. (Dith Pran/The New York Times)(pg. B1)

 BODY:

U.S. Sues to Block Long Island Radio Deal
The Justice Department sued to block Chancellor Media's planned acquisition of four popular Long Island radio stations from SFX, saying the deal would undercut competition, drive up advertising fees and result in higher costs to consumers.
 
 It was the first such move by the department since Federal rules were liberalized in early 1996, unleashing a wave of more than 1,000 radio mergers. Page D10.
 
Halloween Scares Up Sales
Retailers enjoyed an unexpectedly strong October, reflecting the increased importance of Halloween as a selling holiday. Some industry analysts said the economic vibrance suggested that sales would be strong for the rest of the year, too. D8.
 
Three States Investigate Met Life
Metropolitan Life Insurance is under investigation in Florida, Massachusetts and Texas over accusations that its agents misled customers into purchasing more expensive policies. Met Life said it was confident that any wrongdoing had been isolated. D2.
 
Asia Builders Return to Earth
The grand ambitions of construction companies to build skyscrapers, dams and other public works projects in Asia have been humbled by the region's economic and financial market crises. Many construction plans have been scrapped. D8.
 
Asian Stocks Decline
In Hong Kong early today, investors nervous about higher interest rates caused the Hang Sang index to drop 521.14 points, or five percent, at the mid-morning break. In Tokyo, at the close of trading, the Nikkei index was down 697.51 points, or 4.22 percent. D12.
 
A strong auction of Government securities lifted Treasury prices for a second day. D22.
 
America Online Posts Gain
America Online reported strong growth in subscribers as it posted quarterly earnings that matched Wall Street expectations. But revenue from advertising and electronic commerce sales was down slightly. D6.
 
Profits Rise at Toyota
Toyota said that earnings rose in the fiscal first half as cost cuts, growing exports to the United States and Europe, and the weaker yen made up for slack sales in Japan. D8.
 
Research Spending Rises
United States companies increased their spending on research and development by 9 percent last year, a report says. Spending on basic research held steady. D8.
 
Morgan Stanley Employee Charged
Prosecutors announced the arrest of a Morgan Stanley employee responsible for protecting market-sensitive information and charged her with using it to profit illegally. D8.
 
Stephen King in Book Deal
Stephen King and Simon & Schuster have reached an unusual deal in which Mr. King will get a share of nearly 50 percent of the profits from his next three books. D10.
 
Where There's Good Smoke . . .
The company that makes Cuban Cohiba cigars -- cherished by tobacco lovers but not legally available in the United States -- is engaged in a dispute with an American competitor that sells a cigar with the same name and a similar logo. The trademark challenge suggests that the companies may be looking to the day when the trade embargo of Cuba ends. A4.

HEADLINE: Hong Kong Stocks Fall 5%; Investors Act on Interest Rates

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News

 BODY:
Stocks fell sharply in Asian markets early today.
Hong Kong's key Hang Seng index dropped 521.14 points, or about five percent, to 9,891.42, at the mid-morning break. Dealers said investors went on a selling spree because of higher interest rates. 
 Investors were nervous because of higher interbank rates, which have been spiked up to defend the local currency, dealers said.
In Tokyo, stocks were sharply lower here this morning. At the close of trading, the Nikkei index of 225 leading issues was down 697.51 points, or 4.22 percent, at 15,836.36. On Thursday, the Nikkei rose 85.82 points, or five-tenths of 1 percent.
In the United States, stocks ended lower yesterday in a decline led by makers of personal computers.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 9.33 points, or one-tenth of 1 percent, to 7,683.24. I.B.M. and Hewlett-Packard were among the component stocks that dragged down the Dow, amid concern that lower prices for PC's would hurt earnings this holiday season.
I.B.M. drew attention to falling prices when it introduced an Aptiva PC for $999, its first foray into the red-hot sub-$1,000 market. Lower prices allow PC makers to sell more machines, though they make less in profit for each one sold.
"This Christmas there is concern that the average selling price is lower," said Bob Finch, a money manager at Aeltus Investment Management. "From a consumer perspective, they don't see the need to spend more than $1,000."
I.B.M. fell 17/16, to 101 1/16. Shares of Hewlett-Packard, another Dow component as well as another personal computer vendor that sells a sub-$1,000 machine, slumped 15/16, to 63 5/8. Broader market indexes were also lower yesterday. The Standard & Poor's 500 Index declined 4.73 points, or five-tenths of 1 percent, to 938.03. The Nasdaq composite index fell 13.89, or nine-tenths of 1 percent, to 1,623.44.
Over all, it was the third quiet session in a row for the stock market, following a tumultuous six sessions.
"My gut is we had a correction, and we're going through a quiet period," said Ken Fisher, who runs his own $1.7 billion firm in Woodside, Calif. "We're still seeing people who are shaking off their emotion about last week."
Among personal computer makers, the Compaq Computer Corporation dropped 1 1/2, to 65 7/16 and the Dell Computer Corporation, the top direct-mail retailer, declined 2 5/8, to 81. Dell, however, does not offer a $999 computer.
Compaq, whose shares more than doubled this year, has fallen 16 percent since hitting a high on Sept. 22.
Intel fell 1, to 73 5/8, its third straight decline. Analysts said they expected company officials to issue a gloomy forecast at a meeting with analysts today because of the potential for lower demand in Southeast Asia and the popularity of lower-priced personal computers.
Aluminum Company of America fell 1 3/4, to 72 1/4, and was the top decliner in the Dow, after Tom M. Van Leeuwen, an analyst with Credit Suisse First Boston, said slack Asian demand was expected to hurt ingot prices. Mr. Van Leeuwen cut his earnings forecast by 7.3 percent, though he maintained his "buy" rating, as recent price declines take into account the weaker outlook.
The biggest gainers were retailers, which jumped on hopes that healthy employment trends will bring a strong holiday selling season this year.
Wal-Mart, which said sales in stores open more than a year climbed 6 percent in October, saw its shares rise 13/16, to 36 7/8. The Dayton Hudson Corporation, whose sales jumped 6.1 percent, gained 3 1/4, to 68 3/4. Kohl's reported a 14 percent jump, and saw its shares rise 11/16, to 69 7/16.
The News Corporation's American depository receipts, each representing four ordinary shares, rose 13/16, to 20 3/8. The Australian media company said first-quarter earnings rose 7.1 percent in United States dollar terms.
