HEADLINE: East Europeans Fill Job Gap in Florida

BYLINE: By DENNIS BLANK

DATELINE: ORLANDO, Fla., Nov. 7

 BODY:
This is the land of the perpetual help-wanted sign.
Even though 700 people move to Florida every day from elsewhere in the United States, economic development officials say, there are still not enough newcomers to satisfy the never-ending demand for service workers to meet the needs of the tourism industry. 
 But some hotels have found one way of at least partly plugging the gap. They are hiring workers from Russia, Poland, the Czech Republic and Lithuania.
"It has been a godsend," said Moira Oliver, director of human resources for the Hyatt Orlando. "I honestly don't know what we would do without them."
These workers, who fill 30 jobs at the Hyatt alone as housekeepers, laundry workers, janitors, food service workers and the like, are provided by a contractor, Florida Coastal Maintenance from Venice, Fla. The Hyatt Orlando would not divulge the amount but says it pays a flat fee to the company, which handles payroll tax withholding and other administrative chores.
Florida Coastal recruits the workers by placing advertisements in European newspapers and in New York and Chicago papers read by recent immigrants.
In a system reminiscent of the European "guest worker" programs of the 1960's and early 1970's, the hotel workers here are among 55,000 Eastern Europeans picked annually in a Government-run lottery and granted one-year work visas. Many who hold these American work permits, known as H-2 visas, receive one- and two-year extensions before they return to their country.
In the Czech Republic "it is very hard to get a good job," said Antonin Sandor, 39, a Czech native who works for $5.85 an hour in the Hyatt Orlando laundry. He shares a nearby $650-a-month apartment with three other employees, gets most of his meals free at the hotel and is supplied with uniforms. He says he is able to save about $500 a month. If allowed to stay at his job for three years, Mr. Sandor expects to have enough money to build a home in the Czech Republic.
By recruiting workers from the old East bloc countries, where jobs do not pay nearly as well, hotels here are able to meet some of their needs for low-skilled employment without having to increase wages and benefits as much as might otherwise be required to lure American workers from other jobs. It is a small part of an overall strategy aimed at attracting students, retirees, people on welfare and migrants from other states at a time when the United States labor market is at its tightest in a quarter century.
The Hyatt chain employs 100 foreign laborers from the old East bloc countries around the nation, half in Florida.
Florida Coastal has been providing imported workers to the Hyatt-Key West and two other hotels in the Florida Keys since 1988 and started providing them in Orlando last year. Gale Killion, human resources director at Hyatt-Key West, said many of the workers eventually became permanent employees. "We have had some problems," Ms. Killion said, "but most have been very dependable."
Just this week Ms. Oliver and personnel officials from four other Hyatt hotels flew to Switzerland in an effort to persuade culinary schools to send their students as interns to fill vacancies in Hyatt kitchens.
Personnel directors say that elsewhere in the nation a lot of hotels have turned to schools like New Hampshire College, in Manchester, which brings in 75 students who have completed three years of schooling in the hospitality industry in Canada, Europe and Latin America, trains them for three months and then places them in jobs that range from desk clerks to accounting.
While Federal officials say a number of cheaper independent hotels have hired illegal aliens, that is much riskier than relying on the H-2 visa program. Last year 110,000 illegal immigrants were forced to leave the United States. Nearly 1,700 were deported from Florida. Lemar Wooley, a spokesman for the Immigration and Naturalization Service in Miami, said it was "not unusual" to find undocumented workers in the hotel industry.
Ann Krutchik, personnel director for Marriott in Fort Lauderdale, who recruits workers for nine Marriotts in the state, said, "It is becoming more and more difficult to hire because there is more competition."
Service industries are eager to recruit imported workers because the labor pool for low-wage, relatively unskilled work is so shallow. With the unemployment rate in the Orlando area at 3 percent, students and retirees are snapped up instantly.
"Employers are hungry," said Tom Weinberg, chairman of Wages, a local coalition dedicated to finding jobs for welfare recipients in five central Florida counties.
Many hotels in central Florida are working harder to keep the employees they have and are offering special incentives for new ones, such as $50 bonuses for any employee who recruits someone to the hotel. At the high-end hotels, employees usually start at $6 an hour and receive full medical, dental and life insurance benefits. They are also given pay increases and promotions for improved job performance.
With recruitment of new workers so difficult, "we are focusing more attention on retention," said Rosa Pettus, human resources director at the Peabody Hotel in Orlando. "Going to the outside can be very challenging."

HEADLINE: Michael von Clemm, 62, Eurobonds Pioneer

BYLINE: By EDWARD WYATT

 BODY:
Michael von Clemm, an investment banker who used a lifelong interest in anthropology to help pioneer the global Eurobond market, died on Thursday at his family home in Wellesley, Mass. He was 62.
The cause was a brain tumor, his son-in-law, William Iselin, said. 
 Mr. von Clemm, who held senior positions at Credit Suisse First Boston and Merrill Lynch, lived most of the last 35 years in London, where since 1996 he served as president of Templeton College, Oxford University's graduate management school.
As one of a handful of multilingual bankers residing in London in the 1960's, Mr. von Clemm recognized that growing numbers of individuals, corporations and even countries were looking for ways to invest abroad without becoming entangled in national currency controls.
Thus were born "Eurocurrencies" -- money on deposit in countries outside of those that printed it. The idea of offering dollar-denominated certificates of deposit in Europe was jointly devised by Mr. von Clemm, who at the time worked in London for the First National City Bank, and a friend, Stan Yassukovich, who worked for the London office of White, Weld & Company, an American investment bank.
The bankers who began accepting the deposits also recognized they might lend the money at higher rates to customers seeking to borrow foreign currencies from an offshore source. Mr. von Clemm was one of several bankers credited with devising a way to spread the risk of those loans by transforming them into a short-term security that could be traded and whose interest rate varied according to changes in international financial markets -- the Eurodollar floating-rate note.
"Today's seamless global stock and bond markets would never have developed without Michael von Clemm," said John M. Hennessy, former chief executive of the American branch of Credit Suisse First Boston. "There are many countries that have access to credit today solely because of him."
In 1971, Mr. von Clemm joined the London-based company that is now Credit Suisse First Boston. In his 15-year tenure there -- the last seven as chairman -- Mr. von Clemm led the investment bank to its still-dominant position as the largest underwriter of Eurobonds, debt securities issued outside the confines of any national market that are denominated in any of a variety of currencies, including marks, yen, pounds or dollars.
Mr. von Clemm, who was born March 18, 1935, in New York City, earned four degrees in anthropology, graduating from Harvard College in 1956 and from Corpus Christi College of Oxford University in 1962.
Reflecting that academic background, he was said to have come upon his interest in international banking in a less-than-usual way: While living for 14 months with the Wachagga tribe in Tanzania, he became intrigued by how people who were normally separated by great distances managed to exchange and barter goods when they came together.
He also dabbled in other careers along the way. He worked as a crime reporter for The Boston Globe in 1959 and 1960 and taught at the Harvard Business School for four years. While working at Credit Suisse First Boston, he also served as chairman of Roux Restaurants, owner of Le Gavroche, which for a time was the only restaurant in Britain with three Michelin stars.
In 1984, while scouting a site for a processing plant to house Roux's planned venture into packaged foods, Mr. von Clemm came upon a ramshackle stretch of the London waterfront known as the Docklands. He thought the docks, occupied by abandoned warehouses where a century ago ships unloaded their cargoes of bananas from the Canary Islands, could provide vast, inexpensive space to house the back-office operations of securities firms like Credit Suisse First Boston.
That proved the beginnings of Canary Wharf. Mr. von Clemm's firm initially considered joining a partnership to develop the property, but instead signed on only as a tenant. The company thereby avoided the financial trouble that led its primary developer, Olympia & York, to lose the property to lenders shortly after it opened in 1992. Today, however, the Canary Wharf complex is 95 percent occupied, and generally considered one of the prime business sites in London.
In January 1986, at age 50, Mr. von Clemm resigned abruptly from Credit Suisse First Boston and implied that he was leaving the Eurobond business, saying he wanted "new mountains to climb." But barely two months later he joined Merrill Lynch as chairman of its capital markets subsidiary, serving as the primary diplomat for the company to its network of global customers. He retired at the end of 1992, but continued to invest through a private company, Highmount Capital.
Mr. von Clemm also served on the board of Massachusetts General Hospital, the Harvard School of Public Health, the East Africa Development Bank, and the U.S.-Korea Business Council. In addition, he was a member of the corporate boards of Eastman Chemical and the Liberty Financial Companies.
Mr. von Clemm is survived by his wife, Lisa Hunnewell von Clemm; two daughters, Stefanie Claire von Clemm of Boston and Charlotte von Clemm Iselin of London; a sister, Alison von Clemm Curtis of Switzerland, and a grandson.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Rome Talks Seek to Defuse Trade Disputes

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE

DATELINE: ROME, Nov. 7

 BODY:
Dismantling hidden barriers to increased trans-Atlantic trade was the focus of two days of discussions here by European and American business leaders with government officials from both sides of the Atlantic.
Participants in the discussions, which ended today, pleaded with the United States and European Union for a "globally harmonized and market-driven legal framework" for electronic commerce, and made proposals aimed at defusing a trans-Atlantic trade conflict that threatens an estimated $4.5 billion of annual pharmaceutical trade. 
 The business leaders, about 70 executives of major European and American corporations, also called on European and American negotiators to expedite an agreement on financial services when negotiations resume in Brussels next week.
The gathering, known as the Trans-Atlantic Business Dialogue, produced a 17-page industry wish list with appeals to eliminate duplication -- and consequent increased costs -- in certifying products on both sides of the Atlantic.
When Washington and Brussels moved to liberalize trans-Atlantic trade in the mid-1990's, it became clear that a trans-Atlantic free-trade zone, similar to the North American arrangement with Mexico and Canada, was impractical.
Instead, corporate leaders told political leaders it was more important to expand the $2 trillion in trans-Atlantic trade by simplifying the hodgepodge of duplicate registration and testing requirements. European and American officials then invited executives to meet to make proposals. They met in Spain in 1995, Chicago last year and Rome this year.
One important subject of discussion was how to defuse a potential trade dispute focusing on a European Union directive that threatens trade in pharmaceutical products. If enforced on the Jan. 1 effective date, the directive will block deliveries to Europe of tallow and gelatin derived from cattle carcasses because of the presumed threat of mad cow disease. About 40 percent of the tallow and gelatin used in Europe to produce filler and casings for pharmaceutical products like pills and tablets comes from the United States. Industry officials said about 85 percent of medicinal products sold in Europe would be affected. "We face the threat of a ban on all this trade," said Stuart E. Eizenstat, the United States Under Secretary of State.
Martin Bangemann, the European Union Commissioner for Industry, said a possible solution would be to postpone enforcement of the directive to allow non-European suppliers time to adjust to the new European requirements. "We are determined to find a solution," he said.

HEADLINE: El Nino Versus El Nonsense;
Keeping Cool Heads in Midst Of Serious Ocean Warming

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Nov. 7

 BODY:
Early this summer, Smith Barney Inc.'s Latin American stock trading desk in New York held a meeting for brokers and money managers on how the latest episode in the periodic warming of Pacific Ocean waters known as El Nino might affect corporate profits across that continent.
"Commodities traders have been interested in El Nino events for years," said Jon B. Davis, the company's meteorologist, who was flown in from his office here for the gathering. "But this was the first time I'd seen the equities side talking about it." 
 At the time, Mr. Davis took the meeting as a healthy sign that El Nino was finally getting the respect it deserved. As traders in the energy and agricultural markets have long known, El Nino conditions are linked to drastic shifts in weather patterns across much of the globe.
Since then, though, El Nino has gone on to become to weather what the O. J. Simpson case was to the legal system. Loose talk has gathered so much momentum that El Nino has smashed through the common sense barrier into misconceptions that are influencing consumer behavior and businesses in ways that leave Mr. Davis and other meteorologists shaking their heads in amazement and dismay.
"I knew it was completely out of control," he said, "when a broker in New York told me he'd heard people in elevators saying they didn't need to buy a coat this winter because of El Nino. You can have plenty of cold days -- you can have record cold days -- even if past El Ninos suggest that conditions in the Northeast will be milder than normal."
The misconceptions have put meteorologists in a tough position. No one wants to play down the dangers associated with this El Nino. Already, much of Southeast Asia is in the grip of a drought that threatens to cut production of internationally important crops like coffee and palm oil. Some mines in Asia dependent on hydroelectric power have even closed.
Weather linked to El Nino has also cut potential wheat yields in Australia, delayed spring planting in Brazil and Argentina, and ravaged the tourist trade on the west coast of Mexico. Peru shut down all anchovy fishing for three months, forcing thousands of fishermen out of work and sending futures traders scrambling to bid up the prices of alternative animal feed ingredients. And most meteorologists believe much more is still to come, especially for North America.
Still, weather experts shudder at how exaggerating the likely impact of El Nino could end up costing businesses and consumers a lot of money: unnecessarily canceled vacations, hasty and poorly executed roof repairs where they may not be needed, overconfidence about low energy prices based on projections of a mild winter in the snow belt, shady stockbrokers hyping investments in building supply companies -- the list is endless. And they worry that unchecked misconceptions will end up breeding public skepticism when El Nino hype and misinformation are eventually exposed.
Michael R. Smith, president of Weather Data Inc., a weather forecasting and consulting firm based in Wichita, Kan., said he concluded things were "out of hand" during a recent trip to Southern California when he heard a television weatherman there attributing a wildfire to El Nino.
"You always have fires at this time of year out there," Mr. Smith said.
In the Midwest, harsh weather is much more common and sensitivity to changes is heightened because of its effects on transportation, farming and commodity markets. But Midwesterners, too, are not immune from El Nonsense. Although there is nothing unusual about fall blizzards on the Great Plains, for instance, Mr. Smith has fielded countless calls from clients assuming El Nino played a role in the severity of the snowstorm that socked the region late last month.
El Nino "events," as Mr. Davis and other weather experts call them, develop every three to five years. El Nino -- a reference to the birth of Jesus -- got its name from Peruvian fishermen, who noted nearly a century ago that the periodic ocean warming often peaked around Christmas.
The Peruvians realized such conditions often went hand in hand with unusually heavy rains and flooding. In recent decades, computers, satellites and vastly improved data gathering have made it clear that El Nino's tentacles spread to vast areas in Asia, Australia and Africa, which become much more susceptible to drought.
The warming water pattern also increases the likelihood of hurricanes and violent weather on Mexico's west coast while tending to suppress such giant storms in the Atlantic Ocean. During the winter, much of the southern tier of the United States, from California to Florida, is likely to experience heavier, more frequent winter rains.
El Nino commonly shakes up global temperatures, too, altering normal patterns enough to have an impact on certain regional energy markets. The Upper Midwest, a major cold weather market for natural gas, typically experiences milder-than-normal winters during an outbreak.
El Nino began to achieve celebrity status this summer when ocean temperatures rose so rapidly that this year's episode began shaping up as the strongest yet recorded, surpassing that of the winter of 1982-83. The climbing temperatures sent marlin, swordfish and other exotic warm water species north as far as Washington State, much to the delight of American anglers and TV camera crews.
But they also dredged up memories of the torrential winter rains and tornadoes in Southern California and other unusual weather attributed to the 1982-83 El Nino. By some estimates, weather linked to that El Nino killed 2,000 people around the world and caused $13.6 billion in damage.
Many Californians are rushing to prepare for an equally brutal winter this year. Demand for roofing material, gutters and related products is up as much as 20 percent from a year ago, according to Matthew Janke, inventory control manager for Ace Hardware, who monitors shipments from the hardware cooperative's warehouses to Ace members. Some Ace stores are encouraging the frenzy with special end-of-aisle displays tied to El Nino.
Indeed, local retailers that stand to benefit from "El Nino" can be quick to spread misconceptions. "The current extreme heat displays the power of El Nino," trumpeted a press release on Tuesday by Pioneer Roofing Tile Inc., which is based in Fontana, Calif., about 50 miles east of Los Angeles. It was looking to gain publicity to help increase sales of its roof repair products.
"That's ridiculous," said Mr. Davis, the Smith Barney meteorologist. No weather condition over just a few days in any one area should be blamed on El Nino, and while temperatures in Southern California were unusually high recently, extreme autumn heat there is not associated with El Nino, he said. Diane Hernandez, a spokeswoman at Waters & Company, Pioneer's public relations firm, said that "local media" had been the source of the company's information.
Lest anyone take too laid back an attitude about the potential dangers, a group of California state agencies is sponsoring El Nino preparedness briefings in communities ranging from San Diego to Chico, about 150 miles northeast of San Francisco. Local newspapers, television and radio stations feature a steady diet of El Nino-related reporting that runs the gamut from sober to silly to sarcastic.
"This is the best-publicized potential disaster in history," said Mr. Smith, the weather consultant. "Some of the precautions like cleaning out flood-control channels will pay off handsomely if there are problems. But people are drawing too close a parallel to 1982-83."
The deluge of coverage has spilled well beyond California, meteorologists say, and overwhelmed cautionary notes about how varied the impact of El Nino is likely to be around the country. Indeed, this year's El Nino has already diverged from the norm in many ways.
As often happens during an El Nino episode, Indonesia and other parts of Southeast Asia have suffered from drought this year. That calamity became acute and big news around the world last month when fires set to clear land burned out of control. That sent choking clouds of smoke across the region. By contrast, neither Australia nor India, which are also prone to El Nino-related droughts, have had severe water problems yet.
Such variations mean that it is just as easy to bet too heavily on El Nino-driven weather as to prepare too little. Cocoa future prices, which had been rising based in large part on fears that El Nino-related dryness in West Africa would limit this year's harvest, have tumbled recently with reports that those fears appear to be overblown.
Investors also need to be aware that business conditions may be very different from the last big El Nino 15 years ago. Even if weather patterns in the months ahead come close to those experienced in the fearsome 1982-83 El Nino, the results this time could be quite different. Already, for example, sugar production in Central America has been less hurt by drought than some investors expected because many farmers now irrigate their fields.
In any event, analysts note, bets on El Nino's impact have to be weighed against the many other factors that also affect business. Tensions with Iraq could send energy prices soaring even if this El Nino, as expected, produces a milder winter across much of North America.
Rather than betting on how closely this El Nino will track previous events, some businesses are focusing on the market volatility that comes with uncertainty about the weather. Utilicorp United, an energy provider and trader based in Kansas City, Mo., recognizes that natural gas prices could tumble in a mild winter but it has opted to buy and store more gas this winter than normal, according to a company spokesman. It does not want to worry about price gyrations after each winter storm.
Strange as it may seem, given El Nino's still-gathering strength and increasing fame, the biggest risk to the economy lies in what may come after El Nino has faded from the headlines. If El Nino wanes or gradually disappears altogether by next summer, as Government forecasters currently expect, farmers in the Midwest can expect fairly normal growing conditions.
But if temperatures in the eastern Pacific sink early and quickly fall into lower-than-normal ranges -- an event known as La Nina -- the chances of drought here in the world's most important farm region soar. With grain supplies already near post-World War II lows, La Nina could send prices to record highs, punishing consumers around the globe while encouraging farmers in developing countries to expand their environmentally disastrous practice of setting forest fires to clear land.
"Just the threat of that has limited the interest farmers have in selling all of the crop they are harvesting now or pre-selling next year," said Charles Flory, editor of ProFarmer Newsletter in Cedar Rapids, Iowa. "The grain markets are saturated with information about El Nino but we certainly haven't factored in that worst-case scenario."

GRAPHIC: Charts/Photos: "El Nino Fever"
Traders in commodity markets have long known that the periodic warming of Pacific Ocean waters known as El Nino can have dramatic effects on weather patterns around the world. But this year for all the genuine dangers associated with the latest outbreak, weather experts worry that fears of El Nino have become so exaggerated that businesses and consumers may end up overreacting to the threat. One example: prices in commodities like cocca and coffee rose this summer, only to retreat after initial worries appeared overblown. Charts show the prices for coffee and cocca since July of 1997. HEADLINE: Markets Fall Worldwide; Dow Off 101

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The around-the-world stock slide was back in sync again yesterday with another 3 percent fall in Hong Kong helping to depress markets in Europe, Latin America and the United States.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 195 points before recovering at the close to finish off 101.92, or 1.3 percent, at 7,581.32. European markets fell more than 2 percent. The biggest declines came in Latin America, with the Brazil market off more than 6 percent to a level below where it plunged last week. Mexico was down 3.5 percent. 
 The losses worldwide suggested two negatives for stocks. One is that the market's rally in recent days, which nearly erased the record 554-point plunge in the Dow average on Oct. 27, came too fast.
The second is that the drag on economic growth in the United States and the damage to American corporate earnings from the expected slowdown in Asia may have been underestimated. The slowdown is coming from the increase in interest rates needed to support currencies in Asia and calm financial markets.
"So this could still play out for a while," said Eric Miller, chief investment officer at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette in San Francisco. "We are not condemned to disaster, but some seem to be taking it too lightly."
Computer and high-technology stocks, including I.B.M. and Hewlett-Packard, led the markets lower. These sectors have seesawed day to day, partly because of the feared impact from the slowdown in Asia. Stocks of companies that could be especially hurt by a slowdown of growth here, like Whirpool, Allied Signal and Goodyear Tire, also dropped sharply as more investors considered the drag from Asia on American growth next year.
Also adding to the decline was the Labor Department's strong employment report for October, which showed a 284,000 increase in nonfarm payroll jobs, a rise in hourly earnings and a drop in the unemployment rate to a 24-year low of 4.7 percent. All the data aggravated inflation concerns at a time when the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, has noted that labor markets are already tight and likely to add to wage pressures.
But analysts said they did not think the strength of the jobs report would force the Fed to raise interest rates when its policy-making committee meets next week. That is because a rate increase in the United States could contribute to the turmoil in Asia and Latin America by forcing interest rates higher there.
In the bond market, the inflationary fears generated by the employment report depressed prices and sent yields on shorter maturities higher. But the losses were probably much less then they could have been because of buying from investors seeking a haven from the stock market turmoil. The yield on the 30-year Treasury settled at 6.16 percent, down from the 6.20 percent average at auction on Thursday.
One new element adding to the fear about contagion from financial turmoil in Asia yesterday was the recent decline in South Korea's currency and record 6.9 percent drop in its stock market.
Alone, the South Korean economy is the size of the four Southeast Asian countries -- Thailand, Malaysia, Indonesia and Philippines -- that became embroiled in the financial turmoil starting last summer.
"In a nutshell, if the crisis in South Korea were to deepen, the economic impact on Japan, the United States and emerging markets would be much greater because Korea's economy equals the size of the Southeast Asian countries already in trouble," said Desmond Lachman, global coordinator for emerging market research at Salomon Brothers.
John Lipsky, chief economist at Chase Manhattan Bank, said there was "still plenty of uncertainty" in the economic and financial outlook.
"It is easy to see," he said, "that the Korean economy is under pressure, and we don't know what government response will be."
The South Korean currency, the won, had held up well at the beginning of the Southeast Asian crisis, which started with the devaluation of Thailand's currency, the baht, in July. But at the end of October, the won began to tumble against the dollar, and is now off about 6 percent. Currency traders say that it was the next target to test.
South Korea also has a troubled banking sector and faces a presidential election next month that could make it more difficult for the Government to respond to a crisis. South Korean banks have been roiling emerging markets by selling a lot of the Latin American and other emerging market bonds they hold to raise funds. That selling has been a reason for the sharp decline in this market the last several days.
Mr. Lipsky said there could be another surprise if the financial turmoil does not subside. That would be in Europe, where, he said, investors and policy makers had not taken the Asian crisis seriously enough. "No one seems to be considering what would happen if the 1998 growth outlook for Europe became downbeat," he said.
In trading yesterday, things could have been worse, but an early rebound of the Dow that narrowed its loss to about 70 points helped European markets rally a little before closing. And the afternoon rebound from a 195-point deficit seemed to help Latin America, where Brazil's Bovespa index was off 10 percent at one point.
Thomas McManus, investment strategist at NatWest Securities, noted that the performance recently of consumer stocks, which generally hold up better when economic growth is slowing, compared with stocks sensitive to higher interest rates and sluggish growth, shows that investors are beginning to worry about a drag from Asia.
Since Oct. 14, the Morgan Stanley index of cyclical, or interest-rate-sensitive, stocks is down 9.7 percent, while the Morgan Stanley index of consumer stocks is off 1.3 percent.
One sign of investor confidence may be in the mutual fund data for the week ended Wednesday. It shows $2.8 billion of inflows into equity funds, compared with an outflow of $1.3 billion the previous week, according to AMG Data Services. But Robert Adler, the head of the firm, also noted that all equity funds had only regained about 44 percent of the value they lost in the previous week.

HEADLINE: With the Apocalypse Almost Now, It Becomes a New Field of Study

BYLINE: By DINITIA SMITH 

 BODY:
Doomsday prophecies have already become a familiar staple of popular television series, shrill tabloid headlines and trade paperbacks, but now the coming millennium has found a home in academia in a new scholarly field: millennial studies.
A surge of interest among scholars in what they refer to as "end-time" has produced a wave of books, papers, courses and conferences. Last year Boston University even created a Center for Millennial Studies as a clearinghouse for scholars. 
 With so many focusing on the millennium, new areas of research are opening up, ranging from reactions to the first millennium, the year 1000, to the impact of the apocalyptic tradition on the nuclear age. Throughout this new field, the term "millennium" increasingly refers not simply to a unit of time -- 1000 years -- but also to the biblical prophecy interpreted by some to mean that Jesus will appear, followed by Armageddon, a battle between good and evil, and by His 1,000-year reign on earth.
A result is that millennialists can be divided into "roosters" and "owls," according to the director and co-founder of Boston University's millennial center, Richard Landes. "The roosters say the apocalypse is imminent," he said in an interview. "Jesus, Paul and John, the presumed author of the Book of Revelation, were all roosters. The owls are the ones who say: 'Not yet. It is still the middle of the night.' " (Mr. Landes says he's an owl.)
At the heart of the new scholarly effort, Mr. Landes said, is the question: "What role do imagined futures have in shaping the present? The apocalypse is used as a conceptual framework for discussion of future cultural mutations."
Mr. Landes was one of the 100 or so scholars who attended a three-day conference this week sponsored by the millennial center and called "The Apocalyptic Other: Millennialist Views of Unbelievers Among Jews, Christians and Muslims." Historians, medievalists and theologians traded theories on the world's end and listened to papers on topics including "Locusts From the Bottomless Pit: Islamic Orientalism and Protestant Eschatology" and "The Mongols as Nonbelieving Apocalyptic Friends Around the Year 1260?"
In between papers, the scholars chatted about similarities between "Eco-Prophecy" (of the destruction of the environment) and biblical prophecies of the end of the world. They scanned the T-shirts and books for sale, like "Omens of the Millennium," by Harold Bloom, "Questioning the Millennium," by Stephen Jay Gould, and "The 2,000-Year-Old Man in the Year 2,000: The Book," by Mel Brooks and Carl Reiner.
Mr. Landes, author of "Relics, Apocalypse and the Deceits of History," a book on the first millennium, said that previously scholars believed there had been no reaction to the approach of the year 1,000. But thousands of Christians made pilgrimages to Jerusalem, he said, and the Peace of God movement of the 990's -- "weeping penitential warriors in huge public gatherings" -- had all the markings of a millennial movement.
Elsewhere, American historians are examining the way apocalyptic ideas have pervaded American culture. Paul Boyer, a history professor at the University of Wisconsin, helped set the standard for contemporary millennial studies in his 1992 book, "When Time Shall Be No More."
"Polls show that 30 to 50 percent of Americans believe that the end of history is foretold in the Bible," he said in a telephone interview. "Anyone interested in American culture has to take that seriously."
Mr. Boyer traces the evolution of apocalypticism from the Pilgrims, who believed they were founding a new Jerusalem, through the evangelical groups of the 18th and 19th centuries, with failed movements like that of the Millerites, followers of William Miller. Miller predicted the Second Coming in about 1843. When it didn't materialize, his disciples suffered what has come to be called "the Great Disappointment." (The Millerites were the forerunners of the Seventh-day Adventists, who do not ascribe an exact date to the end of the world.)
Mr. Boyer showed how "prophecy belief" has continued to shape ideas about nuclear war, the rise of Communism in the Soviet Union, the relationship between Israel and the Middle East.
In a similar vein, other scholars are examining millennarian ideas in contemporary American religious and political movements.
Michael Barkun, a professor of political science at Syracuse University, is studying how militia groups use the idea of the apocalypse, while Charles B. Strozier, a historian, has linked end-time beliefs with contemporary fundamentalist sects.
Hillel Schwartz, a senior fellow at the Millennium Institute in Arlington, Va., has studied how doomsday prophecies incorporate notions of economic ruin and fiscal horror, like "the Antichrist arising from the midst of the governors of the European Economic Community or the World Bank," he wrote in a recent essay.
At the Boston conference, Dr. Kenneth G. C. Newport, who teaches theology at Liverpool Hope University College in England, traced the image of the lamblike beast from the book of Revelation to its role in the theology of David Koresh and the Branch Davidians. Four years ago, 76 members of the sect and 4 Federal agents died during a siege of the Branch Davidians' compound near Waco, Tex. The lamblike beast is generally interpreted in Christian belief to be an ally of the Antichrist, who will appear before the end of the world actually occurs, Mr. Newport said.
"Koresh probably did intend to keep his promises to 'come out,' " Mr. Newport said. But, he added, "When on 28 February 1993, the F.B.I. arrived and laid siege to the Mount Carmel center, it must surely have seemed to those inside that those days had now come."
What happens to apocalyptic groups when the end of the world doesn't come? Some, Richard Landes said, simply reset the date. "When it didn't happen in 1,000," he said, "the French, for example, redated it to 1033."
"I think the whole notion of the Second Coming is an example of resetting the date," Mr. Landes said. "You say it didn't happen the first time, in the year 1,000. So you say it is going to come in the year 2,000."
Mr. Landes has no fear that interest in millennial studies will die out on the first day of the 21st century. "An apocalypse is like a ticket to the Superbowl," he said. "Once the game's over, if the right team doesn't win, you end up with people trying to bleach out the more embarrassing aspects. We're here to build an archive of late 20th- and early 21st-century material for future historians."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Surge in Jobs Last Month Raises Inflation Fear
The nation's unemployment rate declined to 4.7 percent in October, the lowest since 1973, the Labor Department said in a report that provided compelling evidence of further stamina in the United States economy.
 
 But the report contributed to weakness in the American financial markets because it showed an unexpected pickup in wages that could presage higher inflation. Some economists also worried that the Federal Reserve's flexibility to thwart inflation with higher interest rates has been hindered by the financial-market turmoil in Asia and Latin America, which could suffer from any upward pressure on rates. Page A1.
 
Vote on Fast-Track Bill Delayed
At the request of President Clinton, the House of Representatives delayed a vote on a bill to restore enhanced trade-negotiating authority to the President. The debate over the so-called fast-track bill became entangled yesterday in the unrelated issue of funds for family planning programs overseas and the subtle play of politics and egos between the President and House Speaker Newt Gingrich. A1.
 
Embarrassing Finds at Nike Plant
A prominent accounting firm hired by Nike to inspect its factories has undermined the shoemaker's boast of maintaining model work places abroad, finding harsh and hazardous conditions at its Vietnam plant. Though other American manufacturers also have problems in overseas plants, Nike, the world's largest shoe manufactuer, has become a lightning rod for criticism. A1.
 
Iraq Impasse Strengthens Oil
Crude oil prices rose after talks between United Nations envoys and Iraqi officials failed to resolve a weapons-inspection dispute. Crude oil for December delivery rose 38 cents, to $20.77 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Elsewhere, soybeans hit a four-month high on expectations of tightening supplies. D11.
 
Trans-Atlantic Trade Meeting Ends
European and American business leaders and government officials ended a two-day meeting with pleas for a global protocol for electronic commerce and proposals to defuse a potential conflict in pharmaceutical trade. D2.
 
Merger of Parking Lot Operators
The Central Parking Corporation has agreed to buy the Kinney System Holding Corporation, one of the largest parking companies in the Northeast, for about $187 million in cash and stock. D3.
 
Chip Maker Sees Rising Demand
Executives of the Intel Corporation said they believed a slowdown in sales growth for chip makers was nearing an end because personal computer manufacturers had reduced inventories, suggesting demand for chips will increase. D3.
 
Help Wanted, Badly
Demand for service workers is so intense in Florida that some hotels are hiring Russians and Eastern Europeans to fill jobs as chambermaids, laundry workers and the like, under a special program granting them one-year work visas. D3.

Texas Sues Microsoft
The Texas Attorney General filed suit against Microsoft, accusing it of hindering the state's investigation of the leading software company through its use of secrecy clauses in contracts with computer makers D3.
 
Thai Markets Heartened
Markets in Thailand rose after a Thai opposition leader announced that he had gathered enough support in Parliament to form a new government. The leader, Chuan Leekpai, is a former Prime Minister. The main Thai stock index rose more than 3 percent and the baht rose against the dollar. A8.

Hong Kong Backed on Dollar
Despite recent market turmoil, the International Monetary Fund has endorsed Hong Kong's decision to maintain its 14-year link to the United States dollar. D2.

HEADLINE: U.S. Immigration Court Grants Asylum to German Scientologist

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS FRANTZ 

DATELINE: TAMPA, Fla., Nov. 7

 BODY:
A Federal immigration court judge has granted asylum to a German member of the Church of Scientology who claimed that she would be subjected to religious persecution had she been required to return to her homeland, the woman's lawyer and a Scientology official said today.
While few details of the case were available, it is believed to be the first time the United States has given asylum protection to a Scientologist. The Church of Scientology has been waging a highly public international campaign against what it considers discrimination against its members by the German Government. 
 The asylum case comes as the treatment of Scientologists in Germany remains a topic of dispute between Washington and Bonn, which has refused to recognize Scientology as a religion.
Officials at the German Embassy in Washington said today that they had not heard of the asylum decision and would have no reaction until it was confirmed.
For the last four years, the State Department has criticized Germany's treatment of Scientologists in its annual human rights report. But the dry language of the reports did not reach a level that might have been expected to justify asylum.
An immigration court judge decided to approve the woman's application to remain in this country after a hearing last February. Officials at the State Department and the Immigration and Naturalization Service in Washington said they were unaware of the case.
John E. Lund, an immigration lawyer in Tampa who represents the German woman, said his client was in the United States legally.
"She voluntarily applied for asylum," Mr. Lund said, "and the matter was referred to the immigration court by the Immigration and Naturalization Service. The court made the decision, based on her individual facts, that she should be granted asylum."
Mr. Lund said the woman's case was not part of any orchestrated effort by the Church of Scientology to publicize its claims of discrimination.
"Our matter was totally outside of any campaign by the church," Mr. Lund said. "This individual was acting solely on her own."
To protect relatives still in Germany, Mr. Lund and Scientology officials refused to disclose the woman's name or where she lived.
The asylum process is closed to the public for the protection of asylum seekers, said Richard L. Kenney, a spokesman for the Executive Office for Immigration Review, which oversees the immigration courts. Mr. Kenney said the decision of an immigration judge was final unless the Immigration and Naturalization Service appealed.
Kurt Weiland, an official with the Church of Scientology International, said a dozen German witnesses testified at the immigration hearing that the woman faced severe persecution in her homeland.
"She proved her suffering, the damage she experienced emotionally and economically, and how she was ostracized from society, all for no other reason than her religion," Mr. Weiland said.
German officials consider Scientology an extremist organization dedicated to bilking its parishioners of money. The German Government has barred Scientologists from membership in major political parties and placed the organization under surveillance. Some local governments have prohibited Scientologists from holding public service jobs.
Church members in Germany also claim that they have been barred from other types of jobs, that their businesses have been boycotted and that their children have been expelled from public schools.
Under international standards and American law, actions that restrict a person's rights to practice his or her religion, including prohibitions against membership in political parties or holding government jobs, could constitute persecution, said Karen Musalo, a lawyer and director of the international human rights project at Santa Clara University in California.
"Taken cumulatively," Ms. Musalo said, "these constitute serious forms of discrimination against the practitioners of a particular religion for the sole reason of their membership in this religion."
Under immigration law, religious persecution is one of five justifications for granting asylum to a foreigner in the United States. The others are race, nationality, political opinion and membership in a particular social group. People who are granted asylum are generally allowed to become permanent residents within a year.
In the first eight months of the current fiscal year, immigration judges heard 54,276 applications for asylum and granted 4,293 of them.
Mr. Kenney said that a decision made by a judge in one case would not be binding on applications by people in similar situations. Each request for asylum, he said, is judged individually.
A State Department spokesman, James P. Rubin, said he was unaware of the Scientology asylum case. But Mr. Rubin said the treatment of Scientologists in Germany was discussed on Wednesday by Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright in a meeting in Washington with Foreign Minister Klaus Kinkel of Germany.
The Clinton Administration has discussed the issue several times with German officials. While maintaining that Scientologists should be granted religious freedom, Ms. Albright herself accused the church of distorting history last summer when it compared its treatment to the persecution of Jews in Nazi Germany.
In January, 34 show-business celebrities ranging from actors to studio heads signed a $56,000 full-page advertisement in The International Herald Tribune scolding Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany for his Government's "shameful pattern of organized persecution" of the Church of Scientology.
The German Government has maintained that Scientology is not a religion, but a profit-making venture. Officials have argued that restricting the activities of the church members is necessary to protect against the expansion of an extremist group in a nation with acute sensitivities on the subject.
Until a landmark reversal in 1993, the United States Government also refused to recognize Scientology as an organized religion. In that year, the Internal Revenue Service granted tax-exempt status to the organization.
Congress entered the dispute last week. The House International Relations Committee approved a resolution condemning the German Government for its treatment of Scientologists and members of other minority religions.
The resolution drew a sharp protest from Foreign Minister Kinkel, who called the accusations of discrimination baseless and argued that Scientology's goals in Germany were exclusively economic.

HEADLINE: U.S. JOBLESS RATE DECLINES TO 4.7%, LOWEST SINCE 1973

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7

 BODY:
Unemployment fell last month to 4.7 percent, the lowest rate since 1973, helping push the hourly earnings of workers higher, the Government reported today.
Although this was good news for workers, private economists fear that an increasingly tight labor market will revive inflation, which has been remarkably absent through nearly seven years of economic expansion. 
 "We are beginning to see a pickup in wage increases that's closely related to the very low and still-declining unemployment rate," said Michael L. Penzer, senior economist at the Bank of America. With the unemployment rate well below 5.5 percent for the last year and a half, some acceleration in wages and prices is practically inevitable, he said.
In normal circumstances, the Federal Reserve would be expected to take some countermeasure, typically raising interest rates, to keep price increases in check. But with the recent financial turmoil in Asia, the Fed will be reluctant to raise rates at its meeting on Wednesday, analysts agreed, since such action could further upset global markets.
President Clinton seized on today's news to boast of the strongest economy in a generation and to appeal to Congress to set aside any fears that restoring broad Presidential trade authority would ultimately cost American jobs.
"Every time there's a trade agreement, we hear dire predictions of the consequences for American workers," he said at a news conference where he urged lawmakers to renew his authority to put trade pacts on the so-called fast track for quicker Congressional action. "The opponents of fast track would have you believe that if we hadn't done these trade agreements in the last five years, we'd still have all the good new jobs we have and we wouldn't have lost any jobs. That is simply not true."
Mr. Clinton said the economy, bolstered by exports to markets the United States had long sought to pry open, had added 13.5 million jobs since 1993. Analysts noted that the unemployment rate was nearly two percentage points lower than when the President signed the North American Free Trade Agreement in December 1993.
The assumption that the Federal Reserve would stay on the sidelines for the time being seemed to blunt market reaction to the unexpectedly strong job figures. Bond prices fell a bit and interest rates edged up, while stocks finished well above their lows of early in the day as the Dow Jones industrial average ended the day with a loss of about 102 points.
The Labor Department's monthly report was unambiguous in its portrayal of economic vigor, surprising analysts with its breadth as well as impressing them with such figures as payroll growth of 284,000, about one-third more than what most analysts had expected.
Factory jobs rose a sharp 54,000, continuing their recovery from a lull that ended just over a year ago, and construction added 20,000 last month, the biggest increase since May. Jobs in finance climbed 18,000, with 5,000 of these in brokerage houses, lifting the expansion of this industry to 19,000 since June.
"The job market continues to crank out new positions at an unsustainably fast rate," said Joshua N. Feinman, an economist at Bankers Trust. "Wages are starting to creep up, too."
As for the pay increases, the survey of employers showed a 6-cent jump, to $12.41, in average hourly earnings, a hefty increase that followed gains totaling 11 cents in August and September. Analysts said a 40-cent-an-hour increase in the Federal minimum wage that took effect Sept. 1 appeared to have been only a modest factor in the overall advance.
"Tightness in the labor market is intensifying," said Tim O'Neill, chief economist at Harris Bank/Bank of Montreal, noting that average earnings are now 4.2 percent higher than in October 1996, a half-point more than the September-to-September rise. The 4.2 percent rise is the largest for any 12-month period since July 1989.
Figures for hourly earnings, however, are not considered as good a measure as the Government's Employment Cost Index, calculated quarterly, which makes adjustments for shifts in the mix of higher-paid and lower-paid workers.
The decline in the unemployment rate, to the lowest since October 1973, resulted from a rise of 179,000 in the number of people with jobs combined with a shrinkage of 106,000 in the labor force, a combination that thinned the ranks of the jobless to fewer than 6.5 million.
Adult women accounted for much of the lower unemployment rate, as the jobless rate for women dropped to 4 percent.
Although there were more women with jobs, the main reason for the lower rate was fewer women in the labor force.
The jobless rate for all women, including teen-agers, dropped to 4.6 percent last month, the lowest since December 1969, from 5.1 percent in September.
The jobless rate for adult men was unchanged at 4.1 percent while that for all males was down one-tenth of a point, to 4.8 percent.
Some analysts fretted that the proportion of the working-age population that is in the labor force has now slipped to 66.9 percent from a March peak of 67.3 percent. A shrinking pool of available workers, if not reversed, would tighten the labor market even more and could mean mounting wage pressure.
One seeming anomaly in today's report was a plunge in the so-called quit rate, the share of the unemployed who voluntarily left their latest job. That is a statistic that Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, has often cited. After climbing sharply for much of the year, the quit rate fell to 11.2 percent last month from 12.9 percent in September.
This suggested that workers were more uneasy about their jobs, reluctant to leave in hopes of finding a better one despite a market where demand for workers is extremely strong.
By region, the improvement in the unemployment rate came from the South and West, each of which registered drops of three-tenths of a point, to 4.6 percent and 5.4 percent, respectively.
The jobless rate in the Northeast was unchanged at 5.3 percent, while the rate in the Midwest remained the nation's lowest at 4.2 percent.
A report today from the Federal Reserve showed that consumer borrowing rose at a seasonally adjusted rate of 1.9 percent in September, a decline from the 4.2 percent rate in August and the slowest pace in three months.

HEADLINE: U.S. Says It Is Prepared To Use Force on Iraq

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7

 BODY:
Signaling a growing frustration with diplomatic efforts, the Clinton Administration made clear today that the United States was prepared to retaliate with force if President Saddam Hussein continued to defy the United Nations.
While President Clinton said the United States and its allies had to be "firm and resolute," Secretary of Defense William S. Cohen declared that "clearly some action" had to be taken to punish the Iraqi President. 
 Mr. Cohen, emerging as the Administration's strongest voice for retaliation, explicitly raised the possibility of a military strike.
In an interview on the ABC program "Good Morning America," he said the United Nations Security Council could consider "greater economic sanctions" and implied that it could refuse to renew the deal that allows Iraq to sell some oil for food and other relief supplies.
He then added: "There are a variety of things that can be done to put more pressure on Saddam Hussein, but clearly there are other options. There are military options, as well."
Mr. Cohen's remarks -- coupled with new warnings from Baghdad that Iraqi forces will shoot down American U-2 spy planes that fly over Iraq -- appeared to increase the possibility of a new military confrontation with Iraq, although officials said the United States would do nothing before the Security Council considered its options in a meeting on Monday.
For now, the United States has not put its sizable forces in the region on a heightened state of alert, as it did last year before attacking Iraq when Mr. Saddam Hussein's forces pushed into the Kurdish region in northern Iraq. But on Thursday the commander of the United States Central Command, Gen. Anthony C. Zinni, canceled a scheduled port call this weekend by the Nimitz, the aircraft carrier steaming around the Persian Gulf.
In all, the United States has 20,000 troops in the region. More significantly, it has a dozen warships able to launch cruise missiles into Iraq, including the Nimitz, two cruisers, four destroyers, three frigates and an attack submarine. There are also more than 200 fighter aircraft stationed aboard the Nimitz or at bases in Saudi Arabia.
"We have everything we need," an Administration official said.
Ever since the latest confrontation began last month, the United States has been careful to insist that the matter was for the Security Council to resolve first, playing down the likelihood of a unilateral strike. The coalition against Iraq that fought the Persian Gulf war in 1991 has frayed, with countries like France, Russia and China arguing that it is time to ease sanctions imposed at the end of the war.
Administration officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, have said they are worried that a strike by the United States would split the coalition. Those sensitivities, an official said today, are the reason the United States is unlikely to act on its own before exhausting diplomatic efforts at the United Nations next week.
"You're better off moving more slowly, with the international community, than acting unilaterally in a way that could do what Saddam Hussein wants, which is to divide the coalition," the official said.
At the State Department, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright said she expected that the Security Council would take "firm action" to compel Mr. Saddam Hussein to cooperate with international inspections of Iraq's weapons and drop a demand that all Americans be excluded from the inspection teams.
She declined to elaborate on what that action might be, and Mr. Clinton, speaking to reporters at the White House, said it was inappropriate to discuss any options the United States and its allies on the Security Council might be considering.
The President added, however, that he had seen "no indication" that the United States' allies had lost their resolve. "Everyone seems to be united in their determination to restore the inspections on terms that the United Nations decides, not on Saddam Hussein's terms," he said.
With United Nations envoys having failed to break the impasse, however, officials sounded increasingly impatient today.
"We went the extra mile diplomatically by allowing and supporting the idea of this mission," the State Department's spokesman, James P. Rubin, said of the envoys' trip to Baghdad.
"To the extent that governments around the world want to see all diplomatic means pursued before going farther in the Security Council towards firm action, this mission hopefully will have united the world in the conclusion that we've done all we can," he said.

HEADLINE: Racism Is (a) Entrenched? Or (b) Fading?;
The Answer for Many Is (b) as Optimists Dispute Decades of Pessimism on Race Relations

BYLINE: By RICHARD BERNSTEIN 

 BODY:
"America in Black and White," a new book by Stephen and Abigail Thernstrom, is a vast, data-laden study whose most important conclusion is that the United States has gone a long way in the past six decades toward eliminating the stain of racism from the white American heart.
"A Country of Strangers: Blacks and Whites in America" by David Shipler, another large, data-filled book, comes to the nearly opposite conclusion. Racism has not disappeared, says Mr. Shipler, but has simply gone underground; so this is still a nation living on two sides of a yawning racial divide. 
 Two weighty new books; two very different points of view on what remains the primordial American subject: race. In a publishing season that has brought a large outpouring of new works on race relations, these two ambitious books represent a sharpening of the debate. How to characterize the two points of view?
Prof. Randall Kennedy of the Harvard Law School speaks of two traditions, one optimistic and the other pessimistic, that have almost always coexisted on the fiendishly complicated question of race. The two traditions -- debated this week at the Manhattan Institute in New York, where the Thernstroms faced off with some of their adversaries -- are present in virtually all of the new books.
"The pessimistic tradition, represented by such very different figures as Thomas Jefferson and Malcolm X, holds that racism is so deeply entrenched in the American soul that it will never loosen its grip, even if it does change form," Mr. Kennedy said. "Then there's the counter-tradition, the optimistic tradition, represented by Frederick Douglass and Martin Luther King Jr. and many others: We have gigantic problems but we shall overcome."
The optimistic tradition, which includes Mr. Kennedy's own book, "Race, Crime and the Law," may represent a new turn in the scrutiny of race in America. While many points of view have always competed for attention, it is probably fair to say that the pessimistic tradition -- or at least the view that the country is doing badly in its efforts to bring about true racial justice -- has predominated for several decades. Now, judging from the recent flood of new books, a troubled optimism has risen more strongly than ever before.
For most of the last 30 years or so, the prevailing view expressed in books and by political leaders like the Rev. Jesse Jackson or the directors of the major civil rights groups was that America was continuing to fulfill the dire predictions made by the Kerner Commission report. Formed in the aftermath of the devastating urban riots of the 1960's, the Kerner Commission predicted that the country was "moving toward two societies, one black, one white -- separate and unequal." It also found that the main responsibility for this unfavorable state of affairs was "the tenacity of white racism."
That theme ran heavily through much of the commentary on race. There was, for example, Andrew Hacker's 1992 book, "Two Nations," a national best seller whose basic argument was that the Kerner Commission was correct. Another influential book of the time was Derrick Bell's "Faces at the Bottom of the Well," which argued that even those herculean efforts we hail as successful will produce no more than "short-lived victories that slide into irrelevance as racial patterns adapt in ways that maintain white dominance." Clearly, books like Mr. Shipler's and several others, including "Long Way to Go," a study of race in Milwaukee by Jonathan Coleman, though more nuanced, elaborate on the pessimistic tradition. They try to show, in large part by examining the states of mind of both blacks and whites, that racism continues to be responsible for many of the disadvantages that blacks experience.
In one climactic moment near the end of his book, for example, Mr. Shipler reports on a corporate diversity training seminar during which the leader asks how many of the people present had "considered not having children because of racism." When a dozen or so women, mostly black or Hispanic, stand up, having decided that the "trial of raising a black child in America would be too severe," Mr. Shipler uses the occasion to reflect on the enduring strength of racial misunderstanding:
"We cannot escape from our intimate histories, our unacknowledged racial mixtures, our awkward and unsatisfying efforts at integration. We have not completely purged the prejudices from our inner thoughts: We do not discount the body's appearance, the voice's sound, the suspicions of the mind's inadequacy."
That is a powerful statement. But it is also exactly the sort of declaration that has been energetically challenged by the new wave of books.
The most encyclopedic and perhaps the most optimistic of them is the Thernstroms', which has already been widely reviewed, both positively and negatively. Among the others is Mr. Kennedy's "Race, Crime and the Law," a penetrating study of the ways in which racial politics has affected the legal system. In it Mr. Kennedy argues that we have moved a long way since the era of Jim Crow toward eliminating racism from the law.
Among the most sharply polemical of the new books are "Liberal Racism," by the journalist and essayist Jim Sleeper, and "The Ordeal of Integration," by Mr. Kennedy's colleague at Harvard, the sociologist Orlando Patterson. Both rail against what Mr. Patterson calls "the bizarre cult of the victim that has become the hallmark of late-20th-century liberal doctrine."
Mr. Patterson writes perhaps the harshest and most unforgiving response to the Kerner Commission-Hacker point of view. He cites one passage in Mr. Hacker's book in which the author describes the pain he says parents must feel at telling their children they will never be "treated as other Americans."
"Oh God!" Mr. Patterson writes sarcastically. "And this is barely the start of the daily pile of agonies. . . . For even a Colin Powell must know in his heart that even though he may have headed the greatest military machine in the history of the world, he is still only a nigger in the eyes of the land he has so loyally served."
Similarly, Mr. Sleeper, a strong opponent of what he calls "diversity-driven color coding," argues that many liberals have fostered the idea that "one's skin color determines one's destiny." Put another way, he says, the very people "who fought nobly to help this country rise above color have become so blinded by color that they have leapt ahead of conservatives to draw new race lines in the civic sand."
These books in the optimistic tradition are by no means alike, and none proclaim that racial equality has been achieved. But they are all inclined to give the country a good deal more credit in the battle against racism than the books in the pessimistic tradition. Speaking of the Kerner Commission, for example, the Thernstroms say: "What is striking, with the benefit of hindsight, is not how prescient the report was, but how far off the mark it has turned out to be."
What the authors do disagree on is the cause. The Thernstroms argue that more progress was made between 1940 and 1960, when there were no special government programs aimed at insuring racial equality, and they use that argument in a powerful attack on affirmative action. Mr. Patterson, by contrast, is an ardent defender of affirmative action and gives it credit for much of the progress that has been made.
Still, Mr. Patterson writes, "The changes that have taken place in the United States over the past 50 years are unparalleled in the history of minority-majority relations." And where serious problems exist, including the high number of black males in the criminal justice system and the rise in out-of-wedlock births among blacks, Mr. Patterson rejects the conventional "two-nation" theory that racism is at work.
Not surprisingly, each of the various arguments seems to carry a political subtext. Those who emerge in the "pessimist" camp are more likely to favor racial preference programs, the "optimists" to oppose them.
Mr. Patterson alone seems to break this pattern. Though clearly in the optimistic camp, he argues in his book, "Affirmative action has made a major difference in the lives of women and minorities, in the process helping to realize, as no other policy has done, the nation's constitutional commitment to the ideal of equality, fairness and economic integration."

HEADLINE: HOUSE POSTPONES TRADE-ISSUE VOTE

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7

 BODY:
President Clinton encountered new obstacles today in assembling the majority needed to pass legislation granting him expanded trade authority, forcing him to ask House leaders to delay a vote on the bill at least until Sunday.
Mr. Clinton spent another day and night seeking votes for the so-called fast-track measure, but the gains were slim. By nightfall the White House still appeared to be about 10 to 15 votes short of a majority. 
 The trade debate became entangled in the unrelated issue of funds for family planning programs overseas and the subtle play of politics and egos between the President and Speaker Newt Gingrich.
The White House expressed hope that an additional 48 hours would give the President time to make his case for the measure, which allows him to negotiate trade treaties that Congress must approve or reject without amendment.
The President again issued a public plea for support today, as he had on Thursday night, insisting that the nation's economic security depended on a renewal of his unencumbered power to negotiate trade agreements, a power that other world leaders possess. Every President since Gerald R. Ford has had such authority, but Mr. Clinton allowed his to lapse before the last election, fearing the issue would divide his party.
"More than ever, our economic security is also the foundation of our national security," the President said today. "Our strength depends upon our economic allies, our trading partners and our economy. It affects our ability to get other nations to cooperate with us militarily, and against the new threats of terrorism and drugs, organized crime and weapons proliferation."
He said defeat of the measure would send a signal that the United States did not want to be a full partner in the global trading system.
"It would be folly to turn back now," Mr. Clinton said in a televised statement from the Roosevelt Room in the White House.
The White House also prepared amendments intended to attract support. One would declare fast-track authority to be a matter of national security, making a vote against it more difficult. Another would set up Congressional delegations to monitor compliance with trade agreements. A third would give the President authority to impose harsh sanctions on countries that violate agricultural trade pacts.
But the President's task of rounding up votes was complicated by a high-volume debate on the question of financing family planning programs overseas, a politically charged issue that is certain to cost the President votes no matter what position he adopts. A partisan squabble over how to conduct the census in 2000 was also injected into the debate, with some Republican threatening to withhold support for the trade bill unless President Clinton drops his plan to use sampling rather than direct counting.
Erskine B. Bowles, the White House chief of staff, insisted family planning and the census should not be linked to the trade debate.
Opponents of family planning and abortion want Mr. Clinton to rescind United States financial support for international organizations that provide or counsel abortion. The appropriations bill for State Department foreign operations contains $385 million for such programs.
Senate Majority Leader Trent Lott warned Mr. Clinton this morning that if he did not agree to a compromise on the abortion issue, he would lose the House vote on the trade issue because anti-abortion members who now support the bill would defect.
But several Democratic members of Congress -- including some who now support "fast track" authority -- protested vehemently, saying such a reversal would cost him votes.
Mr. Clinton also had to contend with restive members of his own party who have been alienated by his assertions that opponents of the trade measure are succumbing to pressure from labor unions and environmental groups. And he angered some Democrats today by saying that a vote for fast-track authority is a "no brainer," implying that opponents were acting irrationally.
Mr. Gingrich, whose credibility as House leader is also at stake, said he had persuaded several more Republicans to support the measure, bringing the Republican count to about 160. That means that Mr. Clinton could win with the votes of 60 Democrats, less than a third of the party caucus but still a high hurdle in a party deeply divided on the issue of free trade.
"We are going to cooperate with the Clinton Administration in every way we can to get it through," Mr. Gingrich said. "In all fairness, they face a much harder job and the labor union pressure -- and, frankly, blackmail -- has been so extraordinary."
Mr. Gingrich is the President's firmest ally on Capitol Hill on the fast-track bill, but he is making certain that Mr. Clinton suffers the agony of having to drag reluctant members of his own party into the "yes" column.
One White House official expressed confidence that ultimately Mr. Gingrich would deliver enough votes to assure passage. "He doesn't want to be the first Speaker since Gerald Ford was President who could not get fast-track authority through the House," the official said.
But Representative Richard Gephardt, the Democratic leader in the House and the chief of the fast-track foes, expressed concern that the President, in his eagerness to accommodate Mr. Gingrich and the Republicans, would cut deals that are anathema to Democrats.
"This fast track is bad enough," Mr. Gephardt complained. "The President should publicly stand up and say that he won't trade away core Democratic values for Republican votes."
Commerce Secretary Bill Daley and the national security adviser, Samuel R. Berger, were on the Hill again today on behalf of the Administration and announced that they had snagged five undecided votes, from Representatives Bob Clement of Tennessee, Anna Eshoo of California, Ike Skelton of Missouri, Bobby R. Etheridge of North Carolina and Earl Pomeroy of North Dakota.
"This is a matter of national security," said Mr. Skelton. "This is about America staying engaged in the world."
But several other Democratic House members were infuriated that President Clinton had suggested that they opposed the measure only because they were beholden to organized labor, which strongly opposes the bill. Mr. Clinton said Thursday that the bill would win overwhelmingly if the vote were held in private, implying that many Democrats would vote no only because they feared retaliation from the unions.
Mr. Gephardt called Mr. Clinton's questioning of the motives of his opponents "a sign of desperation."
"Members of Congress are honorable people who base their decisions on what they believe is in their constituents' best interest," Mr. Gephardt said. "I don't question the motives of those who disagree with me.
The President's comments also provoked a half-dozen Democratic women in the House to call a news conference to denounce any suggestion of a compromise on international family planning programs.
When he came into office, Mr. Clinton signed an executive order rescinding President Reagan's order banning financing for any international family planning groups that perform abortions or counsel on abortions and provide family planning services. Now some Democrats fear that Mr. Clinton is considering agreeing to Mr. Reagan's language.
"The White House wants to work, in this period of time before the vote is brought up again, some secret deals on the appropriations bills," said Rosa L. DeLauro, Democrat of Connecticut. "Our votes are not for sale in this process. We won't allow playing fast and loose with appropriations bills and policy that we feel deeply about."
Representative Nita Lowey, a New York Democrat who is undecided on the trade issue and strongly supports abortion rights, said any compromise on funds for family planning would be "unconscionable," and said it would probably cause her to vote against the trade bill.
